"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224542","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose; rhizomes creeping.      Leaves: 2-5 mm wide, soft, smooth. Basal sheaths: dark reddish brown. Bracts: sheathless, leaf-like.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: dark reddish brown, apex long awned. Spikes: terminal spikes staminate, oblong ellipsoidal, 0.5-1 cm long: lateral spikes pistillate, pedunculate, nodding or drooping, oblong ellipsoidal, 1-2 cm long. <br /><br/>       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, lanceolate, 7-8 mm long, glabrous, beak long conical, mouth notched or shortly bidentate, dark purple. <br /><br/> Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, trigonous, 2 mm long. Styles: 8-10 mm long, sometimes flexed at base.<br /><br/> Stigmas: 3, 5-7 mm long, persistent.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-apoiensis-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","7404e1ed-548c-4e8a-8afd-f4f01d4079ff#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224556","conservation","<p>Carex appropinquata is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Near threatened (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-appropinquata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","568e2388-9d71-4d55-add0-56757c506281#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224556","diagnostic","<p>Possibly sometimes overlooked or confused with C. diandra and the former record in Pembrokeshire was in error for a form of that species (forma pseudoparadoxa) with compound, pedunculate, proximal spikes (David 1990). It can also be confused with depauperate specimens of C. paniculata, from which the blackish, fibrous sheaths, the red colouring of the glumes (both more pronounced on drying) and the unwinged utricle should sufficiently distinguish it. <br />C. appropinquata hybridises in England with C. paniculata (C. × rotae De Not.). Hybrids with C. canescens, C. diandra and C. remota are recorded in mainland Europe and could occur in our area.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-appropinquata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","568e2388-9d71-4d55-add0-56757c506281#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224556","distribution","<p>Carex appropinquata is frequent in East Anglia and very local in SE and mid-west Yorkshire and in Roxburgh and Selkirk; formerly also on the Middlesex-Herts-Bucks borders but now extinct. In Ireland it is widespread but local in the centre. See also David (1990).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-appropinquata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","568e2388-9d71-4d55-add0-56757c506281#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224556","ecology","<p>A plant of similar habitats to C. paniculata (in M9), with which it sometimes grows, but perhaps requiring less water movement, as in Juncus subnodulosus mires (M13) and Filipendula-Angelica-Valeriana officina/is mires (M27) where grazing or cutting has ceased, and occasionally in more acid fens (e.g. at edges of Molinia mire (M26), as at Malham Tarn).  <br />C. appropinquata has declined in its East Anglian stronghold and in its Yorkshire lowland sites as a result of drainage and recent dry summers (Porter & Foley 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-appropinquata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","568e2388-9d71-4d55-add0-56757c506281#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224556","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> very short, ascending, usually forming dense tussocks up to 1 m high and 80 cm in diameter; roots thick, dark brown, felty; scales dark brown-black, eventually breaking up into wiry fibres. <i>Stems </i> 40-80 cm, rough, trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> 20-80 cm × 1-3 mm, stiff, keeled, yellow-green; hypostomous; sheaths of sterile shoots forming a false stem, the lowermost dark brown with shorter blades, with inner face hyaline; apex brown, concave; ligule 2-3 mm, rounded. <i>Inflorescence </i> a compact panicle 4-8 cm; bracts setaceous or glumaceous. <i>Spikes </i> made up of spikelets 4-7 mm, male at top, female below; lower spikelets pedunculate and compound, some all female. Male glumes 3-4 mm, ovate, reddish-brown, with hyaline margin and apex acute. Female glumes 3-4 mm, ovate, acuminate, red-brown, becoming hyaline in fruit. <i>Utricles</i>  (2.7-)3-4 mm, ovoid to subglobose, ± abruptly narrowed into the beak; beak (0.7-)1 -1.5 mm, rough, not winged, notched, sometimes split on adaxial side; stigmas 2; nut ovoid, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-appropinquata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","568e2388-9d71-4d55-add0-56757c506281#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224563","diagnostic","<p>C. aquatilis is easily distinguished by the shiny bright green lower surface of the leaf, the red sheaths and the slender, more neatly packed female spikes with very long bracts and nerveless utricles. Also, the brittle, ± subterete stern (which snaps when folded) is characteristic of the species. C. acuta which is similar in stature, has leaves glaucous beneath, sheaths rarely red, tough, sharply angled concave-sided stems which do not snap, and robust, more open spikes with faintly ribbed utricles.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-aquatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","dbed13bb-e24f-4259-b2c5-4a6d172e7bde#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224563","distribution","<p>Carex aquatilis is basically a northern species from Shetland to the Scottish border, although extinct in many former localities; local in the English Lakes, rare in Teesdale and in the northern Pennines and in N and W Wales, where it is considered a glacial relict. In Ireland, uncommon and scattered.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-aquatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","dbed13bb-e24f-4259-b2c5-4a6d172e7bde#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224563","ecology","<p>C. aquatilis is predominantly a lowland swamp species. In lakes it grows with C. vesicaria (S11), C. rostrata (S27), etc. In rivers and muddy estuaries in the N it is often the only sedge in the scanty riparian flora, but further S it grows with C. riparia and C. acutiformis. In the east-central Highlands a smaller upland form (similar, except in stature, to the lowland plant and sometimes called var. stans (Drejer) Boott) grows with C. canescens, C. rariflora, C. nigra and Sphagnum spp. (M7) up to 775 m on Glas Maol (v.c. 90). This form has recently been found also at c. 800 m in the Pennines.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-aquatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","dbed13bb-e24f-4259-b2c5-4a6d172e7bde#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224563","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping; shoots tufted; roots red-brown, up to 2 mm thick, much branched; scales orange-or red-brown, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 20-110 cm, smooth, bluntly trigonous above, subterete at base, brittle. <i>Leaves </i> 15-130 cm × 2.5-5(-8) mm, smooth, shiny, dark green or yellow-green beneath, rough or smooth and ± glaucous above, culm leaves flat, vegetative leaves weakly keeled, gradually tapered to a flat point, with the margins rolling inwards on drying; epistomous, with a few scattered stomata below; sheaths herbaceous, wine-red or red-brown, persistent, with inner face hyaline, soon decaying; apex straight or concave; ligule 4-15 mm, obtuse or acute, ± tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/6 to 1/3 length of the stem; bracts leaf-like, lowest conspicuously broad and ensheathing at base, exceeding inflorescence. <i>Male spikes</i>  2-4, 5-50 mm; male glumes 3-4 mm, obovate to oblanceolate, hyaline at margins; apex obtuse. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-5, 15-70 mm, cylindric, slender, dense-flowered, becoming lax below, upper contiguous, ± sessile, often male at top, lowest ± distant, ensheathing much of the spike; peduncles more than 20 mm, smooth; female glumes 2-3 mm, ovate or broadly elliptic, hyaline at margins; apex acute to cuspidate or obtuse. <i>Utricles</i>  2-3 mm, ellipsoid to obovoid, nerveless, green; beak almost absent, truncate; stigmas 2; nut ellipsoid to obovoid, biconvex, shiny.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-aquatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","dbed13bb-e24f-4259-b2c5-4a6d172e7bde#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224567","distribution","<p>St. Pierre and Miquelon; Alta., B.C., Man., N.B., Nfld. and Labr., N.W.T., N.S., Nunavut, Ont., P.E.I., Que., Sask., Yukon; Alaska, Ariz., Calif., Colo., Idaho, Maine, Mich., Minn., Mont., Nev., N.Mex., N.Dak., Oreg., Utah, Wash., Wis., Wyo.; Eurasia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-aquatilis-var-aquatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","bcafac9d-430c-4961-b613-9370ae4394cd#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224567","general","<p>Culms 20–120 cm, angles glabrous. Leaves: basal sheaths leafless, usually red-brown; blades amphistomic, 2.5–8 mm wide, papillose on both surfaces. Inflorescences: peduncle of proximal spike 1 cm or longer; proximal bract slightly longer than inflorescence, 2–8 mm wide. Spikes erect; proximal 2–7 spikes pistillate, 1–10 cm × 3–7 mm, base cuneate; terminal 2–4 spikes usually staminate. Pistillate scales red-brown to purple-brown with narrow pale midvein. Perigynia pale brown, ellipsoid or obovoid, 2–3.6 × 1.3–2.3 mm, apex rounded or obtuse; beak pale brown, thickened, not more than 0.2 mm. 2n = 72, 74–77, 79–80.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-aquatilis-var-aquatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","bcafac9d-430c-4961-b613-9370ae4394cd#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224575","general","<p>Culms 35–100 cm, angles scabrous. Leaves: basal sheaths leafless, usually red-brown; blades amphistomic, 5-8 mm wide, papillose on both surfaces. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224589","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.   Culms: 10-30 cm tall.  Leaves: 1-2 mm wide, scabrous. Basal sheaths: slightly elongate, brown, lustrous. Bracts: setaceous, with short sheaths. Pistillate scales: linear, apex obtuse, margins broadly whitish. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, shortly pedunculate, filiform, 1-1.5 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, upper 1 or 2 crowded, linear, 1-1.5 cm long, subsessile. Staminate scales: pale green, apex rounded. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoidal, 1.5 mm long, style base minutely annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224590","distribution","<p>Colo., Utah, Wyo.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-arapahoensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c76f6869-4682-4c6b-9506-c95f67657b49#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224590","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms 20–30 cm. Leaves: sheaths white-hyaline, summits usually U-shaped; distal ligules 1–2(–2.5) mm; blades 3(–5) per fertile culm, 10–40 cm × 2.2–3.2 mm. Inflorescences dense or sometimes open proximally, brown or purplish, 1.2–2(–2.5) cm × (8–)12–18 mm; proximal internode 1.5–3.5 mm; 2d internode 0.5–2.5 mm; proximal bracts bristlelike, shorter than inflorescences. Spikes 4–5, densely aggregated, usually at least proximal 1 distinct, obovoid, 9–12 × (5.5–)7–9 mm, base rounded or attenuate, apex rounded or acute. Pistillate scales red- or purple-brown to dark brown, sometimes gold above the middle, sometimes with paler midstripe, ovate to broadly ovate, 4.3–5.6 mm, shorter than or equaling perigynium beaks, equaling or narrower than perigynia, margin white-hyaline, green, or gold 0.15–0.3 mm wide, apex usually acute. Anthers long-persistent. Perigynia appressed to ascending, usually dark brown, often green or gold distally and at margins, veinless or conspicuously 3–6-veined abaxially, inconspicuously veined adaxially, broadly obovate to broadly ovate, flat except over achene, 4–5.5 × 2–2.7 mm, 0.25–0.4(–0.5) mm thick, margin flat, including wing 0.4–0.6 mm wide, ciliate-serrulate at least on distal body; beak purplish or brown to red-brown, white-hyaline at tip, cylindric, unwinged, entire for 0.5–1.3 mm from tip, abaxial suture with conspicuous white margin, distance from beak tip to achene (1.9–)2.2–2.9 mm. Achenes obovate or ovate, 1.6–2.1 × 1–1.4 mm, 0.3–0.5 mm thick.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-arapahoensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c76f6869-4682-4c6b-9506-c95f67657b49#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224590","habitat","<p>Dry mountainsides, high meadows; of conservation concern; 3400–4000 m</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-arapahoensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c76f6869-4682-4c6b-9506-c95f67657b49#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224594","general","<p>Rhizome long; shoots ± loosely tufted. Culms erect, slender, terete, smooth, 3–25 cm long, c. 0.5 mm diam.</p><br/><p>Leaves usually shorter than culms; blade to 0.5 mm wide; sheath dark yellow-brown; ligule truncate to rounded.</p><br/><p>Inflorescence erect, c. 0.5 cm long, with 1 few-flowered spike; lowest involucral bract exceeding inflorescence. Spike androgynous (very short male portion). Glumes obtuse to acute, red-brown with narrow hyaline margins; female glumes 2.5–4 mm long. Utricles ellipsoid to ovoid, ± falcate, nerveless or faintly nerved, 3–5 mm long, c. 1 mm diam., glabrous or minutely hispid on upper margins, red-brown to dark red-brown; beak 1.3–2.5 mm long, with apex notched. Anthers 0.8–1.8 mm long excluding appendage <0.2 mm long. Style 3-fid.</p><br/><p>Nut narrow-ellipsoid, trigonous in cross section, pale yellow-brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-archeri-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","ab49f1ac-9f99-498f-ac2d-16bb91eca62b","","c75b59f4-3ed0-4d46-bbcf-94ab4bd19728#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224594","morphology","Plant: Perennial. Below-ground structures: Rhizome long, with shoots ± loosely tufted along it.  Culms: Erect, slender, terete, smooth, 3–25 cm long, c. 0.5 mm diam. Inflorescence: Erect, c. 0.5 cm long, with 1 few-flowered spike; lowest involucral bract exceeding inflorescence.  Leaves: Usually shorter than culms; blade to 0.5 mm wide; sheath dark yellow-brown; ligule truncate to rounded. Pistillate scales: Obtuse to acute, red-brown with narrow hyaline margins, 2.5–4 mm long.  Spikes: Spike androgynous (very short male portion), often only 3 female spikelets.  Staminate scales: Obtuse to acute, red-brown with narrow hyaline margins.     Anthers: 0.8–1.8 mm long (excluding appendage <0.2 mm long).  Perigynia: Ellipsoid to ovoid, ± falcate, nerveless or faintly nerved, 3–5 mm long, c. 1 mm diam., glabrous or minutely hispid on upper margins, red-brown to dark red-brown; beak 1.3–2.5 mm long, with apex notched. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224597","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms dark maroon at base; flowering stems 20–100 cm, much longer than leaves at maturity, 0.6–1 mm thick, glabrous but scabrous within inflorescence. Leaves: Inflorescences: peduncles of lateral spikes slender, to 30 mm, shorter than spikes; peduncle of terminal spike to 28 mm, usually shorter than adjacent pistillate spikes, minutely scabrous on angles; proximal bracts shorter than inflorescences; sheaths to 30 mm; blades 2–3 mm wide. Pistillate scales white-hyaline with green midrib, oblong-lanceolate, shorter than mature perigynia, apex acuminate to cuspidate or awned, awn to 1.5 mm, margins and awn scabrous or ciliate, otherwise glabrous. Perigynia green, often red dotted, 2-ribbed and finely 10–15-veined, loosely enveloping achene, ellipsoid-ovoid, 3–5 × 1–2 mm, membranous, base with stipe 2–3 mm, apex tapering to minute beak, glabrous but sometimes ciliate between apical teeth; beak bidentate, 0.7–1.5 mm. Achenes sessile, 1.7–2.6 × 0.8–1.7 mm. (Flora North America 2002)</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-arctata-boott-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","533f6975-a089-4a6a-8809-5879f3b5a047","","98a9b060-9d1d-4662-ab6a-7ad8e1a5a57b#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224597","morphology","Plant: Plants densely cespitose.    Inflorescence: Racemose with 3-5 spikes, the terminal one staminate and lateral ones pistillate on peduncles that are erect at flowering, but soon drooping on longer peduncles. Leaves: basal sheaths maroon, bladeless, rarely minutely scabrous, glabrous; others grading from maroon to green on back, white to tan-hyaline on front, minutely red dotted; blades flat, 3–10(–13) mm wide, glabrous with minutely scabrous margins.  Spikes: Terminal spike staminate, 6–40 × 0.8–2 mm; lateral spikes 2–5, 1 per node, well separated, erect at anthesis, but soon drooping, pistillate with 15–45 perigynia attached 1–2 mm apart, linear-elongate, 25–80 × 3–4 mm.        Achenes: Sessile (not-stipate), 1.7–2.6 × 0.8–1.7 mm Stigmas: 3    Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-arctata-boott-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","533f6975-a089-4a6a-8809-5879f3b5a047","","98a9b060-9d1d-4662-ab6a-7ad8e1a5a57b#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224611","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos muy largos, total o parcialmente cubierto por escamas que surgen de los nudos, de color pardo, deshechas en fibras en su parte proximal, raramente enteras. Tallos (8)15-30(40) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos agudos, escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas (1)2-3,5(5) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, canaliculadas, plegadas o enrolladas, en este último caso pueden ser muy estrechas (0,4 mm), ásperas en los bordes, no muy rígidas; lígula (0,8)1-2(3) mm, con los bordes levantados, de anchura menor que el limbo, de ápice obtuso o redondeado y borde generalmente ciliolado; sin antelígula; vainas basales subterráneas, iguales a las escamas del rizoma, las aéreas generalmente con limbo desarrollado. Bráctea inferior de longitud mucho menor que la inflorescencia, setácea, rara vez cortamente foliácea, con vaina abierta en su base. Espigas dispuestas en espiga simple (1,8)4-6(7) cm, agrupadas, la superior frecuentemente masculina, las medias andróginas y la inferior generalmente femenina. Glumas ovales, acuminadas o aristadas, de color pardo claro cuando jóvenes y pardo rojizo ± obscuro en la madurez, las femeninas mayores que los utrículos. Utrículos (4)4,5-5,5(5,8) × (1,1)1,5-2(2,2) mm, de contorno lanceolado u oval, plano-convexos o cóncavo-convexos, esponjosos en la base, con 1 ala ancha en la mayor parte de la longitud de cada uno de sus bordes, prominentemente nerviados, oliváceos o de color pardo obscuro en la madurez, gradualmente atenuados en un pico 1,2-1,7(2) mm, escábrido-serrulado, bífido. Aquenios (1,4)1,7-2,1 × (0,6)0,9-1,1(1,2) mm, de contorno oblongo, obovado o elíptico, biconvexos, rara vez plano-convexos, con la base del estilo persistente en forma de una corta columna. 2n = 58, 60*, 64*.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-arenaria-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","9b68deb3-2526-4ea7-b365-d7f03b004798#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224704","distribution","<p>Finnland, nordöstliches Mitteleuropa, Rußland, Kaukasus, Sibirien, Mongolei, China, Nordamerika. In Ostsibirien eine besondere Sippe mit kürzeren Schnabelzähnen (C. orthostachys C. A. MEY. Syn. C. aristata R. BR. ssp. orthostachys (C. A. MEY.) KÜK.), die vielleicht als Unterart richtig bewertet ist. In Ostasien weitere nahe verwandte Sippen. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. Carex atherodes kommt in Mitteleuropa nur an wenigen Stellen im nordöstlichen Flachland vor. Diese mitteleuropäischen Fundorte sind als südwestliche Vorposten des finnisch-nordrussischen Teilareals aufzufassen.- Verbreitungskarte für Mitteleuropa bei ÜLESINSKI (1962, S. 414).- In Ostpreußen im Waldgebiet ""Puszcza Romincka"" westlich von Wehrkirchen [Zytkiejmy] bei Goldap in den Flußtälern Zytkiejmska Struga und Bl~dzianka (vgl. die Karte bei ÜLESINSKI 1962, S. 415).- In Westpreußen im Kreise Kulm [Chelmno] (westlichster der beiden nordwestlich von Orlowen zwischen Lissewo [Lisewo] und Ostrowo gelegenen Tümpel).- Im Gebiet von Hohensalza [Inowrodaw] früher auf einer Sumpfwiese zwischen Balino und Slonsk (in der Nähe dieses- jetzt erloschenen- Fundortes wurde die Segge von WILKON-MICHALSKA [1960] bestätigt).- In Brandenburg nur bei Nauen (Kleiner Hüllpfuhl in der Nähe des Forsthauses Friedrichshof, etwa 1,5 km südwestlich von Klein Behnitz; vgl. die Karte bei FISCHER [1966, S. 56]). Der Kleine Hüllpfuhl ist neuerdings wegen des Vorkommens von Carex atherodes als Naturdenkmal geschützt.- In Schlesien bei Kanth [Canth] (bei Koslau und auf den Wiesen vor Neudorf) sowie neuerdings bei Breslau (""Niskie Laki"" in der Nähe des Oderkanals).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atherodes-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","cc2e5f1f-4d90-406f-9f10-1c6cef5264e9#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224704","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze. Wurzelstock mit kräftigen Ausläufern. Stengel aufrecht, stumpf dreikantig, etwa so lang wie die Blätter oder kürzer als diese, (50-)60-120(-200) cm hoch, bis 3 mm dick, am Grunde verdickt, glatt oder oberwärts und besonders im Blütenstand mehr oder weniger rauh, beblättert. Grundständige Blattscheiden spreitenlos, braun bis schwarzpurpurn, stark netzfaserig. Blätter etwas steif, flach, oberseits glatt und kahl, unterseits durch den Mittelnerv gekielt und schwach behaart, allmählich zugespitzt, 3-7 mm breit, an den Rändern rauh, hellgrün. Blattscheiden (besonders im oberen Teil) weichhaarig, lang. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes laubblattartig, die unteren meist so lang wie der Blütenstand oder länger als dieser, ohne oder mit kurzer Scheide (das unterste Hüllblatt zuweilen mit bis 1 cm langer Scheide). Blütenstand bis über 40 cm lang, aus 2-4 männlichen Ährchen und (2-)3-4(-5) darunter stehenden weiblichen Ährchen bestehend (oberstes weibliches Ährchen zuweilen am Grunde oder an der Spitze männlich); männliche Ährchen genähert bis wenig entfernt, weibliche Ährchen meist voneinander und von den männlichen Ährchen entfernt. Weibliche Ährchen sitzend bis kurz gestielt (Stiel des untersten Ährchens bis 3 cm lang), aufrecht, zylindrisch bis keulenförmig, 40-80(-95) mm lang, (8-)10-12(-15) mm breit, vielblütig, dichtblütig (am Grunde oft lockerblütig). Männliche Ährchen aufrecht, schmal zylindrisch, 20-60 mm lang, 3-6 mm breit. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten eiförmig, an der Spitze gewimpert, in eine lange, gezähnte Granne auslaufend, meist kürzer als die Schläuche, 6-7 mm lang, 1-2 mm breit, bleichgrün, mit wenig ausgeprägtem Mittelstreifen. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten eiförmig, mit gewimperter, breiter Spitze, die oberen mit langer, rauher Granne, 4-6 mm lang, bis 2 mm breit, rostbraun, mit weißhäutigen Rändern. Schläuche schräg abstehend, eiförmig, zusammengedrückt, außen stark gewölbt, innen fast flach, oberwärts allmählich in den langen, tief zweizähnigen Schnabel verschmälert (Schnabelzähne schlank, zuletzt nach außen gekrümmt [1,2-]2[-3] mm lang, glatt), 6-8 mm lang, 2 mm breit, mit 10-15 Längsnerven, in der oberen Hälfte und am Grunde des Schnabels auf den Nerven zerstreut behaart oder fast ganz kahl, gelbgrün bis gelbbraun, glänzend. Narben 3.· Frucht ellipsoidisch, dreikantig, den Schlauch nicht ausfüllend. 2,5 mm lang, 1,2 mm breit, gelbbraun, oft fehlschlagend.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atherodes-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","cc2e5f1f-4d90-406f-9f10-1c6cef5264e9#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224704","habitat","<p>Sehr selten, auf buschigen, nassen Wiesen, in Waldsümpfen, auf feuchten Waldlichtungen, in Großseggen-Beständen an Tümpeln; auf nassen, zeitweise überschwemmten, nährstoffreichen Torfschlammböden. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224723","diagnostic","<p>It occasionally grows with C. atrofusca, with which, at first glance, it can be confused. When sterile, the creeping rhizome of C. atrofusca (although that may not always be obvious) is usually sufficient to separate it, as are the pale, often yellow-brown leaf-sheaths and rhizome-scales. The Jack of a creeping rhizome can separate C. atrata. The lack of a terminal male spike and the bract exceeding the inflorescence will distinguish C. atrata from C. bigelowii, with which it can also grow. Vegetatively, the lack of obvious rhizomes and the tufted shoots will distinguish C. atrata. Hybrids between C. atrata and C. norvegica are known but are not recorded for Britain.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22a77830-23b3-49dc-8045-1ff15b44f495#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224723","distribution","<p>In Scotland Carex atrata is found in the higher Grampians, reaching just westwards into E Westerness; it also occurs at one site in Peeblesshire. In England it is found in the Lake District (v.c. 69) and in Wales in Caemarvonshire (v.c. 49). It is absent from Ireland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22a77830-23b3-49dc-8045-1ff15b44f495#distribution"

Korea.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","5986128e-63b4-4541-84dd-6d8c12f9a634#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224723","ecology","<p>C. atrata is found on steep ungrazed cliff-ledges, usually where there is calcareous veining. Thus it is found on cliffs associated with the Luzula sylvatica-Geum rivale tall-herb community (U17) in Scotland, northern England and N Wales. In Scotland it also grows in Salix lapponum-Luzula sylvatica scrub (W20) and the Dryas-Silene acaulis ledge community (CG14) with C. norvegica, C. vaginata and other rare calcicolous species; usually above 700 m, reaching 1095 m on Ben Lawers, v.c. 88 (Foley & Porter 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22a77830-23b3-49dc-8045-1ff15b44f495#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224723","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots tufted; roots pale brown; scales brownish or reddish-purple, persistent. <i>Stems </i> (25-)30-55 cm, thick, rigid, trigonous, solid. <i>Leaves </i> 15-30 cm × 2-6 mm, ± flat or slightly keeled, abruptly tapered to a rough apex, mid green to deep blue-green; hypostomous; sheaths dark brown, often wine-red, persistent, with inner face hyaline (reflecting as silvery-green), persistent; apex straight; ligule 2-3 mm, obtuse to acute. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/8 to 1/6 length of stem; bracts leaf-like, lower exceeding inflorescence, the lowest not or scarcely sheathing. <i>Spikes </i> 3-5, ovoid, 8-20 mm, clustered in an inclined head, becoming ± nodding in fruit, terminal spike female at top, male at base, lower female only; lower peduncles rough, as long as spike. Male glumes 4.5-6 mm, ovate-elliptic, red-black with pale midrib; apex acute or rounded. Female glumes 3.5-4.5 mm, ovate-elliptic, purple or reddish-black with pale midrib; apex ± acute. <i>Utricles</i>  3-4 mm, obovoid-ellipsoid, compressed at edges, green; beak 0.3-0.5 mm, slightly notched; stigmas 3; nut obovoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22a77830-23b3-49dc-8045-1ff15b44f495#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224723","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.     Leaves: 3-6 mm wide, dorsal surfaces<br /><br/>papillated. Basal sheaths: reddish brown. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like, sheathless. Pistillate scales: dark purple, apex acute.<br /><br/> Spikes: terminal spike gynecandrous, 1.2-2.3 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, 1.5-3 cm long, pedunculate.       Perigynia: as long as pistillate scales, ovoid, 3-3.5 mm long, glabrous, veinless, upwardly papillated, shortly beaked, beak darkish brown, mouth slightly bidentate.<br /><br/> Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 1.3-1.5 mm long.<br /><br/> Stigmas: 3","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","5986128e-63b4-4541-84dd-6d8c12f9a634#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224728","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, con rizoma de entrenudos cortos. Tallos 13-26(35) cm, agudamente trígonos, lisos o algo escábridos, densamente papilosos. Hojas (2)3-6(6,8) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes de la zona superior, planas, muy papilosas, glaucas, no muy rígidas; lígula hasta 2 mm, de ápice obtuso, redondeado o truncado; sin antelígula o con ésta corta y de ápice redondeado; vainas basales de escuamiformes a con limbo desarrollado, ± enteras, de color púrpura obscuro o negruzcas. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de longitud mayor o menor que la inflorescencia, no o cortamente envainante. Espigas (2)3-5(7), de 12-21 mm, pedunculadas, las inferiores colgantes o inclinadas, ovoides, ± aproximadas, la superior ginecandra, el resto femeninas o raramente todas ginecandras. Glumas ovales, agudas, negras, las masculinas frecuentemente con margen escarioso muy estrecho, papilosas, de mayor longitud que los utrículos. Estigmas 3. Utrículos 3-3,5 × 2-2,4 mm, suberectos, de contorno anchamente oval o suborbicular, comprimidos o planoconvexos, con los nervios no perceptibles, glabros, muy densamente papilosos, verdosos o de color pardo claro, variablemente teñidos de negro, bruscamente estrechados en un pico de 0,4-0,6 mm, recto, de ápice bidentado, papiloso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224773","diagnostic","<p>C. atrofusca could be confused with C. atrata, but the position of the male florets, the stiffer and distinctly glaucous leaves and the rock-ledges habitat of the latter are sufficient to distinguish them. No hybrids of C. atrofusca are recorded.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8798179e-6e4a-4343-9711-376de2a4e3d0#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224773","distribution","<p>Carex atrofusca has been found only on the Breadalbanes in mid Perth and in Westerness and Argyll. The record of the species on Rum (Heslop Hanison 1945) is unconfirmed and is ecologically unlikely (Pearman & Walker 2004).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8798179e-6e4a-4343-9711-376de2a4e3d0#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224773","ecology","<p>A rare plant of micaceous stony flushes between 540 and 1000 m (on Beinn Heasgamich, v.c. 88), although now known no lower than 680 m, on Ben Lawers, v.c. 88 (Porter & Foley 2002). In Carex-Saxifraga mires in which the dominant species are C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa and S. aizoides (M11) and C. saxatilis (M12) with other sedges (such as C. dioica, C. nigra, C. panicea and C. pulicaris), Juncus alpinoarticulatus, J. biglumis, J. castaneus, Pinguicula vulgaris, Thalictrum alpinum, Blindia acuta etc. Often in rock-flushes on steep slopes and then protected by a small rock or tuft of Nardus stricta or Festuca ovina (R.E. Thomas in Wigginton 1 999).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8798179e-6e4a-4343-9711-376de2a4e3d0#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224773","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping; shoots in loose tufts; roots yellowish; scales pale brown, soon decaying. <i>Stems </i> 5-35 cm, trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> 2-12 cm × 2-5 mm (those of sterile shoots often less than 1 mm), soft, ± flat or slightly keeled, stem-leaves abruptly tapered to a short trigonous point, those of sterile shoots more gradually tapered to a finer trigonous point 1-3 cm long, tn.id green, very rarely glaucous; hypostomous; sheaths pale with green veins, becoming pale yellow-brown, soon decaying, with inner face hyaline and apex concave, soon splitting; ligule 1-2.5 mm, obtuse. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/6 to 1/4 length of stem; lower bracts narrowly leaf-like, shorter than the spike, the lowest with a sheath 5-15( -25) mm, upper glumaceous. Male spike 1, 5-10 mm, broadly ellipsoid; male glumes 3.5 mm, ovate-elliptic, dark red-brown, rarely pale, with pale or green midrib; apex acute to acuminate. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-4, 5-12 mm, clustered, lowest rarely distant, ovoid-globose, nodding; peduncles smooth, up to 3 times as long as spike, half-ensheathed; female glumes c. 3 mm, oblanceolate, purple-or red-black with pale, thin or often indistinct midrib; apex acuminate. <i>Utricles</i>  4-4.5 mm, narrowly obovoid or ellipsoid, purple-black; beak 0.3 mm, notched; stigmas 3; nut ± ellipsoid, trigonous, stalked.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8798179e-6e4a-4343-9711-376de2a4e3d0#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224782","distribution","<p>Qinghai, Shaanxi, W Sichuan, Xizang.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofuscoides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9f0e10f1-4f64-478d-a33a-f90bc608c494#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224782","general","<p>Rhizome short, oblique. Culms 20-30 cm tall, trigonous, smooth, clothed at base with brown sheaths. Leaves ca. 1/2 length of culm, blades pale greenish, linear, 2-4 mm wide, flat, margins scabrous, apex acuminate. Lower involucral bracts reduced to shortly bladed or setaceous, longer or shorter than inflorescence, sheathing ca. 4 mm, purple, upper bracts glumelike. Spikes 2 or 3, entirely gynaecandrous, ovate or elliptic, 1-1.5 × 0.8-1.2 cm, with slender pendent peduncles. Female glumes dark purple-red, lanceolate, 5.5-6 × ca. 1.2 mm, 1-veined, upper margins narrowly white hyaline, apex long acuminate. Utricles stramineous at base, dark purple-brown above, shorter than glume, ovate-lanceolate, compressed trigonous, ca. 4 mm, membranous, glabrous, nerveless, base cuneate, apex gradually narrowed to a short beak, orifice smooth, white hyaline, emarginate. Nutlets pale brown, loosely enveloped, elliptic, obtusely trigonous, ca. 1.5 mm, base with a stipe ca. 0.5 mm; style enclosed in utricle, erect, base scabrous; stigmas 3.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofuscoides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9f0e10f1-4f64-478d-a33a-f90bc608c494#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224782","habitat","<p>Alpine meadows, alpine meadows in thickets; 1000-4700 m.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atrofuscoides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9f0e10f1-4f64-478d-a33a-f90bc608c494#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224794","distribution","<p>Japan: Hokkaido, Honshu and Kyushu.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atroviridis-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","f2c57aec-bbfb-4f4a-a104-270565a049bb#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224794","habitat","<p>Widely distributed in temperate regions of the northern hemisphere.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atroviridis-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","f2c57aec-bbfb-4f4a-a104-270565a049bb#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224794","morphology","Plant: perennial, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 30-100 cm tall, smooth or scabrous along angles.  Leaves: 3-8 mm wide, light green, scabrous. Basal sheaths: reddish brown, ladder-like fibriilose. Bracts: leaf-like, with sheathless or shortly sheathed. Pistillate scales: pale brown, midrib green, apex acute or acuminate. Spikes: upper 2 or 3 spikes slaminatc, crowded, linear, 3-5 cm long, long pedunculate; lower 2-4 spikes pistillate, remote, upper spike shortly pedunculate, lower spikes sometimes long pedunculate, cylindrical, 3-7 cm long, densely flowered. Staminate scales: brown, apex obtuse or acute.<br /><br/>      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 6-8 mm long, many veined, glabrous, inflated at maturity, long beaked, mouth rigid bidentate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2-3 mm long.  Stigmas: 3    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Takuji Hoshino <br /><br/>Additional authors: Tomomi Masaki <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: March, 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: Illustrated Sedges of Japan.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-atroviridis-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","f2c57aec-bbfb-4f4a-a104-270565a049bb#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224799","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with short rhizomes.     Leaves: 2-3 mm wide, dorsal surfaces papillate. Basal sheaths: reddish brown. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224800","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose; rhizomes shortly creeping.     Leaves: longer than culms, 2-4 mm wide, soft. Basal sheaths: brown or reddish brown. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224802","general","<p>Culms 5–40 cm. Leaves: blades 3–20(–30) cm × 1.4–3 mm. Inflorescences: proximal bracts with well-developed blades exceeding inflorescence sheaths 2–4(–10) mm; lateral spikes with 4–20 perigynia, approximate or proximal distant, lax, 4–20(–30) × 3–5 mm, middle internodes (0.5–)0.7–1.5 mm; terminal spike usually staminate, occasionally gynecandrous, sessile or short-pedunculate, 3–10(–15) × 0.9–2 mm. Pistillate scales brown with paler or green midvein, divergent in mature fruit, ovate to ovate-circular, 1.2–2.5 × 1.1–1.8 mm, apex subacute to obtuse or cuspidate. Proximal staminate scales brown with paler or green midvein and hyaline margins, oblong-ovate, 2–3.5(–4) mm, apex obtuse to subacute. Perigynia divergent, bright orange, somewhat inflated and fleshy when mature, circular-obovate, 2.3–3.2 × 1.2–1.8 mm, smooth or minutely papillose. Achenes subcircular, 1.4–1.8 × 1–1.5 mm. 2n = 52.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/node/6859","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","d48a037d-0644-4e15-a919-ba5ab4b96f8c","","7c92575b-ef52-4d92-84c0-eb56f52ce24e#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224810","general","<p>Densamente cespitosa. Tallos (30)40-90 cm, trígonos, generalmente lisos. Hojas (0,8)1-2(2,4) mm de anchura, de longitud igual o menor que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes, planas, canaliculadas o, más raramente, enrolladas; lígula hasta 1 mm, de ápice redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, de enteras a ligeramente fibrosas, pardas o variablemente teñidas de color púrpura. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia, envainante. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (15)18-30(35) mm, estrechamente fusiforme; espigas femeninas 1-2(4), de 10-25(30) mm, erectas o colgantes, ± cilíndricas, laxifloras, separadas, pedunculadas, raras veces con algunas flores masculinas en el ápice. Glumas masculinas estrechamente ovales u obovadas, de ápice agudo a cortamente mucronado, raramente obtuso, de color pardo o pardo-rojizo, con margen escarioso; glumas femeninas ovales, de ápice agudo, cortamente mucronado o, con menos frecuencia, obtuso, de color pardo claro, pardo-rojizo o pardo-púrpura, con margen escarioso, de longitud menor o igual que los utrículos. Utrículos (2,8)3-3,5(4,2) × 1,1-1,7 mm, erectos o suberectos, de contorno oval o elíptico, trígonos, con varios nervios marcados, pubescentes en la mitad superior, glabros o casi en la inferior, verdosos o parduscos, a veces con manchas rojas, ± bruscamente estrechados en un pico de 0,5-1 mm, recto, de ápice escarioso, irregularmente roto o bidentado, escábrido. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224853","distribution","<p>In den Südalpen zwischen Corner See und Valsugana ziemlich verbreitet, sehr selten in den Zentralalpen und Nordalpen. Die eigenartige Verbreitung von Carex baldensis deutet ebenso wie die isolierte systematische Stellung (die Art ist die einzige Vertreterin der Sektion Baldenses) darauf hin, daß es sich um eine sehr alte, zweifellos tertiäre Art handelt. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. In Deutschland nur in Bayern In den A mmergauer Bergen (an der Loisach und Naidernach westlich von Garmisch; von Griesen etwa 3 km loisach-abwärts auf Alluvionen, neuangesiedelt am Bahndamm Hechen- In Österreich nur in Tirol (nördlichund nordöstlich des Plansees, jedoch nicht a m Solstein bei Innsbruck). - In der Schweiz nur im östlichen Graubünden am Ofenpaß (Val Chaschlot bis 240o m, Val Nüglia, Munt della Bescha, Plan dell'Aua, Alp da Munt, Buffalora) und (adventiv) bei Solothurn (hier wohl von Zugvögeln verschleppt). - Das Vorkommen an den bisher genannten nord und zentralalpinen Fundorten wurde früher durch Einschleppung (Schafe!) aus den Südalpen erklärt. MERXMÜLLER (1952, p. 46) lehnt diese Deutung ab. Die glatten Schläuche von C. baldensis sind für eine epizoische Verbreitung nicht sonderlich geeignet. - In den Italienischen Alpen zwischen Corner See und Valsugana, bei Menaggio auch auf der Westseite des Corner Sees; sehr häufig im Gardaseegebiet, besonders in den Judikarischen Alpen. In Südtirol verläuft die Nordgrenze vom Idro-See über Preore, Toblino-See, Scanuppia, Ci mone di Caldonazzo nach Bassano.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-baldensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","510bf365-8f72-4211-ba90-274a4b7e4387#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224853","ecology","<p>Die Bestäubung erfolgt zum Teil durch Käfer.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-baldensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","510bf365-8f72-4211-ba90-274a4b7e4387#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224853","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze. Wurzelstock lockere bis dichte Rasen bildend. Stengel stei aufrecht, 10-30(-40) cm hoch, bis 2 mm dick, schwach dreikantig, glatt, nur am Grunde beblättert. Blätter gedrängt, kürzer oder länger als der Stengel, 2-4 mm breit, flach oder zusammengefaltet, ziemlich starr, an den Rändern ziemlich stark rauh, an der Spitze eingerollt, graugrü n. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes 2-5, horizontal abstehend oder zurückgeschlagen, bis 5 cm lang. Blütenstand ein aufrechtes, breit dreieckiges, etwas gelapptes, 1,5 cm langes, 2-2,5 cm breites Köpfchen aus 3-9 Ährchen. Ährchen länglich eiförmig, 1 cm lang, etwa 4 mm breit, androgyn (am Grunde weiblich), vielblütig. Spelzen länglich dreieckig bis eiförmig, meist spitz, viel länger als die Schläuche, weißlich bis gelblich, mit grünlichem Kiel, dreinervig. SchIäuche länglich, stumpf dreikantig, ungeschnäbelt, spitz, 4-5 mm lang, dunkelbraun, viel nervig. Achsen fortsatz zuweilen aus dem Schlauch herausragend. Narben 3. Frucht eiförmig, scharf dreikantig, mit konkaven Seitenflächen.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-baldensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","510bf365-8f72-4211-ba90-274a4b7e4387#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224853","habitat","<p>Selten, aber gesellig, in sonnigen Steinrasen, im Kalk- und Dolomitgeröll steiniger, trockener Abhänge, auf Kies, auf steinigen Weiden, auch herabgeschwemmt im Flußschotter; auf mäßig frischen, kalkreichen, mild-humosen, lehmigen Steinböden. Charakterart des Seslerio-Sempervirentetum (Seslerion), auch im schneeheidereichen Kiefernwald, im Flaumeichenbusch und in lichten Latschenbeständen. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224932","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, con entrenudos no muy largos. Tallos 2,5-8(10) cm, trígonos, lisos o escábridos hacia el ápice. Hojas (0,8)1-2,5(3,1) mm de anchura, de longitud menor o raramente algo mayor que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes y el nervio medio del envés hacia el ápice, planas, muy papilosas, glaucas, ± blandas; lígula hasta 1,5 mm, de ápice obtuso o redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado, a veces las más inferiores escuamiformes, enteras o algo rotas, pardas. Espigas 2-4, de 3,5-7(10) mm, anchamente ovoides, aproximadas o la inferior separada, frecuentemente subbasilar, la superior ginecandra, raramente masculina, el resto femeninas, las superiores sésiles o casi, las inferiores pedunculadas, erectas. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224946","diagnostic","<p>The purplish, not orange-brown, scales and glaucous, not dark green, leaves (often showing a thin band of red on decaying) distinguish this species from C. binervis, which can grow at the lower ranges of C. bigelowii, while the shiny red-or purple-brown rhizome scales help to distinguish it from C. nigra, with which it commonly hybridises (C. × decolorans Wimm.). It also hybridises with C. aquatilis (C. × limula Months of the fruiting period:). With both of these hybrids there is the possibility of backcrossing, so identification can be difficult (see, e.g., Corner 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-bigelowii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ae2f74c8-cabf-48ed-b193-6913622a70de#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224946","distribution","<p>C. bigelowii is a mountain plant, occurring above 600 m for most of its range and reaching 1305 m on Ben Macdui, although in Shetland growing at 15 m (Foley & Porter 2002). Through Scotland to the High Pennines and Lake District, south to North Wales. In Ireland a local plant of mountain summits and ridges and, as in Scotland, at a lower altitude on west coast headlands.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-bigelowii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ae2f74c8-cabf-48ed-b193-6913622a70de#distribution"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224946","ecology","<p>C. bigelowii can be a dominant sedge on exposed humic, base-poor soils in the Rhacomitriurn lanuginosurn-Vaccinium myrtillus-Cladonia lichen-rich heaths (H19, H20) and prominent with C. canescens, C. echinata and Sphagnum lindbergii (M7a) and on edges of Calluna-Eriophorurn blanket mire (M19). A component of 13 windswept montane communities (U5-14, Ul6-18), e.g. constant with Nardus stricta and Galium saxatile (U7), Dicranurn fuscescens and Polytrichastrum alpinum (U8), Juncus trifidus (U9) or Rhacomitrium lanuginosurn (U10). On ledges of flushed gullies it can be a robust plant.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-bigelowii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ae2f74c8-cabf-48ed-b193-6913622a70de#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:224946","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short-or long-creeping; shoots solitary or in pairs, ± close together; roots often as thick as rhizomes, grey-brown; scales red-or purple-brown, shiny, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 4-30 cm, usually rough, rigid, usually >2 mm wide near base, sharply trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> up to 25 cm × 2-7 mm, stiff or arcuate ± rough, keeled, ± abruptly tapered to a flat apex, with margins often revolute and rolling outwards on drying, glaucous and papillous below, less glaucous, ± glossy and devoid of papillae above, dying to a red-brown; hypostomous; sheaths brown or red-brown and shiny, persistent, with inner face hyaline, soon decaying, and apex ± straight; ligule 1-2 mm, acute, shortly tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/8 to 1/5 (up to 1/2) length of stem; bracts leaf-like, with blackish auricles, lowest shorter than inflorescence. Male spike 1, rarely 2, 5-20 mm; male glumes 3-4 mm, obovate-elliptic, black with green midrib; apex acute or rounded. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-3, contiguous or lower ± distant, 5-15 mm, cylindric-ovoid, erect, sessile, lowest only sometimes shortly pedunculate; female glumes 2.5-3.5 mm, ovate-elliptic, black with green midrib; apex obtuse. <i>Utricles</i>  2.5-3 nun, broader than glumes, suborbicular-ellipsoid, nerveless, green; beak c. 0.2 mm, truncate or slightly notched; nut ovoid-ellipsoid, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-bigelowii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ae2f74c8-cabf-48ed-b193-6913622a70de#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225005","general","<p>Cespitosa. Tallos 5-30(60) cm, trígonos, lisos. Brácteas inferiores 2-5, de longitud mucho mayor que la inflorescencia, foliáceas, patentes salvo la más inferior que es erecta. Espigas densamente agrupadas formando una inflorescencia netamente capituliforme. Glumas linear-lanceoladas, aristadas, hialinas con el nervio central verde, las femeninas de longitud mucho menor que los utrículos. Utrículos 7-10 × 0,9-1,1 mm, de contorno linear, plano-convexos, no esponjosos en la base, con los nervios prominentes, pajizos, estrechamente alados, largamente estipitados y gradualmente atenuados en un pico muy largo –hasta de 7 mm–, muy escábrido, profundamente bífido. Aquenios 1,3-1,5 × 0,6-0,7 mm, de contorno ± elíptico, ligeramente biconvexos, de color pardo claro. 2n = 62-64*, 80*.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-bohemica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","bf8dbfc9-0487-4e2d-8bf7-2a37b4ae8ffd#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225048","general","<p>Tufted perennial, 3-10 cm. Rhizome short, with tillers and emitting ascending subterranean stolons. Stem obtusely trigonous to terete, grooved, smooth. Leaves from 2/3 to equalling stem; sheaths up to 2 cm, brown to yellow-brown, rather soft, mat, margin of scarious side deeply oblique; ligule to 0.3 mm, nearly straight; blades c. 0.5 mm wide, conduplicate, flexuous or curved, margins smooth, apex long attenuate, smooth or slightly scabrous. Inflorescence of 1-3 androgynous, or of 1 androgynous and 1-2 pistillate spikes, overlapping or lowest remote. Bracts clasping, mostly shorter than their spike. Spikes 5-12 x 3-5 mm, ovoid to obovoid, sessile or subsessile; female glumes 2.5-3 x 1.5-2 mm, obtuse to acute, yellowish and with hyaline margin to dark brown, midnerve yellowish, sides nerveles; utricles 2-2.5 x 1.1-1.3 mm, widely fusiform to obovoid, slightly inflated, lustrous, upper part yellowish or dark brown, weakly papillose, beak c. 0.1 mm. Stigmas 3. Nut 1.7-2 x 0.8-1 mm, ellipsoid to obovoid, plano-convex, trigonous, reticulate, yellowish to olive brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-borii","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-0","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","125a23bb-7a9a-4a01-9195-6510dc1fadd6#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225059","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 15-35 cm tall, upwardly slighty scabrous.  Leaves: 1.5-3 mm wide. Basal sheaths: brown. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225134","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos muy largos, total o parcialmente cubierto por escamas que surgen de los nudos, de color pardo, enteras o ± fibrosas. Tallos 20-60(100) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos agudos, escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas 1-2,5(4,3) mm de anchura, de mayor longitud que los tallos, planas, ásperas en los bordes y nervio medio del envés, blandas; lígula (0,4)0,7-2(3) mm, con los bordes levantados, de anchura mayor o menor que el limbo, de ápice obtuso o redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, de color pardo claro, enteras. Bráctea inferior de longitud mucho menor que la inflorescencia, glumácea, con ápice setáceo que rara vez supera la espiga. Espigas 5-9(16) mm dispuestas en espiga simple de 1-3,5(5,4) cm, agrupadas, a veces con la espiga inferior separada del resto, en cuyo caso la inflorescencia puede alcanzar hasta 5,8 cm, ginecandras, aunque las espigas superiores tienen 1-2(3) flores masculinas en el ápice y la inferior puede ser enteramente femenina. Glumas ovales, agudas, de color verde pálido o pajizo, las femeninas generalmente mayores que los utrículos. Utrículos 2,5-4(5) × 1-1,8 mm, de contorno oval, planoconvexos, esponjosos en la base, con 1 ala ancha en gran parte de la longitud de cada uno de sus bordes, con los nervios perceptibles pero no muy prominentes, verdosos, gradualmente atenuados en un pico de 0,8-2 mm, escábrido-serrulado, bífido. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225200","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose; rhizome internodes 1.6–2.2 mm thick. Culms strongly purple-red to 3–7.4 cm high at base, 10–65 cm. Leaves: sheaths glabrous; blades green, widest blades 2.2–3.5(–3.9) mm wide, smooth abaxially. Inflorescences 0.31–0.94 of culm height; peduncles of lateral spikes barely scaberulous or smooth; peduncles of terminal spikes 1.8–28 mm, usually slightly exceeding lateral spikes; proximal bract sheaths tight, abaxially glabrous, sheath front convex, elongated 0.3–1.1(–1.7) mm beyond apex; ligules 0.4–2.2 mm; distal bract usually much exceeding terminal spike. Spikes 4–5, widely separate or distal 2–3 spikes overlapping; lateral spikes pistillate, with (1–)3–9(–11) perigynia, 4–19 × 5.1–8.2(–10.2) mm, ratio of spike length (in mm) to flower number = 1.4–1.9; terminal spikes (7–)10–29 × 1.1–2.1(–3.1) mm. Pistillate scales 2.8–5.4 × 1.7–2.5 mm, margins whitish, entire, apex with awn 0.8–2.6 mm. Staminate scales 3.6–5 × 1–1.8 mm. Anthers 2.9–3.7 mm. Perigynia distichously imbricate, 51–67-veined, inflated, unwrinkled, oblong-obovoid, orbicular or suborbicular in cross section, 3.6–4.4 × (1.8–)2–2.5(–2.8) mm, 1.6–2(–2.1) times as long as wide, dull, base very gradually tapered, apex abruptly contracted; beak straight, 0–0.2(–0.3) mm. Achenes obovoid, 2.6–3.3 × 1.6–2.1 mm, loosely enveloped by perigynia; stipe straight, 0.3–0.7 mm; beak straight, 0.05–0.3 mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-bulbostylis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-griseae-lhbailey-k%C3%BCckenthal","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0e4471fc-08bd-44e3-a1a4-305b0584e22b#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225208","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, in the interior, in North-West and Northern Cape. Endemic to southern Africa.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-burchelliana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","85e20baf-d070-4d8a-b6d9-7cbb5581e1d9#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225208","general","<p>Plants 340–440 mm tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 1.5–2.5 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves mid-green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade 200–210 × 4–5 mm, flat in cross-section; adaxial surface glabrous; abaxial surface scabrid; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth convex, membranous; ligule 2–4 mm high, fuscous, membranous, apex acute. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1.2–1.7 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 1 node exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 80–440 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheaths 15–55 mm long; blades 220 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 3–5, erect or suberect, not clustered, excepting frequently apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 10–25 × 3–8 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 8–22 mm, glabrous. Apical spikes usually staminate. Staminate spikes 1–2. Pistillate spikes 1–3. Bisexual spikes 0–3. Small accessory spikes not present. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.0–2.2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets broadly ovate, 2.5–3.0 × 2.0–2.2 mm, shorter and narrower than perigynium, stramineous, glabrous, but ciliate distally on margin; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex obtuse or emarginate, shortly awned; awn 0.2–0.4 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, not stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 3.0–3.5 × 1.6–2.0 mm, triangular in cross-section, much inflated, green, or stramineous with ferruginous spots, without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, glabrous, nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum abrupt, 0.5 mm long, straight; rostrum margin not winged, scabrid; apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.2 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base slightly bent, or straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate, narrowly clawed, 2.0–2.4 × 1.0–1.4 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-burchelliana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","85e20baf-d070-4d8a-b6d9-7cbb5581e1d9#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225208","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, in perennially waterlogged marshland, on dolomite-derived substratum.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-burchelliana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","85e20baf-d070-4d8a-b6d9-7cbb5581e1d9#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225215","conservation","<p>Carex buxbaumii is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Vulnerable (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-buxbaumii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c63087ae-f452-4236-bf15-b3e02d5c8757#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225215","diagnostic","<p>Superficially like C. nigra, but the three stigmas, shape of female glume and terminal female florets distinguish it (although very occasionally C. nigra has a few female flowers at the top of the male spike). Vegetatively, distinguished from C. lasiocarpa by the acute ligule and less tapered leaf. Plants from Lough Neagh formerly identified as C. hartmanii Cajander, a plant of C Europe and Fennoscandia, are a form of C. buxbaumii. A northern taxon, C. buxbaumii subsp. alpina (Hartman) Liro, which has similar utricles to C. hartmanii but shorter, acute but not acuminate male glumes, could occur in alpine Scotland; it also has all spikes cylindrical, whilst in typical C. buxbaumii the terminal spike is clavate and the others ovoid or obovoid. No hybrids between C. buxbaumii and other species in this section have been recorded; the hybrids recorded with C. acutiformis and C. nigra are probably aberrant forms of those species.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-buxbaumii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c63087ae-f452-4236-bf15-b3e02d5c8757#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225215","distribution","<p>Carex buxbaumii was previously known from three single localities in Scotland (in v.cc. 96, 97 and 98; mapped above). In 2006 it was recorded from Skye (v.c. 104, not included above) and it has been possibly overlooked in other sites. Fir t discovered in our island in Ireland in 1835 around Lough Neagh (v.c. H39), where it has long ago disappeared through drainage.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-buxbaumii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c63087ae-f452-4236-bf15-b3e02d5c8757#distribution"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225215","ecology","<p>C. buxbaumii is a sedge of mesotrophic C. rostrata-Calliergonella cuspidata/Calliergon giganteum mires (M9), but also often associated with dwarf shrubs, Erica tetralix and Myrica gale (M15), although it does less well when Myrica invades (P. Batty in Wigginton 1999).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-buxbaumii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c63087ae-f452-4236-bf15-b3e02d5c8757#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225215","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping; shoots single or in small tufts; roots pale yellow- brown; scales shiny, red-orange-brown, occasionally blackish, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 30-70 cm, rigid, sharply trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> 25-60 cm × 1.5-2.0 nun ± flat or keeled, gradually tapered to a fine rough point, grey-green to glaucous, with margins ± inrolled; hypostomous; sheaths red- or orange- brown, with inner face hyaline-brown, persistent, fibrillose; ligule c. 3 nun acute. <i>Inflorescence </i> c. 1/4 length of stem; upper bracts glumaceous/ setaceous, lower bracts leaf-like, ranging from equalling inflorescence to slightly longer, scarcely sheathing. <i>Spikes </i> 2-5, contiguous or remote, 715 mm, erect, the terminal female at top, male at base, the lower spikes female; peduncles 2-12 mm, rough. Male glumes 4 mm, lanceolate-elliptic, reddish-black with pale midrib; apex acute. Female glumes 3-5 mm, ovate-triangular, asymmetrical, dark red-brown with pale midrib; apex acuminate or aristate. <i>Utricles</i>  3-4.5 mm, indistinctly ribbed, pale green, oblong-ovoid, slightly tapering with ± straight sides, ± inflated; apex obtuse; beak absent or very short, notched; stigmas 3; nut ellipsoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-buxbaumii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c63087ae-f452-4236-bf15-b3e02d5c8757#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","diagnostic","<p>The soft, pale green leaves and the acutely trigonous stems with pale fruiting heads distinguish this from any other sedge in Britain or Ireland. Hybrids with C. paniculata (C. × ludibunda J. Gay), C. echinata (C. × biharica Simonk.) and C. lachenalii (C. × helvola Blytt ex Months of the fruiting period:) are found in Britain. Hybrids with C. appropinquata, C. dioica, C. elongata and C. remota are reported from elsewhere in Europe and Egorova (1999) lists a total of 13 species with which C. canescens hybridises in Eurasia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-canescens-cyperaceae-1","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","423d1968-f0c0-476b-9174-deca85516226#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","distribution","<p>Carex canescens is found on wet sandy heaths in E England, Dorset etc. and becomes frequent in W and N Wales, N England and Scotland. In Ireland it is frequent in the NE but rare and scattered in the west and south.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-canescens-cyperaceae-1","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","423d1968-f0c0-476b-9174-deca85516226#distribution"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","ecology","<p>C. canescens is a component of the oligotrophic alpine Carex-Sphagnum mires (M2, M4) and of transitional zones with C. echinata and S. fallax (M6). A dominant sedge in high-altitude mires with C. aquatilis, C. echinata and C. rariflora (M7) to 1100 m (on Ben Alder: Foley & Porter 2002). Found also in lowland Britain in more mesotrophic mires (M5), e.g. those in the valley bogs of the New Forest, where it is usually associated with C. rostrata, Eriophorum angustifolium and Sphagnum squarrosum.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-canescens-cyperaceae-1","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","423d1968-f0c0-476b-9174-deca85516226#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> very shortly creeping; shoots loosely tufted; roots pale brown or whitish; scales pale or pink-brown, usually persistent. <i>Stems </i> 10-50 cm, rough above, slender, sharply trigonous, scarcely ribbed. <i>Leaves </i> 15-55 cm × 2-3 mm, soft, thin, flat or ± keeled, tapering gradually to a fine, rough, ± flat tip, pale green; amphistomous but with stomata mostly on underside; sheaths thin, forming short false stems only, lower pink-brown, soon decaying; inner face hyaline; apex ± straight; ligule 2-3 mm, acute. <i>Inflorescence </i> 3-5 cm; bracts glumaceous, lower sometimes setaceous. <i>Spikes </i> 4-8, contiguous or ± distant, 5-8 mm, female at top, male at base. Male glumes 2.5 mm, ovate or broadly elliptic, hyaline, with green midrib; apex obtuse. Female glumes c. 2 mm, ovate-oblong, hyaline, with green midrib; apex acute or apiculate. <i>Utricles</i>  2-3 mm, ovoid-ellipsoid, piano-convex, pale or blue-green to yellow, with yellowish ribs; beak 0.5-0.75 mm, minutely rough, notched; stigmas 2; nut obovoid or ellipsoid, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-canescens-cyperaceae-1","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","423d1968-f0c0-476b-9174-deca85516226#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","general","<p>Plants cespitose, in small and medium-sized clumps; rhizomes short. Culms erect, not stiff, 15–90 cm. Leaves: sheaths pale brown abaxially, inner band thin, hyaline, sometimes slightly red tinged, concave at summit; ligules slightly longer than wide; blades pale green to gray-green flat, 10–20(–30) cm × (1.5–)2–4 mm, subequal to shorter than culms, not stiff. Inflorescences 2–15 cm × 5–10 mm; proximal bracts shorter than to exceeding spikes; distal bracts usually scalelike. Spikes 4–8, gynecandrous, proximal ± remote, distal spikes approximate, sometimes flexuous, containing (5–)10–20(–30) perigynia suborbicular to oblong, 3–12 × 3–5 mm; terminal spike staminate for less than 1/2 of length, often clavate due to more conspicuous staminate part. Pistillate scales hyaline with green, 3-veined center when young, usually brownish tinged in age, broadly ovate, subequal to, not concealing perigynia, apex obtuse to acutish. Perigynia appressed-ascending, gray-green, becoming yellowish brown, obscurely many-veined, elliptic-ovate, 1.8–3 × 1.2–1.7 mm, widest near middle, membranous; beak abaxial suture inconspicuous, small marginal teeth. Achenes pale brown, oblong-obovate, 1.25–1.5 × 1–1.25 mm, dull to slightly glossy. 2n = 56.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-canescens-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-section-glareosae-g-don","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8e55d051-be6d-44dd-947f-517c296ef45b#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","habitat","<p>Subalpine marshes.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-canescens-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","104a19dd-6555-4891-9a06-69bd8efb15c2#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225264","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with short rhizomes.    Inflorescence: 5-8 cm long. Leaves: shorter than culms, 1.6-4 mm wide, densely papillate. Basal sheaths: pale brown to brown. Pistillate scales: pale, apex acute. Spikes: 4-8, ovoid, 0.5-1 cm long, gynecandrous.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, 2.5 mm long, 1.5-1.7 mm wide, veined, glabrous, scarcely papillate, mouth bidentate, margins scabrous. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, broadly ovoid 1 4-16 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225431","general","<p>Densamente cespitosa, de cepa robusta que forma grandes macollas. Tallos 23-150 cm, escábridos en la zona superior, agudamente trígonos. Hojas 2-4 mm de anchura, de longitud generalmente igual a los tallos, planas, ásperas en los bordes y el nervio medio por el envés y por el haz hacia el ápice, ± rígidas; lígula 1,5-2,5 mm, de ápice agudo a obtuso; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, de color púrpura, enteras. Bráctea inferior setácea a cortamente foliácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia, no envainante. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (12)15-30 mm, de fusiforme a subcilíndrica; espigas femeninas 1-2(3), de (8)12-25(30) mm, cortamente cilíndricas, densas, situadas en la parte superior del tallo junto a la masculina, ± solapadas, erectas. Glumas masculinas estrechamente oblongas u obovadas, de ápice redondeado, pardo-rojizas con estrecho margen escarioso; glumas femeninas de menor longitud que los utrículos, de estrechamente oblongas a elípticas, de ápice redondeado a obtuso, pardo-rojizas ± obscuras, con quilla verde a pajiza y margen escarioso muy estrecho. Utrículos 2-2,7 × 1,2-1,7 mm, erectos, obovados a elípticos, ± comprimidos, plano-convexos, con papilas blanquecinas al menos hacia el ápice, sin nervios, sin pico o bruscamente estrechados en un pico hasta de 0,1 mm, truncado o raramente emarginado, generalmente papiloso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225431","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose, tussock-forming.    Inflorescence: consisting of 2-4 spikes. Leaves: 2-3 mm wide, hard, strongly scabrous.
