"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225504","ecology","<p>Grows in wet areas in grassland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-chlorantha-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","ab49f1ac-9f99-498f-ac2d-16bb91eca62b","","29797de8-bd0e-4d97-b412-57ff0cc821c8#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225504","general","<p>Rhizome long; shoots loosely tufted.</p><br/><p>Culms erect, trigonous, smooth below, scabrous above, 10–35 cm long, to 1 mm diam.</p><br/><p>Leaves usually shorter than culms; blade 0.7–1.7 mm wide; sheath pale brown; ligule rounded or obtuse. Inflorescence erect, narrow, 1.5–2.5 cm long, with 6–12 spikes solitary at nodes; lowest involucral bract shorter than inflorescence. Spikes sessile, contiguous, appressed or slightly spreading at maturity, to 0.5 cm long; uppermost spike androgynous; lower spikes female or androgynous. Glumes acute, dark yellow-brown to red-brown, with broad whitish or hyaline margins; female glumes 3.3–4 mm long. Utricles ovoid, nerveless, 3.0–4.0 mm long, 1.0–1.2 mm diam., shortly hispid on angles, green to red-brown; short beak c. 1 mm long, with apex split abaxially or 2-fid. Anthers 1.8–3 mm long excluding appendage c. 0.1 mm long. Style 2-fid.</p><br/><p>Nut ovoid, lenticular in cross section, yellow-brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-chlorantha-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","ab49f1ac-9f99-498f-ac2d-16bb91eca62b","","29797de8-bd0e-4d97-b412-57ff0cc821c8#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225504","morphology","Plant: Perennial. Below-ground structures: Rhizome long; with shoots loosely tufted along it.  Culms: Erect, trigonous, smooth below, scabrous above, 10–35 cm long, to 1 mm diam. Inflorescence: Erect, narrow, 1.5–2.5 cm long, with 6–12 spikes solitary at nodes; lowest involucral bract shorter than inflorescence.  Leaves: Usually shorter than culms; blade 0.7–1.7 mm wide; sheath pale brown; ligule rounded or obtuse.  Pistillate scales: Acute, dark yellow-brown to red-brown, with broad whitish or hyaline margins, 3.3–4 mm long.  Spikes: Sessile, contiguous, appressed or slightly spreading at maturity, to 0.5 cm long; uppermost spike androgynous; lower spikes female or androgynous.  Staminate scales: Acute, dark yellow-brown to red-brown, with broad whitish or hyaline margins.      Anthers: 1.8–3 mm long excluding appendage c. 0.1 mm long.  Perigynia: Ovoid, nerveless, 3.0–4.0 mm long, 1.0–1.2 mm diam., shortly hispid on angles, green to red-brown; short beak c. 1 mm long, with apex split abaxially or 2-fid. <br /><br/><br /><br/> Achenes: Ovoid, lenticular in cross section, yellow-brown. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225519","diagnostic","<p>Distinctive in having creeping decumbent shoots that in their second year give rise to similar shoots from the basal four or five, more or less widely spaced, nodes. The leaves are often inrolled, giving the plant the appearance of marram grass. A hybrid with C. canescens has been described from Norway.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-chordorrhiza-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","bb800c6f-7425-4e8d-8d82-3ecb1367cd55#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225519","distribution","<p>Carex chordorrhiza was first found in 1897 by E.S. Marshall and W.A. Shoolbred at the head of Loch Naver, Altnaharra, W Sutherland (v.c. 108); Since found in several places within a 5-km radius of there. Discovered in 1978, in quantity, .in the Inch Marshes (v.c. 97) (Page & Rieley 1985). The record for South Uist (v.c. 110) is in error (J.E. Raven in Preston 2004).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-chordorrhiza-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","bb800c6f-7425-4e8d-8d82-3ecb1367cd55#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225519","ecology","<p>Carex chordorrhiza is a plant of very wet base-poor mires, growing with C. canescens, C. limosa, C. rostrata, Sphagnum fallax, s. papillosum etc. (M4), although it does not survive prolonged inundation (Legg et at. 1995). In the Inch Marshes locality it is found in C. rostrata-Potentilla palustris Menyanthes mires (S27). Although it occurs in two areas only, present conditions appear to be favouring the vegetative spread of the plants, especially in the v.c. 97 locality where the plant is increasing (N.R. Cowie in Wigginton 1999). There is no appreciable difference in genotypic diversity in the British populations (Jardine 1994). See also Cowie & Sydes (1995).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-chordorrhiza-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","bb800c6f-7425-4e8d-8d82-3ecb1367cd55#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225519","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping, often ascending; shoots solitary, arising from elongated, decumbent base of flowering stem; roots red-brown; scales pale yellow-brown, chaffy, soon decaying. <i>Stems </i> 15-40 cm, stout, ± terete striate, with few short leaves at base. <i>Leaves </i> up to 30 cm × 1-2 mm, stiff erect, flat or ± involute, gradually narrowed to a ± trigonous fine point, mid green; hypostomous; sheaths forming short false stem, with inner face hyaline-brown and apex concave; lower sheaths pale brown-hyaline, often darkening; ligule 1-2 mm, rounded. <i>Inflorescence </i> a compact ± ovoid head 7-15 mm; bracts glumaceous. <i>Spikes </i> 2-4, 4-8 mm, male at top, female a~ base, lower often entirely female. Male glumes c. 3.5 mm, oblanceolate  elliptic, pale red-brown; apex acute. Female glumes 3-4 mm, broadly ovate-elliptic, pale red-brown, hyaline towards margin; apex ± acute. <i>Utricles</i>  (3-)3.5-4.5 mm, ovoid-ellipsoid, ± compressed, faintly ribbed, shiny, yellow-brown or often dark brown; beak c. 0.5 mm, bifid; stigmas 2; nut obovoid-oblong, stalked, with truncate apex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-chordorrhiza-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","bb800c6f-7425-4e8d-8d82-3ecb1367cd55#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225553","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.     Leaves: 4-6 mm wide, margins scabrous. Basal sheaths: yellowish brown, ladder-like fibrillose. Bracts: lower bracts leaf-like.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: purplish brown, apex obtuse or shortly awned. Spikes: terminal spikes staminate, linear terete, 2-5 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, terete, 2-7 cm long.       Perigynia: ovoid, 2.5-3 mm long, upwardly papillate, beak short, mouth bidentate. Achenes: ovoid, about 2.3 mm long. Stigmas: 2","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cinerascens-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","0ef7aca5-b1cd-4884-9332-0afd89f47432#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225570","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in winter and in all seasons, at sea level and near the coast, in Western and Eastern Cape. Endemic to the southern coast.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-clavata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","e7657e22-acc9-4d21-9918-c43711cb01c9#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225570","general","<p>Plants (410)–1700 mm tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 3–5 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow-green, glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade 300–500 × 6–11 mm, plicate in cross-section; adaxial surface glabrous; abaxial surface papillate; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, membranous; ligule 35 mm high, whitish with ferruginous spots, membranous, apex acute. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1.5–3.0 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; (0)–2 nodes exposed. Inflorescence comprising a raceme of spikes, 115–650 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheaths 23–90 mm long; blades 110–350 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes (3)–6, erect or suberect, not clustered, excepting frequently apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 30–100 × 10–15 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 0–45 mm, scabrid on angles. Apical spikes usually staminate. Staminate spikes 1–3. Pistillate spikes 1–4. Bisexual spikes 0–3. Small accessory spikes occasionally present at base of basal pistillate spikes. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 3.0–5.5 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate-lanceolate, 5–6 mm long, 1.9–4.0 mm wide, shorter and narrower than perigynium, stramineous with light to heavy ferruginous striae and hyaline margins, glabrous, but ciliate distally on margin; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex acuminate, or emarginate, awned; awn 0.7-2.0 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium spreading, not stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 6–7 × 2.5–3.0 mm, shallowly triangular in cross-section, much inflated, green, or stramineous with ferruginous spots, base without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, glabrous; nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum abrupt, or sometimes tapered, 1.0–1.5 mm long, straight; rostrum margin not winged, scabrid; rostrum apex deeply bidentate, apical teeth 0.5–1.0 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base slightly bent, or straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate, narrowly clawed, 2.8–3.5 × 1.7–2.5 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-clavata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","e7657e22-acc9-4d21-9918-c43711cb01c9#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225570","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, in perennially waterlogged marshland, on clay or loam substrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-clavata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","e7657e22-acc9-4d21-9918-c43711cb01c9#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225584","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, winter, or in all seasons, from sea level to the alpine plateau, in Namibia, Botswana, Limpopo, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, Free State, Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal, Lesotho and Western and Eastern Cape. It is also fairly widespread in East Africa, in Tanzania, Kenya, Zimbabwe and Mozambique.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cognata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","afcae87a-dd7f-4bd3-8d1d-f24da141eb52#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225584","general","<p>Plants 340–765 mm tall, caespitose (sometimes very loosely caespitose). Rhizomes very short to long, 2.5–4.0 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow-green, not glaucous, with conspicuous transverse venation, especially in dry material. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face tearing into membranous strips or simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade 230–680 × 6–8 mm, flat in cross-section; adaxial and abaxial surfaces scabrid; margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth truncate, or usually concave, membranous; ligule 4 mm high, stramineous, membranous, apex acute or obtuse. Culms sharply triangular in cross-section, 2–3 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 1–2 nodes exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 115–195 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheath 0–20 mm long; blade 300–500 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 3–6, erect, suberect, or pendulous, all clustered, or only apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 20–70 × 7–11 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 0–65 mm, scabrid on angles. Apical spikes staminate, occasionally androgynecandrous. Staminate spikes 0–2. Pistillate spikes 2–6. Bisexual spikes 0–1. Small accessory spikes not present. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.3–2.5 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate-lanceolate, 5–6 mm × 1.2–1.8 mm, the same length as and narrower than the perigynium, ferruginous, glabrous; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex obtuse or sometimes emarginate, awned; awns 1.2–3.0 mm long, margins scabrid. Mature perigynium spreading, stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 4.0–5.2 × 1.5–2.0 mm, elliptic or rotund in cross-section, much inflated, stramineous and ferruginous, base without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, glabrous, nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum abrupt, 1.1–2.0 mm long, straight, margin not winged, glabrous; apex deeply bidentate, apical teeth 0.5–1.0 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base twisted; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate or elliptic, not clawed, 1.7–2.8 , 1.2–1.5 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cognata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","afcae87a-dd7f-4bd3-8d1d-f24da141eb52#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225584","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, or light shade, in perennially waterlogged marshland or wet flushes, or in riparian situations, on clay or loam substrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cognata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","afcae87a-dd7f-4bd3-8d1d-f24da141eb52#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225591","distribution","<p>Scattered in C. Europe (mainly E.), Balkans, S. Russia, Caucasia, W. Siberia, Transcaspia. Euro-Sib. element. The isolated occurrence in Antalya may be non-spontaneous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-colchica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","51d2b5f6-e0b4-4309-aa0c-dbb3ad1cf3eb#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225591","general","<p>Rhizome far-creeping, branching, 1.5-2 mm thick, covered with pale to dark brown scales usually shorter than internodes and which become fibrous and darker with age; shoot arising at intervals, singly or in small tufts. <i>Stems</i> 15-35 (-50) cm, rather slender, sometimes slightly nodding, scabrid above; basal sheaths tightly clasping, usually pale reddish-brown. <i>Leaves</i> 1-2.5 mm broad, ± shorter than <i>Stems</i> , rather stiff, ± erect, canaliculate, greyish-green, with scabrid margins and long trigonous tip, minutely papillose above. Spikes 4-10, all ± similar, ± aggregated in an oblong, lobed <i>Inflorescence</i> to 4.5 cm; spikes usually male below or some entirely female or middle ones entirely male, ovoid-oblong, 1-1.3 cm; bracts glumaceous, lowest often with setaceous tip frequently longer than its spike. Female glumes narrowly ovate, c. as long as or shorter than utricles, acute to long-acuminate, chestnut-coloured. <i>Utricles </i> yellowishbrown to chestnut-coloured, ovoid, 3.5-4.5 mm, distinctly many-veined on both faces, veins ± elevated; surfaces minutely papillose; basal part filled with whitish spongy tissue; upper half of <i>Utricles </i> distinctly but narrowly winged, with scabrid margins; apex rather abruptly tapering into deeply bifid beak, with ± straight points. <i>Nut </i> oblong, flattened, brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-colchica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","51d2b5f6-e0b4-4309-aa0c-dbb3ad1cf3eb#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225596","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.     Leaves: 1.5-4 mm wide, slightly scabrous. Basal sheaths: brown, fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, with sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale, apex acute.  Spikes: terminal spike staminate, shortly pedunculate, 5-10 mm long; lateral spikes pistillate, sessile or shortly pedunclate, 5-10 mm long.        Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, narrowly ovoid, 5-6 mm long, glabrous, long beak, mouth bidentate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, oblong ellipsoidal, 4 mm long, angles shallowly constricted at middle, apex slightly annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225643","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with shortly creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 10-20 cm tall.  Leaves: 0.2-0.5 mm wide. Basal sheaths: pale brown. Bracts: setaceous, with short sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale brown, apex obtuse or shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear, 0.5-1.3 cm long, with short peduncles; lateral spikes pistillate, 0.5-0.8 cm long, 3-4 flowers. Staminate scales: pale brown, apex obtuse.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, narrowly ovoid, 3-3.3 mm long, glabrous, beak very short, mouth notched. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, narrowly ovoid, 2-2.3 mm long, style base annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225652","general","<p>Perennial herbs. Rhizome short, caespitose, with short stolons. Culms 20-40 cm tall, longer than leaves, trigonous, scabrous.  Leaves basal; blades flat, 1.5-2.5 mm wide, slightly stiff, margins serrulate. Bracts setaceous with long sheaths. Basal sheaths dark brown, slightly fibrillose. Flowers April to June; inflorescence racemose, with 4-5 spikes, bearing on upper 1/2 to 2/3 of the culm, single at each node; terminal spike staminate, linear, 2-4 cm long, 2-3 mm wide, dark brown; lateral spikes pistillate, erect to ascending, short pedunculate, cylindrical, 1.5-3 cm long, 2.5-3.5 mm wide, densely many flowered. Pistillate scales ovate, almost same or longer than perigynia, acute to aristate, pale or upper part brownish to reddish brown.  Perigynia ovoid-fusiform, trigonous, 3-3.5 mm long, 1-2 mm wide, membranaceous, finely nerved, glabrous, base cuneate to short stipitate, short beaked, beak curved at maturity, margins distinctly scabrous, apex bidentate. Achenes tightly enveloped, ellipsoid, trigonous, 2-2.5 mm long, 1 mm wide, base short stipitate, style base minutely annulate.  Stigmas 3.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-conica-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","ff9fe558-b0c9-4e9d-a241-bf5330f01ee4","","e8452ff7-e122-4c53-ba49-aeccc03f8dfd#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225652","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, usually with shortly creeping rhizomes.      Leaves: 2-4 mm wide, dark green, slightly stiff, margins serrulate. Basal sheaths: dark brown, slightly fibrillose. Bracts: long setaceous, with reddish brown sheatlis. Pistillate scales: with reddish brown, apex acute or aristate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225658","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.   Culms: 20-70 cm tall, soft, smooth.  Leaves: longer than culms, 2.5-5.5 mm wide. Basal sheaths: reddish purple. Bracts: leaf-like, with short sheaths. Pistillate scales: light green, apex long aristate,<br /><br/>margins of awns serrulate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear, 1.5-3 cm long, reddish brown; lateral spikes pistillate, upper spike subsessile, lower spikes pedunculate, cylindrical, 1.5-3.5 cm long, densely flowered.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, reflexed at maturity, ovoid, 4.5-6 mm long, many veined, glabrous, turning black after drying, long beaked, mouth obliquely truncate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2.5-3 mm long. Stigmas: 3    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Takuji Hoshino <br /><br/>Additional authors: Tomomi Masaki <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: March, 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: Illustrated Sedges of Japan.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-conicoides-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","8a2ffb9c-1f76-4857-9882-a1c116cc9ba9#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225662","distribution","<p>Man., N.B., Nfld. and Labr., N.S., Ont., Que.; Conn., Del., Ill., Ind., Iowa, Maine, Mass., Mich., Minn., Mo., N.H., N.J., N.Y., N.C., Ohio, Pa., R.I., Vt., Va., Wis.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-conoidea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-griseae-lhbailey-k%C3%BCckenthal","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4a6f8edc-a057-4f3e-8013-bf5f1d5d6459#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225662","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose; rhizome internodes 1.2–2.8 mm thick. Culms yellow-brown to dark brown at base, 2–75 cm. Leaves: sheaths glabrous; blades green, widest blades (2.3–)3–3.9(–5.6) mm wide, smooth abaxially or sparsely antrorsely scaberulous on main veins. Inflorescences (0.12–)0.21–0.91(–0.99) of culm height; peduncles of lateral spikes scaberulous; peduncles of terminal spikes 2.9–71(–103) mm, barely exceeded by to much exceeding lateral spikes; proximal bract sheath loose, abaxially glabrous, sheath front slightly convex, elongated 0.5–1.6 mm beyond apex; ligules 0.8–2.9(–3.7) mm; distal bract slightly shorter than to much exceeding terminal spike. Spikes (2–)3–6, widely separate or distal 2–4 overlapping or rarely all congested; lateral spikes pistillate, with (6–)18–37(–86) perigynia, 5–29 × 3.1–10.2 mm, ratio of spike length (in mm) to flower number = 0.51–0.95; terminal spikes (5–)8–26(–30) × 1–3.3(–4.2) mm. Pistillate scales 2.4–4.7 × 1.4–2.1 mm, margins red-brown to whitish, entire, apex with awn 0.2–2.7 mm or rarely awnless. Staminate scales (2.3–)2.9–4.5 × 1–1.6 mm. Anthers 1.8–3.6 mm. Perigynia spirally imbricate, 17–25-veined, unwrinkled, oblong-ovoid to oblong-obovoid, orbicular or suborbicular in cross section, (2.5–)2.8–3.6(–4.3) × (1.2–)1.3–1.7(–1.8) mm, (1.7–)1.9–2.5(–2.8) times as long as wide, lustrous, base very gradually tapered, apex gradually tapered; beak absent or straight, 0–0.2 mm. Achenes obovoid, 1.8–2.6 × (1–)1.2–1.4 mm, loosely enveloped by perigynia; stipe straight 0.1–0.3(–0.4) mm; beak straight, 0.2–0.4(–0.5) mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-conoidea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-griseae-lhbailey-k%C3%BCckenthal","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4a6f8edc-a057-4f3e-8013-bf5f1d5d6459#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225662","habitat","<p>Moist meadows and prairies, shores of lakes, ponds, and rivers, usually in acidic sands or loams; 10–1400 m</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-conoidea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-griseae-lhbailey-k%C3%BCckenthal","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4a6f8edc-a057-4f3e-8013-bf5f1d5d6459#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225695","distribution","<p><em>Carex cordillerana</em> is found primarily west of the continental divide where it occurs in a wide area from central British Columbia, through eastern Washington and eastern Oregon south to central Utah. Apart from the few populations of <em>C. backii</em> that are found in British Columbia, this is the only member of the <em>C. backii </em>complex found in western North America. </p><br/><p></p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cordillerana-saarela-ba-ford-1","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","5d5db384-9908-41ee-ba49-ed0d3a1a091f","","0ebb166e-3bec-4190-93d6-080a3e22f3f2#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225695","evolution","<p><em>Carex cordillerana</em> is a member of sect. <em>Phyllostachyae</em>, a monophyletic group found within the Core Unispciate Clade of the tribe Cariceae. Previous phylogenetic studies have shown that section <em>Phyllostachyae</em> is composed of two monophyletic groups, termed the narrow- and wide-scaled clades. The narrow-scaled clade (<em>C. basiantha, C. jamesii, C. juniperorum, C. superata, C. timida, C. willdenowii</em>) is characterized by scales that do not conceal the perigynia, filiform stigmas, and relatively large numbers of staminate flowers. In contrast, the wide-scaled clade (<em>C. cordillerana, </em><span><em>C</em></span><em>. </em><span><em>backii</em></span>, and <span><em>C</em></span><em>. </em><span><em>saximontana</em>)</span> is distinguished by pistillate scales that conceal the perigynia, thick, clavate stigmas, and relatively small numbers of staminate flowers. <em>Carex latebracteata</em>, a narrowly distributed species from the Ouachiata Mountains of Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma, is sister to all species within the section.</p><br/><p></p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cordillerana-saarela-ba-ford-1","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Evolution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","5d5db384-9908-41ee-ba49-ed0d3a1a091f","","0ebb166e-3bec-4190-93d6-080a3e22f3f2#evolution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225695","habitat","<p><em>M</em>esic, mixed forests with naturally disturbed, rocky slopes that have a well-developed organic layer and a large accumulation of leaf litter. Populations are widely scattered and often comprised of only a few individuals. </p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cordillerana-saarela-ba-ford-1","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","5d5db384-9908-41ee-ba49-ed0d3a1a091f","","0ebb166e-3bec-4190-93d6-080a3e22f3f2#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225695","look_alikes","<p><em>Carex cordillerana</em> is most similar to <em>C. backii</em> and <em>C. saximontana</em> but is best distinguished from these taxa by its densely papilose leaf margins and short-beaked perigynia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cordillerana-saarela-ba-ford-1","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","5d5db384-9908-41ee-ba49-ed0d3a1a091f","","0ebb166e-3bec-4190-93d6-080a3e22f3f2#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225695","morphology","Plant: Densely caespitose perennial herbs with rhizomes < 3.0 mm long.   Culms: Phyllopodic with stramineous to medium brown basal sheaths. Fertile culms 68–400 mm high, overtopped by the leaves, 0.6–1.5 mm wide at mid-height, triquetrous, dilated in distal portion, 1.0–1.9 mm wide at junction with terminal inflorescence unit; margins hyaline, papillate (occasionally scaberulous), becoming densely scaberulous towards apex. Inflorescence: Inflorescence consisting of androgynous spikes, a single terminal, and 0–3 basal. Basal spikes, like terminal but generally smaller on erect peduncles 17–60 mm long arising from the base of the culm. Leaves: 2–4 per culm, 14–428 mm long, 1.5–5.9 mm wide, dull green to yellow-green, plicate to flat, margins green, densely papillate becoming antrorsely scaberulous in distal portion, abaxial surface smooth, the mid-rib densely papillose, adaxial surface smooth except papillate towards margins; outer leaves shorter than inner leaves, ligulate, ligules longer than wide, obtuse at apex, sheaths enveloping culm, hyaline ventrally; inner leaves longer than outer leaves, eligulate, sheathless, the lamina free to the base of the culm. Pistillate scales: Lowermost pistillate scale of terminal spike leaf-like, concealing the perigynia,14–55 (–72) mm long, 2–5.3 mm wide, long acute, yellow-green to dull olive green, many nerved, margins green or narrowly hyaline, papillate to antrorsely scaberulous. Uppermost pistillate scale like lowermost scale but much reduced, 1.9–8.8 (–12.2) mm long, 1.0–2.1 mm wide. Other pistillate scales intermediate in size and morphology between lowermost and uppermost scale. Spikes: Terminal spikes 7.1–13.7 mm long, 3.2–5.0 mm wide, with 3–5 perigynia arising from a zigzag, triangular, winged rachis; staminate portion 1.7–2.6 mm long, 0.4–0.9 mm wide, 2–3 flowered, inconspicuous and hidden by the perigynia. Staminate scales: Lowermost staminate scale of terminal spike 1.5–2.6 mm long encircling and concealing the staminate portion of the inflorescence unit, connate 0–95% of total length, apex obtuse, center green to white with a single nerve, margins whitish often with a ferruginous tinge.   Flowers: Filaments flat, as wide or wider than the anthers.  Anthers: 0.9–1.4 mm long Perigynia: Perigynia of terminal inflorescence unit ascending 3.9–5.4 mm long, 1.6–2.5 mm wide, smooth, nerveless, yellow-green to dull-olive green, terete, tightly investing achene, body ovoid-orbicular, abruptly or gradually tapering into a beak; beak (as measured from the summit of the achene to the summit of the perigynium), 0.5–1.6 mm long, smooth, apex ± truncate. Achenes: 2.8–3.5 mm long, 1.5–2.4 mm wide, obpyriform, subterete in cross-section, yellowish green to brownish black; style dark brown, minutely papillose, filiform, fused beyond beak apex, proximal end articulate with summit of achene and withering with age. Stigmas: 3, dark brown, minutely papillose, clavate, erect.   Elevation: 500-2400 m. Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cordillerana-saarela-ba-ford-1","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","5d5db384-9908-41ee-ba49-ed0d3a1a091f","","0ebb166e-3bec-4190-93d6-080a3e22f3f2#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225729","distribution","<p>Alta., B.C., Man., N.B., Nfld. and Labr., N.W.T., N.S., Ont., P.E.I., Que., Sask., Yukon; Alaska, Conn., Idaho, Maine, Mass., Mich., Minn., Mo., Mont., N.H., N.J., N.Y., Oreg., Pa., Vt., Wash., W</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-crawfordii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","bfaf3a9a-885b-4806-a244-4e21620ebb4c#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225729","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms 25–60(–85) cm; vegetative culms with few leaves clustered at apex. Leaves: sheaths adaxially white-hyaline, summits U-shaped; distal ligules 1.5–6 mm; blades (2–)3–4(–5) per fertile culm, 7–22 cm × 2–4 mm. Inflorescences erect, usually dense, green, gold, or dark brown, 1.8–3 cm8–14 mm; proximal internode 2–3(–5) mm; 2d internode 1–3 mm; proximal bracts bristlelike, shorter than or equaling inflorescences. Spikes 6–14, distant, distinct, ovoid to broadly ovoid, 8–10 × 4.5–6.5 mm, base and apex acute to truncate. Pistillate scales gold to dark brown, with whitish, green, or brown midstripe, lanceolate, 3–3.8 mm, shorter and narrower than perigynia, apex acuminate to short-awned. Perigynia ascending, white to gold or light brown, 0–5-veined abaxially, 0–4-veined adaxially, narrowly lanceolate to narrowly ovate, flat except over achene or, occasionally, plano-convex, 3.4–4.1(–4.7) × 0.9–1.3 mm, 0.15–0.35 mm thick, margin flat, including wing 0.1–0.2 mm wide, usually crinkled distally; beak brown or red-brown at tip, flat, ± ciliate-serrulate, abaxial suture inconspicuous, distance from beak tip to achene (1.8–)2.1–3 mm. Achenes ± elliptic, 1.1–1.5 × 0.6–0.8 mm, 0.15–0.35 mm thick; style usually persistent, sinuate. 2n = 52, ca. 66, 70.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-crawfordii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","bfaf3a9a-885b-4806-a244-4e21620ebb4c#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225729","habitat","<p>Often in standing water, moist to wet places, open, sandy, dryish disturbed areas; 100–1500 m;</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-crawfordii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","bfaf3a9a-885b-4806-a244-4e21620ebb4c#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225734","general","<p>Similar to C. distans but laxly caespitose; <i>Stems</i> 10-3 5 cm; <i>Leaves</i> 1.5-3 mm broad, much shorter than <i>Stems</i> ; male spike 1-1.5 cm, usually with small female spike near its base; female spikes 3-4, 0.5-1.8 cm, all distant, sessile or shortly pedunculate, occasionally lowest arising almost from base of stem, with long, (0.5-)3-8 cm, comparatively coarse smooth peduncle, the others almost sessile or snortly pedunculate; lowest bract long, much exceeding its spike; female glumes thin, scarious with greenish, 3-ribbed mid-line, acute; <i>Utricles </i> pale greenish-brown, 2.2-3 mm, not shining, veinless, suberect, rather gradually tapering into slightly scabrid beak to 0.75 mm; nut filling utricle.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cretica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","491f5efe-6bef-454b-8455-727a4e97e172#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225754","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.     Leaves:  2-1 mm wide, dark green, stiff, scabrous. Basal sheaths: bladeless, long, sometimes ladder-like fibrillose. Bracts: setaceous with short sheaths.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: apex acute, brown. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, filiform 1-2 cm long: lateral spikes pistillate with short staminate apical section.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 2.5-3 mm long, 1-1.5 mm wide, many veined, scabrous along margins, mouth notched. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoidal, 1.5-2 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225781","distribution","<p>Japan:<br /><br/>Hokkaido, Honshu and Kyushu.<br /><br/>Endemic to Japan.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cucullata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","8cad9818-36a9-4701-a8db-c39bee536c8f#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225781","habitat","<p>Sandy<br /><br/>places in marshes or grasslands.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cucullata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","8cad9818-36a9-4701-a8db-c39bee536c8f#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225781","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 30-70 cm tall, elongating after flowering, upper scabrous.  Leaves: 3-8 mm wide, deep green, scabrous. Basal sheaths: reddish brown, ladder-like fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, upper bracts sheathless, lower bracts short sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale dark brown, apex aristate. Spikes: upper 1-4 spikes staminate, linear, 1-3 cm long; lower 2-5 spikes pistillate, remote, subsessile or shortly pedunculate, cylindrical, 1.5-6 cm long, densely flowered. Staminate scales: reddish brown, apex obtuse or acute.      Perigynia: as long as or longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 4-5 mm long, veined, densely pilose, suddenly narrowed above to beak, beak long, mouth deeply bidentate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2 mm long. Stigmas: 3, usually persistent.    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Takuji Hoshino <br /><br/>Additional authors: Tomomi Masaki <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: March, 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: Illustrated Sedges of Japan.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cucullata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","8cad9818-36a9-4701-a8db-c39bee536c8f#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225789","distribution","<p>Casi toda Europa, W y N de Asia, N de África. Crece en la mayor parte de la Península Ibérica y Baleares. <br />Esp.: A Ab Al Av B Ba Bi Bu C Ca Cc Co CR Cs Cu Ge Gr Gu H Hu J L Le Lo Lu M Ma Na O Or P PM[Mll Mn] S Sa Se Sg So SS T Te To V Va Vi Z Za. <br />Port.: AAl Ag BAl BB BL E R TM.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cuprina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","90c78871-b176-41f5-8c69-35a4a62e08dc#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225789","general","<p>Densamente cespitosa, con el rizoma bastante robusto. Vainas basales ± fibrosas, escuamiformes, de color pardo claro. Tallos 30-100(120) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos estrechamente alados y las caras planas o cóncavas en la zona superior, muy escábridos hacia el ápice. Hojas (2,5)3,5-7(8) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, ásperas en la parte superior, medianamente rígidas, generalmente de color anaranjado cuando se secan; lígula (2,5)4-9 mm, de longitud mayor que la anchura, rara vez de longitud y anchura similares, aguda o subaguda; sin antelígula. Bráctea inferior de longitud mayor o menor que la inflorescencia, setácea, no envainante. Espigas dispuestas en inflorescencia simple de 2,5-4,5(5,5) cm, en ocasiones ramificada en la base, oblonga o piramidal; las espigas se disponen agrupadas o la inferior algo separada del resto. Glumas ovales, acuminadas o cortamente mucronadas, de color pardo, las femeninas menores que los utrículos. Utrículos (4)4,5-5,5 × 1,2-2,3 mm, ± piriformes, plano-convexos, con nervios muy prominentes, verdosos o parduscos, patentes, gradualmente atenuados en un pico de 1,2-2 mm, escábrido, bífido, no hendido en el dorso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225853","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 20-50 cm tall, smooth.  Leaves: longer than culms, 4-10 mm wide, light green, scabrous. Basal sheaths: yellowish brown, soft, slightly fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, sheathless. Pistillate scales: pale brown, midrib broad, green, apex acuminate or shortly aristate. Spikes: racemase; terminal spike staminate, pedunculate, linear, 2-3 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, crowded, sessile, shortly cylindrical, 1.5-2 cm long, densely flowered.  Staminate scales: pale brown, midrib broadly light green, apex acuminate.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, reflexed at maturity, ovoid, 8-10 mm long, many veined, glabrous, inflated at maturity, base shortly stipilate, long beaked, mouth bidentate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, rhombic, 2-3 mm long, base shortly stipitate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225868","general","<p>Dioecious, densely caespitose without creeping rhizomes. Female plants 15-40 cm, male plants usually not more than 20 cm. Basal scales and lower sheaths pale brown to yellowish-brown, becoming fibrous while decaying. Leaves setaceous, canaliculate, c. 1 mm wide, up to 1/2 as long as stems. Inflorescence a cylindrical terminal spike 1-1.5 cm, male or female. Glumes reddish-brown, often with narrow hyaline margins, acute. Stigmas 2. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225868","general","<p>Dioica. Densamente cespitosa. Tallos (5)15-30(50) cm, trígonos con los ángulos agudos u obtusos, lisos o ligeramente escábridos en la parte superior. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225886","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms dark maroon at base; flowering stems 25–100 cm, as long as leaves at maturity or often longer, 0.5–1 mm thick, glabrous but scabrous within inflorescence. Leaves: basal sheaths maroon, bladeless, glabrous or rarely minutely pubescent; others grading from maroon to green on back, pale brown-hyaline or reddish brown on front, often red dotted, sometimes finely pubescent; blades flat, 2–7 mm wide, glabrous on both surfaces, margins and abaxial midribs often finely scabrous. Inflorescences: peduncles of lateral spikes slender, to 50 mm, usually shorter than spikes or only slightly longer, scabrous; of terminal spike 15–50 mm, finely scabrous; proximal bracts longer, or more often, shorter than inflorescences; sheaths 1–7 cm; blades 1–3.5 mm wide. Lateral spikes 2–5, 1 per node, well separated, erect at anthesis, soon nodding, pistillate with 10–25 perigynia attached 2–9 mm apart, linear, 25–80 × 2–3 mm. Terminal spike staminate or sometimes gynecandrous with a few pistillate flowers distally; 15–50 × 0.6–1.2 mm. Pistillate scales white-hyaline, sometimes tinged with pale brown or suffused with chestnut, with broad green midrib, finely red dotted, oblong, 2.8–6 mm, much shorter than mature perigynia, apex obtuse, acute or cuspidate, awn to 0.2 mm, glabrous, distal margin ciliate. Perigynia green to olive-green, usually red dotted, prominently 2-ribbed, finely 12–20-veined, loosely enveloping achene, fusiform to lance-ovoid, 5–9.5 × 1.1–2.2 mm, membranous, base acute, apex tapering gradually to abruptly contracted beak, glabrous or short-pubescent; beak bidentate 0.7–2 mm, including teeth to 1 mm. Achenes stipitate, 1.9–2.5 × 1–1.5 mm, stipe 0.5–1.5 mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-debilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-section-hymenochlaenae-drejer-l-h-bailey","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5eb7b196-196b-4c73-ae50-db53759b6e52#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225929","general","<p>Cespitosa. Tallos fértiles 3,5-35(45) cm, lisos, obtusamente trígonos, frecuentemente arqueados. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225968","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely tufted.    Inflorescence: racemose, 5-10 spikes, 2-3 cm long.  Leaves: shorter than culms, 1.5-2.5 mm wide, scabrous. Basal sheaths: brown, fibrillose.  Pistillate scales: brown, apex acute.  Spikes: androgynous, 0.3-0.8 cm long. Staminate scales: brown, apex acute. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225980","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.   Culms: 20-40 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.   Leaves: 3.5-4.5 mm wide, slightly soft. Basal sheaths: dark brown, strongly fibrillose. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like, with sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale green, apex acute.  Spikes: terminal spike staminatc, linear, 2-3 cm long, pedunculate; lateral spikes pistillate, linear cylindrical, 1.5-2.5 cm long, 2.5-3.5 mm wide, pedunculate, loosely flowered.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ellipsoidal, 4.2-5 mm long, 1.3-1.5 mm wide, puberulcnt, long beaked, margins serrulate, mouth notched. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoidal, 2.2-2.5 mm long, style base minutely annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225990","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms erect or ascending, 7–52 cm × 0.5–1 mm. Leaves: basal sheaths white or light brown; nonbasal sheaths green, 8–37 mm; blades green, 8–44 cm × 0.8–5 mm, shorter than or overtopping culm, 0.5–1.3(–1.8) times as tall as tallest flowering culm; blades of vegetative shoots 1–3.5 times wider than bract blades. Inflorescences: spikes (2–)4 per culm, scattered; peduncles of pistillate spikes 0.5–10.2 cm; of staminate spike 0.4–8.7 cm. Bracts 2.2–11.4 cm × 1–3 mm. Pistillate scales keeled, 1.8–2 × 1–1.2 mm, midribs green, margins hyaline, apex acute, proximal scales of lateral spikes subtending perigyinia. Staminate scales oblong, 2–3.6(–5.5) × 1–1.5 mm, midribs green, margins hyaline, frequently brown tinged, apex acute. Anthers 2–3.3 mm. Perigynia 3–9 per spike, finely veined, obovoid, 2–4.2 × 1.2–1.8 mm; beak tapering. Achenes obovoid, 1.8–2.8 × 1–1.6 mm, sides plane or slightly concave at maturity, tightly fitting perigynia. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:225999","general","<p>Cespitosa, a veces con rizomas de entrenudos algo alargados, ascendentes. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226034","diagnostic","<p>Variable in size of female spike, utricle and whole plant. The narrow leaf with three veins is a useful vegetative character. Occasionally found with a few female flowers at the base of the male spike, when it may be mistaken for C. pulicaris. Hybrids with C. echinata (C. × gaudiniana Guthnick) have been confirmed from Wales and Ireland. Hybrids with C. canescens, C. lachenalii and C. maritima are reported from Europe. C. parallela (Laest.) Sommert., a North Scandinavian plant with narrower, smooth-beaked utricles, has been confused with forms of C. dioica; it could possibly occur here. Another dioecious species, the Central European C. davalliana Sm., with long-beaked, oblong-lanceoloid utricles, occurred in Somerset but the site has completely changed and it is now considered extinct; other British records for this species have proved to be forms of C. dioica.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-dioica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5ddd776d-0758-46da-957d-60ab2d2ee296#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226034","distribution","<p>Carex dioica is common in base-rich flushes in the Lake District N Pennines and N Wales; likewise in Scotland, especially on mica-schists and limestones of the N and W, rising to c. 1000 m in Breadalbanes (v.c. 88). Scattered in lowland Britain and Ireland. Rapidly diminishing in lowland areas owing to drainage.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-dioica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5ddd776d-0758-46da-957d-60ab2d2ee296#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226034","ecology","<p>Carex dioica is a species of mesotrophic to eutrophic (calcareous) mires in wet, silty muds, rarely in pure peat, in pH range 5.5-6.5, at altitudes of0 to c. 1000 m. Characteristic, with Pinguicula vulgaris and several other sedges, in M10 communities; also in MU, M12, M13, M15, M34, M37 and M38 and in Narthecium-Sphagnum valley mires (M21) with Rhynchospora alba.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-dioica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5ddd776d-0758-46da-957d-60ab2d2ee296#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226034","general","<p>Plants dioecious. Rhizomes shortly creeping; shoots loosely tufted, often decumbent; roots often as thick as rhizome, pale purple-brown; scales pale purple- or orange-brown, soon decaying. <i>Stems </i> 5-30 cm, erect, terete, striate. <i>Leaves </i> 5-20 cm × 0.3-1 mm, rigid, ± erect, channelled or semicircular in transverse section, with 3 main veins and rounded apex, dark green, dying to a dull red-brown; hypostomous; sheaths becoming pale orange-brown persistent, with inner face hyaline; apex straight but soon split; ligule 0.5 mm, rounded, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single terminal, usually unisexual spike; bracts glumaceous or 0. Male spike 8-20 mm; male glumes 3-4 mm, ovate-oblong, red-brown with hyaline margin; apex obtuse or acute. Female spike 5-20 mm, subglobose to cylindric; female glumes 2.5-3.5 mm, red- to purple-brown, with pale midrib, dark nerve and ± hyaline margin, persistent; apex obtuse or acute; glume of lowest floret often enlarged, with acuminate apex. <i>Utricles</i>  2.5-3.5 mm, patent, rarely deflexed when ripe, broadly ovoid, compressed, pale red-purple-brown with darker ribs; beak 0.5-0.75 mm, serrulate, notched; stigmas 2; nut subglobose, compressed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-dioica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5ddd776d-0758-46da-957d-60ab2d2ee296#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226075","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.     Leaves: 3-7 mm wide, soft. Basal sheaths: reddish brown or dark brown, fibrillose. Bracts: upper setaceous, lower leaf-like with long sheaths, 5-15 cm long, blades shorter than inflorescences.  Pistillate scales: pale brown, apex acute. Spikes: androgynous, 2-4 cm long, terminal spikes linear terete; lateral spikes with long peduncles, staminate parts short with few perigynia.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, lanceolate, 10-12 mm long, 1.3-1.6 mm wide, finely many veined, smooth, shortly stipitate, long beaked, mouth obliquely truncate.  Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoidal, 2.7-3.5 mm long, 1-1.2 mm wide. Stigmas: 3","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-dissitiflora-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","dbe92d7d-421d-41ef-83a9-2f83a7bc425f#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226080","general","<p>Cespitosa. Tallos (2,5)15-40(46) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos agudos u obtusos, lisos o escábridos hacia el ápice. Hojas (0,2)0,5-2(2,8) mm de anchura, a veces de mayor longitud que los tallos, planas o canaliculadas, ± blandas, antrorso-escábridas en los márgenes; lígula 0,1-0,3 mm, de mayor anchura que el limbo, truncada, en ocasiones con cilios diminutos en el borde superior; sin antelígula; vainas basales enteras o algo fibrosas, las más inferiores escuamiformes, de color pardo obscuro. Bráctea inferior de longitud mucho mayor que la inflorescencia, foliácea, estrechamente linear, con una vaina de 2-5 mm. Espigas (1)2-3(4), de (6)13-25(35) mm, pedunculadas o la inferior subsésil, ± separadas, erectas, con la parte masculina estrechamente fusiforme, densiflora, y la femenina laxiflora con (1)2-6(10) flores, oblonga. Glumas masculinas obovadas o estrechamente lanceoladas, agudas o subagudas, con nervio central verde y los lados de color pardo, con ancho margen escarioso en la mitad o el tercio superior; glumas femeninas agudas, mayores o menores que los utrículos, anchamente lanceoladas, pardas o hialinas con el nervio central verde y margen escarioso (a veces sin margen) de mayor anchura en la mitad superior. Utrículos (4)4,5-6(7) × 1,5-1,8(2,3) mm, suberectos, de contorno elíptico, trígonos, generalmente con solo los 2 nervios laterales resaltados, en ocasiones plurinerviados, de color verde pálido, variablemente teñidos de pardo, atenuados en un pico de (0,2)0,5-1 mm, liso o con algunos acúleos, verde en la base, con una banda de color pardo en la zona media y escarioso en el ápice que es truncado y suele estar hendido en una de sus caras. Aquenios 2,3-4 × 1,2-2(2,2) mm, de contorno elíptico, trígonos, estipitados, con la base del estilo persistente en forma de una corta columna. 2n = 74.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-distachya-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","0ca3ec0e-535e-42d6-a85e-3b5ae6ba0328#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226132","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer and winter, from near the coast to the interior, in Free State and Northern Cape. It is fairly common and widespread in Europe and Asia, and in North Africa (Morocco, Algeria, Egypt and Libya); also recorded from New Zealand and Australia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divisa-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","71493e0a-6de5-45fb-8c33-da1e1e594970#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226132","general","<p>Plants 100–415 mm tall. Rhizomes long, 1.5–5.0 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow-green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths tubular, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade (140)–150 × 2.0–2.5 mm, channelled in cross-section; adaxial surface papillate; abaxial surface glabrous; margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth truncate, membranous; ligule 1.5 mm high, fuscous, membranous, apex obtuse. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1 mm in diameter; uppermost internode very long, the lower all more-or-less basal, very short, concealed by leaf sheaths. Inflorescence glomerate-spicate to glomerate-paniculate, 12–17 × 7–8 mm. Basal inflorescence bract bristle-like, not sheathing; blade 10–17 mm long; opposing bracteole exposed, not sheathing. Primary inflorescence units 5–7; all androgynous; the largest 5 × 2 mm. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.8–3.2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate, 4.5–5.0 × 2.5 mm, longer and wider than perigynium, golden-brown, with wide hyaline margins, glabrous; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex acute, awned to muticous; awn 0–0.3 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, not stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 4.2 × 1.8 mm, elliptic in cross-section, not inflated, golden brown, without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, glabrous, nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum tapered, 1.5 mm long, straight, margin not winged, scabrid; apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.8 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base straight; stigmas 2. Mature nutlet ovate, broadly clawed, 2 × 1.6 mm, narrowly elliptic in cross-section, yellowish-brown, glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divisa-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","71493e0a-6de5-45fb-8c33-da1e1e594970#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226132","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos muy largos, cubierto por escamas, enteras o algo fibrosas. Tallos (8)15-50(70) cm, trígonos con los ángulos agudos u obtusos, lisos o algo escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas (0,4)1-3(5,3) mm de anchura, de longitud menor que los tallos, planas o canaliculadas, ásperas en los bordes en una longitud variable, algo rígidas; lígula 0,5-1 mm, con los bordes levantados, de ápice obtuso o redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, de color pardo, enteras o poco fibrosas. Bráctea inferior de longitud de menor a mucho mayor que la inflorescencia, glumácea con ápice setáceo o foliácea. Espigas agrupadas en una espiga simple, generalmente lobulada, de (0,5)1-2(3,5) cm, a veces la inferior está un poco separada del resto, andróginas, y en ocasiones la(s) inferior(es) femenina(s). Glumas ovales, aristadas o mucronadas, muy raramente agudas, de color pardo obscuro, sin margen escarioso o con él estrecho en la zona superior, las femeninas mayores o algo menores que los utrículos. Utrículos (3,2)3,5-4(4,2) × (1,2)1,7-2(2,2) mm, de contorno anchamente oval, plano-convexos, esponjosos en la base, con los nervios muy prominentes, verdosos o parduscos, bruscamente estrechados en un pico de (0,5)0,7-1,1 mm, escábrido, bífido u oblicuamente truncado. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226143","distribution","<p>Carex divulsa is the most common species of the group, widely distributed (Fig. 5) from Madeira to Iran (55°E). It is frequently found in Mediterranean areas in Spain, France, Italy, Greece, Turkey and the islands (Balearic, Corsica, Sicily, and Crete), northern Africa (from Morocco to Algeria), and in the Canary and Madeira Islands. It is scarce in temperate zones, and very scarce towards the northeast of Europe, for example it is rare in Belgium (Lambinon, 2004). In Russia, it appears only in the south-west and Caucasus region, and it extends from Iran to south-east of the Caspian Sea. No specimens have been found in Iraq.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divulsa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-carex-divulsa-aggregate-eurasia-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","10d70122-f731-4e2f-b6a2-5a2f498e7e15#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226143","distribution","<p>Gran parte de Europa, N de África y zonas del W de Asia; introducida en el E de Norteamérica. En la Península Ibérica crece en casi todas las provincias, y en Baleares. <br />Esp.: A Ab Al Av B Bi Bu C Ca Cc Co CR Cs Cu Ge Gr Gu H Hu J L Le Lo Lu M Ma Mu Na O P PM[Mll Mn] Po S Sa Se Sg So SS T Te To V Va Vi Z Za. <br />Port.: Ag AAl BA BAl BB BL DL E TM.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divulsa-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","0eefd51c-7750-4245-8dbc-388827e456c0#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226143","general","<p>Caespitose perennial tufted plant with or without short rhizomes c. 6 mm in diameter. CULMS 15–70 cm × 0.8–1.25 mm at mid-height, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; sheaths pale to dark brown. LIGULE 1.25–4.0 mm long, wider than long, usually rounded at apex. LEAF blades about three quarters or as long as culms, dark green to grey green, widest leaf blades 2–3 mm, plicate to flat. INFLORESCENCE oblong, 50–135(150) × 6–9 mm, with 7–12 globular sessile and unbranched spikes, except the lowest that is usually branched and pedunculate. Lowest internode 12–45 mm long, the second one 6–28 mm. BRACTS glume-like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than inflorescence, 6–50(-63) mm long. FEMALE GLUME hyaline to golden-yellow, with a midrib green, 3.0–4.0 × 1.75–2.30 mm, ovate, apex acuminate 0.15–0.3 mm long. STAMINATE GLUME 2.75–3.5 × 1.4–2.0 mm, similar to the female. ANTHERS 3, 1–2.5 mm long. PERIGYNIUM patent to erect-patent, greenish, body elliptic to rounded, nerveless or faintly veined, 3.5–4.0(4.25) × 1.75–2.30 mm, acute at base, gradually tapered into a beak. BEAK 0.5–1.0 mm long, white distally, with scarcely serrulate margins, apex bidentate, apical teeth 0.3–0.5 mm. ACHENE elliptic to rounded, shining brown when ripe, 2.0–2.5 × 1.5– 2.25 mm. STIGMA 2, 2.0–3.0 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divulsa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-carex-divulsa-aggregate-eurasia-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","10d70122-f731-4e2f-b6a2-5a2f498e7e15#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226143","general","<p>Rizoma grueso, que forma céspedes hasta de 60(80) cm de diámetro. Tallos (15)25-60(90) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos agudos, escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas (1,5)2,5-3,5(4,3) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, rara vez mayor, planas, algo ásperas en los bordes, no muy rígidas; lígula (0,3)1,5-2(3) mm, generalmente de longitud algo menor que la anchura, de ápice obtuso o redondeado; generalmente sin antelígula; vainas basales poco o muy fibrosas, de color pardo. Bráctea inferior de longitud mucho menor que la inflorescencia, setácea, no envainante. Espigas dispuestas en espiga simple de 2,3-17 cm, rara vez con alguna rama en la base. Glumas ovales, acuminadas, hialino-verdosas o, raramente, de color pardo muy pálido, las femeninas menores que los utrículos. Utrículos 3,2-5,5 × 1,5-2,2 mm, de contorno estrechamente oval y base ± atenuada, plano-convexos, con nerviación apenas perceptible o con un número variable de nervios bien marcados, verdosos, gradualmente atenuados en un pico de 0,5-1,4 mm, escábrido-serrulado, bífido. Aquenios 1,9-2,5 × (1,2)1,7-2,3(2,5) mm, de contorno elíptico, oblongo u orbicular, biconvexos, rara vez plano-convexos, con la base del estilo persistente en forma de una corta columna.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divulsa-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","0eefd51c-7750-4245-8dbc-388827e456c0#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226143","habitat","<p>Carex divulsa seems to need some moisture in the soil. It grows in shady habitats, such as forest and disturbed places (Guinochet, 1978; Chater, 1980; Clapham et al., 1987), but also in sunny open habitats (David & Kelcey, 1985). In the latter case, specimens are harder. Carex divulsa occurs at low altitudes (0–700 m), although in the warmest, southern part of the distribution area it can be found at 1000–1200 m. Greuter et al. (1985) quoted 1800 m. According to David & Kelcey (1985) and our own observations, it tolerates a wide range of soil acidity (pH 5.3–7.4).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-divulsa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-carex-divulsa-aggregate-eurasia-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","10d70122-f731-4e2f-b6a2-5a2f498e7e15#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226267","general","<p>Plants 170–710 mm tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 1.5 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow-green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths tubular, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face tearing into membranous strips. Largest basal leaf blade 80–340 × 2.5–4.0 mm, channelled or plicate in cross-section; adaxial and abaxial surfaces glabrous; margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, membranous; ligule 1 mm high, fuscous, membranous, apex obtuse or occasionally emarginate. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1–2 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 0–1 nodes exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 20–50 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, sharply reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheath 0–25 mm long; blade 60–190 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 4–5, spreading, clustered; the largest 15–22 × 7–10 mm. Peduncles not exserted, glabrous. Apical spikes usually staminate. Staminate spikes 1. Pistillate spikes (0–)3–4. Bisexual spikes 0–3. Small accessory spikes occasionally present at base of basal pistillate spikes, usually absent. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.5 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate, 4.2–5.0 × 1.8–2.2 mm, shorter and narrower than perigynium, ferruginous, glabrous; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex obtuse or emarginate, shortly awned; awn 0.8–2.0 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 4.5–5.5 s 1.8–2.5 mm, triangular with rounded base in cross-section, much or slightly inflated, green, or stramineous with ferruginous spots, base without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, glabrous, nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum abrupt, 0.7–1.2 mm long, straight, margin not winged, glabrous; apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.3–0.5 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base twisted, slightly bent, or straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate, narrowly clawed, 2.5–3.2 l 1.5–2.0 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ecklonii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","3999bd09-fd29-4e62-9aab-99a050c96077#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226267","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, in perennially waterlogged marshland, on sandy substratum.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ecklonii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","3999bd09-fd29-4e62-9aab-99a050c96077#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226284","general","<p>Densamente cespitosa, de cepa robusta que forma grandes macollas, aunque puede desarrollar rizomas con entrenudos de varios centímetros. Tallos 30-170 cm, escábridos a lisos en la zona superior, agudamente trígonos. Hojas 3-6(10) mm de anchura, generalmente de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, ásperas en los bordes y el nervio medio por el envés, con frecuencia también hacia el ápice por el haz, de blandas a medianamente rígidas, un poco glaucas; lígula hasta 5 mm, de ápice subagudo a redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, de color pardo amarillento a pardo rojizo obscuro, raramente purpúreas, enteras. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de longitud de mucho menor a algo mayor que la inflorescencia, no o apenas envainante. Espigas masculinas 1-4, de (10)20-80 mm, ± cilíndricas; espigas andróginas 0-5(6) y/o espigas femeninas 0-3(4), de 13-80(115) mm, cilíndricas, densas, distribuidas a lo largo de la parte superior del tallo, generalmente cercanas las unas de las otras, erectas o colgantes. Glumas masculinas estrechamente oblongas, de ápice redondeado a subagudo, pardo-rojizas a negras, con la quilla verde, sin margen escarioso; glumas femeninas de longitud igual o algo menor que los utrículos, ovales, oblongo-lanceoladas u oval-lanceoladas, de ápice agudo, de pardas a negruzcas con quilla central verde. Utrículos 1,8-4,5 × 1-2,5 mm, suberectos o erecto-patentes, de contorno ± elíptico, comprimidos, ligeramente biconvexos o planoconvexos, lisos o papilosos, con los nervios perceptibles, bruscamente estrechados en un corto pico hasta de 0,2 mm, truncado o raramente emarginado, papiloso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226304","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose.     Leaves: 1.5-2.5 mm wide, soft, both surfaces papillate. Basal sheaths: dark brown, fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, sheathless. Pistillate scales: dark purplish brown, apex obtuse. Spikes: terminal spike 1-2 cm long, gynecandrous; lateral spikes pistillate, 1-2 cm long.       Perigynia: as long as or lower than pistillate scales, ovoid, 2.2 mm long, papillate, with purplish brown speckles, mouth truncate. <br /><br/> Achenes: ovoid, 1.4-1.6 mm long.  Stigmas: 2","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-eleusinoides-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","2e618310-6076-4645-93b2-f25fe66c8193#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226312","diagnostic","<p>This is a distinct species characterised by the long, divaricate, brownish spikes and the narrow, ellipsoid, ribbed utricle (with the ribs distinctively reddish at maturity); vegetatively the long ligule, pink-brown, persistent, non-fibrous sheaths and substantial tussocks separate it from 40-42 the C. muricata group. Hybrids with C. appropinquata, C. paniculata and C. remota are recorded from mainland Europe but not from the British Isles.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-elongata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","93b9706b-fdda-4952-8826-40224e4d760a#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226312","distribution","<p>In Britain Carex elongata is found in the SE, as far west as the Hants-Dorset border and in Warwickshire; scattered in Wales from Monmouth to Denbigh and then north from Cheshire to Cumberland and Stirlingshire. In Ireland It grows around Lough Neagh and from County Down south to Roscommon and Cavan. See also David (1978b).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-elongata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","93b9706b-fdda-4952-8826-40224e4d760a#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226312","ecology","<p>C. elongata is a very local plant of damp soil in water-meadows, beside ditches, pools and lakes, and often with C. paniculata in boggy woodland, especially that dominated by alder (W5) or Salix cinerea and Betula pubescens (W2). It can withstand waterlogging where tussock growth is above the water level (David 1978b). Although C. elongata flowers quite freely, in England at least, reports suggest that the seed seldom appears to be viable and spread by that means is rare (R.W. David in Stewart et al. 1994).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-elongata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","93b9706b-fdda-4952-8826-40224e4d760a#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226312","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots densely tufted, forming substantial tussocks in old populations; roots pale brown; scales grey-brown, usually persistent. <i>Stems </i> 30-80 cm, rough with upward-pointing teeth, trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> 25-90 cm × 2-5 mm, rough beneath, thin, ± flat or slightly keeled, tapering gradually to a very fine, flat tip, mid green, often red-brown and persistent on dying' hypostomous; sheaths forming short false stems, lower pale brown or pink: brown, shiny, persistent, with the inner face hyaline; apex concave; ligule 48 mm, acute, with little or no free margin. <i>Inflorescence </i> 3-7 cm, lax; lower bracts setaceous, upper glumaceous. <i>Spikes </i> 5-18, ± contiguous or lowest distant, 5-15 mm, ± erect, becoming divaricate on ripening, sessile, Upper female at top, male at base, lower entirely female. Male glumes 2.5-3 mm, ovate-oblong, pale red-brown, with green midrib and broadly hyaline margin; apex rounded or obtuse, ± mucronate. Female glumes c. 2 mm, ovate-elliptic, red-brown, with green midrib; apex acute or obtuse. <i>Utricles</i>  3-4 mm, lanceoloid-ellipsoid, piano-convex, often curved, distinctly ribbed, green, with the ribs becoming dark red-brown; beak 0.5-0.75 mm, often minutely serrulate, truncate or indistinctly notched; stigmas 2; nut compressed cylindric, stalked.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-elongata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","93b9706b-fdda-4952-8826-40224e4d760a#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226367","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos largos y ± gruesos, a veces laxamente cespitoso. Tallos (8)10-25(32) cm, obtusamente trígonos, lisos, rectos o un poco curvados. Hojas 2-3,8 mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes de casi toda su longitud, planas; lígula diminuta, truncada; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado, enteras o algo fibrosas, de color pardo. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (6)9-14(16) mm, oblonga o anchamente fusiforme; espigas femeninas 1-2(3), de 5-16 mm, ovoides, densifloras, aproximadas junto a la masculina, sésiles o cortamente pedunculadas, en ocasiones la inferior subbasilar con pedúnculo largo, erectas.
