"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226503","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with long creeping fine rhizomes.   Culms: 20-40 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.<br /><br/>  Leaves: as long as culms, 2-4 inm wide. Basal sheaths: pale yellowish brown. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like, sheathless. Pistillate scales: pale, apex acute or shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical, 2-4 cm long, pale brown; lateral spikes pistillate, pedunculate, shortly cylindrical, 1-2 cm long, densely flowered.        Perigynia: ovoid, 3.5-4 mm long, 0.9-1.2 mm wide, 5-7 veined, smooth, long beaked, mouth bidentate, shortly stipitate.  Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 1.8-2 mm long. Stigmas: 3, long, persistent.    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Takuji Hoshino <br /><br/>Additional authors: Tomomi Masaki <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: March, 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: Illustrated Sedges of Japan.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-fibrillosa-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","025ff1d1-d1af-4faa-bb42-c26016fba7a2#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226527","diagnostic","<p>The small, very hairy utricles of C. filiformis distinguish it from any other British sedge of comparable size; the leaf-like bracts of this species separate it from C. caryophyllea. Vegetatively it may be similar to C. flacca and other glaucous sedges of its habitat (e.g. C. nigra), but the shiny, red basal leaf-sheaths and scales and the brown, persistent inner face of the leaf sheath, usually showing some fibrillae, serve to distinguish it.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-filiformis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22656884-c968-411d-bb2f-40fe72d4b8e8#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226527","distribution","<p>The limited distribution of this species in Britain is not easy to explain; it is possibly more widespread than recorded, as it is difficult to detect when not in flower. A hybrid with C. flacca has been described from France. Carex filiformis is recorded for Surrey, Middlesex, where it became extinct in the 1960s (Kent 1976), Oxfordshire, E Gloucs and N Wilts; it was found in N Somerset in 2003. See also David (1983, 1993).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-filiformis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22656884-c968-411d-bb2f-40fe72d4b8e8#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226527","ecology","<p>Carex filiformis is a local plant of fairly rich pastures with a substantial availability of calcium (MG6 Lolium associations, though not listed by Rodwell 1992) and of damper meadows, roadsides and rough ground, especially on gravelly soils which are continuously irrigated and contain other sedges (e.g. C. panicea, C. flacca and C. nigra) with Molinia caerulea, Filipendula ulmaria and Potentilla erecta (David 1983).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-filiformis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22656884-c968-411d-bb2f-40fe72d4b8e8#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226527","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> long-creeping, often very slender, sometimes forming de patches; shoots 2-3 per tuft; roots pale; scales red-brown, shiny, with sharp points, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 20-50 cm, rough above, trigonous, slender. <i>Leaves </i> 15-40 cm × 1.5-2 mm, rough, flat, gradually tapering to a fine Point ± glaucous, grey-brown on decay, often overwintering; hypostomous; sheaths red or red-purple, becoming brown, often persistent and fibrillose on splitting, with inner face hyaline; apex concave; ligule 1-2 mm, acute to obtuse, tubular, entire. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/6 or less of stem length; upper bracts setaceous, lower leaf-like, ± equalling inflorescence, the lowest not or shortly sheathing. <i>Male spikes</i>  1-2, 12-25 mm; male glumes 4-5 mm, elliptic-ovate red-brown with paler midrib and hyaline margin; apex ± acute, often apiculate. <i>Female spikes</i>  1-2, contiguous, 5-14 mm, oblong-ovoid to subglobose; female glumes 2-3 mm, ovate to subrotund, purple- or red-brown with pale midrib; apex acute or lowermost in spike mucronate. <i>Utricles</i>  2-3 mm, subglobose or pyriform, trigonous, densely tomentose, green; beak 1-0.2 mm, notched; stigmas 3; nut obovoid or pyriform, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-filiformis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","22656884-c968-411d-bb2f-40fe72d4b8e8#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226548","distribution","<p>Westalpen (von den Cottischen Alpen ostwärts bis ins Puschlav im Kanton Graubünden). Verbreitung im Gebiet. Carex fimbriata kommt in Mitteleuropa nur in der Schweiz vor (Kantone Wallis und Graubünden). Sie erreicht hier ihre Ostgrenze.-Wallis (Val de Bagnes, Umgebung von Zermatt [Gornergrat, Riffel-alpe, Gagenhaupt, Schwarzsee, Lychenbretter, Gandegghütte, Matterhorn, Augstelberg]).-In Graubünden nur im Puschlav beim Passo di Canciano und Passo delle Ruzze zwischen Val Poschiavo und Val Malenco.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-fimbriata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","666ee631-a716-428f-a153-2db688905905#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226548","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze. Wurzelstock Ausläufer treibend. Stengel aufrecht, meist schlaff, 10-45 cm hoch, bis etwa 1 mm dick, scharf dreikantig, rauh. Grundständige Blattscheiden ohne Spreiten, purpurrot, ohne Faserschopf. Blätter flach, steif, all-mählich in eine lange, feine Spitze verschmälert, meist etwas kür-zer als der Stenge!, 2-3 mm breit, rauh, graugrün. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes laubblattartig, scheidig, das des untersten Ähr-chens etwa so lang wie der Blütenstand. Blütenstand 5-15 cm lang, aus einem endständigen männlichen Ährchen (selten zwei männliche Ährchen entwickelt) und 1-3 (meist 2) seitlichen weib-lichen Ährchen bestehend. Weibliche Ährchen stets aufrecht, voneinander entfernt, meist nur kurz gestielt (das unterste später bis über 3 cm lang gestielt), zylindrisch, 10-20 mm lang, etwa 4 mm breit, lockerblütig. Männliches Ährchen linealisch, aufrecht, etwa 20 mm lang, etwa 3 mm breit. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten eiförmig, ziemlich kurz und scharf zugespitzt, wenig kürzer als die Schläuche, rotbraun, mit grünem Mittelstreifen und weiß-häutigen Rändern. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten lanzettlich, an den Rändern oft fransig zerschlitzt, scharf zugespitzt. Schläuche aufrecht, verkehrt eiförmig bis ellipsoidisch, allmählich in den Schnabel verschmälert, zusammengedrückt-dreikantig, 3-4 mm lang, an den Kanten gewimpert, oberwärts angedrückt behaart, längsnervig, hellgrün, braun getönt. Narben 3. Frucht ellipsoidisch, dreikantig, sehr klein.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-fimbriata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","666ee631-a716-428f-a153-2db688905905#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226551","general","<p>Ausdauernde, dichte und feste Polster bildende Pflanze; Polster halbkugelig, bis 30 cm breit. Wurzelstock kurz, dick, verzweigt. Stengel aufrecht, an der Spitze mehr oder weniger übergebogen, viellänger als die Blätter, 5-20(-30) cm hoch, unter 1 mm dick, glatt bis undeutlich rauh, stumpf dreikantig, nur am Grunde beblättert. Grundständige Blattscheiden gelbbraun, alle mit Spreiten, viele Jahre erhalten bleibend, nicht zerfasernd. Blätter rosettig ausgebreitet, steif, vom Grunde an allmählich in eine starre Spitze verschmälert, kurz, bis 5 cm lang, 2-3(-4) mm breit; flach, gelbgrün. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes spelzenartig, nur das unterste laubblattartig, das zugehörige Ährchen selten überragend. Blütenstand 2-5 cm lang, aus einem endständigen männlichen Ährchen und 1-3 seitlichen weiblichen Ährchen bestehend. Weibliche Ährchen aufrecht oder übergebogen, sitzend oder seltener langgestielt (""f. longipedunculata""), voneinander entfernt, eiförmig, 5-10 mm lang, etwa 3-4 mm breit, ziemlich dichtblütig, 3-8-blütig. Männliches Ährchen gestielt, kurz eiförmig, nicht über 10 mm lang, oft nickend. Spelzen eiförmig, spitz bis stumpf, etwas kürzer als die reifen Schläuche, braun, mit hellgrünem Mittelstreifen und weißhäutigen Rändern. Sch1äuche aufrecht abstehend, länglich lanzettlich, dreikantig, mit rauhen Kanten, 3,5-4,5 mm lang, bis 1,5 mm breit (wenig unter der Mitte am breitesten), allmählich in den am Rande borstig gewimperten Schnabel verschmälert, undeutlich längsnervig, braun, matt. Narben 3.· Frucht eiförmig, braun.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-firma-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","fbdfc224-506e-49c6-8bc5-c829cfde5e8e#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226551","habitat","<p>Meist häufig und gesellig, in alpinen Steinrasen, auf Graten und Felsen, in Felsspalten; auf mäßig trockenen, kalkreichen, flachgründigen, milden bis mäßig sauren, moderighumosen Steinböden, auch auf Felsbändern tieferer Lagen oder-als Alpenschwemmling im Flußkies. Wind- und kälteharte, extreme Temperaturschwankungen ertragende Pionierpflanze. Charakterart des Caricetum firmae (""Firmetum""; Sesterion variae). In der alpinen und subalpinen Stufe zwischen etwa 1600 und 2900 m, häufig aber auch tiefer. Höchste Fundorte: Bayerische Alpen 2580 m, Graubünden (P. Nair am Ofenpaß) 2970 m.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-firma-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","fbdfc224-506e-49c6-8bc5-c829cfde5e8e#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226558","general","<p>Culms to 80 cm × 3–8 mm, scabrous. Leaves: sheath fronts not spotted, slightly thickened near hyaline margins, apex convex, membranous, rugose; ligule retuse or rounded, to 3 mm, free limb to 0.2 mm; blades 60 cm × 5 mm, shorter than flowering stem. Inflorescences spicate, 3–7 cm × 15–25 mm, with 10–15 branches, proximal branches not distinctly separate; the proximal internode to 10 mm; bracts setaceous, usually only the proximal conspicuous. Scales hyaline, pale brown, becoming colorless with green midrib, awn usually not longer than the body. Perigynia pale brown, body broadly ovate, 3.2–4 × 2–2.6 mm, base rounded or cordate, apex abruptly contracted to beak; beak 1.3–1.5 mm, 1/3 length of perigynium. Achenes brown, ovate, 1.5–1.9 × 1.2–1.6 mm, dull.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-fissa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-section-multiflorae-j-carey-kukenthal","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b2876146-4028-4c52-b8be-99f75b174baa#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226564","morphology","Plant: perennial, cacspitose.     Leaves: 5-10 mm wide, grayish green, dorsal surfaces papillate. Basal sheaths:reddish brown, front of sheaths ladder-like fibrillose. Bracts: sheathless, upper setaceous, lower leaf-like. Pistillate scales: apex emarginated and shortly awned. Spikes: terminal spikes staminate, linear, 3-5.5 cm long; lateral spikes almostly pistillate, pedunculate, drooping at matured, terete, 3-8 cm long.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, broadly ovoid, 2.8-3 mm long, 1.8-2 mm wide, finely 3-4<br /><br/>veined on both sides, beak short, 0.2-0.3 mm wide, mouth notched or weekly bidentate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226565","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos largos, no muy grueso. Tallos fértiles (10)20-60(95) cm, lisos o escábridos, trígonos. Hojas (1,8)3-5(7) mm de anchura, generalmente de menor longitud que los tallos, en ocasiones casi igual, planas, ásperas en los bordes, bastante rígidas, glaucas en ambas caras o sólo por el envés; lígula 2-3 mm, de ápice obtuso, redondeado o emarginado, de bordes convolutos; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado, pardas, purpúreas o rojizas, ± enteras. Bráctea inferior foliácea, igual, poco mayor o menor que la inflorescencia, envainante o no. Espigas masculinas (1)2-3(5), de (8)15-50(70) mm, ± fusiformes; espigas femeninas 2-4, de (7)15-50(100) mm, ovoides o cilíndricas, densifloras, muy rara vez laxifloras, ± separadas, a veces la(s) superior(es) andrógina(s), en ocasiones ramificadas en la base, de casi sésiles y erectas a largamente pedunculadas y colgantes. Glumas masculinas obovadas, agudas o mucronadas, de color pardo rojizo obscuro, con nervio medio verde y margen escarioso de anchura variable; glumas femeninas ovales, de ápice agudo o largamente aristado o mucronado, de longitud menor o mayor que los utrículos, de color pardo-rojizo o pardo purpúreo muy obscuro con margen escarioso o sin él. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226588","general","<p>Cespitosa. Tallos fértiles 10-20 cm, obtusamente trígonos, lisos o ligeramente escábridos bajo la inflorescencia. Hojas 3-4 mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, de color verde pálido, ± lisas, poco rígidas; lígula hasta 3 mm, de ápice truncado, de menor anchura que el limbo; antelígula hasta 2 mm, de ápice truncado o redondeado, a veces inexistente; vainas basales enteras, de color pardo claro. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de c. 5 cm × 2,5-3 mm, de longitud mayor que la inflorescencia. Espiga masculina solitaria, de 1-1,8 cm × 2 mm, ± fusiforme, sésil o con un pedúnculo hasta de 5 mm; espigas femeninas 2-3, de 7-8 × 8-9 mm, aproximadas, erectas, subglobosas, subsésiles. Glumas masculinas ovales, de ápice obtuso, de color pardo-rojizo claro u obscuro; glumas femeninas ovales, obtusas, agudas o acuminadas, de color pardo rojizo con estrecho margen escarioso, uninervias. Utrículos 3,8-4,5 × 1-1,8 mm, los inferiores reflejos, los de la mitad superior de patentes a erectos-patentes y los apicales generalmente erectos, de contorno oval, trígonos, inflados, plurinerviados, estrechados bruscamente en un pico de 1,5-1,8 mm, reflejo en los utrículos de la mitad inferior de la espiga (20-60º respecto del cuerpo del utrículo), recto o casi en los de la mitad superior, bífido, liso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226735","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos largos, a veces laxamente cespitoso. Tallos (9)25-70 cm, trígonos, lisos o algo escábridos hacia el ápice. Hojas (2)3-5,5(6) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes y a veces en el haz, planas, algo rígidas; lígula hasta 1,5 mm, de ápice redondeado u obtuso; sin antelígula o con ésta corta y de ápice redondeado; vainas basales escuamiformes, ± enteras, de color pardo claro, en ocasiones con manchas negras. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia, envainante. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (13)15-25(33) mm, fusiforme, de contorno oval, claviforme o cilíndrica, en ocasiones con flores femeninas en el ápice y en la base; espigas femeninas 3-4, de (6)12-30(35) mm, a veces la inferior ramificada en la base, ovoides, raramente subcilíndricas, densifloras, las superiores solapadas junto a la masculina, la inferior generalmente separada, en ocasiones subbasilar, largamente pedunculadas, la(s) inferior(es) colgante(s), muy raramente todas erectas. Glumas masculinas ± ovales, agudas, subagudas, obtusas o mucronuladas, negras o de color pardo obscuro, sin margen escarioso; glumas femeninas ovales, agudas o mucronadas, negras, sin margen escarioso, de menor longitud que los utrículos. Utrículos 4-6,1 × 0,8-2,2 mm, suberectos, de contorno oval, comprimidos, con los nervios poco marcados o imperceptibles, de paredes muy delgadas, glabros, lisos, a veces con algunos acúleos en los bordes superiores del cuerpo, generalmente negros, rara vez verdosos, aunque en su madurez al menos algunos son casi completamente negros, gradualmente atenuados, a veces bruscamente estrechados en un pico de 0,9-1,8 mm, recto, de ápice bidentado, cortamente bífido, o roto irregularmente, escábrido. Aquenios 1,4-2 × 0,6-0,9 mm, de contorno elíptico u obovado, trígonos, holgadamente inclusos en el utrículo, con un estípite de longitud 1/2-1 veces la del aquenio, verdosos o parduscos. 2n = 56, 58*.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-frigida-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","b89320c0-da17-4b00-937f-1d299e71b0d5#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226744","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze. Wurzelstock sehr dichte, kreisförmige Rasen bildend, aus deren Rand kurze, extravaginale Sprosse heraustreten, stark faserschopfig. Stengel zahlreich, aufrecht, schlank, undeutlich dreikantig, (20-)40-65 cm hoch, etwa 1 mm dick, oberwärts rauh, nur am Grunde beblättert. Grundständige Blattscheiden braun, zum Teil purpurn überlaufen, in einen dichten Faserschopf aufgelöst. Blätter zuletzt länger als der Stengel, (1,5-)2-4 mm breit, flach, oberseits rauh aber nicht behaart, lang zugespitzt, freudiggrün, weich. Hüllblätter der Ährchen spelzenartig, das des untersten Ährchens bisweilen laubblattartig, ohne oder mit sehr kurzer Scheide. Blütenstand gedrängt, 25-35 mm lang, aus einem endständigen männlichen Ährchen und 2-3 seitlichen weiblichen Ährchen bestehend, alle Ährchen einander genähert. Weibliche Ährchen kugelig eiförmig, 6-12 mm lang, etwa 5 mm breit, dichtblütig, sitzend. Männliches Ährchen keulenförmig, zylindrisch, bis über 20 mm lang, etwa 5 mm breit. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten eiförmig, spitz, rotbraun, mit hellerem Mittelstreifen und weißhäutigen Rändern. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten hellbraun. SchIäuche breit verkehrt eiförmig, aufgeblasen, dreikantig, etwas länger als die Spelzen, 3,5 mm lang, bleichgrün, kurz borstlieh-flaumig bis kahl, nicht zottig, außer den zwei hervorragenden Rand nerven mit mehreren schwächeren Nerven, oberwärts in einen kurzen aber deutlichen, ausgerandeten Schnabel verschmälert. Eine arktische, circumpolar verbreitete Sippe ist die schmalwüchsige ssp. misandra (R. BR.) DIETR. (Syn.: C. misandra R. BR.). Verwandte Sippen kommen im Kaukasus und in Asien vor. In Kleinasien (Ala Dag) C. aladagensis W. SCHULTZE-MOTEL. <br />In die Karte von HULTEN ( 1964, The cireumpolar plants 1: 2o, Karte 14) sind irrtümlich Fundorte von C. frigida ALL. aufgenommen worden. <br />In folgenden Gebieten kommt C.fuliginosa nicht vor: Pyrenäen, Vogesen, Westalpen, Korsika, Apenninen. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. Stengel aufrecht oder mehr oder weniger bogig aufsteigend, schlank, 2-3 mal länger als die Blätter, 10-30 cm hoch, bis etwa 1 mm dick, stumpf dreikantig, schwach rauh, nur am Grunde beblättert. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226797","morphology","Plant: perennial; rhizomes shortly creeping and branching.   Culms: 5-20 cm tall.  Leaves: 1-2 mm wide. Basal sheaths: pale brown. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226854","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.   Culms: 30-70 cm tall, smooth, soft.  Leaves: 4-6 mm wide deep green glahrous. Basal sheaths: pale brown. Bracts: lower bracts leaf-like, with short sheaths. <br /><br/> Pistillate scales: pale green, apex acute.  Spikes: terminal spike stammate, shortly pedunculate, linear, 4-7 mm long, pale, shorter than pistillate spikes, hidden by pistillate scales; lateral spikes pistillate, long pedunculate, drooping, shortly cylindrical, 6-10 mm long loosely flowered.<br /><br/> Staminate scales: pale green, apex acute.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 5.5-6.5 mm long, several veined, glabrous, rarely sparsely pubescent long beaked, mouth truncate or notched. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2-2.5 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226909","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose, in small clumps; rhizomes short. Culms often arching, weak, 10–40(–60) cm. Leaves: sheaths pale to mid brown abaxially, inner band thin and hyaline, concave at summit; ligules as wide as long, 2–8 mm; blades usually gray-green, flat to channeled, 5–15 cm × 1–2 mm, usually shorter than culms. Inflorescences erect, 1–2 cm × 5–12 mm; proximal bracts usually scalelike, shorter than spikes. Spikes 2–4, closely approximate, individually distinct, proximal lateral spikes pistillate, containing 5–10(–15) perigynia, oblong-linear; terminal spike gynecandrous, containing 10(–20) perigynia, clavate. Pistillate scales pale to red-brown with yellow-brown center and white-hyaline margins, oblong-ovate, subequal to perigynia, apex obtuse. Perigynia ascending, light to pale brown, often gray-brown at maturity, lightly or obscurely several-veined, from broadly elliptic-obovate to lanceolate, 1.5–3.5 × 1.–1.5 mm, widest near middle, subcoriaceous; beak short, entire. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226982","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, winter, or in all seasons, from near the coast to the alpine plateau, in Gauteng, KwaZulu-Natal, Lesotho, and Northern, Western and Eastern Cape. Apparently endemic to southern Africa.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-glomerabilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","68a0e2da-61ba-4cb5-891a-38e724bc1ff1#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226982","general","<p>Plants (100)–675 mm tall. Rhizomes long, 1.5–3.5 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow-green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths tubular, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade 130–300 × 2.5–5(–9) mm, flat or channelled in cross-section; adaxial surface papillate; abaxial surface glabrous; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth truncate, membranous; ligule 1.5–2.0 mm high, whitish, or stramineous, membranous, apex obtuse. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1–3 mm in diameter; uppermost internode very long, the lower all more-or-less basal, very short, concealed by leaf sheaths. Inflorescence glomerate-spicate to glomerate-paniculate, 15–60 × 8–15 mm. Basal inflorescence bract bristle-like, not sheathing; blade 10–45(–140) mm long; opposing bracteole exposed, not sheathing. Primary inflorescence units 7–10, the largest 5–15 × 5–10 mm. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 1.7–2.6 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate, 3.0–5.5 × 1.3–2.0 mm, shorter and narrower than perigynium, golden-brown or ferruginous, scabrid (mainly on distal half) or glabrous but ciliate distally on margin; carina narrow, single-nerved; apex acute or rarely obtuse, awned, or muticous; awn 0–2 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium spreading, sometimes stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, (3.0–)3.5–5.5 × (1.1–)1.8–2.2 mm, elliptic with flat base in cross-section, not inflated, stramineous, or ferruginous, base with a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, conspicuously many- (more than 10-) nerved, glabrous; rostrum tapered, 0.8–2.0 mm long, straight; rostrum margin winged, scabrid; apex shallowly bidentate; apical teeth 0.3–0.7 mm long. Rachilla sometimes present in perigynia of basal spikelets. Style base straight; stigmas 2. Mature nutlet square, broadly clawed, 1.7–2.2 × 1.0–1.7 mm, narrowly elliptic in cross-section, yellowish-brown, glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-glomerabilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","68a0e2da-61ba-4cb5-891a-38e724bc1ff1#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226982","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, or light shade, in perennially waterlogged marshland, on clay or loam substrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-glomerabilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","68a0e2da-61ba-4cb5-891a-38e724bc1ff1#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:226987","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose.      Leaves: 3-5 mm wide, hard, thick, both surfaces scabrous. Basal sheaths: reddish brown, reticulate fibrillose. Bracts: sheathless, upper scale-like, lower 1-2 leaf-like.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: darkish purple, apex long awned. Spikes: terminal spike gynecandrous; lateral spikes pistillate, subsessile or pedunculate, ellipsoidal, 1.5-3 cm long.<br /><br/>       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, obovoid, 4.5-5 mm long, 2.5-2.8 mm wide, glabrous, 6-7 veined, beak short, mouth dark brown, truncate or notch. <br /><br/> Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoid, 2-2.2 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227096","morphology","Plant: perennial, dioecious.     Leaves: longer than culms after flowering, 1-1.5 mm wide, margins serrulate. Pistillate scales: margins scarious, midrib reddish brown, apex obtuse. Spikes: Staminate spike: filiform, Pistillate spike: linear terete, 1-1.5 cm long, 3-6 perigynia. Staminate scales: margins scarious, midrib reddish brown, apex obtuse.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, oblong ellipsoidal, 2-2.5 mm long, distinctly veined, scabrous, beak reflexed, mouth truncate. Achenes: tightly envelopes by perigynium, 2 mm long. Stigmas: 3 Additional characters: Open woods in mountains. Regional variation: ""Japan"" Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu (including Is. Tsushima). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227097","morphology","Plant: monoecious, perennial.  Vegetative shoots: short  Inflorescence: solitary, androgynous, liner, 1-1.5 cm long. Leaves: longer than culms at maturity, 1-2.5 mm wide, margins serrulate. Basal sheaths bright reddish brown. Pistillate scales: pale or reddish purple, apex obtuse. Spikes: Pistillate parts longer than staminate parts. Staminate scales: pale or reddish purple, apex obtuse.      Perigynia: oblong ellipsoidal, longer than pistillate scales, 2-2.5 mm long, sparsely scabrous, beak reflexed, mouth truncate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, 2 mm long. Stigmas: 3 Additional characters: Open woods in lowlands. Regional variation: ""Japan"" Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu (including Is. Tsushima, Is. Yakushima). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227125","general","<p>Cespitosa, con rizoma ± robusto, a veces con entrenudos algo largos. Tallos (30)50-70(100) cm, obtusamente trígonos, casi lisos o escábridos. Hojas (2)2,5-5(5,5) mm de anchura, de longitud igual o mayor que los tallos, muy ásperas en los bordes, planas; lígula 4-8 mm; de ápice obtuso o agudo; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, enteras, de color pardo claro o rojizas. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de mayor longitud que la inflorescencia, envainante. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (15)30-50(60) mm, linear o estrechamente fusiforme; espigas femeninas (3)4-5(6), de (4)6-9 mm, ovoides, densifloras, la superior junto a la masculina, el resto separadas por una distancia tanto mayor cuanto más inferiores, la más inferior largamente pedunculada, erectas. Glumas masculinas estrechamente ovales u oblongas, ± obtusas, hialinas; glumas femeninas ovales, agudas o mucronuladas, hialinas, de menor longitud que los utrículos. Estigmas 3. Utrículos 2-2,8 × 1-1,4 mm, suberectos, de contorno obovado o elíptico, trígonos, con 3 nervios muy prominentes, con un denso indumento de pelos blancos en la parte superior y glabros o casi en la inferior, verdosos, ligeramente estipitados, bruscamente estrechados en un pico de 0,3-0,5 mm, de ápice hialino, irregularmente roto, muy raramente bífido. Aquenios 1,8-2 × 0,9-1,1 mm, de contorno obovado, trígonos, pardos. 2n = 48*.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-grioletii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","41a22773-0e5e-4d3b-9263-7e8a195a2ffb#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227125","habitat","<p>Prados húmedos y bordes de cursos de agua en claros de encinares y avellanedas; 100-460 m.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-grioletii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","41a22773-0e5e-4d3b-9263-7e8a195a2ffb#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","associations","<p>Carex gynocrates is occasional to common across the far north in humid and peaty, open to semi-shaded habitats (ombrotrophic bogs). Prominent Cyperaceae and bryophytes of widespread distribution lend character to the fens of western Greenland, where C. gynocrates predominates on somewhat drier sites with Carex stans, C. norvegica, C. rariflora, Trichophorum cespitosum, Polygonum viviparum, Salix arctogena, Scorpidium revolvens, and Meesia uliginosa (Dierssen & Dierssen 2005). Toward wetter conditions Eriophorum angustifolium, Salix arctophila, Scorpidium revolvens, and Warnstorfia sarmentosa are its most constant associates. Along the west coast of Newfoundland it is uncommon to rare in larch and dwarf ericaceous scrub. In a fen southeast of Churchill, Manitoba, the ground cover consists chiefly of sedges (Carex aquatilis, C. saxatilis, C. gynocrates, C. limosa, and Trichophorum cespitosum) mixed with Ledum decumbens, Saxifraga oppositifolia, scrub birch, trailing willow, lichens (Cetraria spp., Cladina spp.), and the moss Scorpidium turgescens (Eaton et al., 2001). On shaded hummocky ground in young Picea glauca-Larix laricina forest in the same area C. gynocrates grows with sedges (Carex leptalea, C. concinna), orchids (Orchis rotundifolia), Ericaceae (Ledum groenlandicum, Moneses uniflora, Vaccinium vitis-idaea var. minor, V. uliginosum), and various other shrubs and herbs (e.g., Polygonum viviparum, Empetrum hermaphroditum, Petasites sagittatus, Salix reticulata) (Ritchie, 1957). At Hasbala Lake in northeastern Saskatchewan C. gynocrates grows in Picea mariana muskeg with Betula glandulosa, Dasiphora fruticosa ssp. floribunda, and Vaccinium uliginosum (Argus, 1966). In wetland complexes near Grande Prairie, Alberta, Carex gynocrates occurs in treed bogs with characteristic Sphagnum fuscum and S. girgensohnii together with Ledum groenlandicum, Smilacina trifolia, and Vaccinium vitis-idaea and in adjoining open poor fens with Aulacomnium palustre and Tomenthypnum nitens as well as Betula pumila, Ledum groenlandicum, Menyanthes trifoliata, Oxycoccus microcarpus, and Maianthemum trifolium (Addy et al., 2000). In Yukon it is “restricted to a distinctive type of bog on calcareous soil, where it is often associated with Scirpus cespitosus [Trichophorum cespitosum] and Tofieldia pusilla” (Porsild, 1951). In fens on the Tanana Flats southwest of Fairbanks, Alaska, five dominant sedges, Carex gynocrates, C. aquatilis, C. diandra, C. magellanica, and C. utriculata, are commonly associated with Comarum palustre, Equisetum fluviatile, and Menyanthes trifoliata (Zacheis & Doran, 2009). Frost boils and hummocks in the Meshik River lowlands on the south side of the Aniakchak Caldera, Alaska, are dominated by sedges, including Carex aquatilis, C. gynocrates, C. limosa, C. pluriflora, and Trichophorum cespitosum (Lipkin, 2005). Typical associates of Carex gynocrates in Wisconsin include black spruce, tamarack, white cedar, and poison sumac with Amerorchis rotundifolia, Carex crawei, C. tenuiflora, Platanthera clavellata, P. dilatata, Rhynchospora alba, R. capillacea, Saxifraga pensylvanica, and Triglochin maritima (Hipp, 2008). In a peat- and marl-filled, post-glacial lake basin in eastern Wisconsin it grows on slightly elevated moss hummocks under stunted Thuja occidentalis trees, Ilex verticillata, and Frangula alnus with Osmunda regalis var. spectabilis, sedges (Carex aurea, C. gynocrates, C. interior, C. leptalea, C. limosa, C. livida, C. tenuiflora, Eriophorum sp.), Vaccinium myrtilloides, and Trientalis borealis (sub Cochrane 13651, WIS). Farther north, in Door County, it grows along moist borders of sloughs between beach ridges in full sun. In a cold calcareous sphagnous white cedar swamp in north-central Wisconsin it grows with Calla palustris, Carex interior, C. stricta, Glyceria striata, and Rhamnus alnifolius (sub Judziewicz 14189). The hybrid between Carex gynocrates and C. maritima, C. ×langeana Fernald (pro sp.) [C. dutillyi O’Neill & Duman], strongly resembles C. maritima; the leaves are slightly scabrous-roughened toward the apex; the heads are smaller, ellipsoid to ovoid-oblong and only 3–5 mm thick; the perigynia are appressed-ascending and ± flat; and the achenes are not well-developed. Carex ×langeana is reported as forming close turf on dry, peaty limestone barrens in Newfoundland (Fernald 1933, 1950) and as occasional upon humid rocks and coastal fens along Hudson Bay (Deshaye & Cayouette, 1988). The hybrid should be expected where the parents coexist and has been reported from most of those areas (Cayouette & Catling, 1992), although the report of the hybrid from Alaska by Scoggan (1978–1979) is based on a specimen of C. maritima. Phialocephala fortinii, a common root endophytic fungus with a wide geographic distribution and little, if any, host specificity, has been isolated from Carex gynocrates in the bogs and open fens of boreal Alberta (Addy et al., 2000).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#associations"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","conservation","<p>Carex gynocrates is ranked as secure (G5) by The Nature Conservancy. Although populations are relatively small and scattered along the southern edge of its range, it currently has no federal status. It was initially given protective status in Wisconsin (Read, 1970) but has not appeared on subsequent NHI working lists for that state. It was considered but rejected for listing in Montana. Although once designated as Threatened in Maine (Dibble et al., 1989), it has since been downgraded to Special Concern (Maine Natural Areas Program, 2010). It has been declared Rare in Nova Scotia (Maher et al., 1978), Endangered in New York (New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, 2000; New York Natural Heritage Program, 2010), and Sensitive in Washington (Washington Natural Heritage Program, 2002). Carex gynocrates is included on List 2 in Oregon (Kagan et al., 2010), meaning it is threatened, endangered, or possibly extirpated from that state but is stable or more common elsewhere.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","diagnostic","<p>A small, usually dioecious species with solitary spikes. The staminate plants especially are easily overlooked. The pistillate spikes bear divergent, dark-colored, plump perigynia and are not likely be mistaken for anything else in the North American flora.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","dispersal","<p>Growing as it does in a low-energy environment, Carex gynocrates may rely heavily on vegetative reproduction by the stolon-like rhizomes half buried in the sphagnum as well as sexual reproduction.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Dispersal","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#dispersal"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","distribution","<p>Chiefly boreal, infrequent to rare southward: western Greenland and Baffin Island to northern Alaska, south to Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, northern Maine (Aroostook and Piscataquis cos.), New York, northern Michigan, northeastern Wisconsin, Minnesota, Saskatchewan, and southern British Columbia (Marble Mts.), south in the mountains to Colorado and Nevada; somewhat disjunct in western Pennsylvania (a single specimen from Pittsburgh), North Dakota (one station), and Oregon (Wallowa Mts.); Asia (China [Jilin], Japan, Russian Far East and eastern Siberia). Its distribution includes all 13 Canadian provinces and 17 U.S. states. A marginal note in F. J. Herman’s copy of Mackenzie’s monograph (1931–1935) says “N. Mex.” adjacent to the range statement, but no specimen has been seen.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","habitat","<p>Sphagnum bogs, wet mossy woods (especially white cedar and black spruce swamps, muskeg forests), openings in boggy woods, boggy shores, and alder swamps, less commonly calcareous swales adjacent to the Great Lakes and swampy subalpine meadows; in the subarctic in mossy muskeg thickets, sedge-willow meadows at the edge of muskeg, minerotrophic mires (fens), and outwash gravel; usually in sphagnum or peat that is commonly developed on calcareous deposits. Although widely distributed in the holarctic region, edaphic and hydrologic factors of microhabitats are more important to Carex gynocrates than regional climatic limitations. In western Greenland this obligate wetland plant grows on hummocks or in swards in open fen communities consisting primarily of graminoids forming the herb layer and bryophytes forming the field layer (Dierssen & Dierssen 2005). The sites are saturated by percolating water during snow melt but are seldom flooded; they may dry out in late summer. Carex gynocrates occurs in four associations of the class “Scheuchzerio-Caricetea nigrae,” all of which have a thin upper well-decomposed peat layer (mean ash contents 27, 24, 23, 52%; mean C/N ratios 19.3, 21.6, 26.1, 16.6) having a sub-neutral reaction (mean pH 5.4, 5.8, 5.6, 6.2) (Dierssen & Dierssen 2005). Although all the fens are wet, some are wetter than others. Carex gynocrates predominates in the Caricetum gynocratis relevé on somewhat dry sites. In sedgy wetland complexes in the central Canadian subarctic Carex gynocrates grows on hummocky terrain in which both the hummocks and hollows are comprised of peat. In general, the peats tend to be at least 30 cm thick and loose and spongy toward the surface (Addy et al., 2000; Eaton et al. 2001). At sites on the Hudson Bay lowlands southeast of Churchill, Manitoba, the peat overlies a thick layer of highly calcareous, glaciomarine silty clay and is underlain by continuous permafrost with an active layer depth of 1.0 m in late August (Ritchie, 1957; Eaton et al., 2001). Environmental relations of 37 Cyperaceae species were studied in detail across 498 peatland sites in Canada by Gignac et al. (2004). Carex gynocrates had a relatively narrow range along the pH gradient, reaching its maximum frequency of occurrence at pH values >6. It had the following mean (±1 SD) values: height above water table (cm), 16±9; percent shade, 46±23; mean annual temperature, (ºC) –0.7±2.7; and mean annual total precipitation (mm), 507±111. The mean, minimum, and maximum values for pH were 6.3, 4.4, and 8.2, respectively, and for calcium content (mg•liter–1) they were 32.6, 0.4, and 146.6. Anderson et al. (1996), who investigated chemical and physical characteristics of Maine peatlands, presented data for only three of the rare calciphilic sedge species they encountered. Carex gynocrates occurred at one site, which had a pH reading of 8.3 and a calcium content of 20.9 mg liter–1. In fens on the Tanana Flats, SW of Fairbanks, Alaska, Carex gynocrates occurs with other sedge species on floating mats of vegetation 0.5–1.5 m thick (Zacheis & Doran, 2009). The mats float above silt on water or loose peat mixed with water. The height of the water table above the silt fluctuates annually and seasonally, the mats rising and falling with the water. In these fens Carex aquatilis, C. gynocrates, C. diandra, C. magellanica, and C. utriculata proved to be more resistant to air-boat disturbance than other sedge species and many of the less numerous forbs (Zacheis & Doran, 2009). Carex gynocrates is rare on wet tundra flats covered by Sphagnum at Cape Prince of Wales on the western tip of the Seward Peninsula, Alaska, the closest approach of continental North America to Asia (Kelso, 1989). On a research site near the confluence of the Mackenzie and Great Bear Rivers, the Northwest Territories, Canada, comparative pre-fire and post-fire studies (Nowak et al., 2002) on a right-of-way (ROW), along a seismic line (SL), and in the adjacent upland Picea mariana-dominated forest (BF) showed that fire considerably reduced diversity on all sites. After a wildfire Carex gynocrates was eliminated on the ROW and in the BF but persisted on the SL. Carex gynocrates was one of the common indicator herbs that showed significant decreases in relative percent frequencies in both 1–4-year-old and 9–12-year-old clear-cut plots versus wooded control plots in peatlands at Duck Mountain, Manitoba (Locky & Bayley, 2007).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","look_alikes","<p>Most unispicate sedges are cespitose and have three stigmas. Of those most similar to Carex gynocrates none has filiform leaf blades; their widest blades are generally >1 mm. Carex scirpoidea, although dioecious, has smaller, densely short-hairy perigynia. Carex exilis, C. leptalea, and C. pauciflora also occur in bogs, fens, and conifer swamps. However, C. exilis is non-rhizomatous and has denser spikes with broader, flatter perigynia with regularly serrulate beaks. Spikes of C. leptalea and C. pauciflora contain both staminate and pistillate flowers. The former has erect-ascending, beakless perigynia, whereas C. pauciflora has spreading to strongly reflexed, slender perigynia (usually 6–9 times longer than wide) that taper gradually into an awl-shaped beak.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-gynocrates-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","ef885ad5-2e0a-4ee4-ada5-5add61eef605#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227152","morphology","Plant: clonal. Below-ground structures: rhizomes horizontal, threadlike, 0.3–0.8 mm in diameter. Vegetative shoots: lateral, often prostrate or curved at base. Culms: arising singly or 2–3 together, filiform, ± terete, scarcely furrowed, 2–30 cm tall, stiff, smooth. Inflorescence: solitary, usually pistillate (74%), less often androgynous (14%) or wholly staminate (12%); bracts lacking. Leaves: basal sheaths usually not persisting for more than a year; leaves of the year with well-developed blades 3–5, on the lower 1/4 of the culm, shorter than the culm; sheaths very tight, not prolonged at the mouth; ligules very short; blades light-green, almost bristle-shaped, 2–15 cm × 0.3–0.7 mm, wiry, smooth. Pistillate scales: persistent, usually wider and nearly equaling (to slightly longer than) the perigynia, uniformly light reddish- or yellowish-brown to dark brown in age with pale or green, poorly defined midvein, ovate to triangular- or oblong-ovate, 2.4–4 × 1.1–2.1 mm, apex acute, acuminate, or short-aristate, margins scarious, narrow to broad. Spikes: staminate spike 8–16 mm, ca. twice the thickness of the culm; pistillate spike ± densely 4–15(–18)-flowered, transversely broadly oblong to ovoid-oblong or oblong, 5–14 × 4–8 mm. Staminate scales: similar to pistillate scales but lighter-colored and blunter.     Anthers: ca. 1–2.5(–3) mm long. Perigynia: generally 5–15 per spike, at first erect-ascending, becoming divergent or slightly deflexed, yellow, olive, or at maturity chestnut-brown, obscurely to evidently 17–20-striate (2 marginal ribs seldom prominent), oblong-ovoid, biconvex but slightly flattened in cross-section, sharply but narrowly edged, 2.9–3.4 mm long × 1.2–1.7 mm thick, 2–2.6 times as long as wide, rounded and spongy (especially adaxially) at the substipitate base, subcoriaceous, lustrous; beak conic, 0.5 mm, margins glabrous or very obscurely scabrid, orifice at length minutely bidentate; rachilla obsolete. Achenes: closely enveloped in distal portion of perigynial body, yellowish-brown, lenticular, the body ellipsoid to circular in outline, 1.5–1.8 × 1–1.2 mm, short-tapering at the base, apiculate. Stigmas: 2.   Elevation: 0–3130 m. Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): T.S. Bracts:<br /><br/>leaf-like, with sheathless.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: apex acute. Spikes: upper 2 or 3 spikes staminate, crowded, linear, 3-5 cm long, long pedunculate; lower 2-4 spikes pistillate, narrowly cylindrical, 2-3 cm long, shortly pedunculate, densely flowered. Staminate scales: apex obtuse.      Perigynia: as long as or longer than pistillate scales, slightly narrowly ovoid, 6-8 mm long, many veined, glabrous, long beaked, mouth rigid bidentate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227232","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.     Leaves: 1.5-3.5 mm wide, stiff, scabrous. Basal sheaths: dark brown, fibrillose. Bracts: blades upwardly setaceous, lower leaf-like.  Pistillate scales: brown, slightly shorter than perigynia, apex acute. Spikes: androgynous, staminate and pistillate sections almost equal, lower spikes with several branches, shortly cylindrical, 1-3 cm long.       Perigynia: narrowly ellipsoidal, 4-5 mm long, puberulent, beak long, mouth hidentate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, ovoid, 2-2.5 mm long. <br /><br/> Stigmas: 2, 4-5 mm long, persistent.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-hattoriana-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","29e9f5f5-aa8f-434d-a08c-0fbe3dd04722#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227256","distribution","<p>Variabilität der Art. Durch 4-6 Ährchen ist ""f. sendtnerana"" gekenn zeichnet. Wahrscheinlich handelt es sich hierbei nur um eine Modifikation. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227256","general","<p>Ausdauernde, dichte bis lockere Rasen bildende Pflanze. Blätter steif aufrecht, allmählich zugespitzt, scharf dreikantig, rinnig, gekielt, schmal, 1,5-2 mm breit, ziemlich stark rauh, graugrün. Untere Blattscheiden hellbraun. Unterstes Hüllblatt des Blütenstandes zuweilen laubblattartig. Blütenstand ziemlich kurz, nicht über 2 cm lang, aus 3-4, seltener (""f. sendtneriana"") aus 4-6 einander genäherten, sich deckenden Ährchen bestehend. Ährchen rundlich bis länglich eiförmig, bis 1 cm lang, bis 5 mm breit, 6-10-blütig, androgyn (am Grunde männlich). Spelzen eiförmig, ziemlich stumpf, hellbraun, seltener rötlich, mit weißhäutigen Rändern und grünem Kiel. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227256","habitat","<p>Sehr selten, aber gesellig, in Zwischen- und Hochmooren, in Moorsümpfen, in moosreichen, flachen (auch zeitweise austrocknenden) Moorschlenken; auf nassen, mäßig basen- und nährstoffreichen Torfböden. Charakterart des Caricetum heleonast is (Eriophorion gracilis). Vom Tiefland (hier als Glazialrelikt zu betrachten) bis in die Alpen (Bayerische Alpen bis 930 m; Graubünden [Furnerberg] bis 1580 m). Allgemeine Verbreitung. Nord- und Mitteleuropa, Piemont, Seealpen, Bulgarien, Kaukasus, Sibirien, Grönland, Nordameri ka. Ein Teil der asiatischen und nordamerikan ischen Exemplare wird von Böcher (1952) zu der nahe verwandten C. amblyorhyncha KREC. gerechnet, die jedoch nach HULTEN (1964, The circumpolar plants 1: 68) vielleicht besser als Subspecies von C. heleonastes zu betrachten ist <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. In Deutschland nur im Norddeutschen Flachland und im Alpenvorland. In Ostpreußen selten in den Kreisen Insterburg, Heilsberg, Mohrungen, Osterode, Allenstein, Sensburg, Lötzen, Angerburg, Lyck, Oletzko, Johannisburg, Ortelsburg, Neidenburg. In Westpreußen selten im Kreis Rosenberg. In Pommern im Kreis Flatow. Polen (Schwetz [Swiecie] und Krone [ Koronowo]). In Brandenburg sehr selten, nur am Kulmer See bei Sommerfeld in der Niederlausitz. Die Angabe"" Esterwege auf dem H ümling im Emslan de"" ist zweifelha ft und seit langem nicht bestätigt. In Baden-Württemberg selten (Tiefer Graben und Ruhestetter Gemeinderied, Außenrand der Würm-Moräne: Federseeried, Wurzacher Ried). Im Bayerischen Alpenvorland mehrfach: Ratzenherger Moos, Degermoos, Schwarzensee bei Hergatz, Bodelsberg im Kempterwald, Memmingen, Rottenbuch, Eilbach bei Tölz, Reutberg, Rauchmoos bei Wilzhofen, Degerndorf bei Wolfratshausen, Heilbrunn, Weitfilz und Eschenau westlich des Chiemsees, Oy (Bezirk Kempten), Leonhardfilz bei Dietramszell, Tannenbachfilz am Staffelsee, Görblmoos bei Gilching und Schluifeld (Bezirk Starnberg), Thaler See bei Hartmannsberg (Bezirk Prien), Haspelmoor, Jauchenmoos bei Oberstdorf, Wagenbrüchsee bei Klais; wohl nicht mehr überall. - In Österreich sehr selten, nur in Tirol (Wildmoos bei Seefeld) und in der Steiermark (Hechtenseemoor bei Mariazell); in Oberösterreich (Kellermoos bei Ibm) und Salzburg (Ursprungmoos und Schleedorf) ausgestorben. - In der Schweiz im Jura (Les Ponts, La Brévine; La Vraconnaz, Ste. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227268","general","<p>Cespitosa, con rizoma muy robusto. Tallos fértiles 50-100(140) cm, lisos, agudamente trígonos. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227350","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose; rhizomes long ascending.   Culms: 10-25 cm tall, slightly longer than<br /><br/>leaves.  Leaves: elongating after fruiting, 2.5-3 mm wide. Basal sheaths: dark brown, dead leaves remaining at base, fibrillose. Pistillate scales: purplish red, apex shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical or clavate, 1.5-2 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, ellipsoidal, 0.5-1.5 cm long, shortly pedunculate, loosely 2-5 flowered.  Staminate scales: purplish red, apex acute.      Perigynia: slightly shorter than pistillate scales, obovoid, 2.5 mm long, 0.8-1.2 mm wide, membranaceous, finely 4-6 veined, densely pilose, base shortly stipitale, extremely shortly beaked, apex purplish, truncate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2 mm long, base shortly slipitate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227356","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos largos, muy grueso. Tallos fértiles (40)50-100 cm, lisos o escábridos, trígonos. Hojas (2,5)5-7(10,5) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, aquilladas, plegadas o canaliculadas, muy ásperas en los bordes, muy rígidas y cortantes, glaucas; con frecuencia las vainas foliares se rompen en una cara y producen un retículo laxo y ± pinnado de nervios obscuros; lígula 2-20 mm, de ápice obtuso o subagudo, frecuentemente de anchura mayor que el limbo en la base; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado o, las más inferiores, escuamiformes, de color pardo claro a negruzco, enteras o algo rotas. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227376","general","<p>Plants loosely cespitose, long-rhizomatous. Culms 10–30 cm, distally finely scabrous. Leaves 1.5–3 mm wide. Inflorescences: proximal bract shorter than or equaling inflorescences; spikes contiguous, overlapping, short-oblong or cylindric, 3–8 × 2–2.5 mm; proximal spikes sometimes erect, distinct, separate, short-pendunculate; lateral 1–2(–3) spikes pistillate, of similar length; terminal spike staminate, spikes can be hidden by larger, overtopping lateral spikes. Pistillate scales dark brown or black, margins hyaline, ovate, shorter or equaling, as broad as perigynia, midvein lighter colored than body, conspicuous, sometimes raised, prominent, mucronate. Perigynia ascending, brown, obscurely veined, elliptic or obovate, 2–2.5 × 1.25–1.75 mm, apex beakless or abruptly beaked, papillose; beak to 0.2 mm, truncate, smooth. Achenes nearly filling body of perigynia. 2n = 60.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-holostoma-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-racemosae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","ede88d59-6038-4b76-ba73-d9c0399c080a#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227467","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with terrestrial short stolons.   Culms: 20-35 cm tall, upwardly slightly scabrous.  Leaves: 1.5-2 mm wide. Basal sheaths: yellowish brown or pale brown. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like, with short sheaths, 1-3 cm long. Pistillate scales: pale green, apex mucronate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear, 1.5-3.5 cm long, with short peduncles; lateral spikes pistillate, linear cylindrical, 1.5-3 cm long, with short peduncles. Staminate scales: pale green, apex acute.      Perigynia: as long as or longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 2.5-3 mm long, 1 mm wide, scarcely pubescent, very short beak, mouth slightly bidentate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, ovoid, 1.7-2 mm long, style base annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227499","general","<p>Caespitose. <i>Rhizomes</i> stout, long with short internodes. <i>Stems</i> 20-40 cm, erect, stiff, base somewhat swollen; basal sheaths and leaf bases blackish-brown, persistent, firmly enclosing <i>Stems</i> . <i>Leaves</i> 1.5-3 mm broad, exceeding <i>Stems</i> , flat or channelled, attenuate above into a linear, sometimes curled point, with scabrid margins, glaucous-green, rigid; ligule truncate, ciliate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227595","morphology","Plant: Cespitose. Below-ground structures: Rhizomes short; roots smooth, yellowish to dark brown.  Culms: 10–95 cm, erect, elongating in fruit, aphyllopodic, smooth; basal sheaths persistent, light brown.  Inflorescence: 8–37 mm, dense to more or less lax Leaves: 3–5 per culm, all in basal third, often shorter than culms in fruit; blades 6–31 cm × 0.6–2.4 (2.7) mm, plicate, antrorsely scabrous on margins above; upper blades of culm longer than lower and blades of sterile shoots longer; widest leaf 1.0–2.4 (2.7) mm. Sheaths covering nodes, tight, glabrous, that of uppermost leaf 1.8–13.0 cm; inner band hyaline, sometimes purple dotted; sheath apex concave, not or scarcely thickened; ligule of uppermost culm leaf 0.6–2.2 mm, obtuse to rounded.  Pistillate scales: 1.2–2.1 (2.4) × 1.0–1.6 mm, ovate, one-veined, usually obtuse, castaneous with green center and broad hyaline margins.  Spikes: 2–5 (6). Terminal spike 5.2–20 mm, staminate at base, pistillate above; staminate portion 2.2–14.5 mm × 0.7–1.4 mm, 3–10-flowered; pistillate portion 3.0–7.0 mm × 4.0–5.8 mm, 4–16-flowered. Lateral spikes 3.0–9.5 mm, sessile, pistillate with often a few staminate flowers at base; stami¬nate portion up to 2.2 mm and 3-flowered; pistillate portion 2.3–8.0 mm, 3–18-flowered. Distance between upper 2 spikes 0.4–5.8 mm, distance between lower 2 spikes 2.1–11.0 mm; lateral spikes with short scale-like bracts.  Staminate scales: 1.4–2.9 mm × 1.0–1.3 mm, ovate, one-nerved, obtuse to acute, castaneous with green center and hyaline margins.     Anthers: 3, 0.6–1.4 mm.  Perigynia: Lower perigynia of spikes spreading to reflexed, ovate to broadly ovate, 1.95–3.0 (3.3) mm × 1.1 – 1.8 mm, 1.4–2.0 (2.2) times as long as wide; tapering to a beak, plano-convex to slightly biconvex, green to mostly castaneous when first ripe, dark brown when over-mature, sessile spongy-thickened at base surrounding achene, serrulate on margins up to 1.0 mm below base of beak; adaxial veins over achene none or occasionally up to 6; abaxial veins 4–12, sometimes faint. Beak 0.4–0.95 mm, 0.18–0.44 times as long as body, setulose-serrulate on margins, apex toothed; teeth more or less blunt, 0.15–0.4 mm.  Achenes: 1.2–1.8 mm × 0.95–1.5 mm, ovate, biconvex, sessile. Stigmas: 2; style deciduous.    Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-interior-l-h-bailey-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","c2d3c800-2d49-4c7d-a0de-40bbfaa496a4","","11692b8e-985c-46fb-ba90-3e76054cc8c7#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","associations","<p>    Often found in gaps, subject to being shaded out.  In northern Wisconsin, found on a rocky seepage slope under white cedars, growing with Carex crinita and C. scabrata.<br /><br/>	     Remaining green at least into early winter, the abundant foliage of C. intumescens probably provides greens pulled from under the snow by deer, but there has been limited evidence of grazing on Carex at the Kemp Station in northern Wisconsin.  Insect damage consists of achenes eaten out of perigynia, and of whole inflorescences nipped off their culms.  Green caterpillars have been seen on damaged plants (Zimmerman, E. H., unpubl. data).</p><br/><p>Southward, C. intumescens is mostly confined to river floodplains where it associates with C. lupulina, C. tuckermanii, C. crinita and other floodplain sedges, there preferring somewhat shadier sites than some of the others.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#associations"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","cyclicity","<p>Flowering in May and June; achenes ripe by July or August, fruits persisting into early autumn if not eaten by insects.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Cyclicity","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#cyclicity"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","diagnostic","<p>Easily recognized by the few large green perigynia amid crowded foliaceous bracts, C. intumescens is one of the three (with C. gracillima and C. arctata) common large red-based sedges found throughout the northern forest of Wisconsin.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","distribution","<p>Carex intumescens ranges the most widely of the species in section Lupulinae, from southeast Manitoba to Labrador (Reznicek 2002) and Nova Scotia, and Texas (Reznicek 2002) to Florida.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","habitat","<p>In Wisconsin, occurs state-wide in mesic forest to forested wetland edges, commoner in the north.</p><br/><p>At the Kemp Natural Resources Station in northern Wisconsin, where it has been studied since 1994 in long-term plots, C. intumescens occurs in low, moist woods and has also colonized an area of bulldozed and restructured upland soil, pH 6.0 (Zimmerman, E. H., unpubl. data).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","lifespan","<p>Two individual plants, already fruiting when found at the Kemp Station in northern Wisconsin, have been observed from 1994-2011, and must be at least 18 years old.  Many others are 10-15 years old (Zimmerman, E. H., unpubl. data).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeExpectancy","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#lifespan"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","look_alikes","<p>Carex grayi, C. louisianica.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227619","morphology","Plant: glabrous, cespitose, shoots red based; forming dense clumps of a few up to 30-40 fruiting culms on a robust plant; clumps dividing and spreading over years. Below-ground structures: the short rhizomes 2-2.5 mm thick, reddish or brown. Vegetative shoots: New (autumnal) shoots with several cataphylls and short leaves, becoming both flowering and vegetative shoots of the next season, when they are clothed in old brown leaves at the base.  Summer vegetative shoots rosette-like, with about 8 foliage leaves spreading out as the delicate hyaline ventral sheath bands break away, the lower sheaths red and septate-nodulose on dorsal side. Culms: 30-75 cm tall, 2 mm thick, tough and wiry, bluntly triangular, scabrous on angles distally. Inflorescence: 5-10 cm long, spikes 2-4, the terminal spike erect, on a stiff capillary peduncle 1.0-2.5 cm long, often overlapped by 1-3 lateral, pistillate spikes; these stiffly erect, short-stalked or nearly sessile, usually crowded into a nearly globose mass 2-4 cm long and 2-4 mm thick.  Bracts subtending proximal 1-3 spikes, foliaceous, spreading or drooping, with often shirred blades to 4-6 mm wide, exceeding inflorescence by up to 20 cm.  Cladoprophyll 4.8-5.4 mm long, tan or tinged with reddish brown. Leaves: 4-7 foliage leaves near base and 1-2 higher up,  blades 5-8 mm wide, up to 40 cm long, M-shaped, sometimes septate-nodulose.  Lower leaves with long ventral band hyaline, but sometimes minutely scabrous, brown at maturity, sometimes finely dotted with reddish brown; apex concave, sides of collar very prolonged, ligule rounded; the distal 1-2 leaves sheathless or short-sheathed, with 2 tan to reddish flaps at apex. Pistillate scales: 4-5 mm long, 2.8 mm wide, ovate, acuminate, white-hyaline, with slightly excurrent rough midrib in broad green center strip, at most half as long as perigynia. Spikes: Terminal spike 1-3 cm long, 1-2 mm thick, staminate, erect, linear, triangular in section.<br /><br/>Pistillate spikes each with 1-7 (-12) approximate, ascending-to-divergent perigynia.  A robust plant may average 7-10 perigynia per inflorescence, with a maximum of 17 (-20).  One plant growing wild at the Kemp Natural Resources Station in northern Wisconsin carried 43 culms with 449 perigynia.  Staminate scales: 5.1-6.7 mm long, 0.6-0.9 mm wide, linear-lanceolate, acute, brownish with green midrib.     Anthers: 2.1-4.0 mm long, brown. Perigynia: 12-15 mm long, 4-7 mm thick, lance-ovoid, terete, much-inflated, glossy, slightly translucent, pale to dark green, finally leaden brown; with about 18 veins including the similar marginal ribs, tapering to a slender beak, straight or slightly recurved, teeth 1.2-1.5 mm long, straight, hispid. Achenes: 4.0-5.7 mm long including style base and stipe, 3.0-3.5 mm thick; achene relatively small, its body filling about half the perigynium length; bluntly trigonous, the angles not thickened, faces ellipsoid to obovoid, flat to slightly convex, light to reddish brown, with looped greenish style dehiscent from base 0.6-1.3 mm long; achene sessile on perigynium stipe 0.8-1 mm long. Stigmas: 3  Regional variation: There is only slight variation in perigynium and achene shape throughout the range (Reznicek 2002).  Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-intumescens-rudge-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","58b42552-f4aa-49b5-92da-bf5272ddf513#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227624","general","<p>Rhizomatous; very variable in size, flaccid, bright green, forming a matted sward. Rhizome long-creeping, to 2 mm. diam., covered by closely appressed brown scales or their fibrous remains; shoots ± distant, singly from the rhizome, c. 1 mm. diam. at base including basal sheaths. Culms (2)–8–30–(45) cm. × c. 0.5–1 mm., weak, smooth, green, obtusely trigonous; basal sheaths pale brown almost cream. Lvs < mature culms, 0.5–1.5 mm. wide, channelled to flat, soft, grasslike, margins us. smooth or very minutely scabrid towards tip. Infl. a pale green or bright green ovate head, c. 1 cm. long, of 2–5 closely packed ± sessile spikes, or occ. 1–2 spikes distant from the rest; bracts subtending infl. and lower spikes green and lfy, much longer than infl. Spikes androgynous, 4–8 mm. long, male fls 1–3 at base of spikes, occ. 0. Glumes < utricles, ovate, acuminate, white or pale brown, with a green, faintly scabrid keel. Utricles 3–3.5 × c. 1.5 mm., plano-convex, ovoid, elliptical, distinctly nerved on convex face, light greenish brown; narrowed to a scabrid beak c. 1 mm. long; stipe slightly > 0.5 mm. long, pale cream. Stigmas 2. Nut c. 1.5 mm. long, plano-convex, broadly oblong, shortly stipitate, light to dark brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-inversa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-3","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f28fce0e-bd70-4fd5-845e-1f2d99eacf30#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227685","general","<p>Rhizome short, with slender stolons. Culms laxly tufted, 20-40 cm tall, rather slender, compressed triquetrous, scabrous on upper angles, clothed with few brownish and bladeless sheaths at base, sheaths usually split into reticulate fibers. Upper leaves longer than culm, basal leaves usually shorter than culm, blades 3-4 mm wide, slightly stiff, flat, distinctly 2-veined laterally, scabrous on margins, sheathed. Involucral bracts leaflike, lower involucral bracts longer than subtending spike, upper 1 or 2 involucral bracts shorter than subtending spike, not sheathed. Spikes 3 or 4, rather remote; terminal spike male, linear, 2-4 cm, pedunculate; lateral spikes female, oblong-cylindric or oblong, 1-2.5 cm, densely many flowered, lower ones shortly pedunculate, upper ones sessile or nearly sessile. Male glumes pale, lanceolate, ca. 5 mm, membranous, 3-veined, greenish between veins, apex acuminate; female glumes pale or brownish, narrowly ovate, 2.5-3 mm, membranous, 3-veined, greenish between veins, apex acuminate. Utricles yellowish green or stramineous, obliquely patent, elliptic-ovate or ovate, slightly inflated trigonous, 4-4.5 mm, papery, glabrous, slightly shiny, obscurely veined, base broadly cuneate, apex abruptly contracted into a medium-sized to long beak, orifice hyaline-membranous on margins, shortly 2-toothed. Nutlets brownish, slightly loosely enveloped, elliptic or obovate-elliptic, trigonous, ca. 2 mm; style base slightly thickened; stigmas 3.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-japonica-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8cb97fcb-3ae0-4c6a-bc6d-f5dc33a408d3#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227727","morphology","Plant: perennial, dioecious (rarely monoecious). Below-ground structures: loosely caespitose; rhizomes shortly creeping.  Culms: 15-35 cm tall, stout, smooth. Inflorescence: solitary at terminal, usually unisexual. Leaves: shorter than culms at maturity, 1-1.5 mm wide. Basal sheaths brown to dark brown. Pistillate scales: chestnut, margins scarious, apex obtuse. Spikes: Staminate spike: liner terete, 1.5-2.5 cm long. Pistillate spike: terete, 1.5-2.5 cm long.  Staminate scales: chestnut, apex obtuse.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, oblong ovoid, 3 mm long, 1 mm wide, dorsally few veined, glabrous, reflexed, beak slightly long, mouth bidentate, base shortly stipitate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 1.7-1.9 mm long, biconvex. Stigmas: 2 Additional characters: Wet places in moors of alpine regions. Regional variation: ""Japan"" Hokkaido (Mt. Taisetsu-zan). ""Sakhalin"". Rare. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227727","morphology","Plant: perennial, dioecious (rarely monoecious).    Inflorescence: solitary at terminal, usually unisexual. Leaves: shorter than culms at maturity, 1-1.5 mm wide. Basal sheaths brown to dark brown. Pistillate scales: chestnut, margins scarious, apex obtuse. Spikes: Staminate spike: liner terete, 1.5-2.5 cm long. Pistillate spike: terete, 1.5-2.5 cm long.  Staminate scales: chestnut, apex obtuse.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, oblong ovoid, 3 mm long, 1 mm wide, dorsally few veined, glabrous, reflexed, beak slightly long, mouth bidentate, base shortly stipitate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 1.7-1.9 mm long, biconvex. Stigmas: 2 Additional characters: Wet places in moors of alpine regions. Regional variation: ""Japan"" Hokkaido (Mt. Taisetsu-zan). ""Sakhalin"". "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227747","general","<p>Stoloniferous perennial, forming loose tufts, (13-)20-40 cm. Rhizome covered by dark brown, soon fibrous scales. Stem obtusely trigonous, smooth. Leaves 1/2-2/3 of stem length, erect, sometimes curled; sheaths 20-30 mm, grey to grey-brown, margin of scarious side almost straigth; ligule c. 0.2 mm, scarcely arched; blades 1-2 mm wide, flat, long-attenuate, basal part adaxially frequently scabrous, margins and keel scabrous towards apex. Inflorescence by 1-5 male spikes, overlapping, and 1-3(-4) female spikes below, more distantly spaced. Bracts up to longer than their spikes, lowest sheath up to 20 mm. Male spikes 5-10 x 2-4 mm, fusiform or club-shaped, brown or yellow; male glumes 4.7 x 2 mm, oblanceolate, light-brown, margins scarious, apex acute or arista to 0.8 mm. Female spikes 8-20 x 3-5 mm, cylindrical or club-shaped, peduncle to 35 mm; female glumes 3.5-3.7 x 1.7-2.3 mm, ovate, acute or with mucro to 0.4 mm, reddish brown, margins widely scarious; utricles 3.8-4 x 1.2-1.3 mm, ellipsoid, fusiform or obovoid, bi-convex, clearly nerved, reddish-brown, finally dark-brown, white pilose all over, beak 1-1.3 mm, cylindrical, ostiole oblique, with widely scarious margins. Stigmas 3. Nut 2.2 x 1.2 mm, including persistent style base c. 0.3 mm, obtusely trigonous, brown, finely reticulate and papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-kashmirensis","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-0","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","be9d7736-f9b6-4569-8378-15d3ab05a56a#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227825","general","<p>Culms to 15(–35) cm. Leaf blades flat or folded, 2–8 cm × 1–2 mm. Terminal spike gynecandrous, 7–10 mm, 1.3–1.5 mm wide in the staminate portion, level with or overtopped by some lateral spikes. Lateral spikes 4–10, 10–20-flowered, 6–10 × 2–3 mm, the proximal usually drooping. Pistillate scales brown with paler margins, often with paler midvein, obovate to obovate-circular, 1.6–2.1 × 1.2–1.6 mm, apex obtuse, mucronate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227854","diagnostic","<p>Closest in morphology to C. leporina, but in its British habitats this cannot be confused with any other sedge except its hybrid with C. canescens (C. × helvola Blytt ex Months of the fruiting period:). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227854","distribution","<p>Carex lachenalii is found in the Caimgorms, Ben Alder Forest, Glencoe and the Ben Nevis range (Aonach Beag and, in 2002, on Ben Nevis itself). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227854","ecology","<p>A very local but sometimes abundant plant of wet slopes and acid rock-ledges in the Carex bigelowii-Alchemilla alpina-Sibbaldia procumbens community (U14), between 750 and 1150 m and especially where late snow lies and then scattered in Salix herbacea-Racomitrium heterosticum (U12) or Cryptogramma-Athyrium distentifolium (U18) snow-bed communities; other sites on Geal-cham in the Alder Forest are in flushed areas, closest to M6 association with Carex echinata and C. canescens or to Anthelia julacea Sphagnum denticulatum springs (M31) (G. Rothero pers. comm.). On Ben Nevis it grows in very open vegetation on wet rock-ledges with Alchemilla glabra, Cerastium arcticum, Deschampsia cespitosa, Juncus triglumis, Oxyria digyna, Saxifraga stellaris, Silene acaulis, Thymus polytrichus subsp. britannicus and Thalictrum alpinum, with Anthelia julacea, Marsupella emarginata and Philonotisfontana (G. Rothero pers. comm.).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-lachenalii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a9a15914-23cc-4611-ac8f-f34de1445ad5#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227854","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping; shoots closely tufted; roots brown; scales brown, soon fibrous. <i>Stems </i> up to 20(-30) cm, bluntly trigonous, striate. <i>Leaves </i> shorter than stems, 1-2 mm broad, flat, dark green; hypostomous; sheaths deep brown, becoming fibrous; ligule c. 1 mm, rounded. <i>Inflorescence </i> 2-4 cm, red-brown. <i>Spikes </i> 2-5, closely contiguous, the upper at the apex of a triangle completed by the next two below, 5-8 mm, subclavate, female at top, male at base. Male glumes 2-3 mm, elliptic; apex obtuse, red-brown. Female glumes c. 2.5 mm, ovate, red-brown, with broad hyaline margin; apex obtuse. <i>Utricles</i>  2.5-4 mm, ovoid, markedly narrowed at base, usually green below and brown above; beak c. 0.5-0.8 mm, smooth, split at the back, with the halves overlapping; stigmas 2; nut obovoid, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-lachenalii-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a9a15914-23cc-4611-ac8f-f34de1445ad5#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:227942","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose, in small clumps; rhizomes short. Culms erect, relatively strict, 15–40 cm. Leaves: sheaths relatively tight, pale brown abaxially, inner band thin, hyaline, concave at summit; ligules as wide as long; blades pale green to gray-green, flat, 10–20 cm × 1–2 mm, subequal to or shorter than culms, papillose, densely so abaxially. Spikes 3–6(–7), gynecandrous, proximal sometimes remote, distal approximate, containing 10–20 perigynia, suborbicular to ovoid, 3–7 × 3–5 mm; terminal spike staminate for 1/2 length, not or scarely clavate. Pistillate scales hyaline with green, 3-veined center when young, usually brownish tinged in age, broadly ovate, subequal to, not concealing perigynia, apex obtuse to acutish. Perigynia appressed-ascending, gray-green, becoming pale brown in age, obscurely many-veined on both faces, elliptic-ovate, 1.8–2.1 × 1–1.3 mm, widest near middle, membranous; beak short, entire. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228028","distribution","<p>Carex leersii occurs (Fig. 6) from northern Spain and Italy (41°N) to Great Britain and the Scandinavian Peninsula (60°N), and Turkey in the east, between 300 and 1000 m.
