"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228028","general","<p>Caespitose perennial tufted plant with or without short rhizomes. CULMS 39–90 cm × 0.8–2.0 mm at mid-height, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; sheaths pale to dark brown. LIGULE 0.75–3.5 mm long, wider than long, rounded or subacute at apex. LEAF blades green to grey green, about three-quarters to as long as culms, widest leaf blades (2)2.25–3.75(4) mm, plicate to flat. INFLORESCENCE oblong, 35–60(75) × 8–10 mm, with 6–11(13) globular-elliptic spikes. The lowest spike sometimes branched and shortly pedunculate, upper spikes single at nodes, sessile, and contiguous, first internode 8–27 mm long, the second one 5–15 mm. BRACTS glume-like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than the inflorescence, 6–30 mm long. FEMALE GLUMES hyaline to golden-yellow, with a midrib green, 3.0–4.5 × 1.6–2.30 mm, ovate or elliptic, apex acuminate 0.15–0.3 mm long. STAMINATE GLUMES 2.75–3.5 × 1.5–2.5 mm, similar to the female. ANTHERS 3, 1.8–3.0 mm long. PERIGYNIUM erect-patent to patent, greenish, body elliptic to ovate, nerveless or faintly veined, 4.5–5.5 × 1.75–2.25(2.5) mm, acute at base, sometimes slightly corky at the base, gradually tapering into a beak. BEAK 0.67–1.25 mm long, white to brown distally, with serrulate winged margins reaching the summit, apex bifid or bidentate, apical teeth 0.3–0.6 mm. ACHENE elliptic to ovate, shining brown, 2.25–3.0 × 1.5–2.1 mm. STIGMAS 2, 2.0–3.0 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-leersii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-carex-divulsa-aggregate-eurasia-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","1d2d9166-b670-48b3-ac76-1bc96f5a0a4e#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228028","habitat","<p>Carex leersii occurs in areas with a temperate oceanic climate. Although most authors (De Langhe, 1944; Nelmes, 1947; Chater, 1980; Jermy et al., 1982; David & Kelcey, 1985; Clapham et al., 1987; Sell & Murell, 1996) and most of the studied materials indicate that it lives on calcareous or rich soils, other authors, such as Luceño (1994), do not agree. Chabert stated that he sampled his specimens of C. chabertii from ‘coteaux granitiques de Laveyron. Drôme’. Therefore, this taxon is not exclusively calcicolous. We found C. leersii on well-drained, drysummer soils, in sunny open places, and often in disturbed habitats (ravines or roadsides).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-leersii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-carex-divulsa-aggregate-eurasia-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","1d2d9166-b670-48b3-ac76-1bc96f5a0a4e#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228223","general","<p>Plants colonial, long-rhizomatous. Culms 15–55 cm, smooth to scabrous distally. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228240","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 20-40 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.  Leaves: longer than culms, 2-4 mm wide, light green. Basal sheaths: pale brown. Bracts: setaceous or leaflike, sheathless. Pistillate scales: pale green, apex acute or shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical, 1.5-2.5 cm long, pale brown; lateral spikes pistillate, sessile, shortly cylindrical, 1-2 cm long, densely flowered.       Perigynia: ovoid, 3-3.5 mm long, 2.4-2.7 mm wide, 5-7 veined, smooth, shortly beaked, 0.5-0.8 mm long, mouth bidentate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, broadly ovoid, 2 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228308","general","<p>Plants loosely colonial, long-rhizomatous. Culms erect, 20–75 cm. Leaves 4–10; basal sheaths reddish to brownish; sheath of the distal leaf 2–10 cm; ligules rounded to triangular, 2–7 mm; blades 10–40 cm × 2–6 mm. Inflorescences 10–42 cm; peduncles of proximal spikes 0.5–10.5 cm, basal 2 peduncles 2–10 cm apart; of terminal spike (3–)6–18 cm, exceeding the distal pistillate spike by 2–12 cm; bracts leafy, sheaths 0.5–5 cm; blades 10–30 cm × 2–4 mm. Pistillate scales 3–7-veined, lanceolate-ovate, 4.5–6.5 × 1.5–2 mm. Anthers 3, 3–4.5 mm. Perigynia narrowly ovoid, 10–14 × 3.5–6 mm, shiny, glabrous; beak conic, 4.5–7 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228363","ecology","<p>Although the species is also reported to occur in Japan and Korea, some Asian collections show significant morphologic and habitat differences from the North American plants. It is probably most closely related to Carex paleacea and to the South American C. darwinii, and differs from C. paleacea primarily by having acute, rather than awned, scales. Previous reports from eastern North American were misidentifications (J. Cayouette 1987).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-lyngbyei-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","05e35af6-d27f-4bee-923e-fc18fa2895e7#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228363","general","<p>Plants not cespitose. Culms obtusely or acutely angled, 25–130 cm, glabrous. Leaves: basal sheaths red-brown; sheaths of proximal leaves glabrous, fronts lacking spots and veins, apex U-shaped; blades hypostomic, 3–8 mm wide, abaxially papillose. Proximal bract longer than inflorescence, 3–6 mm wide. Spikes usually pendent; staminate 2–3; pistillate 2–4; proximal pistillate spike 1.8–5 cm × 5–7 mm, base obtuse. Pistillate scales red-brown to dark purple-brown, longer than perigynia, apex acuminate, awnless. Perigynia divergent, yellow-brown with pale brown spots on apical 1/2, 5–7-veined on each face, somewhat inflated, loosely enclosing achenes, 2.5–3.5 × 1.6–2.5 mm, leathery, dull, base with stipe to 0.5 mm, apex obtuse or rounded, papillose; beak thickened, 0.1–0.3 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228375","general","<p>Plants loosely cespitose; rhizomes short; stolons present, often long. Culms sometimes curved, slender, 10–40 cm. Leaves: sheaths gray-brown to pale brown abaxially, inner band thin, hyaline, often red tinged, summit prolonged, concave; ligules as long as wide; blades yellowish green to pale gray-green, flat, 5–20 cm × 1–3 mm, subequal or shorter than culms, soft. Inflorescences 1.5–5 cm × 7–12 mm; proximal bracts scalelike, sometimes bristlelike, shorter than spikes. Spikes 3–6, gynecandrous, proximal spikes separate, usually 1–1.5 cm apart, distal approximate, individually distinct, containing 5–15(–20) perigynia, oblong, 5–15 × 4–6 mm; terminal spike conspicuously staminate at base, long-clavate, 10–20 mm. Pistillate scales pale red-brown with lighter center and narrow hyaline margins, ovate, ± equaling, concealing perigynia, apex obtuse. Perigynia appressed-ascending, gray-green, often reddish dotted, often pale brown in age, finely several-veined, oblong-elliptic, 2.5–3.3 × 1.5–2 mm, widest near middle, coriaceous; beak entire or with few marginal teeth. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228375","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with long rhizomes.    Inflorescence: 2.5-5 cm long.  Leaves: shorter than culms at matured, 2.5-4 mm wide, dorsal side papillate. Basal sheaths: pale brown.Bracts: leaflike blade. 3-6 cm long, sheathless.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: yellowish brown, apex acute or shortly awned.<br /><br/> Spikes: 3-6, terminal spikes gynecandrous lower half staminate, sessile; lateral spikes almost with pistillate flowers. <br /><br/>       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 3 mm long, 1.2 mm wide beak short, serrulate, mouth obliquely truncate, surface papillaled or slightly notched.<br /><br/> Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, 2 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228376","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms (9–)16–60 cm. Leaves: sheath adaxially white-hyaline, summits usually U-shaped, rarely prolonged to 3 mm beyond collar; distal ligules 0.5–2.5(–3) mm; blades 2–6 per fertile culm, (4–)8–18 cm × (1.7–)2–3.6(–4) mm. Inflorescences stiffly erect, dense, brown or dark brown, 0.9–2.1 cm × 10–15(–18.5) mm; proximal internode 1.5–3.7(–4.8) mm; 2d internode 1–3 mm; proximal bracts scalelike or bristlelike, shorter than inflorescences. Spikes (3–)5–9, densely aggregated, ± individually indistinct, ovoid to broadly ovoid, 5.5–10.5 × 4–7 mm, base rounded to acute or tapered, apex truncate to tapered. Pistillate scales gold to brown, often reddish, sometimes with whitish or gold midstripe, ovate to broadly ovate, 2.7–3.5(–4) mm, shorter or longer and usually narrower than perigynia, margin, white-hyaline usually conspicuous, 0.03–0.25 mm wide, apex usually obtuse. Perigynia appressed-ascending to ascending-spreading, straw colored, gold, red-brown, or coppery, conspicuously 0–7(–11)-veined abaxially, conspicuously 0–3-veined adaxially, narrowly to broadly ovate, plano-convex to biconvex, occasionally ± flat around achene, 3.5–4.5 × (1.1–)1.3–2 mm, 0.4–0.5 mm thick, margin flat, including wing 0.2–0.5 mm wide, darker than perigynium body, ciliate-serrulate at least on distal body, pithlike tissue usually present in proximal perigynium walls in U-shape around achene, glossy metallic sheen; beak white, golden brown, red-brown, brown, or dark brown, usually white-hyaline at tip, cylindric, unwinged, ± entire for (0.4–)0.5–0.6(–0.9) mm, abaxial suture usually white, conspicuous, distance from beak tip to achene (1.2–)1.6–2.4 mm. Achenes usually elliptic, (1.2–)1.4–1.9 × 0.85–1.1 mm, 0.35–0.5 mm thick. 2n = 86.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-macloviana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linneaus-sect-ovales-kunth","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","f270b80c-1dd7-466f-a8a4-a47dac9c45ee#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228449","distribution","<p>Carex magellanica is scattered from the Lake District to North Uist and West Sutherland; also in North Wales (v.cc. 46, 47, 48 and 49), but very local. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228449","ecology","<p>C. magellanica is a plant more of bryophyte lawns than of pools, with Sphagnum cuspidatum and S. fallax (M1, M2), since, unlike C. limosa, it cannot tolerate standing water. Its favourite habitat is a level or slightly sloping ledge near the crest of a moor, wet but, being close to the watershed, neither inundated nor subject to much if any movement of the water; this is why it is frequently found on county boundaries, as these often run along a watershed. It reaches 685 m on Ben Lui, v.c. 88 (Porter & Foley 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-magellanica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ef1e8edb-2026-49c0-990d-4dd6b837b30c#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228449","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping, often ascending; shoots loosely tufted; roots yellow, felted; scales shiny, red-brown, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 12-40 cm, usually smooth, trigonous, ± solid. <i>Leaves </i> up to 25 cm × 1.5-4 mm, soft, thin, with c. 15 veins, ± flat, rough on the margins towards the abruptly tapered tip, young ones with a waxy bloom, soon becoming mid or apple green; hypostomous; sheaths becoming red-brown, persistent, with inner face hyaline; apex concave; ligule 4-5 mm, acute, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> c. 1/5 length of stem; bracts leaf-like, yellow-green fading to brownish, lower usually exceeding inflorescence, the lowest sheathing to 1 mm or less. Male spike1, 10-20 mm; male glumes 5-6 mm, lanceolate-elliptic, pale red-brown, hyaline at margins; apex acute to acuminate. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-4, 5-18 mm, ovoid, lax and up to 10(-15)-flowered, upper ± erect at first, becoming, as lower, nodding; peduncles smooth, 5-20 mm; female glumes 3-5(-6.5) mm long, narrower than the utricle, lanceolate, caducous, red-or purple-brown with a slightly paler midrib; apex acuminate or cusped. <i>Utricles</i>  3-3.5 mm, ovoid-globose, ± compressed, ± patent, faintly ribbed, pale apple green; beak ± absent; stigmas 3; nut ellipsoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-magellanica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ef1e8edb-2026-49c0-990d-4dd6b837b30c#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228462","distribution","<p>España, Francia, NW de Italia y Marruecos. En la Península Ibérica crece principalmente en su mitad E. <br />Esp.: A Ab Al B Bu Ca Cs Cu Ge Gr Gu Hu J L Le Lo M Ma Mu Na S Sg So T Te V Va Vi Z.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-mairei-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","837db0e3-9b90-4a1e-b80d-fdfa9fdc2d2f#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228462","general","<p>Cespitosa, con rizoma algo robusto. Tallos fértiles 20-80 cm, obtusamente trígonos, ligeramente escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas (2)3-8 mm de anchura, aunque excepcionalmente algunas hojas de los brotes estériles pueden alcanzar los 14 mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas o plegadas, no muy rígidas, algo escábridas en la zona apical, de color verde claro; lígula 2-7(10) mm, de ápice irregular y anchura igual o menor que el limbo; antelígula 3-4 mm, obtusa; vainas basales ± enteras, de color pardo claro. Bráctea inferior foliácea generalmente de longitud igual o mayor que la inflorescencia. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (10)20-40 × 2-3(4) mm, ± cilíndrica; espigas femeninas (2)3-4, de (3)6-17 × (3)6-8 mm, ovoides, las superiores agrupadas bajo la masculina, la inferior erecta pero con un pedúnculo que puede alcanzar los 7 cm. Glumas masculinas oblongas u obovadas, mucronadas, de color pardo claro; glumas femeninas ± ovales, mucronadas o acuminadas, con el mucrón o arista densamente cubiertos de largos acúleos, de color pardo claro. Utrículos (2,8)3-3,8(4,2) × 1,1-1,5(2) mm, de contorno oval, trígonos, patentes o erecto-patentes, con todos los nervios perceptibles, aunque los 2 laterales están mucho más resaltados, mates, atenuados en un pico de 1-1,2 mm, generalmente recto, si bien en algunas ocasiones está curvado hacia atrás, bífido, provisto de numerosos acúleos mayores de 0,1 mm que se extienden por los bordes, a veces hasta la zona media del cuerpo del utrículo. Aquenios 2-2,1 × 1-1,2 mm, de contorno elíptico, trígonos. 2n = 68, 69, 70.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-mairei-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","837db0e3-9b90-4a1e-b80d-fdfa9fdc2d2f#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228466","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.   Culms: 3-5 cm tall, hidden under leaves.  Leaves: elongating after flowering; 0.5-1.5 mm wide. Basal sheaths: reddish brown, fibrillose. Bracts: bladeless, with sheaths. Pistillate scales: reddish brown, apex shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical, 5-10 mm long, shortly pedunculate; lateral spikes pistillate, ellipsoidal, 5-10 mm long, with 2-6 flowers. Staminate scales: reddish brown, apex shortly awned.      Perigynia: shorter than perigynia, ovoid, 3 mm long, densely pilose, base stipitate, shortly beaked, apex truncate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2 mm long. Stigmas: 3    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Takuji Hoshino <br /><br/>Additional authors: Tomomi Masaki <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: March, 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: Illustrated Sedges of Japan.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-makinoensis-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","6cbf9fc8-d10c-4940-b1ac-fecdf684c042#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228510","distribution","<p>Greenland; Man., Nfld. and Labr., N.W.T., Nunavut, Que., Yukon; Alaska; Europe (Spitsbergen Island, Norway; Vajgac Island, Russia).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-marina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-section-glareosae-g-don","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","eb70b451-3f2c-47db-8776-78cef74a2dd6#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228510","general","<p>Plants loosely cespitose, in small clumps; rhizomes short. Culms erect, slender, 10–15(–30) cm, rough distally. Leaves: sheaths pale brown abaxially, persisting, inner band thin, hyaline, sometimes red tinged, truncate or shallowly concave at summit; ligules shorter than wide; blades pale green to gray-green, flat or slightly involute, 5–10 cm × 1–2 mm, shorter than culms. Inflorescences 0.7–1.5 cm × 4–7 mm; proximal bracts scalelike, occasionally bristlelike, shorter than spikes. Spikes 2–3(–4), lateral spikes gynecandrous, closely approximate or the proximal slightly separate, individually distinct, containing 3–8 perigynia, oblong-clavate, 3–6 × 3–5 mm; terminal spike not clavate. Pistillate scales red-brown with lighter center and broad white-hyaline margins oblong-ovate, subequal to perigynia, apex obtuse. Perigynia appressed-ascending, green-white proximally, pale brown distally, often brown in age, finely several-veined, elliptic, 2–3 × 1.25–1.5 mm, widest near middle, apex conic with weakly convex, usually entire margin, subcoriaceous; beak indistinct. Achenes red-brown, broadly obovate, 1.25–1.5 × 1 mm, dull to slightly glossy. 2n = 62, 64.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-marina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-section-glareosae-g-don","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","eb70b451-3f2c-47db-8776-78cef74a2dd6#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228515","conservation","<p>Carex maritima is a Red Data List species . in Great Britain; Status: Endangered (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-maritima-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","2b1991a9-534f-4139-ba90-3c5471cb3a68#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228515","diagnostic","<p>This species is perhaps superficially like a species of Juncus when in the vegetative state, but the thick leaves are not septate and are inserted in three rows. It is distinguished from all other sedges of its habitat by the narrow hyaline strip on the inner face of the leaf-sheath. <br />Hybrids between C. maritima and C. dioica have been recorded in northern Europe.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-maritima-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","2b1991a9-534f-4139-ba90-3c5471cb3a68#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228515","distribution","<p>Carex maritima is found around the Scottish coast, reaching as far south as Holy Island, where it is very scarce (Swan 1993). See also David (1982). Fieldwork in 2005 and 2006 has added new records and confirmed almost all the old sites in N and W Scotland. The record for Westmorland was shown by A.O. Chater (pers. comm.) to be in error.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-maritima-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","2b1991a9-534f-4139-ba90-3c5471cb3a68#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228515","ecology","<p>C. maritima is a rare plant of sandy coasts, able to withstand salt spray and silt accretion to a limited extent; often found with C. distans, C. extensa, Plantago maritima, Juncus gerardii etc. in saltmarsh such as SM16 and SM19. It is likely to be in similar vegetation in the unmanaged 'rough' of coastal golf courses; e.g. it was abundant on St Andrews golf course (v.c. 85) in 1984, although not seen recently (Foley & Porter 2002). Also on almost bare sand with Glaux maritima. Some populations can be large, when on freshly accumulating sand, but others in saltmarsh conditions can be vulnerable to wave-wash and erosion.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-maritima-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","2b1991a9-534f-4139-ba90-3c5471cb3a68#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228515","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping, much branched; shoots loosely tufted or solitary and terminal on short branches of rhizome; roots pale red-brown, with numerous branched laterals; scales dark brown, soon becoming fibrous. <i>Stems </i> 1-18 cm, solid, often curved, terete, striate. <i>Leaves </i> 3-15 cm × 0.5-2 mm, thick, stiff, channelled, often inrolled, tapering gradually to a ± trigonous point, mid green, often overwintering; hypostomous; sheaths hyaline or brown, thin, ribbed, persistent, with inner face with thin hyaline membranous strip only; apex straight; ligule 0.5-1 mm, rounded. <i>Inflorescence </i> a compact ovoid or subglobose head, 0.5-1.5 cm, on initially erect stem (but, when mature, stems bend down to soil level and the heads resemble rabbit-droppings); bracts glumaceous or 0. <i>Spikes </i> 4-8, clustered, 3-6 mm, few-flowered, upper male, often hidden, lower female with occasional male at top. Male glumes c. 4 mm, elliptic, dark orange-brown; apex ± acute. Female glumes 3-4 mm, broadly ovate, red-brown (often bleached), with midrib paler and margins narrowly hyaline; apex ± acute or obtuse and mucronate. <i>Utricles</i>  4-4.5 mm, ovoid to subglobose, faintly ribbed, brown, almost black on maturity; beak 0.5-1 mm, bifid; stigmas 2, often persistent; nut orbicular, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-maritima-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","2b1991a9-534f-4139-ba90-3c5471cb3a68#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228544","morphology","Plant: perennial, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 30-50 cm tall, smooth.  Leaves: 1.5 mm wide, grayish green, blades trigonous. Basal sheaths: grayish brown, soft, slightly fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, sheathless or short sheaths.  Pistillate scales: dark brown, reddish purple, midrib green, apex obtuse or acute. Spikes: terminal spikes staminate, pedunculate, linear, 2-3 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, rarely with few staminate flowers, shortly pedunculate, shortly cylindrical, 1-2 cm long, densely flowered. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228551","general","<p>Plants densely or loosely cespitose. Culms 15–50(–70) cm, distally scabrous. Leaves 2–4 mm wide. Inflorescences: proximal bracts shorter than or exceeding inflorescence; lateral 1–2(–4) spikes pistillate; proximal spikes distant, erect, and short-pedunculate; distal lateral and/or terminal spikes overlapping, sessile, contiguous, and forming dense terminal cluster, globose or oblong, 5–12 × 3–6 mm; terminal spike gynecandrous. Pistillate scales dark brown to black to margins or distally hyaline, ovate or lanceolate, shorter than (often 1/2 the length), as broad as perigynia, midvein same color as body, inconspicuous. Perigynia erect or spreading, proximal ones sometimes reflexed, pale green becoming golden brown, veinless or few-veined from base to summit, ovate, 2.5–3.5 mm, distal margins occasionally serrulate, apex gradually or abruptly beaked, smooth or papillose; beak 0.3–0.4 mm, bidentate, smooth or serrulate. Achenes nearly filling body of perigynia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-media-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-racemosae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","dda6e805-9b3a-4220-ad00-a56b93b1109e#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228584","general","<p><i>Rhizomes</i> long, woody; shoots solitary or sometimes tufted. <i>Stems</i> 20-70 cm, slender, somewhat scabrid above; basal sheaths reticulate at margins, reddish- brown, becoming darker and ± entirely fibrous . <i>Leaves</i> 2-4 mm broad, c. equalling <i>Stems</i> or shorter, revolute to almost flat, stiff, greyish-green. Male spikes 1-2, approximate, terminal longest; glumes lanceolate, acute, ferrugineous. Female spikes usually 2-3, ovoid to shortly cylindrical, 10-35 mm, rather lax at least at base, lowest pedunculate to 1.5 cm; lowest bract leaf-like, equalling inflorescence, sheath to c. 5 mm. Female glumes ovate, acuminate to aristate, slightly shorter than utricles, dark reddish-brown with green mid-vein. <i>Utricles </i> brownish-green, darkest above, ovoid, 4.5-6 mm, adaxially somewhat flattened, coriaceous becoming suberous when ripe, dull but not papillose, with distinctly sunken veins when ripe; apex rather abruptly narrowed into short, distinctly bifid beak 0.7-1.5 mm, with dark brown band on front and with points scabrid on inner sides.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-melanostachya-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","970cc55d-f3a9-4319-8fc5-b1ebb9088d32#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228588","general","<p>Rhizome indurate. Culms 50-95 cm tall, ca. 2 mm thick, acutely trigonous, smooth, scabrous above, clothed at base with dark purple-red bladeless sheaths disintegrating into fibers. Leaves subequaling or shorter than culm, blades linear, 3-5 mm wide, flat, apex acuminate. Involucral bracts leaflike, shorter than inflorescence, sheathless. Spikes 4 or 5, long cylindric, 5.5-11 × 0.3-0.6 cm; terminal spike male, with peduncle 2-5 mm; lateral spikes female, uppermost one approximate to male spike, lowest spike with peduncle 1.5-3.5(-11) cm. Female glumes blackish purple, ovate-lanceolate or oblong-lanceolate, ca. 3 mm, green 1-veined costa excurrent into a mucro, apex rounded. Utricles green, shorter or slightly longer than or equaling glume, elliptic, 2.5-3 mm, smooth or slightly scabrous, purple-red flecked or minutely papillose, apex abruptly contracted into a smooth or scabrous short beak, orifice with 2 divergent teeth; style base not thickened; stigmas 2.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-melinacra-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","cee31728-978f-4b56-97b2-9bdc3f8d15cf#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228604","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.    Inflorescence: drooping, gynecandrous, 2-3 cm long, lower staminate section short. Leaves: 4-8 mm wide, soft, slightly scabrous. Basal shealhs: light brown. Bracts: leaf-like, 7-15 cm long; sheaths short, with reddish purple Iigules.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: reddish purple, apex long awned.  Staminate scales: reddish purple, long awned.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, broadly ovoid, membranous, 4-5 mm long, conspicuously 2 veined, brown speckled, beak dark brown, mouth notched.<br /><br/> Achenes: very loosely enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoidal, 1.8-2 mm<br /><br/>long, base long stipitate.<br /><br/> Stigmas: 3","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-mertensii-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","aae4d9f8-99ec-43e4-b187-098db74ab9a5#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228638","conservation","<p>Carex microglochin is a Red Data List species is Britain; Status: Vulnerable (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-microglochin-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ba94f676-460e-4e52-8d6b-9a2c446409aa#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228638","diagnostic","<p>This species could be confused with C. pauciflora, which has been found in the proximity of C. microglochin. The latter is distinctive in having an exserted bristle arising from well below the nut but within the utricle wall; its outward appearance is very similar to but should not be mistaken for the persistent style of C. pauciflora. Also the utricles of C. microglochin are fewer on each inflorescence and, on average, smaller than in C. pauciflora. The hoots of the latter species are loosely clustered, not solitary or 2 or 3 together, and the lower leaf-sheaths have a short subulate lamina 1-2 mm long, a feature not seen in C. microglochin. No hybrids of this species are known.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-microglochin-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ba94f676-460e-4e52-8d6b-9a2c446409aa#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228638","distribution","<p>Carex microglochin was first found in 1923 on the Ben Lawers massif in v.c. 88, its only British station. The record tor Harris (v.c. 100), based on living material sent to Kew (Clark 1941 ), has never been confirmed for the island, a most unlikely site (J.E. Raven in Preston 2004).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-microglochin-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ba94f676-460e-4e52-8d6b-9a2c446409aa#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228638","ecology","<p>C. microglochin is a member of a distinctive high-level facies (aii), of Carex viridula subsp. oedocarpa-Saxifraga aizoides mire (M11) in which other alpine rarities occur (C. atrofusca, Juncus biglumis, J. castaneus etc.), together with C. dioica, Thalictrum alpinum and the bryophyte Aneura pinguis, Blindia acuta, Campylium tellatum and Scorpidium revolvens, in gently sloping, tony, micaceous flushes between 600 and 900 m where the total plant cover is usually less than 50 per cent.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-microglochin-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ba94f676-460e-4e52-8d6b-9a2c446409aa#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228638","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> slender, shortly creeping; hoots often single; root pale yellow-brown; scales pale brown, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 5-12 cm, stiff, erect, subterete, striate, solid. <i>Leaves </i> 1-5 cm × 0.5-1 mm, thick, stiff, erect, channelled, ± truncate and rounded at apex, mid green; hypostomous; sheath soon becoming brown and decaying, rarely fibrous, with inner face hyaline, becoming brown; apex straight, serrate; ligule c. 0.5 mm, rounded, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, few-flowered, terminal spike 3-5 mm, male above, female below; bracts absent. Male glumes 2.5-3 mm, ovate-lanceolate, red-brown, with pale midrib; apex ± acute. Female glumes c. 2 mm, ovate-lanceolate, red-brown, with pale margin , caducous, with hyaline, acute apex. <i>Utricles</i>  3.5-4.5(-5) mm, narrowly conical, rounded at base, faintly ribbed, pale yellow-green, becoming straw-coloured; apex tapered into conical beak c. 1 mm long, deflexed at maturity; a tiff bristle (rachilla), arising within the utricle from the base of the nut, protrudes from the top of the beak; stigmas 3; nut cylindric-trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-microglochin-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ba94f676-460e-4e52-8d6b-9a2c446409aa#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228640","general","<p>Rhizomes 0.2–4(–6) cm × 0.5–1 mm. Culms arising singly or 2–4 together, (2–)4–23(–36) cm, glabrous. Leaves: the proximal blade-bearing; foliage leaves 4–10 per culm; ligules much wider than long; blades 1–8(–14) cm × 0.5–0.8 mm. Spike with 4–8 staminate flowers and 3–10 pistillate flowers, 6–14 × 2–9 (immature fruit) or 4–11 (mature fruit) mm. Pistillate scales (except the proximal) 2.4–3 mm, wider than and 1/2 length of perigynia. Staminate scales appressed. Perigynia pale green to straw colored, lance-subulate, 3.4–4.7 × 0.5–0.7 mm; beak scarcely differentiated; rachilla bristlelike, exserted 0.5–2.8 mm beyond orifice of beak. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228658","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 50-70 cm tall, as long as leaves, upwardly slightly scabrous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228705","morphology","Plant: Plants tuft forming.   Culms: Culms 40-130 cm. Inflorescence: Infructescence 4.0-12.5 cm long; infructescence bract essentially sheathless with blade 7.0-35.0 cm long, 1.5-6.5 mm wide; the upper bracts increasingly reduced toward the apex of the infructescence. Leaves: Leaves 2-4 per flowering culm, restricted to basal quarter of culm, median leaves 13-37 cm long, 3.0-8.0 mm wide, plicate; sheath variably scabrous, rarely completely glabrous. Pistillate scales: Pistillate scales of proximal perigynia 2.75-6.5 mm long with an awn of 1.3-3.5 mm; apex of scale body usually truncate, less often slightly cordate with a tendency to become attenuate towards the apex of each spike.   Staminate scales: Staminate scales 2.75-4.5 mm long, usually short-awned 0.2-1.9 mm awn occasionally absent.   Flowers: Stamens 3.   Perigynia: Perigynia ascending, glabrous, ovate to broadly ovate, not beaked, 2.5-4.1 mm long, 1.2-2.2 mm wide, 0.7-1.5 mm thick, lenticular and uninflated, stramineous to light brown in color, closely enveloping the achene; densely granular-papillate over the entire surface; usually 1-4 nerved on both surfaces. Achenes: Achene deep reddish brown to dark brown; lenticular with entire margins, never invaginate; orbicular to rhomboid-orbicular, 1.1-2.3 mm long, 1.0-1.5 mm wide, style breaking close to the achene. Stigmas: Stigmas 2. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228751","distribution","<p>The species occurs in an area receiving rainfall in summer, on the alpine plateau in Lesotho, to which it is endemic.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-monotropa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","32dc630a-ef67-4a34-b285-d6bca059e3b0#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228751","general","<p>Plants 20–60 mm tall, caespitose (sometimes very loosely caespitose). Rhizomes very short to long, 1.0–1.5 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves mid-green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face tearing into membranous strips. Largest basal leaf blade 65–100 × 2.2–3.0 mm, flat or keeled in cross-section; adaxial and abaxial surfaces glabrous; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, membranous; ligule 2 mm high, whitish, membranous, apex obtuse. Culms triangular in cross-section, 0.5–1.0 mm in diameter, very short, concealed by leaf sheaths; nodes not exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 12–20 mm long. Basal inflorescence bracts leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheaths 2–4 mm long; blades 15–45 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 3–4, spreading, clustered; the largest 7–9 × 7–9 mm. Peduncles not exserted, glabrous. Apical spikes usually staminate. Staminate spikes 0–1. Pistillate spikes 2–3. Bisexual spikes 0–1. Small accessory spikes not present. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 1–2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets lanceolate, 2.5–3.0 × 1.2 mm, shorter and narrower than the perigynium, yellow and ferruginous, glabrous; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex obtuse or emarginate, awned or muticous, or carina terminating sub-apically; awn 0–0.2 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect to spreading, not stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 4.0–4.5 mm t 1.2–1.5 mm, elliptic or rotund in cross-section, much inflated, bright yellow, 2-layered, without a layer of corky material, herbaceous, glabrous, nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum tapered, 1.2–1.8 mm long, straight; margin not winged, glabrous; apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth (0.2–)0.5–0.7 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate, not clawed, 1.5–1.8 × 1 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-monotropa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","32dc630a-ef67-4a34-b285-d6bca059e3b0#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228751","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, in seasonally waterlogged marshland, on basaltic substratum.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-monotropa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","32dc630a-ef67-4a34-b285-d6bca059e3b0#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228753","general","<p>Más o menos cespitosa; rizomas generalmente con entrenudos largos y gruesos. Tallos (3)8-20(40) cm, trígonos, ± escábridos hacia el ápice. Hojas (1,1)1,5-2(2,8) mm de anchura, de longitud menor o mayor que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes y el nervio medio del envés de la zona superior, planas, blandas; lígula diminuta, de ápice redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado, de algo rotas a fibrosas, de color pardo o púrpura. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228802","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, in the midlands and in montane areas, in Limpopo, Mpumalanga, KwaZulu-Natal, and Eastern Cape. Apparently endemic to southern Africa.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-mossii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","30be92cf-3558-41e7-a0e0-2177de13fbc8#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228802","general","<p>Plants up to 1.4 m tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 5 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves dark green, glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face splitting simply. Largest basal leaf blades about 485 × 12–16 mm, flat or plicate in cross-section; adaxial surface glabrous; abaxial surface papillate; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth convex, membranous; ligule 20 mm high, fuscous, membranous, apex acute or emarginate. Culms triangular in cross-section, 2.5–4.0 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 2 nodes exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 280–560 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheath 50–225 mm long; blade 185–600 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 7–9, pendulous, not clustered, excepting frequently apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 120–185 × 5–8 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 15–100 mm, scabrid on angles. Apical spikes usually staminate, frequently androgynous, occasionally androgynecandrous or gynecandrous or with staminate and pistillate spikelets mixed. Staminate spikes 0–1. Pistillate spikes 0. Bisexual spikes 6–8. Small accessory spikes not present. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 3.5–4.0 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets lanceolate, 4.0–5.5 × 1.0–1.5 mm, longer and narrower than perigynium, golden-brown, with wide hyaline margins, glabrous; carina narrow, single-nerved; apex acute, very shortly awned or muticous; awn 0–0.3 mm long, margin scabrid, or glabrous. Mature perigynium suberect, stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 2.5–3.5 × 1.0–1.5 mm, triangular in cross-section, slightly or not inflated, green or stramineous with rostrum whitish, without a layer of corky material, membranous, glabrous, nerves few (2 or 3) or inconspicuous; rostrum abrupt, 0.5–0.6 mm long, straight, margin not winged, glabrous; rostrum apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.25 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base slightly bent, or straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate or elliptic, narrowly clawed, 1.8–2.0 mm  1.0–1.2 mm, triangular in cross-section, blackish, or fuscous with lighter angles, glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-mossii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","30be92cf-3558-41e7-a0e0-2177de13fbc8#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228804","general","<p>Rhizome short. Culms densely tufted, 5-20 cm tall, slender, smooth, compressed trigonous, 2-leaved in lower 1/3. Basal sheaths with blades, pale brown, not split into fibers; blades slightly shorter to slightly longer than culm, linear, flat, ca. 1 mm wide, smooth, margins scabrid. Inflorescence 1-spiked, terminal, androgynous, pale brown, ovate-elliptic, 1-1.3 × ca. 0.5 cm; male part short, 3-6-flowered; female part longer than male part, densely many flowered, bractless at base. Female glumes pale brown, oblong, ca. 3.5 mm, 1-veined. Utricles ovate-elliptic, ca. 4 mm (including stipe ca. 1 mm), membranous, not distinctly veined on both surfaces, apex gradually attenuate into a short beak, orifice subtruncate. Nutlet elliptic-orbicular, ca. 1.5 mm, lenticular, without or with a very short rachilla at base; stigmas 2.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-motuoensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","230ed4dc-af9b-48ae-a47e-d29da63162cc#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228806","general","<p>Ausdauernde, dichte Rasen bildende Pflanze. Wurzelstock dünn, mit dunklen, zerfaserten Scheidenresten bedeckt. Stengelaufrecht oder meist etwas übergebogen, schlaff, meist etwas länger als die Blätter,.10-40 cm hoch, unter 1 mm dick. ganz glatt, stumpfkantig bis fast rundlich. Grundständige Blattscheiden braun, netzfaserig. Blätter fadenförmig oder borstlieh zusammengefaltet, rinnig, binsenartig, steif, sehr schmal (etwa 0,5 mm breit), an der Spitze meist gekrümmt, hellgrün. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes spelzenartig, das des untersten Ährchens laubblattartig, sehr kurzscheidig, kürzer als der Blütenstand. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228806","habitat","<p>Hier und da, an trockenen Kalkfelsen der Alpen, an sonnigen Felshängen, im Felsschutt, auf verwitterndem Fels, an trockenen, windexponierten Bergrippen, auch in alpinenSteinrasen oder alsAlpenschwemmling im offenen Schotter der Alpenflüsse, auch auf kurzgrasigen Matten, selten in Wäldern; kalkstet, in den Bayerischen Alpen Charakterart des Potentillion caulescentis-Verbandes, auch in Seslerion-Gesellschaften. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228843","distribution","<p>Gran parte de Europa, W de Asia y N de África; las poblaciones norteamericanas se consideran alóctonas. Frecuente en la mitad N de la Península Ibérica y muy escasa en el S. <br />Esp.: Al Av Bi Bu C Cc Cs Cu Ge Gr Gu Hu L Le Lo Lu M Ma Na O Or P Po S Sa Sg So SS Te To V Va Vi Z Za. <br />Port.: AAl BA BB BL DL E Mi TM.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-muricata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","48a7573f-4b07-44d6-ba03-81523565a735#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228843","general","<p>Plants without or with short rhizomes. Culms: 20–100 cm × 1.0–2.0 mm at midheight, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; basal sheaths and sheaths brown to dark brown. Leaves: blades half as long to as long as culms, widest leaf blades 2.25–4.5 mm, plicate to flat; ligule 0.5–3.5 mm, wider than long, round or subacute at apex. Inflorescence: oblong, 17–45(–50) × 8–13 mm, with 5–10 globular spikes, single at nodes, sessile, usually lowest spikes separated 3–15 mm, other crowded; bracts glume like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than inflorescence, 4–20 mm long. Pistillate scale dark brown, some times reddish with a narrow green to brown midrib and without scarious margins, 2.25–3.75 × 1.75–2.25 mm, ovate, apex acute to acuminate 0–0.4 mm long. Staminate glume 2.75–4.25 × 1.5–2 mm, narrower than female. Anthers 3, 1.75–2.5 mm long. Perigynium strongly spreading, dull greenish to yellowish- brown, body round, trullate or oval, nerveless or faint veins with a winged margin, 3.0–6.0 × 2.0–2.75 mm, base rounded to cuneate, abruptly or no tapered into a beak. Beak 0.65–1.75 mm long, brown distally, with serrulate margins reaching the summit or the body of the perigynium, apex bidentate to bifid, apical teeth 0.25–0.6 mm. Achene round to oval, light brown to dark brown, 1.9–3.5 × 1.60–2.25 mm. Stigmas 2, 1.5–2.5 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-muricata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-eurasian-carex-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","971dbabb-ba34-468a-a6ae-3b5fe7c12935#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228843","general","<p>Rizoma grueso, que forma céspedes hasta de 30 cm de diámetro. Tallos (8)20-50(70) cm, trígonos con los ángulos agudos, variablemente escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas (1)2,5-3(4) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, algo ásperas en los bordes, no muy rígidas; lígula (0,3)1,5-2,5(3) mm, generalmente de longitud semejante a su anchura, en ocasiones de anchura algo mayor, triangular, de ápice obtuso; sin antelígula; vainas basales poco o muy fibrosas, de color pardo. Bráctea inferior de longitud mucho menor que la inflorescencia, setácea, no envainante. Inflorescencias (1)2-3(5) cm, simples, con las espigas agrupadas, a veces la inferior separada de las otras por una distancia igual o mayor que su longitud. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228991","general","<p>Rhizome short, indurate. Plant wholly ferruginous puncticulate. Culms tufted, flattened, smooth, clothed with pinkish ferruginous bladeless sheaths at base. Leaves shorter or longer than culm, blades linear, 2-3 mm wide, flat, margins ± involute, scabrous, apex acuminate; membranous side of leaf sheath ferruginous. Lower involucral bracts leaflike, much surpassing inflorescence, sheathless, upper involucral bracts setaceous. Spicate inflorescence dense, pyramidal-cylindric, 2.5-8 × 1-1.8 mm; spikes numerous, androgynous, ovate, 5-8 mm. Pistillate scales  ferruginous-yellow, ferruginous spotted, ovate to oblong- elliptic, 2-4 × ca. 1.5 mm, apex acute, shortly awned. Perigynia ferruginous spotted, longer than glume, suberect, ovate or broadly ovate, plano-convex, 2.5-4 mm, membranous, many veined on both faces, densely ferruginous puncticulate above, margins from middle to apex with broad serrulate wings, apex gradually contracted into a beak, orifice 2-toothed. Achenes pale brown, loosely enveloped, ovate or elliptic, plano-convex, ca. 1 mm, smooth, lustrous. Stigmas 2. Fl. and fr. Jun-Aug. 2n = 108.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-neurocarpa-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","c657d211-e6f8-4b62-bea0-2cfbe04c8c66","","be46545d-9c5f-4608-aee3-36859be5b184#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:228991","morphology","Plant: Perennial. Below-ground structures: Rhizome short, indurate.  Culms: Culms tufted, flattened, smooth, clothed with pinkish ferruginous bladeless sheaths at base. Inflorescence: Lower involucral bracts leaflike, much surpassing inflorescence, sheathless, upper involucral bracts setaceous. Leaves: Leaves shorter or longer than culm, blades linear, 2–3 mm wide, flat, margins ± involute, scabrous, apex acuminate; membranous side of leaf sheath ferruginous. Pistillate scales: Female scales  ferruginous-yellow, ferruginous spotted, ovate to oblong- elliptic, 2–4 × ca. 1.5 mm, apex acute, shortly awned.  Spikes: Spicate inflorescence dense, pyramidal-cylindric, 2.5–8 × 1–1.8 mm; spikes numerous, androgynous, ovate, 5–8 mm.         Achenes: Achenes pale brown, loosely enveloped, ovate or elliptic, plano-convex, ca. 1 mm, smooth, lustrous. Stigmas: 2   Elevation: (below 100–) 100–1700 m Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-neurocarpa-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","c657d211-e6f8-4b62-bea0-2cfbe04c8c66","","be46545d-9c5f-4608-aee3-36859be5b184#morphology"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229087","diagnostic","<p>Sometimes confused with C. nigra or, more likely, C. bigelowii, but these species never form such dense tufts, have far-creeping rhizomes and two stigmas, and also have their terminal spike entirely male (although aberrant forms of these species do very rarely have female flowers at the top of the male spike). The species hybridises in Sweden with C. atrata, but this hybrid has not so far been reported from Britain.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-norvegica-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c96d58fa-079b-48c1-b41a-b7da3a186aa4#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229087","ecology","<p>A very rare plant of wet ledges and stony flushes in N-facing corries where snow lies late, on base-rich mountains, usually between 550 and 900 m but reaching 1095 m on Ben Lawers (v.c. 88) (G. Rothero, pers. comm.). It occurs with other sedges, grasses and dwarf-heath species, e.g. in the Dryas-Silene acaulis ledge community (CG14) and in C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa-Saxifraga aizoides mire (M11), especially where the vegetation is more open.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-norvegica-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c96d58fa-079b-48c1-b41a-b7da3a186aa4#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229087","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots tufted; roots pale yellow-brown; scales brown, red-brown or blackish, becoming fibrous in decay. <i>Stems </i> 6-30(-40) cm, trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> 5-20 cm × 1.5-3 mm, mid green, not glaucous, ± flat or keeled, gradually tapered to a short, fine trigonous point; hypostomous; sheaths white, green-veined, becoming red, red-brown or brown, persistent, with inner face hyaline; apex straight; ligule 0.5-1 mm, obtuse. <i>Inflorescence </i> a compact, terminal cluster of 1-4 subglobose, erect spikes, the terminal one of which is female at the top and male at the base (often only to be detected by the presence of white filaments), the rest being female; upper bracts glumaceous, lower bracts leaf-like, exceeding inflorescence, the lowest not or scarcely sheathing. Male glumes 2-2.5 mm, lanceolate-elliptic, dark red-brown with pale midrib; apex acute. Female glumes 1.5-2 mm, ovate, red-black with narrow, pale midrib; apex acute. <i>Utricles</i>  2-2.5 mm, obovoid-ellipsoid, minutely papillose, greenish-brown; beak 0.25 mm, slightly notched; stigmas 3; nut ellipsoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-norvegica-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c96d58fa-079b-48c1-b41a-b7da3a186aa4#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229087","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose. Culms 5–35 cm, distally scabrous. Leaves 2–3 mm wide. Inflorescences: proximal bracts shorter than or exceeding inflorescences; spikes globose or oblong, 4–10 × 3–6 mm; lateral 1–2(–3) spikes pistillate, distant, distinct, erect, short-pedunculate; terminal and distal lateral spikes overlapping, sessile, forming dense terminal cluster; terminal spike gynecandrous. Pistillate scales dark brown or black, margins hyaline, ovate, shorter than or equaling and as broad as perigynia; midvein same color as body, inconspicuous. Perigynia ascending, green becoming dark brown or purple-black, veinless, elliptic or obovate, 2–2.5 × 1.25–1.5 mm, often serrulate distally, apex abruptly beaked, papillose; beak 0.2–0.3 mm, shallowly bidentate, smooth or serrulate. Achenes nearly filling body of perigynia. 2n = 56.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-norvegica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-racemosae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a51aff90-b986-435d-a452-ce58229b3e68#general"

Stengel aufrecht, dreikantig, 5-10(-40) cm hoch, bis 1 mm dick, oberwärts rauh, so lang wie die Blätter oder länger als diese. Blattscheiden dunkelpurpurn, später braun. Blattscheidenmündung ausgerandet. Blattspreiten linealisch, starr, flach, a n den Rändern rauh, 1,5 mm breit, graugrün. Blütenstand ein einziges endständiges Ährchen. Ährchen zur Blütezeit schlank zylindrisch, am Grunde weiblich, oberwärts männlich, 5-10(-18) mm lang, der weibliche Teil zur Fruchtzeit mehrmals dicker als der männliche. Spelzen eiförmig, 4 mm lang, gelblich rostbraun, breit hautrandig, die unterste zuweilen mit laubblattartiger Spitze (""f. bracteata""), die weiblichen Spelzen zu letzt nur halb so lang wie die meist verkümmerten Schläuche. Schläuche aufrecht abstehend, ellipsoidisch, stumpf dreikantig, in einen kurzen, stielrunden, an der Mündung meist häutigen und kurz zweilappigen Schnabel verschmälert, 2,5 -3,5 mm lang, undeutlich nervig, braungelb, glänzend. Achsenspitze entwickelt, aber viel kürzer als der Schlauch. Narben 3. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229291","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely cnespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 30-70 cm tall, upwardly scabrous, elongating after flowering.  Leaves: 2-4 mm wide, deep green, scabrous. Basal sheaths: reddish brown, ladder-like fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, upper bracts sheathless. Pistillate scales: pale green, midrib broadly green, apex acute or shortly aristate. Spikes: upper 2-5 spikes staminate, linear, 1-3 cm long; lower 2-3 spikes pistillate, shortly pedunculate, cylindrical, 2-5 cm long. Staminate scales: reddish brown, apex obtuse or rounded.      Perigynia: slightly longer than pistillate scales, oblong ovoid, 5-6 mm long, pubescent, gradually narrowed to long beak, mouth deeply bidentate.  Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoidal or ovoid, 2 mm long. Stigmas: 3, slightly persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229293","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose; rhizomes long creeping.     Inflorescence: androgynous, 5-8 mm long, 4-4.5 mm wide. Staminate scales: apex acute. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229325","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, a veces con rizomas de entrenudos algo alargados, ascendentes. Tallos (3,5)5-15(17) cm, obtusamente trígonos, lisos o escábridos en el ápice, laterales, sin hojas o con 1-2 reducidas a una vaina y un limbo poco desarrollado. Hojas (0,3)2-3,5(4,5) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, rara vez algo mayor, lisas salvo en los bordes de la zona apical, planas o un poco canaliculadas, curvadas o rectas, algo rígidas; lígula diminuta, con ápice agudo u obtuso, de anchura mayor que el limbo; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado, de algo rotas a fibrosas, de color pardo. Bráctea inferior glumácea, no o cortamente envainante. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (4)6-9(11) mm, linear; espigas femeninas (1)2-3, de (2,5)5-10(12) mm, agrupadas junto a la masculina, sésiles o subsésiles, erectas, lineares, laxas. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229334","distribution","<p>Europa (fehlt in Nordfennoskandien, Island, Dänemark, Irland, den Niederlanden, Westfrankreich, dem größten Teil der Iberischen Halbinsel, Süditalien und dem südlichen Teil der Balkanhalbinsel), östlich bis zu den Baltischen Ländern und den Karpaten; Angaben aus dem Ural, dem Kaukasus und Kleinasien sind irrtümlich. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. Carex ornithopoda ist in Norddeutschland selten, sie fehlt vollständig in Ostpreußen, Pommern, Mecklenburg, Schleswig-Holstein, Nordwestdeutschland, Westfalen und Schlesien. In Westpreußen nur im Kreis Deutsch Krone (Koronowo) am Großen See bei Salm. In Brandenburg in der Gegend von Krossen an der Oder bei Griezel (Krämersborner Kalkteich und Kalksee). In Sachsen-Anhalt bei Dessau (Fuhnetal bei Zehmitz). In Sachsen selten (Waldhaus bei Greiz sowie um Gera und Eisenberg). In Thüringen nördlich bis zum Südharzrand. Im südlichen Niedersachsen im Weserbergland mehrfach. Sonst in allen Provinzen des Gebiets vorhanden, wenn auch vielfach selten und in kalkarmen Gebieten lokal fehlend (z. B. im nordbayerischen Keupergebiet und im Bayerischen Wald). Im Rheinland selten. - In Böhmen selten (Libechov bei Melnik, Lipovka bei Rynchnov n. Kn., BöhmerwaldVorberge bei Podmokly, Sobesice und Nezdice), in Mähren in den Weißen Karpaten und Vsetin-Bergen.Verbreitungskarte für Mähren bei PODPERA ( 1928, S. 347).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ornithopoda-subsp-ornithopoda-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","b39f8f88-9845-469b-ba6c-38152c8ac430#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229334","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze. Wurzelstock rasenbildend. Stengel seitenständig (nicht zentral aus der Blattrosette entspringend), gerade oder nur schwach gebogen, 5-10(-25) cm hoch, dünn, zusammengedrückt-dreikantig bis fast stielrund, oberwärts etwas rauh oder ganz glatt. Grundständige Blattscheiden hellbraun bis schmutzig purpurfarben. Blätter derb, überwinternd, mehr oder weniger gebogen, flach, kürzer als der Stengel, 2-3(-4) mm breit, an den Rändern rauh, ziemlich stark nervig, hellgrün. Hüllblätter der weiblichen Ährchen kurz, scheidenartig, etwa 5 mm lang, spitz, rotbraun, mit grünem Mittelstreifen und weißen Hauträndern, das unterste oft borsten förmig zugespitzt. Blütenstand 10-15(-20) mm lang, aus einem endständigen männlichen Ährchen und 2-3(-4) seitlichen wei blichen Ährchen bestehend; alle Ährchen einander fingerförmig genähert, fast von einem Punkte entspringend, vom Aussehen eines Vogelfußes, das männl iche Ährchen von den oberen weiblichen oder von allen überragt. Weibliche Ährchen gestielt (die Stiele aus der Scheide der Hüllblätter herausragend), linealisch länglich, 6-10(-15) mm lang, lockerblütig, 2-6-blütig. Männliches Ährchen sitzend, linealisch, 4-8 mm lang. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten verkehrt eiförmig, breit, abgerundet, zuweilen kurz zugespitzt, am Rande nicht gezähnelt, gelbbraun (bei var. castanea kastanienbraun) bis rotbraun, mit grünem Mittelstreifen und helleren Hauträndern, kürzer als die Schläuche. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten heller. Schläuche verkehrt eiförmig, dreikantig, am Grunde allmählich in den sch lanken Stiel, oberwärts in den dünnen, deutlichen Schnabel verschmälert, 2,5-3 mm lang, ziemlich dicht kurzhaarig, an den Kanten längsnervig, sonst nervenlos, braungrün oder rötlich bis schwarzbraun, matt oder (var. castanea) glänzend. Narben 3. Frucht eiförmig, scharf dreikantig, fast schwarz.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ornithopoda-subsp-ornithopoda-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","b39f8f88-9845-469b-ba6c-38152c8ac430#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229334","habitat","<p>Zerstreut, in Wäldern, besonders in wärmeliebenden, lichten Kiefern- und Eichenwäldern, in Gebüschen und Hecken, auf Lichtungen, auf trockenen Wiesen, an sonnigen Hängen, an Felsen; auf trockenen, basen- und kalkreichen, lockeren, mildhumosen Löß-, Kies- und Steinböden, auch auf Kalk- Rohböden. Ameisenverbreitung. Verbreitungsschwerpunkt in Erico-Pinion-Gesellschaften, auch im Lithospermo-Quercetum pubescentis (Quercion pubescenti-petraeae), im Berberidion oder in offenen Brometalia erecti- und Seslerietalia-Gesellschaften, die var. castanea Kobresio-Seslerietea-Klassencharakterart. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229355","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.     Leaves: 4-10 mm wide, soft, margins scabrous, dorsal surfaces grayish green. Basal sheaths: reddish brown. Bracts: sheathless, blades about as long as inflorescence. Pistillate scales: about as long as perigynia, both surfaces reddish to purplish brown, apex long aristate, arista slightly scabrous.
