"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229356","diagnostic","<p>Similar to C. vulpina (which see for diagnostic characters) and certainly hybridises with it in mainland Europe. Narrow-leaved plants are difficult to separate from C. muricata agg., but the thicker, stout stem, the distinctive veining in leaves and sheaths, the acute tubular ligule and ± auriculate leaves of C. otrubae will usually distinguish it. C. otrubae hybridises with C.  spicata (C. × haussknechtii Senay), C. divulsa subsp. divulsa and C. remota (C. × pseudoaxillaris K. Richt.). Hybrids with C. vulpina are difficult to detect but have been tentatively identified in southern England.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-otrubae-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9cf4d4c7-dbf7-4ea3-b10b-3b1d21ba91ed#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229356","distribution","<p>Carex otrubae is a lowland plant which is rare in mountain areas of Britain and becomes almost exclusively coastal in NW England and Scotland. It is scattered throughout Ireland but commonest near the coast.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-otrubae-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9cf4d4c7-dbf7-4ea3-b10b-3b1d21ba91ed#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229356","ecology","<p>C. otrubae is a species of heavy soils, usually in damp situations with Juncus effusus or J. acutiflorus, typically in M28 and related communities, where an element of flushing occurs, and a marginal species in roadside ditches and drainage dykes (S18), becoming in western regions almost exclusively a coastal plant in sites that may be inundated by brackish or even saline water (e.g. MG12).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-otrubae-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9cf4d4c7-dbf7-4ea3-b10b-3b1d21ba91ed#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229356","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots stout, densely tufted; roots thick, grey-brown; scales brown, remaining as black fibres. <i>Stems </i> 30-100 cm, stout, smooth below, rough above, trigonous, their faces ± flat, slightly winged on angles. <i>Leaves </i> up to 60 cm × 4-10 mm, ± erect, obtusely keeled, tapering to a flat, sharp point, bright green, becoming grey-green when dry and often spotted with pale orange-brown in decay; margins rough; hypostomous; base appearing subauriculate, as it abruptly contracts into the sheath; sheaths white with green veins, becoming brown, soon decaying, with inner face hyaline, not wrinkled; apex variable from concave to rarely lingulate; ligule 5-10 mm, ± acute, tubular, contained within the width of the leaf. <i>Inflorescence </i> an elongate panicle, becoming dense when in fruit; lower bracts setaceous, with leaf-like base, half as long as, or often longer than, the inflorescence; upper bracts glumaceous. <i>Spikes </i> numerous, 8-14 mm, compound, all or most male above and female below. Male glumes 3.5-4 mm, oblanceolate-elliptic, pale orange-brown with green midrib; apex acute. Female glumes 4-5 mm, ovate, pale red-or orange-brown with green midrib; apex acurninate-aristate. <i>Utricles</i>  4-6 mm, ovoid, piano-convex, ± shiny, strongly nerved, green, at maturity red-brown to dark brown and not readily dropping; epidermal cells of adaxial face thin-walled and elongated; beak 1-1.5 mm, rough at apex, bifid, not split at back; stigmas 2; nut oblong-obovoid, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-otrubae-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","9cf4d4c7-dbf7-4ea3-b10b-3b1d21ba91ed#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229362","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, in the montane area of Eastern Cape. Adventive in New Zealand (Healy & Edgar, 1980). Introduced from Europe.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ovalis-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","9b5ac1f0-4f95-4917-82c3-fc4022b00a00#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229362","general","<p>Caespitose, without creeping rhizomes. Stems 20-50(-65) cm. Basal scales brown, becoming somewhat fibrous while decaying. Leaves 2-3.5 mm wide, green, usually half as long as stems. Ligule shorter than wide. Inflorescence (1.5-)2-3 cm, spikes 4-8 sessile, crowded or at least overlapping 5-10 mm, obovate acrogynous. Bracts usually shorter than spikes. Female glumes acute, brown; male glumes similar but with hyaline margins. Stigmas 2. Utricles 3.5-4.5 x 1.5-1.8 mm, piano-convex, brown, dull, with distinct veins on both surfaces and with a wing 0.2-0.5 mm wide, beak c. as long as body bifid.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ovalis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-2","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c17a019d-9fbc-4731-938f-72c7bbc1e3b8#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229362","general","<p>Plants (0.15–)0.3(–0.8) m tall. Rhizomes very short, ? mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves mid- to dark green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths tubular, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face splitting simply. Largest basal leaf blade 100–200 × (1.5–)3(–4) mm, flat or channelled in cross-section; adaxial surface glabrous; abaxial surface papillate in vicinity of veins, margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth truncate, membranous; ligule 1–2 mm high, whitish, membranous, apex obtuse. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1.2–1.8 mm in diameter; uppermost internode very long, the lower all more-or-less basal, very short, concealed by leaf sheaths. Inflorescence glomerate-spicate, (15–)20(–30) l (5–)10(–14) mm. Basal inflorescence bract usually bristle-like, not sheathing; blade up to 30 mm long; opposing bracteole exposed, not sheathing. Primary inflorescence units (2– )3–7(–10), the largest 5–15 × 7 mm. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.0–2.2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets lanceolate-elliptic, 3.0–4.5 × ? mm, about the same length and width as perigynium; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex acute, muticous; margin glabrous [check]. Mature perigynium suberect, substipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, including wings 3.5–5.0 × 1.75–2.25 mm, plano-convex with winged base in cross-section, not inflated, light to yellow brown, base without a layer of corky material, membranous, abaxial surface conspicuously several-nerved, glabrous; rostrum tapered, 1.8 mm long, straight; rostrum margin winged, scabrid; apex deeply bidentate; apical teeth 0.8 mm long. Rachilla ?sometimes present in perigynia of basal spikelets. Style base straight; stigmas 2. Mature nutlet obovate, broadly clawed, 1.75 × 1.00 mm, plano-convex in cross-section, yellowish-brown, glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ovalis-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","9b5ac1f0-4f95-4917-82c3-fc4022b00a00#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229362","habitat","<p>Damp meadows and marshy places by streams and lakes, c. 1600-2000 m, on schist, flysch and granite, rarely on limestone.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ovalis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-2","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c17a019d-9fbc-4731-938f-72c7bbc1e3b8#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229362","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, or light shade, in perennially waterlogged marshland, on clay or loam substrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ovalis-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","9b5ac1f0-4f95-4917-82c3-fc4022b00a00#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229372","diagnostic","<p>The new species is here placed in Carex section Phaestoglochin Dumort. It differs from other South American members of this section by having the following combination of characters: culms usually slightly to strongly curved; a small inflorescence (1- 1.5 cm long) with short spikes (5-7 mm long) and few perigynia per spike (4-9); non-tuberculate perigynia that are finely, but distinctly, several veined on both faces; and achenes with a distinctive whitish stipe 0.1-0.3 mm long. While seemingly not closely related to other South American members of section Phaestoglochin, Carex ownbeyi does resemble some members of this section from Mexico and Central America, such as C. xalapenis Kunth from southern Mexico and Guatemala (Hermann, 1974; Chater, 1994).<br /><br/>	Plants with mature perigynia have been collected in March and April. The species is named in honor of Dr. Gerald B. Ownbey, professor emeritus of botany at the University of Minnesota, well known for his floristic and taxonomic work in North America, particularly in Minnesota (U.S.A.) and Mexico, and who first encouraged and then made it possible for me to pursue a study of South American Carex and Uncinia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ownbeyi-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae-south-america-three-new-species-and-some-name-changes","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","3e27f2f7-2a54-475e-b9db-deca5cd64a71#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229372","distribution","<p>Carex ownbeyi is known only from the type locality</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ownbeyi-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae-south-america-three-new-species-and-some-name-changes","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","3e27f2f7-2a54-475e-b9db-deca5cd64a71#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229372","general","<p>Loosely cespitose from brown, prolonged rhizomes. Fertile culms 12–22 cm tall, 0.5–0.8 mm thick, usually slightly to strongly curved, trigonous, smooth proximally and finely scabrousangled distally (especially beneath the inflorescence), with glabrous, brownish basal sheaths. Leaves 3–5, on lower one-fourth of culm; blades 2– 10 cm long, 1.2–2.5 mm wide, plicate, glabrous, the margins antrorsely scabrous distally; leaf sheaths 2–15 mm long, tightly enveloping culms, glabrous; the inner band of sheaths glabrous, white-hyaline or pale brown, the apex nearly straight across; ligules 0.7–1.4 mm long, slightly wider than long, rounded, the narrow free portion brownish. Inflorescences 1–1.5 cm long, 5–8 mm wide, the spikes aggregated into a terminal, ovoid or oblong head; bracts shorter than the inflorescence, the lowermost scale-like with bodies 2.5–5 mm long and 1.6–2.4 mm wide, ovate-lanceolate, acute, with serrulate awns up to 3 mm long, the upper ones reduced. Spikes 3–6, androgynous, 5–7 mm long, 3.5–6 mm wide, ovoid, mostly distinguishable but the apical staminate flowers inconspicuous (except for the anthers), perigynia 4–9 per spike. Pistillate scales 2.6–4.2 mm long, 1.4–2 mm wide, shorter than the perigynia, ovate to broadly ovate, acute or mucronate, reddish brown with a stramineous or pale brown center and with or without narrow hyaline margins, 1–3-veined; staminate scales similar but smaller. Perigynia 3.5–4 mm long, 1.2–1.9 mm wide, ascending, plano-convex with ovate or oblong-elliptic sides, the margins smooth except sometimes scaberulent at the shoulders, greenish or pale brown proximally and often reddish brown distally, glabrous, subcoriaceous, 2 lateral veins prominent and finely, but distinctly, 6–10-veined abaxially and 3–7-veined adaxially, substipitate, more or less tapered into a beak; beaks 0.7–1 mm long, the margins serrulate, the apex bidentulate with teeth up to 0.2 mm long. Achenes 2–2.5 mm long, 1.3–1.5 mm wide, lenticular, ovate-oblong, brown except for a whitish stipe 0.1–0.3 mm long. Stigmas 2. Anthers 3, 1.8–2.2 mm long, including a slender apical appendage 0.1–0.2 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-ownbeyi-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae-south-america-three-new-species-and-some-name-changes","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","3e27f2f7-2a54-475e-b9db-deca5cd64a71#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229374","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.   Culms: 20-50 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.  Leaves: 3-6 mm wide, stiff, margins scabrous. Basal sheaths: brown, strongly fibrillose. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like with sheaths. Pistillate scales: brown, apex acute or shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear, 4-6 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, cylindrical, 2-5 cm long.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, lanceolate 5.5-6 mm long, finely veined, densely puberulent, long beaked, mouth deeply bidentate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by pengynium, oblong ellipsoidal, 2 mm long except for stipe, long stipitate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229388","morphology","Plant: perennial; rhizomes long creeping.      Leaves: broadly lanceolate, 17-20 mm wide, soft, both surfaces densely puberulent. Basal sheaths: rusty brown. Bracts: spathaceous, usually bladeless. <br /><br/> Pistillate scales: margins obtuse or acute, pale, shortly haired. Spikes: terminal spikes staminate, 0.5-1 cm long; lateral spikes androgynous 0.5-1<br /><br/>cm long, pedunculate, 1 spike at each node, staminate parts short; pistillate loosely 2-3 flowered.       Perigynia: as long as pistillate scales, obovoid 3.5-4.5 mm long, 1.5-1.8 mm wide, 5-8 veined, densely pubescent, scabrous, beak extremely short, mouth truncate.<br /><br/> Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, oblong ovoid, trigonous, 2-2.5 mm long, 1.4-1.7 mm wide. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229401","general","<p>Plants without or with short rhizomes. Culms: 20–70 cm × 0.8–1.25 mm at midheight, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; sheaths brown. Leaves: blades about 1/2 or 1/3 as long as culms, widest leaf blades 2.5–3(–3.5) mm, plicate to flat; ligule 1.0–3.5 mm, wider than long, round or subacute at apex. Inflorescence: oblong, 21–30 × 8–10 mm, with 6–10(–11) globular spikes, single at nodes except the lowest, sessile, lowest spikes usually separated 4–9 mm, other crowded; bracts glume like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than inflorescence, 6–15 mm long. Pistillate scale light brown, with a narrow midrib green to brown, with or without lateral scarious margins, 2.75–3.6 × 1.75–2.25 mm, obovate to ovate, apex acuminate 0.3–0.4 mm long. Staminate glume 3.0–3.5 × 1.5–2.0 mm, narrower than the female. Anthers 3, 2–2.5 mm long. Perigynium spreading, greenish to brownish, body rounded to oval-rounded, nerveless or faintly veined, without winged margins, 3.0–4.0 × 1.75–2.25 mm, rounded base, more or less tapered into a beak. Beak 0.5–0.9 mm long, brown distally, with serrulate margins reaching the summit, apex bifid, apical teeth 0.25–0.5 mm. Achene oval to ovate, yellowish brown, 2.0–2.75 × 1.5–2.20 mm. Stigmas 2, 2.25–3.0 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pairae-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-eurasian-carex-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","6893688d-b18e-48df-a1af-9ab1492dbf0e#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229414","general","<p>Plants not cespitose. Culms obtusely or acutely angled, 15–80 cm, glabrous or minutely scabrous. Leaves: basal sheaths brown or red-brown; sheaths of proximal leaves glabrous, fronts lacking spots and veins, apex U-shaped; blades hypostomic, 4–8 mm wide, abaxially papillose. Proximal bract equal to or longer than inflorescence, 3–8 mm wide. Spikes usually pendent; staminate (1–)2–3; pistillate 2–7; proximal pistillate spike 2.2–6.5 cm × 5–13 mm, base obtuse. Pistillate scales yellow-brown; 3.4–20 × 1–1.7 mm (including awn), midvein reaching apex, 1/3–1/2 the width of scale, apex acuminate or retuse, aristate, awn scabrous. Perigynia divergent, pale brown, 0–50-veined on each face, thick-walled, somewhat inflated, loosely enclosing achenes, ellipsoid, 2.4–4 × 1.3–1.9 mm, leathery, dull, base with stipe to 0.5 mm, apex acute, short-papillose; beak cylindric, 0.2–0.4 mm, entire. Achenes deeply constricted on 1 margins or 1 face, apex rounded, glossy; style base strongly bent. 2n = 71, 72, 73.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-paleacea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","d5243c6c-a633-4329-94c8-9c36ac3045d8#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229414","habitat","<p>Saline, brackish, and intertidal marshes, shores, river estuaries; 0–10 m;</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-paleacea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","d5243c6c-a633-4329-94c8-9c36ac3045d8#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","diagnostic","<p>diagnostic features are pubescent foliage, short overlapping spikes, and crowded perigynia that are small, slender, terete, shiny, and virtually beakless, with plump rounded apices and a few faint veins.  They resemble tiny green watermelons</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-l-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","5897495b-be6a-41c8-a7cf-1e5c69a80420#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","distribution","<p>Europa, E de Asia y E de Norteamérica; naturalizada en Islandia y Nueva Zelanda. N de España, Sistema Ibérico y E del Sistema Central. And. <br />Esp.: B Bu Cu Ge Hu L Le Lo M Na O P S Sg So Te Za.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","7f293beb-b25a-496b-b77b-69f884625fed#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","distribution","<p>In Wisconsin, Apostle Islands in Lake Superior, northern counties, Door Peninsula and Milwaukee near Lake Michigan.</p><br/><p>The overall range of C. pallescens runs from Newfoundland through Ontario to northeastern Minnesota, south to New Jersey and west to Illinois; it has also been found in Virginia and Tennessee (USDA 1999, Mohlenbrock 1999). St. Pierre and Miquelon (Ball 2002).</p><br/><p>Also northern Eurasian; introduced New Zealand (Ball 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-l-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","5897495b-be6a-41c8-a7cf-1e5c69a80420#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","general","<p>Cespitosa, con rizoma no muy robusto. Tallos (14)30-70(100) cm, agudamente trígonos, estrechamente alados hacia el ápice, escábridos. Hojas (2)3,8-5(5,5) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, rara vez mayor, pelosas en el envés, con 2 costillas muy marcadas en el haz, planas, blandas, escábridas en los bordes; lígula 2-4 mm, con ápice agudo u obtuso y márgenes pelosos; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, enteras o algo fibrosas, de color pardo a pardo-púrpura obscuro. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de mayor longitud que la inflorescencia, no envainante o con una corta vaina. Espiga masculina solitaria, de (5,5)10-15(20), cilíndrica o fusiforme; espigas femeninas (1)2-3(4), de (5)10-15(18) mm, ovoides, generalmente agrupadas bajo la masculina o la inferior separada, subsésiles o pedunculadas, erectas o raramente la inferior inclinada pero no colgante. Glumas masculinas estrechamente ovales, agudas o acuminadas, de color pardo claro, sin margen escarioso; glumas femeninas ± ovales, agudas o aristadas, de color pardo claro o verdoso-hialinas, menores que los utrículos. Utrículos 2,5-3,3 × 1-1,5 mm, patentes o erecto-patentes, de contorno oval, irregularmente trígonos, con los nervios poco prominentes, diminutamente punteados de rojo, sin pico o bruscamente estrechados en un diminuto pico hasta de 0,1 mm, entero, truncado, liso. Aquenios (1,7)1,9-2(2,2) × (0,9)1-1,3 mm, de contorno obovado, trígonos, de color pardo obscuro. 2n = 58*, 62*, 64*, 66*.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","7f293beb-b25a-496b-b77b-69f884625fed#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","habitat","<p>Prados húmedos, brezales y bosques caducifolios o de coníferas; 50-2200 m.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","7f293beb-b25a-496b-b77b-69f884625fed#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","habitat","<p> open wet soil in a cool damp climate</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-l-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","5897495b-be6a-41c8-a7cf-1e5c69a80420#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229422","morphology","Plant: sparsely pilose, cespitose, forming low clumps 20-40 (70) cm tall of a few up to 50 erect axillary (aphyllopodic)shoots<br /><br/> Below-ground structures: short rhizomes Vegetative shoots: pseudoculms triangular,to 4 cm tall, 2-3 mm thick; the 5 cataphylls red to reddish brown with pale fibers, becoming brown late, sometimes puberulent;  foliage leaves 2-4,leaves and sheaths similar to those of fertile shoots.  Sheaths green on back, ventral band white-hyaline to red-brown, sometimes finely red-dotted near shoot bases, often torn,  sparsely pilose, apex concave to V-shaped, often torn, densely pilose; ligule acute, glabrous to sparsely pilose. Culms: axillary, erect, culm to 60 cm, often exceeding foliage,  basal diameter about 1-3 mm; 1.0-1.5 mm thick above the leaves, triangular, smooth below, antrorsely scabrous on sharp angles toward apex;  Inflorescence: ascending, 2.5-3.0 cm long, 1.0-1.5 cm wide; the terminal spike erect and short-stalked.   Lowest bract scarcely sheathed (sheath to 1 mm long), or reduced to a V-shaped, red-tinged or -dotted apex, with a few hairs; the cladoprophyll often tinged with red-brown.  Bract foliaceous, scabrous, flat or V-shaped, exceeding inflorescence, or at least base of terminal spike. Leaves: Cataphylls 6-8, dark reddish brown with pale fibers. Leaves 4-5, usually confined to lower third of shoot, the blades 2.5-3.5 mm wide, 10-15 cm long, medium to pale green, erect, M-shaped, irregularly and sparsely; short-pilose abaxially, the hairs reaching 0.5 mm long, most reliably present near plant base; blades scabrous toward apex on margins, sometimes turning yellow or brown by fruiting time; sheaths green on back, ventral band white-hyaline to red-brown, sheath apex deeply V-shaped, more or less thickened, often red-brown or red-dotted, thickly pilose; ligule acute, similar to apex, 2-4 times as high as wide.  Upper culm naked or with one narrow leaf below inflorescence, its sheath to 2 mm long and blade overtopping inflorescence. Pistillate scales: 2.4-2.9 mm long, 1.4-1.6 mm wide, ovate to obovate, acute to abruptly scabrously awned, translucent, green with darker green midrib, becoming pale brown, fringed on margin, as long as perigynia, divergent, persistent. Spikes: Terminal spike 8.9-19.9 mm long, 1.2-2.7 mm thick, linear, triangular, staminate; lateral spikes  2-3 (-4), cylindric, overlapping, 4-11 (-22) mm long, 4-5 (7) mm thick, pistillate, up to 40 spreading perigynia in 5 spiral rows; their scabrous peduncles often half or more as long as spike.<br /><br/> Staminate scales: 2.1-4.5 mm long, 0.8-1.3 mm wide, acute to awned, pale red-brown, similar to the pistillate but stramineous in age and appressed-ascending except for the often spreading tips.     Anthers: 1.6-2.15 mm long, pale red-brown. Perigynia: 2.2-2.8 (-3) mm long, 0.8-1.2 mm thick, glabrous, terete or slightly compressed, ellipsoidal to nearly cylindrical, with rounded ends (shaped like short cucumbers or watermelons), straight or slightly curved outward (dorsad), rather tough, translucent, lustrous, pale yellow-green, sometimes finely red-dotted, gradually paler toward whitish or pale brown base; with 10-20 faint parallel veins running from base to apex; the dark persistent tip of the style often protruding 0.1-0.2 mm beyond and completely filling the slightly raised circular orifice; the pale basal walls of the perigynium not thickened, but delicate and slightly spongy.  In maturity, bluntly triangular as perigynium shrinks around brown achene, one angle lying toward the rachis, often showing through the translucent, still-green perigynium.  In age becoming brown. Achenes: 1.6-2.0 mm long, 1.0-1.2 mm thick, sharply trigonous, faces obovate, slightly convex, apex acute; pale olive green, becoming brown with greener, paler ridges; substipitate, the stipe about 0.08-0.15 mm long; style straight, dehiscent from a base 0.1-0.15 mm long. Stigmas: 3   Elevation: 0-500 m (Ball 2002) Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Elizabeth Zimmerman.<br /><br/>Additional authors: Additional editors on this taxon treatment have, unless otherwise indicated here, made primarily stylistic contributions or relatively minor contributions. <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: Originally written on 29 September 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: From a work in preparation: Zimmerman, J H, and E H Zimmerman, Sedges of Wisconsin, Genus Carex, in prep., and unpublished observations by E.H. Zimmerman.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pallescens-l-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","a4e62d46-f4a4-4851-896b-ab3206a490c1","","5897495b-be6a-41c8-a7cf-1e5c69a80420#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229462","distribution","<p>Europa, Groenlandia, W y C de Asia y N de África; introducida en el NE de Norteamérica. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229462","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos ± largos, a veces laxamente cespitosa. Tallos fértiles (5)20-40(50) cm, lisos, trígonos con los ángulos un poco agudos. Hojas (2,5)3-5(6) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, con el ápice de sección triangular, ásperas en los bordes y nervio medio del envés, algo rígidas, glaucas; lígula hasta 2(3) mm, soldada al limbo, con cuyo haz se confunde; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado, de color pardo claro, enteras o algo fibrosas. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia y mayor o menor que su espiga, con una vaina ± inflada. Espiga(s) masculina(s) 1(2), de 15-20(27) mm, estrechamente obovadas o fusiformes; espigas femeninas (1)2(3), de 10-20 mm, hasta de 30 mm cuando las flores inferiores están separadas del resto, cilíndricas, ± separadas, de casi sésiles a variablemente pedunculadas, excepcionalmente subbasilares, erectas. Glumas masculinas obovadas, obtusas, de color pardo-rojizo claro, con margen escarioso ancho salvo, a veces, en el ápice, donde suele ser más estrecho; glumas femeninas anchamente ovales, agudas, de longitud mucho menor que los utrículos, de color pardo-rojizo obscuro, con margen escarioso o sin él. Utrículos (2,7)3-4(4,7) × 1-1,6(2) mm, suberectos, ± ovoides, inflado-trígonos, muy finamente papilosos, verdosos, de color pardo obscuro o negruzcos, con los nervios muy tenues, ± atenuados en un pico de casi nulo a 0,7 mm, generalmente curvado, de ápice truncado o cortamente bidentado, papiloso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229486","general","<p>Densamente cespitosa, formadora de grandes macollas. Tallos 40-130(150) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos agudos, escábridos entre los 3/4 y 1/4 superior. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229517","morphology","Plant: perennial; rhizomes long creeping.     Inflorescence: 1.5-3 cm long, with 3-7 spikes. <br /><br/> Leaves: shorter than culms at maturity, 1-2.5 mm wide.  Basal sheaths: fibrillose, light brown.<br /><br/> Pistillate scales: dark brown, apex acute, sometimes awned.  Spikes: androgynous, upper spikes staminate, lower spikes pistillate. Staminate scales: dark chestnut, apex acute, sometimes awned. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229539","general","<p>Rhizomes ascending, cordlike, 0.5–1.4 mm in diam. Culms arising singly or, occasionally, 2(–4) together, weakly trigonous, distinctly furrowed, 5–30 cm; lateral sterile shoots conspicuously developed, curved. Leaf blades filiform, 1–9(–12) cm × 0.4–1 mm. Inflorescence a unisexual spike (68% pistillate, 30% staminate) or, rarely, gynecandrous (2%); staminate spikes 8–21 mm; pistillate spikes ± loosely 6–20-flowered, narrowly oblong to ellipsoid, 7–17 × 3–6 mm. Pistillate scales with margins yellowish, broad, scarious (almost hyaline), almost 1/2 width of central dark brown portion. Perigynia appressed to weakly spreading, reddish brown, 13–18-striate and 2-ribbed, ovate to oblong-ovate, plano-convex, 2.8–3.5 × 1–1.3 mm; beak 0.7–1 mm, margins glabrous. Achenes 1.6–2 × 0.9–1.3 mm. 2n = 43.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-parallela-subsp-parallela-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-physoglochin-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","17a39636-2fc3-40c7-8af5-44cf1696bec3#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229546","general","<p>Plants loosely cespitose. Culms 10–35 cm, distally scabrous. Leaves 2–4 mm wide. Inflorescences: proximal bracts shorter than or exceeding inflorescences; spikes erect, separate, proximal spikes occasionally distant, pedunculate, short-oblong or cylindric, 5–20 × 2–3 mm; lateral 2–5 spikes pistillate, distalmost often reduced to 1–3 perigynia, of varying lengths, proximal 1 or more as long as the terminal spike; terminal spike pistillate, gynecandrous (proportion of pistillate to staminate flowers variable, as few as 2 or 3 perigynia at summit), or wholly staminate. Pistillate scales light to dark brown, distal margins broadly hyaline, ovate, as long and as wide as perigynia, midvein lighter colored than body, conspicuous, often raised, prominent, distally scabrous, apex rounded, acute or mucronate. Perigynia ascending, greenish yellow or brown, veinless, elliptic, 2–2.5 × 1–1.5 mm, apex abruptly beaked, papillose; beak to 0.2 mm, truncate or obscurely bidentate, serrulate. Achenes nearly filling body of perigynia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-parryana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-racemosae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","cb6f2b78-d8b5-4130-aef4-f4da18c8870e#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229557","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, con rizoma de entrenudos cortos. Tallos (3,5)5-20(60) cm, agudamente trígonos, escábridos hacia el ápice, más raramente lisos, densamente papilosos. Hojas (1,5)2,5-4(4,5) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes de la zona superior, planas, muy papilosas, glaucas, no muy rígidas; lígula hasta 1,5 mm, de ápice obtuso, redondeado o truncado; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, ± enteras o algo fibrosas, de color pardo-rojizo o pardo-púrpura obscuro. Bráctea inferior foliácea, raramente setácea, de longitud mayor o menor que la inflorescencia, no o cortamente envainante. Espigas 3-5, de 5-11(16) mm, sésiles o casi, erectas, ovoides, solapadas, la superior ginecandra, en ocasiones masculina, el resto femeninas, densifloras. Glumas ovales, ± agudas, negras, sin margen escarioso, papilosas, de longitud mayor o menor que los utrículos. Estigmas 3. Utrículos 2,3-3,2 × (0,7)1-1,9 mm, suberectos, planoconvexos o ligeramente trígonos, comprimidos, de contorno oval a suborbicular, con los nervios poco o nada perceptibles, glabros, muy densamente papilosos, negros o raramente de color pardo-rojizo, con la base y los bordes superiores verdosos, estrechados en un pico de 0,1-0,3 mm, de ápice muy cortamente bidentado, papiloso, en ocasiones con acúleos dispersos. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229568","conservation","<p>C. pauciflora is protected in Northern Ireland under Schedule 8 of the Wildlife Order (Northern Ireland) 1985.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pauciflora-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","13722ca4-2eff-400f-a6d2-68b458df2a7c#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229568","diagnostic","<p>C. pauciflora, because of its persistent style, may be confused with C. microglochin with its bristle or rachilla; for differences see that species. It may initially also appear similar to C. pulicaris, although in the field their ecological preferences are distinctive. C. pulicaris is always easily distinguished by the fine red-brown roots (only a rooting shoot needs to be lifted to see this) and the darker brown ellipsoid utricles which lack the persistent style or c. pauciflora. C. dioica is vegetatively similar but has a narrower, channelled and inrolled leaf with only three veins. No hybrids of C. pauciflora are known.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pauciflora-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","13722ca4-2eff-400f-a6d2-68b458df2a7c#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229568","distribution","<p>Carex pauciflora is found throughout the Highlands and N Scotland and is scattered in the Outer Isle; in England, in the Lake District and Pennines, with one isolated locality in v.c. 62; in Wales, only in v.cc. 47 and 49. In Ireland, only in Antrim and Co. Down.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pauciflora-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","13722ca4-2eff-400f-a6d2-68b458df2a7c#distribution"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229568","ecology","<p>C. pauciflora is a species of oligotrophic bogs characterised by Sphagnum cuspidatum/fallax bog-pool communities (M2), growing in the Sphagnum with Andromeda polifolia, Drosera spp., Eriophorum angustifolium, Narthecium ossifragum, Rhynchospora alba and the dwarf shrubs Colluna vulgaris, Erica tetralix, Vaccinium oxycoccus etc. Lowland to 820 m (Foley & Porter 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pauciflora-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","13722ca4-2eff-400f-a6d2-68b458df2a7c#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229568","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> slender, shortly creeping, often much branched, forming an open mat; shoots loosely tufted; roots cream or pale yellow-brown; scales pale (rarely dark) brown, striate, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 7-27 cm, stiff, trigonous, often curved, solid. <i>Leaves </i> up to 20 cm × 1-2 mm, with c. 9 veins, stiff, thick, ± channelled, mid green, gradually narrowed to a wide, rounded apex, those of sterile shoots often narrower and setaceous; hypostomous; sheaths pink-(rarely red-) brown, persistent, the lower ones with very short subulate green tips, with inner face hyaline; apex straight; ligule c. 0.5 mm, rounded, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, few-flowered, terminal spike 3-8 mm, male above, female below; bracts absent. Male glumes 3.5-5 mm, lanceolate, pale red-brown, with hyaline margins; apex ± acute. Female glumes 3.5-4.5 mm, broadly lanceolate, clasping the utricle, caducous, pale red-brown, with margins hyaline towards the ± acute apex. <i>Utricles</i>  5-7 mm, subfusiform, tapered more abruptly below, faintly nerved, pale yellow-or rarely red-brown, tapered above to a beak-like apex; stigmas 3; style persistent in fruit, protruding from apex of utricle; nut oblong-cylindric, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pauciflora-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","13722ca4-2eff-400f-a6d2-68b458df2a7c#general"

Basal sheaths: pale brown.  Pistillate scales: pale brown, apex obtuse or acute, caducous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229576","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.   Culms: 15-30 cm tall.  Leaves: 2-3 mm wide, stiff. Basal sheaths: brown. Bracts: leaf-like with short sheaths Pistillate scales: brown, apex acuminate or shortly aristate. Spikes: terminal spikes staminate, subsessile, linear cylindrical, 0.5-1 cm long, brown; lateral spikes pistillate, crowded, subsessile, shortly cylindrical, 1-1.5 cm long, lowest spikes often at base of culm, long pedunculate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229583","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose.    Inflorescence: racemose.  Leaves: 1.5-3 mm wide. Basal sheaths: pale, fibrillose. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229606","distribution","<p>Die Unterart rhizodes ist folgendermaßen verbreitet: Südfinnland, Schweden (Jämtland, Uppland), Südnorwegen, östliches Mitteleuropa, Polen, Slowakei, Rußland, Westsibirien. - Die Unterart pediformis von Rußland durch Sibirien bis Ostasien. Andere verwandte Sippen in Sibirien, Zentral- und Ostasien. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. Carex pedijormis ssp. rhizodes kommt nur im östlichsten Teil Mitteleuropas vor (Schlesien, Böhmen, Mähren, Oberösterreich ?, Südtirol ?). In Deutschland nur in Schlesien an der Schwedenschanze (Tatarenschanze) bei Pristram unweit Nimptsch, auf Gneis.- In Böhmen am Rollberg [Ralsko] bei Niemes [Mimon], bei Sebusein [Sebuzin], um Smecno, zwischen Perutz [Peruc] und Chrastin, bei Rentsch [Rencov] im Kaliwodertal, Hrebeny, Konopiste, Zvikov, Vedamov na Otave.- In Mähren in den tiefen Flußtälern der böhmisch-mährischen Höhe, von Bitov und Vranov an der Thaya [Dyje] bis Losehitz [Lostice] bei Olmütz [Olomouc] und Lisen bei Brünn [Brno]. Verbreitungskarten für Böhmen und Mähren bei SUZA (1948) und PODPERA (1928, S. 306 und 308). Sehr zweifelhaft ist das Vorkommen in Österreich (Oberösterreich: Neuhaus an der Donau).- In Südtirol (Castello d'Andraz) wohl nicht mehr.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pediformis-subsp-rhizodes-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","12d72f4a-cb31-472d-81ea-c27b87955ce1#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229606","general","<p>Ausdauernde, dichte, zuwei len ziemlich große Rasen bildende Pflanze. Wurzelstock kräftig, 10-20 cm lang, dick, kriechend und reich verzweigt, dicht mit schwarzbraunen, faserigen Blattscheidenresten besetzt. Stengel zahlreich, schlank, aufrecht oder gebogen, ziemlich sch laff, (15-)30-50(-60) cm hoch, etwa 1 mm dick, dreikantig, fast bis zum Grunde rauh, nur am Grunde beblättert. Grundständige Blattscheiden purpurfarbig bis rotbraun, in netzige Fasern aufgelöst. Blätter ziemlich schlaff, flach, so lang wie der Stengel bis länger als dieser, 2-3 mm breit, an den Rändern scharf rauh, allmählich zugespitzt, hellgrün bis dunkelgrün. Hüllblätter der weiblichen Ährchen pfrieml ich-laubblattartig, bis 2,5 cm lang. Blütenstand aus einem endständigen männlichen Ährchen (welches meist von dem oberen weiblichen Ährchen überragt wird) und 2-3(-4) meist voneinander entfernten, seitlichen weiblichen Ährchen bestehend. Weibliche Ährchen bis 5 cm lang gestielt, linealisch, später fast nickend, 15-30 mm lang, 2-4 mm breit, lockerblütig, 10-15-blütig. Männl iches Ährchen sitzend oder kurz gestielt, schmal lanzettlich, 6-20 mm lang. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten lanzettlich bis eiförmig, spitz, etwa so lang wie die Schläuche, 4-5 mm lang, glänzend rotbraun, oberwärts mit weißhäutigen Rändern, mit grünem Mittelstreifen. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten verkehrt eiförmig, stumpf, vorn mit gezähneltem Hautrand, heller als die der weiblichen Blüten. Schläuche schmal, verkehrt eiförmig, stumpf dreikantig bis fast rundlich, mit konvexen Seitenflächen, deutlich gestielt, oberwärts in einen kurzen Schnabel verschmälert, 3,5-4 mm lang, undeutlich nervig bis nervenlos, dicht kurzhaarig, grün. Narben 3. Frucht stumpf dreikantig, 3 mm lang, hellbraun.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pediformis-subsp-rhizodes-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","12d72f4a-cb31-472d-81ea-c27b87955ce1#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229622","general","<p>Densamente cespitosa, con rizoma muy robusto. Tallos fértiles (40)60-150(230) cm, lisos o un poco ásperos hacia el ápice, agudamente trígonos. Hojas 8-16(19) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, plegadas, muy ásperas en los bordes, ± rígidas, de envés algo glauco; lígula hasta 75 mm, de ápice agudo o subagudo; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, de color pardo obscuro, pardo púrpura obscuro o rojizo, enteras. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de longitud poco menor que la inflorescencia, largamente envainante. Espiga masculina solitaria, raramente 2, de 80-160 mm, cilíndrica; espigas femeninas (2)3-5(7), de (60)100-210 mm, cilíndricas, muy densas, separadas, la superior en ocasiones andrógina o excepcionalmente todas andróginas, muy largamente pedunculadas, colgantes. Glumas masculinas lineares, oblongas o estrechamente obovadas, agudas, pardo-rojizas; glumas femeninas estrechamente ovales, aristadas o mucronadas, generalmente de longitud menor que los utrículos, de color pardo-rojizo obscuro, sin margen escarioso. Utrículos (2,3)2,8-3,2 × 1-1,3 mm, erecto-patentes o patentes, ovoides, trígonos, verdosos o parduscos, frecuentemente punteados de rojo, con solo 2 nervios prominentes, aunque en ocasiones se hace visible alguno más, bruscamente estrechados en un pico de 0,4-0,5 mm, truncado con los bordes rotos, liso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229671","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with shortly creeping rhizomes.    Culms: 15-25 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.  Leaves: 1.5-2.5 mm wide. Basal sheaths: brown. Bracts: setaceous, with short sheaths. Pistillate scales: brown, apex acute or shortly aristate.<br /><br/> Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear, 1-1.5 cm long, with short peduncles; lateral spikes pistillate, linear cylindrical, 0.5-1 cm long, with short peduncles. Staminate scales: brown, apex obtuse.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ellipsoidal, 3.8-4 mm long, glabrous, very long beaks, 1.5-1.7 mm wide, margins of beaks serrulate, mouth slightly bidentate. Achenes: lightly enveloped by perigynium, narrowly ovoid, 2-2.2 mm long, style base annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229766","diagnostic","<p>C. pilulifera varies in length of bracts and female glumes. It is distinguished from both C. caryophyllea and C. ericetorum by its tufted habit, reddish sheaths, dull, arcuate leaves and wiry, often incurved stems. The closely related C. montana, also tufted and with wiry stems, differs in its more obviously creeping rhizome, softer (not rough) leaves and purple-brown glumes. Further, C. pilulifera is a plant of more acid soils than any of the other species. Carex pilulifera hybridises with C. caryophyllea, C. ericetorum and C. montana but these hybrids have not been recorded for Britain or Ireland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pilulifera-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b2b09335-36ab-46bd-a22c-9157e610c50f#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229766","distribution","<p>Carex pilulifera is found throughout Britain but is more frequent in acid, sandy regions in N England and common in the hill country of Wales and Scotland, where it ascends to 1140 m (Porter & Foley 2002). In Ireland it is less frequent in the centre.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pilulifera-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b2b09335-36ab-46bd-a22c-9157e610c50f#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229766","ecology","<p>C. pilulifera is a plant of leached, skeletal, sandy, loamy or peaty soils with a low base content and a pH range usually between 4.5 and 6.0. It is found on various Festuca-Agrostis grasslands (CG10, CG11, CG12), in Nardus-Galium saxatile pasture (U5) and with C. bigelowii (U7, U10); also in lowland calcifugous grasslands (U3), open Calluna-moss/lichen heaths (H12-17) and the Alchemilla alpina-C. pilulifera sub-community of H18, often taking advantage of heath-fires to re-establish itself and spread.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pilulifera-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b2b09335-36ab-46bd-a22c-9157e610c50f#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229766","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots densely tufted, often decumbent; roots purple-brown; scales brown, soon becoming fibrous. <i>Stems </i> 8-30 cm, ± rough above, wiry, sharply trigonous below spike, often arcuate and elongating in fruit. <i>Leaves </i> 5-20 cm × 1.5-2 mm, rough above, ± flat, papillose on upper surface, ± abruptly tapered to a short trigonous point, dull , yellow-green or mid green, pink-brown and persistent on decay, overwintering; hypostomous; sheaths pale red-brown or wine-red, becoming fibrous, with inner face hyaline; apex straight; ligule 0.5-1 mm, rounded, with free margin minutely fimbriate. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1-4 cm; spikes clustered; bracts leaf-like or the upper setaceous, rarely exceeding inflorescence, the lowest not sheathing. Male spike1, (6-)8-15 mm; male glumes 3.5-4 mm, oblanceolate-elliptic, brown or chestnut, hyaline towards margin; with pale midrib; apex acute to acuminate. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-4, 4-8 mm, ovoid or subglobose, erect, sessile; female glumes 3-3.5 mm, broadly ovate, red-brown, hyaline towards margin; midrib green, becoming yellow; apex acute. <i>Utricles</i>  2-3.5 mm, obovoid-ellipsoid, downy at least at apex, deep green; beak 0.3-0.5 mm, notched; stigmas 3; nut obovoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-pilulifera-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b2b09335-36ab-46bd-a22c-9157e610c50f#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229802","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.   Culms: 30-70 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.  Leaves: 3-6 mm wide. Basal sheaths: dark brown, fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like, with long sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale green, midrib light green, apex acuminate or aristate. Spikes: terminal spike slaminate or gynecandrous, linear to clavate, 2-5 cm long, green or rusty brown; lateral spikes pistillate, rarely gynecandrous, with short staminale parts, pedunculate, cylindrical, 2-5 cm long, densely flowered.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, oblong ovoid, 7 mm long, fine veined, glabrous, base cuneate or shortly stipitate, long beaked, margins scabrous, mouth bidentate. Achenes: rather tightly enveloped by perigynium, ovoid, 2 mm long, base shortly stipitate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:229813","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with long creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 10-20 cm tall, much longer than<br /><br/>leaves. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230022","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, con rizoma muy robusto de entrenudos algo largos. Tallos fértiles (30)40-80(100) cm, escábridos en la zona superior, trígonos. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230216","habitat","<p>Carex randalpina kommt in den randalpinen Tälern zwischen Lechtal und Ybbstal vor und steigt am Lunzer See bis ca. 600 m bzw. bei Brixen in Tirol bis ca. 790-850 m auf. Vom oberen Lechtal liegen mir keine Belege vor, doch laut Dr. A. Polatschek (Wien) gibt es von dort eine Angabe von Neumann, die wahrscheinlich richtig ist, da flußabwärts die Hybriden gesammelt wurden. C. randalpina folgt dann wohl herabgeschwemmt den Talsystemen bis ins Alpenvorland und tritt in den donaunahen Unterläufen der Flüsse offenbar stark bzw. gänzlich zurück. Die schönsten und typischsten Populationen von C. randalpina wachsen nach meinen Beobachtungen in jenen randalpinen Tälern, in denen C. gracilis offenbar aus klimatischen Griinden fehlt. Diese Gebiete sind wegen der Steigungsregen sehr niederschlagsreich und zeichnen sich durch kühle Sommer und milde Winter aus. C. randalpina scheint auch höhere Luftfeuchtigkeit zu lieben und dürfte deshalb in der Umgebung der randalpinen Seen gehäuft vorkommen. C. gracilis ist hingegen eine wärmeliebende Tieflandpflanze und dürfte in diesen Bereichen völlig oder weitgehend fehlen. Am Westufer des Attersees scheinen zum Beispiel beide Arten trotz günstiger Biotope im Abschnitt zwischen dem Nordufer und Stockwink.l zu fehlen. Erst von Stockwink! an nach Süden konnte C. randalpina beobachtet werden.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-randalpina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/die-entdeckungsgeschichte-von-c-randalpina-b-walln%C3%B6fer-spec-nov-c-oenensis-und-deren","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","72a64ff8-da0e-437a-9c3b-96b37bffae43#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230231","diagnostic","<p>In Britain C. rariflora is separated from its two allies C. limosa and C. magellanica by the different altitudes that they normally inhabit as well as by its form (fewer flowers on the spike and much smaller size). The species hybridises with both C. limosa and C. magellanica but neither hybrid has been recorded from Britain.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rariflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b0a82406-4f1a-4da3-bf05-d56b6b96dd81#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230231","distribution","<p>Carex rariflora, which is found in the E Central Highlands but also occurs very rarely in Breadalbane, is confined to high tablelands where snow lies late. See also David (1980b). A record from South Uist (Heslop Harrison 1945) has been shown to be unsubstantiated (J.E. Raven in Preston 2004).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rariflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b0a82406-4f1a-4da3-bf05-d56b6b96dd81#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230231","ecology","<p>A rare and local sedge forming a characteristic association with C. canescens, C. echinata, C. bigelowii, C. aquatilis, Sphagnum papillosum, S. russowii and Viola palustris (M7) on wet slopes of oligotrophic peat, or, more often, on a fixed bank of silt in the headwaters of a mountain stream just before the gradient steepens (David l980b). Found between 790 and 1125 m, the latter height on Ben Macdui, v.c. 94 (Porter & Foley 2002). It is very shy-flowering in some seasons, and this may have concealed its presence, and certainly its abundance, in a number of localities.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rariflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b0a82406-4f1a-4da3-bf05-d56b6b96dd81#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230231","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping, often producing a close carpet of single shoots; roots yellow, felted; scale red-brown. <i>Stems </i> up to 20 cm, mostly smooth, trigonous, ± solid. <i>Leaves </i> up to 15 cm × I 2 mm, with c. 9 veins, glaucous to grey-green, deeply keeled, often strongly incurved at the tip; hypostomous; sheaths becoming fibrous, with inner face hyaline, turning brown; apex concave; ligule c. 2 mm, obtuse, with free margin c. 1 mm. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/3-1/5( -1/9) length of stem; lower bracts narrow, 8-12 mm, shorter than inflorescence, with sheath up to 5 mm. Male spike 1, 8 12 mm; male glumes c. 4 mm, oblong-ovate, dark brown, with apex obtuse, mucronate. <i>Female spikes</i>  usually 2, rarely 3, with up to 8 flowers; female glumes 3-4 mm, dark purple or chocolate-brown, oblong-ovate, with apex obtuse, mucronate. <i>Utricles</i>  3-4.5 mm, ellipsoid, narrower and shorter than female glumes, strongly ribbed, markedly tapered at either end; stigmas 3; nut ellipsoid, trigonous, stalked.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rariflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b0a82406-4f1a-4da3-bf05-d56b6b96dd81#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230249","conservation","<p>Carex recta is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Vulnerable (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-recta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","10b3f09e-e919-477e-8061-81194870108d#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230249","diagnostic","<p>A fertile taxon probably best thought of as a 'stabilised hybrid' , showing a morphology and ecology intermediate between two closely related species, C. aquatilis (with which it often grows and back-crosses) and C. paleacea, a taxon not yet found in Britain or Ireland. It is distinct in usually having aristate glumes in the lower florets of each female spike, the lower of which are distinctly pedunculate and often pendulous (both C. paleacea characters). C. recta lacks the glaucous upper surface of the leave seen in C. aquatilis and its stem is not so bluntly trigonous nor is it brittle. C. acuta is somewhat similar but has a sharper triquetrous stem and is a southern species.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-recta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","10b3f09e-e919-477e-8061-81194870108d#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230249","distribution","<p>Carex recta is a very local species of estuarine or lower riverine localities in NE Scotland (Eastererness, E Ross, E Sutherland and Caithness).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-recta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","10b3f09e-e919-477e-8061-81194870108d#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230249","ecology","<p>C. recta often forms extensive colonic in stiff peaty alluvium or in more sandy situations, but usually where silt is periodically deposited or the water-table fluctuates seasonally. Often dominant with Phragmites, Phalaris arundinacea and other grasses in species-rich sedge communities of tall-herb fen (S27), with C. rostrata, C. aquatilis, C. nigra and Juncus acutiflorus.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-recta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","10b3f09e-e919-477e-8061-81194870108d#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230249","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> often far-creeping; shoots tufted; root pale purple-brown; scales red-brown, often blackened, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 30-100 cm, tiff, trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> up to 130 cm × 3-7 mm, mid green to yellow-green,± flat or weakly keeled, rough on upper surface, on margins and on keel beneath, lower culm leaves and those of sterile shoots gradually tapering to a flat, tiff point; amphistomous; sheaths herbaceous, becoming brown or tinged wine-red, persistent, with transverse septa distinct and inner face hyaline, ± persistent; ligule 2-4 mm, obtuse, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/6 to 1/3 length of stem; bracts leaf-like with purplish auricles, at least the lower exceeding inflorescence. <i>Male spikes</i>  1 (2 5) 6, I 0-45 mm, lower pedunculate; male glumes 4-6 mm, oblanceolate-elliptic, hyaline at margins; apex obtuse. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-6, 20-80 mm, contiguous or ± overlapping, lax-flowered at base, cylindric, upper often male at top; peduncles 0 35 mm, rough; female glumes 3-7 mm, ovate-lanceolate, brown to red-brown; apex acute or acuminate, usually aristate in lower floret. <i>Utricles</i>  2-3.5 mm, obovate or suborbicular, green, nerveless or faintly nerved; beak c. 0.2 mm, truncate; stigmas 2; nut orbicular or obovate, usually strongly indented on one face, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-recta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","10b3f09e-e919-477e-8061-81194870108d#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230277","distribution","<p>Niederlande, Belgien, Frankreich, Deutschland. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. Nur an wenigen Stellen in Nord- und Mitteldeutschland.- Schleswig-Holstein: Geesthacht-Tesperhude. In Brandenburg bei Küstrin und Zorndorf, bei Cottbus (an der Spree bei Frauendorf) und im Fläming (an der Landstraße von Wiesenburg nach Medewitz, Forsthaus Golmenglin). Sachsen-Anhalt: Im Fläming westlich Griebo und zwischen Nudersdorf und Straach. In Sachsen in der Dübener Heide, Dresdener Heide (Prießnitzgrund), in der Laußnitzer Heide (Königsbrück), in der Nähe der Dörfer Kmehlen und Naundörfel bei Grossenhain, Hoyerswerda, Ruhland, Bautzen, Löbau. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230277","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze, in dichten, ausgedehnten Beständen wachsend. Wurzelstock lang kriechend, 1,5-2 mm dick, mit hellbraunen, faserig aufgelösten Niederblättern bedeckt. Stengel anfangs aufrecht, später bogenförmig gekrümmt, zierlich, 30-50 (-9) cm hoch, 1 mm dick, scharf dreikantig, oberwärts rauh, am Grunde von hellbraunen Blattscheiden umgeben. Blätter flach, 2-3 mm breit, an den Rändern und am Rücken rauh, das unterste sehr kurz und plötzlich in die Spitze verschmälert, die oberen länger, das oberste sehr lang und schlaff, überhängend, allmählich in die Spitze verschmälert, länger als der Stengel, freudiggrün. Blütenstand eine längliche, 3-5 cm lange Ähre, oft mit einem borstigen Hüllblatt. Ährchen 5-12, eiförmig, entweder alle androgyn (am Grunde männlich) oder die oberen im obersten Teil oder ganz männlich, die oberen dicht., die unteren locker angeordnet. Spelzen lanzettlich eiförmig, zugespitzt, etwa 4 mm lang, strohfarbig oder bleich rostfarbig, grün gekielt, mit durchscheinendem Saum. Schläuche etwas länger als die Spelzen, etwa 5 mm lang, zuletzt sparrig abstehend, lanzettlich, plankonvex, kurz gestielt, kahl, beiderseits mehrnervig, am Grunde abgerundet, schwammig, ziemlich allmählich in den langen, zweizähnigen, zuletzt etwas gekrümmten Schnabel verschmälert, an den Rändern mit einem mäßig breiten, unregelmäßig gezähnten grünen Flügelsaum von unterhalb der Mitte bis zur Spitze, hellgrün. Narben 2. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230346","general","<p>Plants 250–605 mm tall, usually but not always caespitose. Rhizomes usually very short, sometimes long, 3 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow- or mid-green, glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face tearing into membranous strips. Largest basal leaf blade 300–480 × 3–7 mm, flat or plicate in cross-section; adaxial and abaxial surfaces glabrous; margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, membranous; ligule 7–11 mm high, fuscous, membranous, apex acute. Culms sharply triangular in cross-section, 2 mm in diameter; uppermost internode very long, the lower all more-or-less basal, very short, concealed by leaf sheaths. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 50–310 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheath 3 mm long; blade 150–380 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 4–6, pendulous, not clustered, excepting frequently apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 25–70 × 7–11 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 20–150 mm, scabrid on angles. Apical spikes usually staminate, occasionally androgynecandrous. Staminate spikes 0–1. Pistillate spikes 3–5. Bisexual spikes 0–1. Small accessory spikes not present. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.5 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate, 4.5–6.5 × 0.8–1.2 mm, longer and narrower than perigynium, stramineous, wholly glabrous or ciliate distally on margin; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex obtuse or emarginate, awned; awn 2.0–4.2 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 3–4 mm × 1.5–1.8 mm, narrowly elliptic in cross-section, slightly inflated, mid-brown, or ferruginous with rostrum whitish, base without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, papillate, with solid papillae, inconspicuously nerved; rostrum abrupt, 0.3–0.5 mm long, straight, margin not winged, glabrous; rostrum apex truncate. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base straight; stigmas 2. Mature nutlet obovate, not clawed, 1.9–2.2 1 1.0–1.7 mm, narrowly elliptic in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rhodesiaca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","7fe00077-b61f-418d-84e1-571b99b5f571#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230353","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze. Wurzelstock kräftig, Ausläufer treibend. Stengel kräftig, aufrecht, scharf dreikantig, etwa so lang wie die Blätter oder etwas kürzer, 60-10(-120) cm hoch, bis 3 mm dick (am Grunde noch dicker), oberwärts rauh, beblättert. Grundständige Blattscheiden mit Spreiten, gelb bis graubraun, rötlich überlaufen, gegittert. Blätter flach, etwas steif, sehr breit, 8-15 mm breit, an den Rändern rauh, sehr stark gegittert, dunkelgrün, glasartig brechend. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes laubblattartig, sehr breit, die untersten meist den Blütenstand überragend, kaum scheidig. Blütenstand bis über 20 cm lang, aus 3-7 männlichen und 2-4 darunter stehenden weiblichen Ährchen bestehend; alle Ährchen etwas voneinander entfernt, das unterste zuweilen weiter abgerückt. Weibliche Ährchen sitzend oder fast sitzend, das unterste kurz gestielt, aufrecht, seltener fast nickend, dick, zylindrisch, 50-70(-80) mm lang, bis 10(-12) mm breit, dichtblütig. Männliche Ährchen am Grunde oft mit einigen weiblichen Blüten, linealisch, 30-60 mm lang, 2-3 mm breit. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten länglich lanzettlich, spitz, kürzer als die Schläuche, rostfarben bis kastanienbraun, mit grünem Mittelstreifen und weißhäutigen Rändern. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten eiförmig, stumpf, braun, oberwärts mit weißhäutigen Rändern. Schläuche gerade abstehend, verkehrt eiförmig bis fast kugelig, stark rundlich-aufgeblasen, oberwärts ziemlich plötzlich in einen langen, dünnen, glatten, zweizähnigen Schnabel verschmälert (Schnabelzähne etwas spreizend), 5-6 mm lang, mit mehreren Längsnerven, kahl, gelbgrün, glänzend. Narben 3. Frucht länglich eiförmig, unter 3 mm lang.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rhynchophysa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","c137b5cc-22d2-4f01-bf31-73cbe71f1fdd#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230353","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with slender creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 20-40 cm tall.  Leaves: 4-10 mm wide, slightly soft. Basal sheaths: whitish brown. Bracts: setaceous, with sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale green, apex acute or shortly awned. Spikes: terminal spike staminale, linear, 1-2.5 cm long, pale green: lateral spikes pistillate, pedunculate, linear cylindrical, 1.5-2.5 cm long, loosely flowered. Staminate scales: pale green, apex acute.      Perigynia: as long as pistillate scales, ellipsoidal. 3-3.5 mm long, puberulent, mouth slightly bidentate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, narrowly obovoid, 2 mm long, style base minutely annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230400","general","<p>Loosely cespitose sedge with short creeping rhizome. Roots grayish or with yellow tomentum. Shoot bases with reddish-brown leaf sheaths. Leaves light green, 1/4 shorter than stems, more or less flat, narrowly acuminate, 2-3 mm broad. Stem 20-45 cm, slender, trigonous, scabrous above or almost smooth. Inflorescence with few not very distant spikelets; upper one staminate, dark cinnamon, on 0.5-1 cm long stalk; rest (2-3) pistillate, strict, rather lax, narrowly cylindrical (1-3 cm long, about 0.3 mm diam.). Lower spikelet on 1-1.5 cm long stalk with bract as long as spikelet or longer. Perigynium bi- or planoconvex, 2.3-3 mm long, without nerves, greenish or sometimes brownish above, with highly conspicuous short undivided beak. Glume dark brown almost throughout, narrowly ovate, subobtuse, as long as perigynium or slightly shorter.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rigidioides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-9","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8ad21579-d0df-424e-9ad6-941c6ae6f5f5#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230403","general","<p>Densely caespitose with very short rhizomes and slender resilient trigonous stems (14-)20-27(-35) cm high, scabrous above the margins, after flowering lie down on the leaves cover. Basal sheaths purplish becoming fibrous. Basal leaves (7-)13-23(-36) cm long, (1.0-)1.6-1.9(-2.5) mm wide, pale green, peristent, setaceous-scabrid on margins with ligules (0.2-)0.5-0.8(-1.2) mm long. Inflorescence (1.5-)1.9-2.5(-3.3) cm long with 1 male spike above and 1-3 female spikes below. Male spike (1.0-)1.7-1.8(-2.4) cm long, peduncle only (0.1-)0.26-0.44(-1.0) cm long. Female spikes sessile or subsessile, overlapping or the lowest remote, (0.5-)0.60-0.63(-0.9) cm long with (l-)5-9(-12) flowers. Male glume (3.8-)4.3-4.9(-6.0) mm long, (1.4-)1.50-1.64(-2.5) mm wide, acuminate, glabrous, dark brown to dark purplish brown with pale midline and scarious margin. Female glume longer than utricle (3.0-)3.40-3.65(-4.5) mm long, (1.6-)1.8-1.0(-2.2) mm wide, acuminate, brown to dark purplish brown with pale midline and scarious margin. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230409","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, con rizoma muy robusto, con algunos entrenudos largos. Tallos fértiles 40-100(150) cm, escábridos en la zona superior, agudamente trígonos. Hojas (4)7-10(19,5) mm de anchura, generalmente de longitud similar a la de los tallos, planas o plegadas, muy ásperas en los bordes y en el nervio medio del envés, ± rígidas; lígula 5-12 mm, de ápice obtuso, con los bordes libres, a veces algo levantados; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrolado, solo las más inferiores escuamiformes, de color pardo, enteras. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de mayor longitud que la inflorescencia, rara vez menor, no envainante o con una vaina hasta de 10 mm. Espigas masculinas 2-4(6), de (9)20-40(60) mm, anchamente cilíndricas o fusiformes, a veces la inferior con algunos utrículos en la base; espigas femeninas 2-5(7), de (23)30-70(110) mm, a veces la superior andrógina, cilíndricas, densifloras, distantes, erectas o la inferior con un largo pedúnculo y colgante. Glumas masculinas estrechamente ovales, mucronadas o aristadas, de color pardo ± obscuro, sin margen escarioso; glumas femeninas de lanceolado-oblongas a estrechamente ovales, aristadas o mucronadas, generalmente de longitud mayor –en ocasiones algo menor– que los utrículos, de color pardo-rojizo o pardo-púrpura obscuro, sin margen escarioso, con tres nervios bien marcados. Utrículos (3)4-5(6) × (1)1,5-2(2,9) mm, suberectos, de contorno oval, inflados, no papilosos, brillantes, verdosos o parduscos, con los nervios bien marcados, en ocasiones muy prominentes, gradualmente atenuados en un pico de 0,4-0,9(1,1) mm, cortamente bífido, con el sinus anchamente redondeado, liso. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230448","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos largos, delgados, cubiertos por escamas enteras, aunque a veces cuando crece en hábitats como repisas o grietas de rocas se acortan los entrenudos y se hace cespitosa. Hojas (0,1)0,3-1 mm de anchura, planas o canaliculadas, algo rígidas, ásperas en los bordes y en el haz, que es papilosa; lígula diminuta, con ápice ± redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado aunque las más inferiores son escuamiformes, enteras o algo rotas, de color pardo obscuro. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230459","distribution","<p>Alta., B.C., Man., N.W.T., Ont., Sask., Yukon; Alaska, Ariz., Calif., Colo., Idaho, Mich., Minn., Mont., Nebr., Nev., N.Mex., Oreg., S.Dak., Utah, Wash., Wyo.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rossii-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","10aa3bb7-f7d8-4f76-95fb-c00a8a23ceda","","c83b0491-a9d1-47d1-9187-9d7f8f67e0de#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230459","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose; rhizomes usually ascending, occasionally horizontally spreading, dark reddish brown to purplish brown, 0–10 mm, stout. Culms ascending, 7–30(–40) cm, weakly to strongly scabrous distally; bases (remnants of old leaves) slightly fibrous. Leaf blades pale to dark green, usually equaling or exceeding stems, occasionally shorter, 0.8–2.5(–4) mm wide, herbaceous, glabrous abaxially, strongly scabrous to papillose adaxially. Inflorescences with both staminate and pistillate spikes; peduncles of basal pistillate spikes erect, elongate, slender; peduncles of staminate spikes 1.1–10 mm; proximal nonbasal bracts leaflike, exceeding inflorescences. Spikes: proximal pistillate spikes 2–4 (basal spikes 1–2); cauline spikes overlapping or somewhat separated, with 3–10(–15) perigynia; staminate spikes (4.8–)6–12.8 × (0.7–) 0.9–1.3(–2.5) mm. Scales: pistillate scales pale to dark reddish brown, with narrow white margins, ovate, 2.9–5.7 × 1.4–2.3 mm, shorter than perigynia, apex acute or acuminate to long-acuminate; staminate scales lanceolate, 3.2–5.8 × 1.2–1.8 mm, apex acuminate. Anthers 1.2–2 mm. Perigynia green to pale brown, veinless, ellipsoid to obovoid, 3.1–4.5 × 1.4–1.7 mm; beak straight or slightly bent, pale green, occasionally with reddish brown tinge, 0.9–1.7 mm, ciliate-serrulate, apical teeth 0.2–0.4 mm. Stigmas 3. Achenes brown, globose to obovoid or ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous in cross section, 1.9–2.4 × 1.3–1.7 mm. 2n = 36.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rossii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-acrocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c1d95347-745a-41b2-80f2-70bfb80380b1#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230459","habitat","<p>Moist or dry, sandy or rocky, open montane pine, fir, and spruce woodlands, sagebrush slopes, deciduous wooded slopes, prairies, alpine meadows</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-rossii-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","10aa3bb7-f7d8-4f76-95fb-c00a8a23ceda","","c83b0491-a9d1-47d1-9187-9d7f8f67e0de#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230459","morphology","Plant: Densely cespitose. Below-ground structures: Rhizomes usually ascending, occasionally horizontally spreading, dark reddish brown to purplish brown, 0–10 mm, stout.  Culms: Ascending, 7–30(–40) cm, weakly to strongly scabrous distally; bases (remnants of old leaves) slightly fibrous. Inflorescence: Inflorescences with both staminate and pistillate spikes; peduncles of basal pistillate spikes erect, elongate, slender; peduncles of staminate spikes 1.1–10 mm; proximal nonbasal bracts leaflike, exceeding inflorescences. Leaves: Leaf blades pale to dark green, usually equaling or exceeding stems, occasionally shorter, 0.8–2.5(–4) mm wide, herbaceous, glabrous abaxially, strongly scabrous to papillose adaxially. Pistillate scales: Pale to dark reddish brown, with narrow white margins, ovate, 2.9–5.7 × 1.4–2.3 mm, shorter than perigynia, apex acute or acuminate to long-acuminate. Spikes: Proximal pistillate spikes 2–4 (basal spikes 1–2); cauline spikes overlapping or somewhat separated, with 3–10(–15) perigynia; staminate spikes (4.8–)6–12.8 × (0.7–) 0.9–1.3(–2.5) mm. Staminate scales: Lanceolate, 3.2–5.8 × 1.2–1.8 mm, apex acuminate.     Anthers: 1.2–2 mm. Perigynia: Green to pale brown, veinless, ellipsoid to obovoid, 3.1–4.5 × 1.4–1.7 mm; beak straight or slightly bent, pale green, occasionally with reddish brown tinge, 0.9–1.7 mm, ciliate-serrulate, apical teeth 0.2–0.4 mm. Achenes: Brown, globose to obovoid or ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous in cross section, 1.9–2.4 × 1.3–1.7 mm. Stigmas: 3.   Elevation: 210–3700 m.
