"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230575","diagnostic","<p>Like C. recta, C. salina is a 'stabilised hybrid', with one parent, C. paleacea, in common with that taxon, the other parent being the pan-arctic coastal C. subspathacea, a species not (yet!) recorded for the British Isles. Compared to C. recta, C. salina flowers very early and has very short stems, overtopped by the narrower leaves that are mixed with, and could easily go undetected amongst, grass-like vegetation on saltmarshes (J. Cayouette pers. comm.). C. recta is usually a taller plant, has longer female spikes and longer female glumes, and usually grows in upper levels of estuaries in more silty soils.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-salina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","174e4b70-95b8-4402-b7b0-d3df24a092df#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230575","distribution","<p>Carex salina was recorded in our area for the first time in 2004 at the head of a sheltered sea-loch at Morvich (v.c. 105). Other similar maritime areas in Scotland and possibly Ireland should be searched for this species.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-salina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","174e4b70-95b8-4402-b7b0-d3df24a092df#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230575","ecology","<p>C. salina is found in extensive clones near mean high tide level and is often inundated at high spring tides. This may explain the scarcity of fully ripe fruit through a failure in pollination. Landwards it extends into a Puccinellia maritima saltmarsh (SM13). The banks just above the sedge are Festuca rubra-Juncus gerardii and Blymus rufus saltmarsh (SM16, SM19).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-salina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","174e4b70-95b8-4402-b7b0-d3df24a092df#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230575","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping; shoots tufted; roots rich brown-grey; scales red-brown, often blackened, persistent. <i>Stems </i> 10-30 cm, smooth, spongy, stiff, obtusely trigonous, soon overtopped by lower leaves and those on sterile shoots. <i>Leaves </i> up to 30 cm (or 60-70 cm where plants more sheltered) × 2-3(-4) mm, mid green, young leaves ± glaucous and matt on both surfaces, stiff, V-shaped, with upper 1/3-1/2 and tip toothed; amphistomous; not overwintering; sheaths herbaceous, pale brown, soon decaying, with inner face hyaline and transverse septa distinct; ligule acute, c. 5 mm; apex concave. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/4 to almost 1/2 length of stem; lowest bract leafy, slightly shorter to slightly longer than inflorescence, often spathe-like, enclosing spike. <i>Male spikes</i>  1-2(-3), 1-2 cm; male glumes 4-6 mm, oblanceolate-elliptic, blackish-brown, hyaline at margins; apex obtuse. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-3, 1-3 cm, erect; lowest spike with peduncle up to 1.5 cm, sometimes lax-flowered at base; female glumes 4-5 mm, ovate-elliptic, mid to dark brown with broad pale centre with obvious midrib; some glumes three-veined; apex of those in upper florets apiculate; lower florets all aristate, with awn ± 1 mm long, toothed. <i>Utricles</i>  2.5-3.5 mm, ellipsoid, with 0-3 veins beneath beak; beak 0.2-0.4 mm, conic, 0.5 mm at base, obliquely truncate or not; stigmas 2; nut orbicular or obovate, biconvex, glossy, usually deeply constricted on one face.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-salina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","174e4b70-95b8-4402-b7b0-d3df24a092df#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230640","diagnostic","<p>A variable plant, especially in size, colour and texture of the utricles. Forms with lax-flowered, more or less pendulous spikes can be confused with C. atrofusca. C. saxatilis has been reported as having two or three stigmas on the same spike; all such plants should be investigated for possible sterility (i.e. hybridity with C. rostrata or C. vesicaria). C. × grahamii Boott is thought to have the latter origin: see that entry. Though C. saxatilis and C. rostrata often grow in the same area, no hybrid between the two has yet been confirmed for Britain. <br />Wallace (1975) discusses a further hybrid with ' C. flava' (called C. × marshallii by A. Bennett but not described and therefore invalidly named: Bennett 1925; Druce 1926). Specimens in BM and OXF may be one of the parents, but collections from v.c. 97 are believed to be the hybrid with C. viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-saxatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c56a428c-d751-4fcf-9b66-93294b18077e#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230640","distribution","<p>Carex saxatilis is confined to the Scottish mountains, mainly in the high rainfall areas of the west and usually in places where snow lies late, at between 460 and 1125 m; very local in the Cairngorms and Clova mountains.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-saxatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c56a428c-d751-4fcf-9b66-93294b18077e#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230640","ecology","<p>A plant of mires where the water movement is not great; tolerant of a wide range of pH and Ca++ content, especially on saddles or slightly sloping hillsides with C. vaginata, C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa, Eriophorum angustifolium, Juncus triglumis, Persicaria vivipara, Thalictrum alpinum and associated bryophytes (Aneura pinguis, Scapania undulata, Scorpidium revolvens etc.) (M12).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-saxatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c56a428c-d751-4fcf-9b66-93294b18077e#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230640","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping, producing tufts of 1-3 shoots at frequent, ± regular intervals; roots pale yellow-brown; scales grey-brown, often tinged wine-red, soon becoming fibrous. <i>Stems </i> 15-40 cm, ± rough above, trigonous, often curved. <i>Leaves </i> 12-40 cm × 2-4 mm, often curved, thick, bluntly keeled or channelled, gradually tapering to a trigonous point up to 5 cm long, midgreen, ± shiny, becoming straw-coloured; hypostomous; sheaths thick, white, tinged with wine-red, persistent, with inner face hyaline; apex straight; ligule 2-4 mm, rounded, slightly tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/5-1/4 length of stem; lower bracts leaf-like, shorter than or equalling the inflorescence, upper usually glume-li.ke. Male spike 1, rarely 2, 10-15 mm; male glumes 3-4 mm, oblanceolate, purple-black with hyaline margin; apex ± acute. <i>Female spikes</i>  1-3, ± contiguous, 5-20 mm, ovoid or subglobose, erect, only the lowest rarely shortly pedunculate; female glumes 2-3 mm, ovate, purple-to dark red-brown with a paler midrib and hyaline margin; apex ± acute. <i>Utricles</i>  3-3.5 mm, ovoid, ± inflated, often dark purple-green on exposed faces, shiny; beak 0.5 mm, ± notched; stigmas 2 (or 3?); nut subglobose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-saxatilis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c56a428c-d751-4fcf-9b66-93294b18077e#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","associations","<p>Typical associates of Carex scabrata in the seeps and headwaters in U.S. Forest Service Region 9 (New England) are Mnium and other mosses, Athyrium filix-femina, Circaea alpina, Chrysosplenium americanum, Dryopteris intermedia, Listera convallarioides, Streptopus amplexifolius, Veratrum viride, and Phegopteris connectilis. Trees commonly found in the surrounding forest include Thuja occidentalis, Abies balsamea, Acer rubrum, A. spicatum, A. saccharum, Betula alleghaniensis, and B. papyrifera (Hoy 2002). Carex scabrata is a significant indicator species of hardwood seeps in eastern Maine, together with Circaea alpina, Chrysosplenium americanum, Symphyotrichum lateriflorum, and Viola cucullata (Morley 2008). In forested seeps in the Allegheny Mountains region of West Virginia Carex scabrata dominates the ground layer together with Glyceria melicaria, Laportea canadensis, Tiarella cordifolia, Viola cucullata, and the characteristic bryophyte Plagiomnium ciliare. Other herbaceous species with high constancy include Arisaema triphyllum, Cardamine diphylla, Cardamine pensylvanica, Chrysosplenium americanum, Dryopteris intermedia, Oxalis montana, Packera aurea, Poa alsodes, Saxifraga micranthidifolia, Symphyotrichum prenanthoides, and Thelypteris noveboracensis. The canopy is characterized by Betula alleghaniensis, Acer saccharum, Picea rubens, and Fagus grandifolia. The shrub layer is sparse. (Byers et al. 2007). Woody associates found with Carex scabrata near the southern end of Lake Michigan include Fagus grandifolia, Lindera benzoin, and Liriodendron tulipifera. Herbaceous associates include Caltha palustris, Cardamine bulbosa, Carex laxiflora, Crysosplenium americanum, Thelypteris palustris, Onoclea sensibilis, Osmunda cinnamomea, Panax trifolius, and Saururus cernuus (Swink & Wilhelm 1994). In central Wisconsin Carex scabrata grows on the banks of cold-water streamlets in deep rich upland forests dominated by Tilia americana and Acer rubrum. Fraxinus nigra and Hamamelis virginiana form the overstory immediately along the springy water courses, where common herbs include Carex prasina, Floerkia proserpinacoides, Hydrophyllum virginianum, Laportea canadensis, Osmorhiza longistylis, Poa alsodes, Symplocarpus foetidus, and Symphyotrichum prenanthoides. In the northwestern corner of its range, on the Penokee Iron Range and Bayfield Peninsula, Wisconsin, Carex scabrata grows in wet spots (seepy openings) in rich northern mesic forests on uneven rocky terrain, wet from seepage, with springy pockets and fallen mossy logs, with Equisetum arvense, Athyrium filix-femina, Onoclea sensibilis, Osmunda claytoniana, Drypoteris cristata, Thelypteris phegopteris, Actaea rubra, Carex disperma, C. gynandra, C. intumescens, C. projecta, C. retrorsa (in wettest spots), C. stipata, Circaea alpina, Clintonia borealis, Glyceria canadensis, G. stricta, Laportea canadensis, Impatiens biflora, Sium suave, Mertensia paniculata, Scutellaria lateriflora, and Symphyotrichum puniceum. The surrounding forests are dominated by Acer saccharum and Tilia americana with Acer spicatum, Betula alleghaniensis, Fraxinus nigra, Ostrya virginiana, and Ulmus americana. On the Apostle Islands Carex scabrata grows under a canopy of mostly northern trees, namely Acer saccharum, Acer spicatum, Betula papyrifera, Betula alleghaniensis, Populus tremuloides, and Tsuga canadensis, and associates with Carex prasina and Listera convallarioides in rich moist soil in seeping shallow draws. Surveys of rust fungi on Carex reported the presence of Puccinia grossulariae (Schum.) Lagerh. (Hunt 1929, Kern 1917) and P. microsora Körn (Kern 1917) on C. scabrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#associations"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","conservation","<p>Carex scabrata has no federal listing. It is ranked as secure by The Nature Conservancy (G5). Listed by NatureServe (NatureServe Explorer 2011) as possibly extirpated in Missouri, critically imperiled in Delaware and Indiana (“endangered;” Indiana Division of Nature Preserves 2002), imperiled in South Carolina and Georgia, and vulnerable in North Carolina. Considered rare in Ohio but not ranked, rare in Ontario but secure. Reported by Peattie (1930) from the Indiana Dunes, but now considered extirpated from that area.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","diagnostic","<p>This species is distinguished by the combination of very scabrous foliage (but not hairy), scabrous perigynia with relatively long beaks, and sheathless bracts. The only other North American member of this section occurs in the Northwest.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","dispersal","<p>Presumably, reproduction is exclusively by seed. Conceivably, new colonies could form were a clump along a streamlet to fragment owing to some specialized disturbance event and the fragments successfully take root on appropriate substrate downstream and grow into new individual clumps.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Dispersal","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#dispersal"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","distribution","<p>Medium to higher elevations in the mountains of northernmost Georgia (Union Co.), South Carolina, and eastern Tennessee to Nova Scotia and southern Quebec, west to Ohio, northernmost Indiana (LaPorte and St. Joseph cos.), Wisconsin, and southern Ontario, disjunct to southwest Missouri (2 stations) and eastern Oklahoma (1 station) (24 states, 5 provinces, and Washington, D.C.). Not common but generally distributed, most frequent in the upland portions of its range, extending southward in the Appalachian system and rarely reappearing westward in the Ozarks and Oachitas. Called a northern species by at least some southern botanists (e.g., Underwood 1945) despite this temperate forest species’ being a member of the Alleghenian-Ozarkian floristic element. Carex scabrata can be frequent (e.g., Lake George area, New York’s Adirondacks) or common (e.g., Keweenaw Peninsula of Michigan) northward.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","ecology","<p>In 60 sample plots from a phytosociological study of the spruce-fir zone of Great Smoky Mountains National Park (Stehn et al. 2011) frequency plus relative percent cover were summed to give importance values. Carex scabrata had an I.V. of 1.0.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","habitat","<p>Creek borders and wet spots in rich deciduous woods and ravine bottoms, springy thickets, and seepage slopes, less often in coniferous swamps or wet open clearings and hollows. Carex scabrata normally grows only in cool wet soils, whether in calcareous, circumneutral, or acidic. It presumably cannot tolerate significant hydrologic fluctuations or chemical pollutants. A different kind of habitat has been found in Greenville and Pickens counties, South Carolina, where C. scabrata is locally subdominant in cracks and crevices on vertical cliff faces (Larson & Batson 1978, Nelson 1986).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","look_alikes","<p>Carex scabrata could be confused only with C.prasina, with which it often grows in Michigan and Wisconsin. The latter species has less harshly scabrous foliage and curious, strongly triangular, flattened arching perigynia that are 2-ribbed but otherwise veinless and glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","morphology","Plant: forming loose, medium-sized clumps and vigorous colonies. Below-ground structures: rhizomes brownish, tough, stout, long-creeping. Vegetative shoots: prominent tufts of basal leaves produced at the tips of rhizome branches, with overlapping sheaths and blades often wider (to 18 mm) than those of flowering culms. Culms: brownish at base, erect, 3--9 dm tall, stiffish, sharply trigonous, very scabrous above. Inflorescence: racemose, with 4--7 (--9) spikes; bracts leaf-like, sheathless or nearly so, mostly longer than the inflorescence. Leaves: dried-up leaves of the previous year persistent, brown at base; basal sheaths of the current year with somewhat reduced blades, not fibrous; cauline sheaths adaxially yellowish-white, thin, papery, concave at the mouth, glabrous; ligules longer than wide, 11--43 (--53) mm long; cauline leaves basal and on lower 1/3rd of the culms, shorter than to about equaling the culms, M-shaped in cross section when young, sparingly septate-nodulose; blades dark green, spreading to arching, 10--40 cm long, 4--8(--12) mm wide, thin, adaxial surface, margins, and midrib very scabrous. Pistillate scales: nearly equaling bodies of perigynia, light brown to reddish-brown with green midrib, ovate or lanceolate, 1.8--4 X 1--1.5 mm long, acute to acuminate or short-awned, ciliolate. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, short- to long-stalked (peduncle 0.3--3.7 cm long), oblong to cylindric, 1.6--4.8 cm long, 2.5--3.6(--5.1) mm thick; lateral spikes pistillate, prophyllate, erect, the proximal one (occasionally branched) often strongly separate, long-peduncled, the median and distal 2 to 7 loosely contiguous, short-stalked to sessile (peduncle 0--4.9 cm long), oblong to short-cylindric, 1--5.5(--7) cm long, 5.5--8(--9) mm thick, closely 10--160-flowered (70--230-flowered if branched). Staminate scales: white to tan with a green midrib and narrowly hyaline margins, narrowly elliptic or lanceolate, 3.5--6 mm long.     Anthers: (2.5---)3--3.6 mm long. Perigynia: spreading-ascending, olive green, ellipsoid-obovoid, rounded-trigonous in cross section, 3.4--4.5 X 1.4--2 mm, slightly stipitate, membranous, 2-ribbed and strongly 6--8-veined, minutely scabrous-puberulent; beak conic, somewhat recurved, 1.3--1.9 mm long, orifice hyaline, obscurely bidentate, the teeth soft, blunt. Achenes: almost as large as bodies of perigynia and rather closely enveloped, brown, obovoid, sharply trigonous with concave sides and thickened angles,1.8--2.3 mm long, 1.2--1.5 mm thick, subsessile, short-apiculate. Stigmas: 3.   Elevation: 20 -- 2000 m Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","physiology","<p>Like the majority of its congeners, Carex scabrata lacks the flavonols kaempferol and quercetin, but like others it contains tricin, which is relatively rare or elusive in nature (Harborne 1971).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Physiology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#physiology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","population","<p>Because colonies of Carex scabrata occur in relatively isolated wetlands, there may be limited chance for gene exchange with other populations. However, it seems unlikely for now that reproductive problems might as the result of too much self-fertilization within populations. Plants apparently produce large numbers of fruits.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#PopulationBiology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#population"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230663","threats","<p>Being characteristically very small and distributed non-uniformly across the landscape, seeps have not received the scientific or regulatory attention they deserve. Vegetation classification systems based on surrounding woody vegetation may not take into account contained wet spots or differentiate among seepage communities on the basis of hydrology, soils, and nutrient levels. Populations could to be lost through destruction of seeps and spring runs by dredging, damming, or grazing, but such activity probably constitutes a low threat impact overall.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scabrata-schwein-2","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","7c688a9c-75c3-489b-ba8d-d61ee2353004","","1a3c1d95-4a1a-4f38-a7f4-9deea30484ef#threats"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230667","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose.   Culms: 30-50 cm tall.  Leaves: 3-5 mm wide, soft. Basal sheaths: purplish brown. Bracts: setaceous, with sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale brown, apex acute. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical, 2-4 cm long: lateral spikes pistillate, shortly pedunculate, linear cylindrical, 1-3 cm long, loosely flowered.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ellipsoidal, 3-4 mm long, 0.6-0.8 mm wide, glabrous, slightly long beaked, mouth notched. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, narrowly ellipsoidal, 2 mm long, style base minutely annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230702","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.     Leaves: 2-4 mm wide. Basal sheaths: dark brown. Bracts: upper setaceous, lower leaf-like, sheathless. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230731","general","<p>Plants usually cespitose, short to long rhizomatous. Culms erect or lax, 5–35(–40) cm. Leaves: sheaths and bases from previous year’s leaves usually absent; ligules rounded or acute; blades glabrous adaxially. Inflorescences unispicate (very rarely with short, sessile lateral spike of same sex), mostly erect, ellipsoid; primary inflorescence bracts leaflike, rarely scalelike, shorter or longer than inflorescences. Scales red-brown to purple, ovate to lanceolate, to 3.5 × 1.5 mm, shorter than, equal to, or longer than perigynia, margins hyaline, narrow to broad, central midrib extending midway or to scale apex, apex acute to obtuse. Perigynia red-brown, ovate to lanceolate, to 4 × 1.6 mm, as wide as subtending scale, apex tapering or rounded, distal 3/4 hirsute with white hairs; beak 0.1 mm, orifice circular; rachilla absent. Achenes 1–2 × 0.6–1.2, tightly enveloped by perigynia, occupying full width and at least 3/4 length of perigynia. 2n = 62.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scirpoidea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-scirpinae-tuckerman-kukenthal","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","6628de01-caf0-4602-a0da-4183f00c692a#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230748","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.      Leaves: 2-4 mm wide, margins scabrous, dorsal surfaces densely papillate. <br /><br/> Pistillate scales: dark reddish purple, apex long awned. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, 1-2, 1.5-2 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, ovate to ctlindrical, 1-3 cm long, drooping. Staminate scales: dark reddish purple, apex long awned. Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, narrowly ovoid, 4-5 mm long, stipe short, densely pubescent mouth shallowly bidentated.  Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, ovoid, 1.7-1.9 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","conservation","<p>According to California Native Plant Society (CNPS), CA Rare Plant Rank: 2.2, and State Rank as S2S3 (Imperiled and Vulnerable).  Global Rank is G5 (commonly found).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","diagnostic","<p>Distinguished from similar species by 1.2-2mm wide lanceolate to ovate perigynia, spikes that are often tapered to both ends, and tight leaf sheaths (Hipp 2008).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","distribution","<p>Widespread in eastern North America, with pockets in the northwest and southwestern United States; from British Columbia to NewFoundland, south to Nova Scotia, South Carolina, Tennessee, Arkansas, Idaho, and Oregon; pocket in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, and Utah. (Fernald 1950, USDA, FNA Basemap unpublished). Southwest may be undersampled; not found in Texas or Florida.<br /><br/>	In Maryland, C.scoparia var. scoparia is common in Allegheny Plateau; frequent in Ridge and Valley, Piedmont, and Western Shore; infrequent in Eastern Shore. (Frye 2001) C.scoparia var scoparia widespread throughout Wisconsin (Hipp 2008); C.scoparia widespread through Illinois (Mohlenbrock 199).  C. scoparia is predominately in northern quarter of Indiana with a few pockets in southern counties. (Rothrock 2000)<br /><br/>	C.scoparia var. scoparia mainly west of the Cascade Mountains in Washington and Oregon (in Willamette Valley area) (Wilson et al. 2008, Wilson et al. 1999).  Listed as imperiled and vulnerable in California by California Native Plant Society.  Rare in Arkansas, confirmed in Benton County, reported in Polk County.  (Hyatt 1998).<br /><br/>	There are two varieties: C.  scoparia var. scoparia and C. scoparia var. tessellata (Ball et al. 2002).  C.  scoparia var. tessellata, limited to two counties in Maine (Hipp et al. 2010) C. scoparia has been introduced to Europe and New Zealand (Ball et al. 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","general","<p>Carex scoparia is a perennial plant, which grows in dense, large clumps, occasionally with noticeable leafy stem-like structures called vegetative culms.  The stem-like structures that hold the inflorescence (culms) are approximately 20-100cm tall.  Leaf blades are 1.5-3.5 mm in width, with tight leaf sheaths. The inflorescence of C. scoparia can be variable within and between populations however, it is typically compact to slender and elongate (1.5-6cm long).  If the inflorescence is long, then it is usually arching. There are 3-10 overlapping spikes on each inflorescence; spikes are tapered at both ends.  These spikes are bisexual, with female flowers at tip of inflorescence and male flowers at base.  The female flowers are covered by a sac-like structure called a perigynia.  In C. scoparia, the perigynia is 4-7mm long, 1.2 to 2.0 mm wide, lanceolate to ovate in shape, and noticeably veined on both sides.  The perigynia is generally flat except over the achene (fruit of Carex) (Ball et al. 2002; Hipp 2008)</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","habitat","<p>Carex scoparia is most common in wetland areas.<br /><strong>Wisconsin:</strong> most common in open, wet, sandy soil; occasionally in microsites that are more or less bare of other vegetation. The species ranges from shallow water (base of plant submerged) to, rarely, dry sandy uplands and from sun to partial shade. Common in wetlands throughout most of the state, uncommon in east-central Wisconsin, Door County, and much of the Driftless Area (though present there in floodplains) Typical habitat include marshes, sedge meadows, lakeshores, ditches, wet prairies, and occasional sphagnum bogs. Associated species include Carex crawfordii, C.echinata, C.tenera, C.utriculata. (Hipp 2008)<br /><strong>Pacific Northwest:</strong>  marshes and wet meadows (Wilson et al. 2008).<br /><br/>	Chicago Region: wet prairies (common), calcareous fens and moist calcareous prairies.  In wet prairies, they are associated with Cakanagristus Canadensis, Carex hysterucubam Carex stipata, Carex vulpinoidea, Dryopteris thelypteris pubescens, Erigeron philadelphicus, Iris virginica shrevei, Juncus dudleyi, Juncus effuses, Onoclea sensibilis, Sagittaria latifolia, Typha latifolia.  In moist calcareous prairies, they are associated with Carex pellita, Carex suberecta, Carex tetanica, Dryopteris thelypteris pubescens, Eleocharis elliptica, Mentha arvensis villosa, Senecio pauperculus, and Sisyrinchium albidum. (Wilhelm 1995)<br /><strong>Maryland:</strong> moist or sometimes dry, open areas. (Frye 2001)<br /><strong>Indiana:</strong> Northern quarter of state (unshaded  borders of lakes, marshes, low fields, wet prairies, wet railroad right of ways, sedge meadows, interdunal flats and open pin oak woods.)  Southern counties (low fields, old pastures, wet woods, sedge filled roadside depressions.  Typically found in acidic, sandy soils. (Rothrock 2000)<br /><strong>Arkansas:</strong> wet, disturbed meadows; they are associated with Juncus, Carex, and diverse weedy grasses.  </p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","look_alikes","<p>C. crawfordii, C. tribuloides, C. leporina, C. feta</p><br/><p><strong>Wisconsin:</strong> C. crawfordii (has narrower pergynia than C. scoparia); C. tribuloides (has loose sheaths, wider leaves, prominent vegetative culms, and usually has stiff and elongate inflorescence compared to C. scoparia’s tight sheaths and compact to elongate, somewhat drooping inflorescence) (Hipp 2008)</p><br/><p><strong>Pacific Northwest:</strong> C. leporina and C. feta (Wilson et al. 2008)</p><br/><p><strong>Maryland:</strong> C. tribuloides (has wider leaver than C. scoparia) (Frye 2001)</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230759","morphology","Plant: Cespitose.  Vegetative shoots: Vegetative culms sometimes obvious in the field, leafy at the summit (Hipp 2008); can produce shoots/roots at nodes which act like stolons (Wilson et al. 2008). Culms: 20-100 cm tall (Ball et al. 2002); Stiff, sharply scabrous-angled (Wilhelm 1995).<br /><br/> Inflorescence: Arching or nodding, dense or open, green, yellow, or brown at maturity, 1.5–6 cm long, 5–20 mm wide; proximal internode 2–12 mm; 2d internode 2–13 mm; proximal bracts scalelike, with bristle tip. (Ball et al. 2002)  Variable within and between populations (Hipp 2008). Leaves: Blades: 3–5 per fertile culm, 10-32 cm long × 1.4-3.5 mm wide (Ball et al. 2002) firm, the midrib often carinate beneath, harshly scabrous along the margins; sheath: summits U-shaped (Ball et al. 2002), tight (Hipp 2008), green-nerved throughout, or with a narrow hyaline band near the summit. (Wilhelm 1995); Distal ligules: 2.3–4.8 mm (Ball et al. 2002). Pistillate scales: Hyaline brown, sometimes with green or gold midstripe, lanceolate, 3.4–4 mm, shorter and narrower than perigynia, apex acuminate (Ball et al. 2002); reach about midway up the beak of the perigynium (Wilhelm 1995). Spikes: 3–10, distinct, ellipsoid, 7–16 mm x 3–9(–13) mm, base acute to short-attenuate, apex acute to rounded (Ball et al. 2002), gynecandrous (Hipp 2008).       Perigynia: Perigynia: Ascending (or rarely widely spreading), green to golden brown, 5-veined on each face (sometimes fewer adaxially) winged to base, lanceolate to ovate, flat except over achene, 5-7mm long and 1.2–2 mm wide ( length is at least 3x the width),  0.35–0.55 mm thick, margin flat, including wing 0.2–0.6 mm wide; beak pale to golden-brown at tip, flattish, ciliate-serrulate, abaxial suture with white or golden brown hyaline margin, distance from beak tip to achene 2.2–4.8 mm (Ball et al. 2002, Wilhelm 1995, Wilson et al 2008). Achenes: Ovate or elliptic, 1.3–1.7 long, 0.7–0.9 mm wide, 0.3–0.4 mm thick (Ball et al. 2002).     Authorship and sources: <","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-scoparia-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","e2481ff6-0050-4947-a9e5-cba5edde0e39#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230784","distribution","<p>Mitteleuropa, Osteuropa (Polen, Slowakei, Ungarn [hier auch am Neusiedler See unweit der Gebietsgrenze ], Rumänien, Südrußland, Kaukasusgebiet), Iran, Sibirien (ostwärts bis zum Baikalsee), Zentralasien. In Ostsibirien und der Mongolei die nahe verwandte C. eremopyroides KREC. <br />Verbreitung im Gebiet. Carex secalina erreicht im Gebiet die Westgrenze ihrer Verbreitung. In Mitteleuropa nur im Gebiet von Posen, in Sachsen-Anhalt, (Thüringen), Böhmen, Mähren und Österreich.- Im Gebiet von Posen bei Inowrodaw und am Seedorfer See bei Argenau.- In Sachsen-Anhalt bei Gröningen (am Schützensee und am Grundlos) sowie früher mehrfach im Gebiet des Süßen und des Salzigen Sees bei Eisleben, ob noch?- In Thüringen (Stotternheim bei Erfurt) nicht mehr.- In Böhmen und Mähren mehrfach (Postelberg, Seidowitz, Budin an der Eger, Saidschitz unweit Bilin, Vsetat an der Eibe, Welwarn, Velver bei Lobositz, Hochpetsch bei Brüx, Brünn [Brno], Moenitz, Tal der Thaya, Hodonin; Verbreitungskarte für Mähren bei PoDPERA (1928, S. 386).- In Österreich nur in Niederösterreich (bei Zwingendorf sowie zwischen Rothenseehof und Alt-Prerau, nordöstlich von Laa an der Thaya, ferner im Pulkautal bei Kadolz, Wulzeshofen und Hanfthal) und im Burgenland (zerstreut am Neusiedler See).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-secalina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-ordnung-cyperales","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","2aaf5db3-2bfe-4004-bac4-2ca79eb89947#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230784","general","<p>Ausdauernde Pflanze, in allen Teilen schwächer als C. hordeistichos. Wurzelstock dichte Rasen bildend. Stengel meist bogig aufsteigend, stumpf dreikantig, schlank, meist kürzer als die Blätter, 10-30(-40) cm hoch, 1-2 mm breit, glatt. Grundständige Blattscheiden hellbraun bis rotbraun. Blättersteil, flach, linealisch, allmählich zugespitzt, 2-4(-5) mm breit, an den Rändern fein rauh, graugrün. Hüllblätter des Blütenstandes laubblattartig, länger als der Blütenstand, die unteren langscheidig, die der männlichen Ährchen kurz, fast spelzenartig. Blütenstand oft schon fast am Grunde des Stengels beginnend, aus 1-3 männlichen Ährchen und 2-5 darunter stehenden weiblichen Ährchen bestehend; meist alle Ährchen voneinander entfernt oder die oberen etwas genähert. Weibliche Ährchen sitzend bis kurz gestielt (Stiel des untersten Ährchens kaum aus der Scheide des Hüllblattes herausragend), aufrecht, schlank zylindrisch, bis über 20 mm lang, 6-7 mm dick, zierlich dichtblütig, die unteren zuweilen am Grunde verzweigt. Männliche Ährchen linealisch bis etwas keulenförmig, das untere oft sehr klein. Spelzen der weiblichen Blüten breit eiförmig, spitz, viel kürzer als die Schläuche, bleichbräunlich, mit gelbbraunem Mittelstreifen und breiten weißhäutigen Rändern. Spelzen der männlichen Blüten hellbräunlich, weißhautrandig. Schläuche meist unregelmäßig angeordnet, nicht in deutlichen Reihen stehend, ellipsoidisch, plankonvex (die Innenseite flach, der Rücken stark gewölbt), oberwärts allmählich in den langen, zweizähnigen, an den Rändern geflügelten und fein rauhen Schnabel verschmälert, 5-7 mm lang, längsnervig, mit häutiger Wandung, bleichgelb bis gelbgrün. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230840","diagnostic","<p>C. serotina ssp. pulchella (Lönnr.) van Ooststr. with smaller utricles and more cylindrical female spikes occurs on seashores and in marshy inland localities in NW and C Europe; it has apparently not been recorded from Greece. <br />In most of its total range the C. flava aggregate (incl. C. lepidocarpa and C. serotina) is extremely variable and difficult to classify satisfactorily. In Greece, however, the taxa are strikingly uniform, have allopatric areas, and are very easy to distinguish by means of several constant morphological and ecological characteristics.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-serotina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-2","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","673e9c8b-5869-402a-9816-66d8fb91b6b5#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230840","general","<p>Caespitose, without creeping rhizomes. Stems 2-8(-15) cm. Scales and basal sheaths pale brown, dull. Leaves 1-2 mm wide canaliculate (convolute, erect and slightly curving outwards in pressed material), equalling or longer than stems; ligule 1-2 mm, rounded. Lower bract 2-5 cm, patent to erect. Female spikes (2-)3-5 7), 5-8 mm, elliptic-oblong to subglobose very dense the upper crowded, lowermost remote, sometimes near base of stem; male spike 1, sessile. Glumes brown to reddish-brown. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230852","morphology","Plant: Loosely cespitose or with solitary stems. Below-ground structures: Rhizomes horizontal, purple to black, 25–75(–100) mm, slender.  Culms: 8–38 cm; bases (remnants of old leaves) weakly to strongly fibrous.  Inflorescence: Inflorescences usually with either staminate or pistillate spikes, occasionally with both; peduncles of staminate spikes short; proximal nonbasal bracts leaflike, dark purple to black at base, shorter than inflorescences.  Leaves: Leaf blades green, 1.5–3.5(–5) mm wide, herbaceous, smooth to scabrous abaxially, smooth to scabrous adaxially.  Pistillate scales: Dark purple to black, with narrow white margins, lanceolate, 3.8–4.6 × 1.3–1.8 mm, apex acuminate. Spikes: Proximal pistillate spikes 1–4 (basal spikes 0–1); cauline spikes overlapping or somewhat separted, with 4–9 perigynia; staminate spikes 13–24 × (1.4–)2–4.1 mm.  Staminate scales: Oblanceolate, 4.6–5.6 × 1.1–1.6 mm, apex acute; proximal staminate scales with narrow white margins 0.1–0.2 mm wide.      Anthers: 2.1–4 mm.  Perigynia: Green, occasionally dark purple in age, veinless or 5-veined near base, obovoid, 3.1–3.6 × 1.5–1.8 mm; beak slightly bent, dark purple, 0.5–1 mm, weakly ciliate-serrulate, apical teeth 0.2 mm.  Achenes: Pale to medium brown, globose, round in cross section, 1.9–2.2 × 1.4–1.8 mm. Stigmas: 3.   Elevation: 60–1200 m. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:230944","morphology","Plant: caespitose, small to medium-sized.<br /><br/> Below-ground structures: Rhizome with short internodes.  Culms: (13-)22-79 cm, ± stout,  trigonous, smooth, green to yellowish-green. Inflorescence: 4-43.5 cm, lowest internode 0.5-15.5(-23) cm and second one 0.5-8(-12) cm; lowest bract 6.5-20 cm × 2-5 mm, shorter than the inflorescence; sheath (0.5-)1-7.5 cm long, the inner side deep purple to blackish. Leaves: 6.5-31 cm × 3-12 mm, keeled to plicate, very rigid, ± coriaceous, slightly scabrid on apical parts; basal sheaths dark purplish to blackish, coriaceous; ligule 3-23 mm, acute; a6.5-31 cm × 3-12 mm, keeled to plicate, very rigid, ± coriaceous, slightly scabrid on apical parts; basal sheaths dark purplish to blackish, coriaceous; ligule 3-23 mm, acute; anteligule concave to convex. Pistillate scales: (3-)4-6(-6.5) × (1.2-)1.4-2.1(-2.5) mm, oblong-elliptic, deep purple to blackish, with very wide and pale midrib, acuminate or aristate, acumen or arista up to 1.6 mm. Spikes: 5-12, heteromorphic, 0-2 male spikes at the top (sometimes the terminal one gynecandrous) and 3-11 female lateral spikes; terminal spike (1-)2.5-4.8(-7) cm × 2-7(-10) mm, terete, sessile or with a peduncle up to 2.5 cm; female spikes, 1.5-6.5(-8) cm × 5-10 mm, subdense-flowered, terete to narrowly ellipsoid, arising singly or in pairs, sessile or with a peduncle up to 8(-10) cm. Staminate scales: (4-)5-8(-9) × (1.2-)1.4-2.2(-2.8) mm, oblong-elliptic to oblong-obovate, blackish with very wide and pale midrib, emarginate-mucronate to mucronate, mucro up to 1 mm, rarely obtuse.      Perigynia: (3.5-)4.5-6.5(-7.2) × (1.1-)1.2-1.6(-2) mm, narrowly ellipsoid-trigonous, straight, plurinerved, tapered to beak, greyish-brown to green; beak (0.7-)1-1.6(-2) mm, bifid, with ± similar dorsal and ventral sinus 0.2-0.6 mm depth, smooth. Achenes: (2.2-)2.3-2.9(-3.2) × (0.9-)1-1.2(-1.3), trigonous, oblong-ellipsoid. Stigmas: 3.   Elevation: 2800-4100 m. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231061","general","<p>Plants without or with short rhizomes. Culms: 20–80 cm × 1.25–2.00 mm at midheight, sharply trigonous, slightly scabrid above. Leaves: basal sheaths and sheaths red or purple tinged, blades about 3/5 as long as culms, widest leaf blades 2.5–4 mm, plicate to flat; ligule 3.5–13 mm, longer than wide, acute at apex. Inflorescence elliptic to oblong, 15–42 × 8–14 mm, with 7–10(–12) elliptic spikes, single at nodes, sessile, usually spikes overlapping, the lowest spikes 2–8 mm distant; bracts glume like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than inflorescence, 4–16(–27) mm long. Pistillate scale purplish-brown, with a narrow green to brown midrib and with or without laterals narrow scarious margins, 4.0–5.0 × 2.0–2.5 mm, ovate, apex apiculate to acuminate 0.1–0.4 mm. Staminate glume 3.5–4.5 × 1.5–2.0 mm, narrower than female. Anthers 3, 2.5–3.0 mm long. Perigynium erect-spreading to spreading, greenish to pale yellowish-brown, body ovate to ovate-elliptic, body nerveless to well marked veins at base, 4.0–5.5(–6) × 2.0–2.5 mm, base rounded and corky, gradually tapered into a beak. Beak 1.15–1.60 mm long, brown to reddish- brown distally, serrulate or smooth, apex bidentate, apical teeth 0.25–0.5 mm. Achenes pentagonal to oval-ovate, dark brown when ripe, 2.15–2.75 × 1.75–2.20 mm. Stigmas 2, 2.0–2.5 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-spicata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-eurasian-carex-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","26b42729-d9c6-4bd6-acbb-8d30059ee40f#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231061","general","<p>Rizoma grueso, que forma céspedes hasta de 50 cm de diámetro. Tallos (10)20-60(85) cm, trígonos, con los ángulos agudos, escábridos en la parte superior. Hojas (1,8)2,5-3,5(4) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, algo ásperas, no muy rígidas; lígula (3)5-7(8,5) mm, de longitud mucho mayor que la anchura, de ápice obtuso o subagudo; generalmente sin antelígula; vainas basales poco o muy fibrosas, de color pardo, frecuentemente teñidas de color púrpura obscuro al igual que la cara interna de la corteza y la externa del cilindro central de las raíces. Bráctea inferior de longitud mucho menor que la inflorescencia, setácea, no envainante. Espigas agrupadas en la parte superior del tallo, a veces las inferiores un poco separadas, en inflorescencias de 2-3(4) cm, simples. Glumas ovales, acuminadas o mucronadas, de color pardo pálido a obscuro, muy rara vez hialino-verdosas, con margen escarioso estrecho o sin él, las femeninas de longitud similar a la de los utrículos. Utrículos (4)4,2-5,5(6) × 1,7-2,2 mm, suberectos, de contorno estrechamente oval y base ± estrechada, plano-convexos, con nervadura solo perceptible en ocasiones, verdosos, gradualmente atenuados en un pico de (1,2)1,5-1,8 mm, escábrido-serrulado, bífido. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231061","habitat","<p>Prados algo húmedos; 300-1900 m.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-spicata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","960ecc62-d688-4079-96a5-d460d3eefed5#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231071","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, in the midlands and in montane areas of Northern Province, Mpumalanga, Gauteng, Swaziland, and KwaZulu-Natal. It is also recorded from East Africa, in southern Tanzania, Kenya, Zambia and Zimbabwe, where it is common in the Eastern Highlands.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-spicatopaniculata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","8a2d2416-14cc-48f2-98ea-505bd4985c2f#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231071","general","<p>Plants 1.0–1.4 m tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 4 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves dark green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face splitting simply. Largest basal leaf blades 600 × 8.5–14.0 mm, flat or plicate in cross-section; adaxial surface scabrid; abaxial surface glabrous; margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth truncate or concave, membranous; ligule 3 mm high, stramineous, or fuscous, membranous, apex acute to obtuse. Culms triangular in cross-section, 2–3 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; (1–)2–3 nodes exposed. Inflorescence paniculate, 270–335 × 35–40 mm. Basal inflorescence bracts leaf-like; sheaths 25–50 mm long; blades 290 mm long. Primary inflorescence units 4–6; all androgynous; usually 1, or sometimes 2 branches from basal nodes, spreading, pyramidal, the largest 40–60 × 25–35 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 50–60 mm, hairy. Bracts subtending higher order branches with a long setaceous cusp; opposing bracteoles inflated. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 1.5–2.2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate, 3–4 × 1.5–1.8 mm, shorter than and the same width as the perigynium, stramineous, with or without light to heavy ferruginous striae and hyaline margins, scabrid (mainly on distal half), or (rarely) glabrous, but ciliate distally on margin; carina narrow, single-nerved; apex acute or obtuse, shortly awned; awn 0.5–0.7 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, not stipitate, with a conspicuous basal callus, rostrate, 5.0–5.5 × 1.2 mm, triangular in cross-section, not inflated, green or golden brown, base without a layer of corky material, herbaceous, with four to six conspicuous curved nerves on abaxial surface, scabrid in distal half; rostrum abrupt, 2 mm long, straight, margin not winged, scabrid; rostrum apex deeply bidentate, apical teeth 0.6–1.0 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet elliptic, narrowly clawed, 2.4–3.0 × 1.0–1.2 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-spicatopaniculata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","8a2d2416-14cc-48f2-98ea-505bd4985c2f#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231071","habitat","<p>The plants grow in light shade, on wet or moist forest margins, on clay or loam substrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-spicatopaniculata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","8a2d2416-14cc-48f2-98ea-505bd4985c2f#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231132","habitat","<p>Rocky places in alpine<br /><br/>meadows.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-stenantha-var-stenantha-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","332ea58e-6746-4726-abbc-712dbbef9d0e#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231132","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose, with shortly creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 20-30 cm tall.  Leaves: 1.5-2.5 mm wide, margins scabrous. Basal sheaths: purplish brown, fibrillose. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like, with short sheaths. Pistillate scales: pale brown, apex shortly awned. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical, 1.5-3 cm long, long pedunculate; lateral spikes pistillate, cylindrical, 2-4 cm long, long pedunculate.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, lanceolate, 6-7 mm long, 1-1.2 mm wide, base shortly stipitate, long beaked, apical margins serrulate, mouth obliquely bidentate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, ellipsoidal, 2-2.5 mm long, long stipitate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231133","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose.   Culms: shorter than leaves, 5-30 cm tall, sometimes hidden at base.  Leaves: 3-7 mm wide, stiff, scabrous. Basal sheaths: dark brown, fibrillose. Bracts: leaf-like with short sheaths, longer than pistillate spikes, 2-5 cm long. Pistillate scales: pale green, apex emarginate, aristate. Spikes: crowed at apex; terminal spike staminate linear cylindrical, 0.7-1 cm long, sessile; lateral spikes pistillate, shortly cylindrical, 0.7-1.5 cm long. Staminate scales: pale green, apex acute or shortly aristate.      Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ellipsoidal, 5-6 mm long, finely many veined, sparsely puberulent base shortly stipitate, long beaked, mouth slightly bidentate. Achenes: slightly tightly enveloped by perieynium, obovoid, 2-3 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231141","general","<p><i>Rhizomes</i> 1-1.5(-2) mm thick; scales straw-coloured to brown, later fibrous; rootlets often pink; shoots in small, dense tufts or sometimes solitary. <i>Stems</i> 5-25(-40) cm, leafy at base; basal sheaths pale to dark greyish-brown, firmly clasping underground part of <i>Stems</i> , becoming fibrous. <i>Leaves</i> 0.5-2(-3) mm broad, usually shorter than <i>Stems</i> , canaliculate to strongly involute, long-attenuate, straight and ± erect or sometimes curved, rather stiff, greyish-green with paler adaxial side; margins scabrid. Spikes (3-)6-12, usually many-flowered, in a dense head-like or ± conical <i>Inflorescence</i> to 1.8 cm; bracts similar to glumes but larger, sometimes mucronate, base clasping. Female glumes broadly ovate, c. as long as utricles, brown to reddish-brown, often broadly hyaline-margined, sometimes with scabrid keels. <i>Utricles </i> pale yellowish- to reddish-brown, paler at base, broadly ovate to ovate, 3.2-4.4 mm, ± piano-convex, strongly convex on back, ± stipitate to 0.5 mm, coriaceous, often distinctly many-veined, with 11-18 ± elevated veins on abaxial side; beak to 0.7 mm, ± scabrid, dark, bifid. Stigmas 3-5 mm, often persistent. <i>Nut </i> pale brown, to 1.9 mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-stenophylla-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","d345166a-bda4-4636-a374-72d7ad6af2ff#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231265","general","<p>Laxamente cespitosa, con rizoma de entrenudos ± cortos. Tallos fértiles 47-54 cm, lisos, agudamente trígonos. Hojas (2,9)5-6,5 mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, ásperas en los bordes y el envés de la mitad superior, ± blandas; lígula hasta 9 mm, de ápice obtuso o redondeado; sin antelígula; vainas basales con limbo desarrollado salvo las más inferiores que son escuamiformes, pardas, enteras o algo rotas. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia, raramente casi igual, con una vaina de 27-50 mm. Espiga masculina solitaria, de 32-50 mm, linear, a veces con algunos utrículos en la base; espigas femeninas 6-8, de 38-60 mm, estrechamente lineares, todas agrupadas junto a la masculina salvo la inferior que suele estar separada del resto, con pedúnculos filiformes generalmente incluidos en la vaina, erectas. Glumas masculinas lanceoladas, agudas o acuminadas, hialinas con una banda verde en el centro; glumas femeninas ovales, agudas, cortamente mucronadas o acuminadas, de menor longitud que los utrículos, hialinas o de color pardo o púrpura, con una banda verde en el centro. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231271","general","<p>Plants cespitose. Culms 15–50 cm, distally slightly scabrous. Leaves 2–4 mm wide. Inflorescences: proximal bracts shorter than or exceeding inflorescences; spikes separate, short-oblong or elongate, 7–20 × 4.5–8 mm; proximal spikes often distant, spreading or pendent, very long-pendunculate; distal spikes erect, pedunculate; lateral (1–)2–3(–4) spikes pistillate, of similar length; terminal spike staminate or with perigynia, neither wholly gynecandrous or androgynous. Pistillate scales brown with hyaline margins, lanceolate, shorter and narrower than perigynia, midvein lighter colored than body, often raised, prominent. Perigynia spreading, green or golden, becoming brown, veinless, elliptic, 2.5–3.5 × 1.5–1.75 mm, apex beakless or abruptly beaked, papillose; beak to 0.2–0.3 mm, truncate, smooth. Achenes nearly filling body of perigynia. 2n = 52.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-stylosa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-racemosae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","f295d977-060f-43d1-b4cf-23147b5a984b#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231284","morphology","Plant: perennial, densely caespitose.     Leaves: blades shorter than culms, 2.5-4 mm wide, ventral surfaces pale bluish green, dorsal surfaces grayish green, densely papillate. Basal sheaths: dark brown, slightly fibrillose, slightly reticulate. Bracts: setaceous or leaf-like, sheathless.  Pistillate scales: apex long awned. Spikes: drooping; terminal spikes gynecandrous with half length of staminate section, 2.5-3.5 cm long; pistillate spikes 2.5-4 cm long: with perigynia densely, drooping, long pedunculate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231302","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, in the midlands, montane areas and on the alpine plateau, in KwaZulu-Natal, Lesotho, and Eastern Cape. Endemic to this region.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-subinflata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","ff77aeeb-b0f3-44cb-b7e8-106dd2d2861c#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231302","general","<p>Plants 285–900 mm tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 2.5–3.0 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves mid-green, glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face tearing into membranous strips. Largest basal leaf blade 220 × 6–10 mm, flat or plicate in cross-section; adaxial surface glabrous; abaxial surface papillate; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, membranous; ligule 35(–45) mm high, whitish with ferruginous spots, membranous, apex acute. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1.5–2.0 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 2–3 nodes exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 65–110 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheaths 15–25 mm long; blades 60–165 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 4–6, erect or suberect, not clustered, excepting frequently apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 20–40 r 9–11 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 0–23 mm, scabrid on angles. Apical spikes usually staminate. Staminate spikes 1–2. Pistillate spikes 3–5. Bisexual spikes 0–2. Small accessory spikes occasionally present at base of basal pistillate spikes. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.5–3.2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets broadly ovate, 3.5–5.0 × 1.5–2.5 mm, shorter and narrower than the perigynium, ferruginous, glabrous; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex usually emarginate, shortly awned; awn 0.5–1.0 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium spreading (usually), or reflexed, stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 4–6 r 1.2–2.5 mm, elliptic or rotund in cross-section, much inflated (‘hump-backed’), green, or stramineous, with or without ferruginous spots, base without a layer of corky material, cartilaginous, glabrous, nerves conspicuous, many (more than 10); rostrum abrupt, 1.0–1.2 mm long, straight, margin not winged, glabrous; rostrum apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.3–0.6 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base slightly bent, or straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate, not clawed, 2.2–2.8 2 1.2–1.8 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-subinflata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","ff77aeeb-b0f3-44cb-b7e8-106dd2d2861c#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231329","general","<p>Plants not cespitose. Culms obtusely angled, 3–15 cm, glabrous. Leaves: basal sheaths brown; sheaths of proximal leaves glabrous, fronts lacking spots and veins, apex U-shaped; blades epistomic, strongly involute, 1–2 mm wide, adaxially papillose. Proximal bract longer than inflorescence, 1–3 mm wide, spathelike at base and enclosing spike. Spikes erect; staminate 1(–2); pistillate 1–3; proximal pistillate spike 0.5–1.4 cm × 2–4 mm, base cuneate. Pistillate scales bright brown to dark purple-brown, 2–3.6 × 0.9–1.5 mm, wider than perigynia, midvein reaching apex, 1/5–1/2 the width of scale, apex acute, rarely acuminate, mucronate to short-aristate. Perigynia ascending, pale brown, sometimes with purple-brown spots on apical 1/2, veinless, somewhat inflated, loosely enclosing achenes, narrowly ellipsoid to narrowly ovoid, 2.7–3.3(–3.6) × 1–1.8 mm, leathery, dull, base with stipe to 0.3 mm, apex acute, short-papillose; beak widely conic, 0.1–0.3 × 0.3–0.5 mm. Achenes entire to slightly constricted on margins, apex truncate to retuse, dull; style base straight, rarely bent. 2n = 78, 80–83.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-subspathacea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","213755c0-6dcd-43fc-9f17-bd0013caa380#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231347","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with shortly creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 10-20 cm tall.  Leaves: 2-3 mm wide, longer than culms, glaucous green, papillate. Basal sheaths: pale brown. Bracts: setaceous, with short sheath. Pistillate scales: reddish brown, apex obtuse. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear cylindrical, 1-1.5 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, erect, cylindrical, 1-2 cm long, sessile.       Perigynia: as long as or shorter than pistillate scales, oblong ovoid, 3-4 mm long, papillate, sometimes brownish spotted, beakless, mouth truncate. Achenes: loosely enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 2.5 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231368","general","<p>Plant forming small dense tufts from long creeping rhizome. <i>Stems</i> 8-10 cm, slender, erect, trigonous, scabrid above; basal sheaths reddish-brown. <i>Leaves</i> 0.8-1.5 mm broad, shorter than <i>Stems</i> , long-attenuate, flat but revolute when dry, scabrid above and on margins, greyish-green. Male spike 1, linear, pale brown, subsessile. Female spikes 1-2, approximate and near male, ovoid or subglobose, 5-8 mm, rather dense but only with 3-9 flowers; lowest bract glumaceous or very shortly setaceous, brownish, scarious, without sheath. Female glumes ovate to narrowly ovate, pale reddish-brown, c. as long as utricles, acute to acuminate, hyaline-margined. <i>Utricles </i> lemon-yellow but often brownish-orange at top, broadly obovoid, 3-3.8 mm, subcoriaceous and often fracturing when dry, shining, almost veinless, abruptly contracted into short cylindrical, smooth, brown, truncate to bifid beak to 1 mm. <i>Nut </i> greyish- olive, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-supina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","6d677696-10e2-4cb9-b1f2-f9a6a12e8dc7#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231389","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer, in the midlands, in KwaZulu-Natal and Eastern Cape. It is apparently fairly recently adventive in southern Africa; it is common and widespread in Europe and Asia Minor, adventive in North Africa (Algeria), North America and New Zealand (Healy & Edgar, 1980).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-sylvatica-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","81993109-8f8f-4ac3-b4cc-d675ce843d90#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231389","general","<p>Cespitosa. Tallos fértiles 20-70(200) cm, lisos, agudamente trígonos. Hojas (2)4-7(12) mm de anchura, de menor longitud que los tallos, planas, ásperas en los bordes, ± rígidas; lígula hasta 1,5-3(5) mm, de ápice obtuso; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, pardas, enteras, rara vez un poco fibrosas. Bráctea inferior foliácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia, muy raramente algo mayor, con una vaina mayor de 20 mm. Espigas masculinas 1-3(7), de 14-45 mm, fusiformes, a veces con algún utrículo en la base y ocasionalmente alguna ginecandra; espigas femeninas 3-4, de (10)30-50(75) mm, estrechamente cilíndricas, separadas o las superiores agrupadas, con largos pedúnculos filiformes, colgantes. Glumas masculinas oblongas u obovadas, agudas, subagudas u obtusas, raramente con un mucrón corto, de color pardo; glumas femeninas ovales, aristadas, de menor longitud que los utrículos, verdosas, hialinas o, excepcionalmente, de color pardo muy pálido con ancho margen escarioso. Utrículos (3,8)4,5-5(5,3) × 1-1,2(1,5) mm, suberectos, ovoides, trígonos, verdosos o parduscos, con solo 2 nervios prominentes, aunque en ocasiones se hace visible alguno más, bruscamente estrechados en un pico de 1,2-2(2,3) mm, bífido, liso o raramente con acúleos dispersos. Aquenios (2)2,2-2,5 × 0,9-1,4 mm, de contorno oval, trígonos (excepcionalmente de sección cuadrangular), de color verdoso o pardo claro.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-sylvatica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","c019916a-87aa-4702-bd07-09da4fb44ad5#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231389","general","<p>Plants about 470 mm tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 1.5–3.0 mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves dark green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade 450 × 7–9 mm, flat in cross-section; adaxial and abaxial surfaces glabrous; margins proximally papillate, distally scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, membranous; ligule 5 mm high, stramineous or fuscous, membranous, apex emarginate. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1.5–2.0 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 1–2 nodes exposed. Inflorescence a raceme of spikes, 200–330 mm long. Basal inflorescence bract leaf-like, not reflexed near base of blade at maturity; sheath 25–50 mm long; blade 300 mm long; opposing bracteole tubular, membranous, usually concealed by bract sheath. Primary inflorescence units 1 from each node. Spikes 7–8, erect or suberect, not clustered, excepting frequently apical 2–3 (usually staminate) spikes; the largest 35–45 s 6–7 mm. Longest peduncle exserted by 35–70 mm, scabrid on angles. Apical spikes usually staminate. Staminate spikes 1. Pistillate spikes 6–7. Bisexual spikes 0. Small accessory spikes not present. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.2 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets lanceolate, 4–5 × 1.5 mm, the same length as and narrower than the perigynium, hyaline with ferruginous striae, glabrous; carina broad, 3-nerved; apex acute, awned; awn 0.5–1.0 mm long; awn margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, stipitate, without a basal callus, rostrate, 4.5–4.7 t 1.3 mm, triangular with rounded base in cross-section, not inflated, green or golden brown, base without a layer of corky material, membranous, glabrous, nerves few (2 or 3) or inconspicuous; rostrum abrupt, 2 mm long, straight, margin not winged, scabrid; rostrum apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.2 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet elliptic, not clawed, 2.3–2.4 × 1.3–1.4 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, glabrous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-sylvatica-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","81993109-8f8f-4ac3-b4cc-d675ce843d90#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231478","general","<p>Plants loosely cespitose; rhizomes long, slender. Culms ± erect, weak, 10–50 cm. Leaves: sheaths pale brown abaxially, inner band hyaline, concave at summit; ligules as long as wide; blades pale green, flat or channeled, 5–15 cm × 0.5–2 mm. Inflorescences erect, ovoid or suborbicular, 0.6–1.2 cm × 4–9 mm; proximal bracts scalelike, sometimes bristlelike, shorter than inflorescences. Spikes 2–4, gynecandrous, closely approximate, containing 3–15 perigynia, short-oblong, 4–9 × 3–6 mm. Pistillate scales white-hyaline with green, 3-veined center, ovate, subequal to perigynia, apex obtuse. Perigynia appressed-ascending, gray-green, obscurely few-veined, obovate-elliptic, 3–3.5 × 1.5–1.75 mm, subcoriaceous; beak absent or nearly so. Achenes pale brown, oblong-elliptic, 1.5–2 × 1.25(–1.5) mm, glossy. 2n = 58.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-tenuiflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-section-glareosae-g-don","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","94fc276c-0b31-4c91-9732-4209ce66f924#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231571","distribution","<p>Carex tincta, clarified by thorough review of herbarium materials, has a much narrower geographic range than previously thought, from southern New England and easternmost New York, north into adjacent areas of Canada from southern Quebec to the Canadian Maritimes, centering on Maine (USA) with rare scattered occurrences to western Lake Superior.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-tincta-fernald-fernald-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","a5a0eafa-cf4b-4022-bedb-be8679303cbb#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231571","habitat","<p>Moist to dry open or lightly shaded habitats in acidic, sandy or gravelly soils. Vegetation cover is often sparse, and many sites are early successional disturbed habitats such as old fields, roadside banks, railroad rights-of-way, and borrow pits. Natural habitats are few, but include the drier, upper shores of rivers and lakes.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-tincta-fernald-fernald-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","a5a0eafa-cf4b-4022-bedb-be8679303cbb#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231571","look_alikes","<p>C. tincta readily separable from the other members of the C. tenera group by the unique combination of compact, erect inflorescences and strongly papillose leaf sheaths.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-tincta-fernald-fernald-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","a5a0eafa-cf4b-4022-bedb-be8679303cbb#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231571","morphology","Plant: Cespitose, forming small, more or less erect clumps with typically (3-) 5-9 culms  Vegetative shoots: annual, few, ca. 20-35 cm tall during fruiting season, leaves 5 to 8, lower 1-2 evenly spaced along culm, the rest clustered apically. Culms: 25-85 cm tall, erect, trigonous, smooth except for finely scabrous angles just below the inflorescence, 0.5-0.8 mm in diameter just below the inflorescence Inflorescence: 1.2-2.5 (-3.5) cm long, stiff and compact, spikes approximate and overlapping, the lowest spikes 1.5-6 (-10) mm apart, the spikes single at nodes, sessile; lowermost bracts 2.5-18 mm long, the tip often an aristate bristle shorter than or sometimes exceeding the spike, sheathless, upper bracts much reduced. Leaves: bladeless basal sheaths pale to dark purple-brown, disintegrating into short brown fibers. Leaves 2-4, on the lower 1/6-1/3 of the culm; blades 2-28 cm long, 1.8-4.3 mm wide, flat to slightly plicate, glabrous or papillose adaxially, the margins and midrib smooth to antrorsely scabrous; leaf sheaths ca. 1.5-28 cm long, tightly enveloping the culms, finely papillose (at 30×) especially near collar, pale, yellowish-green, or light brown, sparsely septate-nodulose; ventral sheaths with a distinct Y-shaped hyaline area reaching 4-20 mm below the orifice, its apex concave, truncate or sometimes V-shaped, extending up to 0.5 mm above the base of the blade; ligules 1.5-3.5 mm long, rounded, the free portion entire and up to 0.5 mm long. Pistillate scales: 2.4-4 × 1-1.5 mm, reaching the lower 2/5 of perigynium beak to nearly as long as the perigynium, 0.2-1.1 mm shorter than the perigynia, 2.1-3.5 times longer than wide, ovate to lanceolate, sharply acute or somewhat obtuse, usually rust- to chestnut-brown tinged, with a narrow pale brown center and hyaline margins, 1-nerved or faintly 3-nerved, the midnerve usually extending to the tip. Spikes: 4-11, gynecandrous, 5-10 mm long, ellipsoid to globose, bases usually acute, apices rounded or broadly acute, pistillate portion 5-8.5 × 3.6-6.5 mm, ca. 10-35 flowered, staminate portion 0.5-3 × 1-2 mm, ca. 4-12 flowered. Staminate scales: 2.7-3.5 × 1.1-1.7 mm, ovate to elliptic, obtuse, rust-brown tinged, with narrow yellowish-green center and hyaline margins, 1-nerved or faintly 3-nerved.     Anthers: ca. 1.7-1.8 mm long. Perigynia: 3.5-4.7 (-5) × 1.5-2.4 mm, 1.6-2.5 times as long as wide, glabrous, sessile, ascending to ascending-spreading, plano-convex, 0.45-0.6 mm thick, more or less thin and membranous; bodies ovate, broadly ovate, or broadly elliptic, 2.3-3 mm long, 1.1-1.5 times as long as wide and 1.3-2.5 times as long as beak, widest 1.0-1.45 mm above the base, narrowly thin-winged, wings 0.25-0.45 mm wide, the margin finely serrulate to shoulder of body, entire below, gradually tapered into a beak, the wing margin quickly maturing to pale or medium-brown, the body often darker brown than the margin, distinctly 3 to 7-nerved adaxially over achene, distinctly 4 to 8-nerved abaxially over achene and 2-nerved in the winged margin; beaks 1-1.8 mm long, strongly flattened and serrulate-margined to apex, pale to medium brown, the dorsal suture hyaline to dark rust-brown, the apex inconspicuously bidentate with teeth 0.1-0.7 mm long, distance from summit of achene to tip of beak 1.7-2.3 mm long. Achenes: 1.3-1.6 × 0.9-1.2 mm, 1.2-1.8 times as long as wide, biconvex, ovate to broadly elliptic, pale to dark brown, very short-stipitate at base, apiculum 0.1-0.3 mm long; style straight. Stigmas: 2.    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Paul E. Rothrock, Anton A. Reznicek, and Andrew L. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231577","morphology","Plant: perennial densely caespitose.     Leaves: 5-10 mm wide, stiff, light green, scabrous. Basal sheaths: pale brown, purplish brown along veins, slightly fibrillose. Bracts: upper blades setaceous, 3-10 cm long, lower bracts leaf-like, 50 cm long.<br /><br/><br /><br/> Pistillate scales: brown, apex acute. Spikes: peduncles 4-8 at each node, long pedunculate, drooping, androgynous, staminate 4-5 times as long as pistillate section, 3-6 cm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231586","general","<p>Rizoma de entrenudos largos, generalmente delgado, a veces laxamente cespitoso. Tallos (8)15-40(50) cm, obtusamente trígonos, lisos o ligeramente escábridos hacia el ápice. Hojas (0,6)1,5-2,5(2,9) mm de anchura, de longitud menor que los tallos, ásperas en los bordes y nervio medio del envés, ± planas, blandas, rectas o algo curvadas, glaucas, frecuentemente pubescentes en el envés y en las vainas; lígula hasta 2 mm, de ápice obtuso o agudo; sin antelígula; vainas basales escuamiformes, enteras, de color púrpura o pardo-purpúreo. Bráctea inferior foliácea o setácea, de menor longitud que la inflorescencia o raramente algo mayor, no envainante o con una vaina muy corta; espiga masculina solitaria, de (8)10-20(24) mm, linear o estrechamente fusiforme. Espigas femeninas (1)2-3, de (5)7-12(15) mm, ovoides o cortamente oblongas, densifloras, sésiles, agrupadas junto a la masculina. Glumas masculinas obovadas, agudas u obtusas, de color pardo generalmente obscuro, con o sin margen escarioso, con la quilla verde; glumas femeninas de anchamente ovales a orbiculares, agudas o mucronuladas, de color pardo generalmente obscuro, menores que los utrículos, sin o con un estrecho margen escarioso.
