"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231605","morphology","Plant: Densely to loosely cespitose. Below-ground structures: Rhizomes ascending to erect, brown to reddish brown, 0–10 mm, stout.  Culms: 4–16 cm, scabrous distally; bases (remnants of old leaves) fibrous.  Inflorescence: Inflorescences with both staminate and pistillate scales; peduncles of basal pistillate spikes erect, short to elongate, stout to slender; peduncles of staminate spikes 0.8–15 mm; proximal nonbasal bracts scalelike, shorter than inflorescences.  Leaves: Leaf blades pale to bright green, equaling or exceeding stems, 0.5–4.3 mm wide, herbaceous or coriaceous, glabrous abaxially, strongly scabrous to papillose adaxially. Pistillate scales: Pale brown to reddish brown, with narrow white margins, ovate, 2.9–4.1 × 1.5–1.9 mm, equaling or exceeding perigynia, apex acute to long-acuminate. Spikes: Proximal pistillate spikes 2–3 (basal spikes 1–2); cauline spikes usually overlapping with staminate spikes, with 3–10(–15) perigynia; staminate spikes 4.5–11.3 × 1.1–3 mm. Staminate scales: Ovate, 4.2–5.4 × 1.2–2.1 mm, apex obtuse or acute to acuminate.      Anthers: 1.6–2.9 mm.  Perigynia: Green to pale brown, veinless, ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous in cross section, 3.1–4.7 × 1.1–1.6 mm; beak straight, pale green, occasionally with reddish brown tinge near apex, strongly 2-edged, 0.9–2 mm, smooth or ciliate-serrulate, apical teeth 0.2–0.5 mm.  Achenes: Brown, ellipsoid to obovoid, obtusely trigonous in cross section, 1.6–2 × 1.2–1.6 mm.    Elevation: 50–1000 m. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231654","general","<p>Rhizomatous perennial; rhizome somewhat creeping. Culms usually solitary, central, 15-50 cm by 0.6-1.2 mm, triquetrous, angles narrowly winged and densely scabrid above. Leaves basal and 1-3-cauline; blade broadly linear, 20-45 cm by 4-11 mm, acuminate, flat; sheath up to 5 cm long, green to dark brown, basal sheaths becoming fibrous. Lowest involucral bract leaf-like, up to 10 cm long. Inflorescence with 1-3(-4) spikes, the upper 2-3 spikes forming a head, the lowermost usually distant. Spikes ± sessile, ovoid-globose, 0.6-1.2 cm long, androgynous, upper section male, lower female. Female glumes ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 2.5-4 mm long, acute to subacute, awned or mucronate, sides membranous, white, densely hispid, keel 3-nerved, whitish. Utricles patent, ellipsoid, trigonous, 4.2-5.8 by 1.8-2 mm, whitish to brownish, several-nerved, densely hispid-pilose, abruptly narrowed into beak; beak 1-2 mm long, apex minutely 2-toothed. Stigmas 3. Nutlets broadly elliptic to obovate-elliptic, triquetrous, 2.5-3 by 1.7-2 mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-tricephala-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-8","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b8868464-24cf-4023-a912-52a356b0d2b7#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231749","morphology","Plant: Loosely cespitose or with solitary stems. Below-ground structures: Rhizomes ascending, brown, 0–5 mm, stout or absent.   Culms: 21–47 cm, scabrous distally; bases (remnants of old leaves) fibrous.  Inflorescence: Inflorescences with both staminate and pistillate spikes; peduncles of staminate spikes 1.1–10 mm; proximal nonbasal bracts leaflike, equaling or exceeding inflorescences.  Leaves: Leaf blades green, shorter than culms, 2–3.5 mm wide, herbaceous to coriaceous, papillose to scabrous abaxially, papillose to slightly scabrous adaxially.  Pistillate scales: Whitish or pale brown to dark reddish brown, with narrow to broad white margins, ovate to lanceolate, 4.2–4.5 × 1.7–2.5 mm, equaling perigynia, apex acuminate or short-awned. Spikes: Proximal pistillate spikes 2–5 (basal spikes 0); cauline spikes with the proximal separated, with 4–10 perigynia; staminate spikes (5.3–) 9.6–26.2 × (1–)1.4–3.4 mm. Staminate scales: Ovate to obovate, 6–6.2 × 1.6–2 mm, apex obtuse or acute to acuminate or short-awned.     Anthers: 2.2–3.3 mm.  Perigynia: Pale green to yellow or pale brown, 10–25-veined to at least mid body, obovoid to globose, 3.1–4.2 × 1.5–2.4 mm, as long as wide; beak straight, pale green to pale brown, 0.4–1.1 mm, smooth, apical teeth 0.1–0.4 mm.  Achenes: Brown, globose, round in cross section, 1.6–2.6 × 1.5–2.4 mm. Stigmas: 3.    Elevation: 600–3300 m. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231786","morphology","Plant: Densely cespitose. Below-ground structures: Rhizomes ascending to erect, reddish brown, 0–5 mm, stout.  Culms: 3–7.5(–18) cm, scabrous distally; bases (remnants of old leaves) weakly to strongly fibrous. Inflorescence: Inflorescences with both staminate and proximal spikes; peduncles of basal spikes erect, short to elongate, slender; peduncle of staminate spikes 0.7–5.2(–12.3) mm; proximal nonbasal bracts scalelike, usually shorter than (occasionally equaling) inflorescences.  Leaves: Leaf blades pale green, greatly exceeding culms, 1–2.3(–3.8) mm wide, herbaceous, glabrous abaxially, strongly scabrous to papillose adaxially. Pistillate scales: Reddish brown with narrow white margins, ovate, 2.8–3.9 × 1.5–1.9 mm, equaling or exceeding perigynia, apex acute to acuminate. Spikes: Proximal pistillate spikes 2–5 (basal spikes 1–3); cauline spikes overlapping with staminate spikes, with (1–)4–12 perigynia; staminate spikes 4.6–13 × 0.7–2.2 mm. Staminate scales: Ovate to lanceolate, 3.5–5.1 × 1.1–2.2 mm, apex obtuse to acute.     Anthers: 1.7–2.2 mm. Perigynia: Pale green to pale brown, veinless, obovoid to globose, rarely ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous in cross section, 2.2–3.2 × 1–1.4 mm; beak straight, pale green to pale brown, strongly 2-edged, 0.4–1 mm, weakly ciliate-serrulate, apical teeth 0.1–0.2 mm. Achenes: Brown, ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous in cross section, 1.4–1.7 × 1–1.3 mm. Stigmas: 3.    Elevation: 90–300 m. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231824","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose; rhizomes creeping.   Culms: thick, 15-40cm tall, smooth. Inflorescence: racemose, with 4-5 spikes.  Leaves: M-shaped in cross section, 5-10 mm wide, dorsal surfaces scabrous. Basal sheaths: bladeless, reddish or purplish brown. Bracts: setaceous, with long sheaths.  Pistillate scales: oblong ovoid, 4-6mm long, scarious, midribs reddish brown or purplish brown, apex shortly awned. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, oblong ellipsoidal, 1.5-4cm long, pedunculate; lateral spikes pistillate, erect or ascending, cylindrical, 2-4cm long, pedunculate.        Perigynia:  shorter than pistillate scales, ascending to patent, broadly ovoid, 2.5-3.5mm long, glabrous, base cuneate or shortly stipitate, long beaked, mouth bidentate. Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigyniura, broadly ovoid, 1.5-2mm long, shortly stipitate, style base slightly annulated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231833","general","<p>Plants densely cespitose; rhizomes short. Culms often slightly curved, weak, 2–10 cm. Leaves: sheaths pale to mid brown abaxially, loose, inner band white-hyaline, concave at summit; ligules shorter than wide; blades usually pale to gray-green, flat at base, involute distally, 1–5 cm × 0.5–1.5 mm, exceeding culms. Perigynia closely appressed, gray-brown to pale or mid brown, lightly or obscurely several-veined, ovate, 1.5–2 × 1.25 mm, widest near middle, subcoriaceous; beak short, entire. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231852","general","<p>Plants colonial; rhizomes long. Culms trigonous in cross section, 25–100 cm, smooth or somewhat scabrous-angled distally. Leaves: basal sheaths brown or lightly tinged with pinkish red, spongy-thickened; ligules as long as wide; blades pale to mid green, flat to broadly V-shaped, widest leaves 4.5–12(–15) mm wide, glabrous. Inflorescences 10–40(–50) cm; proximal bract 12–55(–75) cm, exceeding but not more than 2.5 times longer than inflorescence; proximal 2–5 spikes pistillate, erect or the proximal ascending, ca. 20–150-flowered, cylindric; terminal 2–5 spikes staminate, well elevated beyond summit of separate pistillate spikes. Pistillate scales lanceolate ovate, 2.6–5.5(–7.6) × 0.8–1.7(–2.1) mm, mostly shorter than perigynia, margins entire, apex acute to acuminate, awnless (rarely acuminate-awned). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231852","morphology","Plant: strongly clonal, often forming monotypic colonies. Below-ground structures: long-rhizomatous. Leaves: basal sheaths spongy-thickened, brown or red-tinged; blades mostly over 5 mm broad, broader blades distinctly septate-nodulose. Pistillate scales: awnless, margins entire. Spikes: lateral spikes pistillate spikes oblong to cylindrical, the longest to 7 – 10 cm long, occasionally tipped with male flowers, arching or ascending; distal 2-5 spikes staminate, occasionally gynecandrous, tipped with perigynia. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231857","general","<p>Plants not cespitose. Culms acutely angled, 15–60 cm, scabrous or glabrous. Leaves: basal sheaths brown; sheaths of proximal leaves glabrous, fronts lacking spots and veins, apex U-shaped; blades usually amphistomic, 2.8–4 mm wide, papillose or glabrous. Inflorescences: peduncle of proximal pistillate spike 0.6–1.7 cm; proximal bract equal to or longer than inflorescence, 2.5–5 mm wide. Spikes erect or the proximal pendent; proximal 2–4 spikes pistillate, 2.8–5 cm × 5–7 mm, base cuneate or attenuate; terminal 1–3 spikes staminate. Pistillate scales dark purple-brown, 2.5–5.5 × 0.9–1.8 mm (including awn), narrower than perigynia, midvein not reaching apex, 1/10–1/3 the width of scale, apex acuminate, aristate, awn scabrous. Perigynia ascending, pale brown, prominently 2–5-veined on each face, somewhat inflated, loosely enclosing achenes, thin-walled, widely ellipsoid to obovoid, 2.5–3.3 × 1.5–2.2 mm, dull, base with stipe to 0.2–0.5 mm, apex acute to rounded, papillose; beak weakly cylindric, 0.1–0.3 × 0.2–0.3 mm, entire. Achenes entire or slightly constricted on 1 face, apex rounded to slightly truncate, dull; style base straight to bent. 2n = 78, 79.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vacillans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","37eb885e-636b-463b-a964-efa3b65ff3b1#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231857","habitat","<p>Saline, brackish shores, swales, salt and intertidal marshes; 0–10 m;</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vacillans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-linnaeus-sect-phacocystis-dumortier","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","37eb885e-636b-463b-a964-efa3b65ff3b1#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231861","diagnostic","<p>Similar to C. panicea in its few-flowered spike and utricle shape but distinguished by the yellow-or bronzy-green (not glaucous) colouring of the leaves with their flat, abruptly tapered tips. In fruit the apple-green utricles and the loose sheaths of both the bracts and the markedly short leaves at the base of the stem are distinctive. Potential hybrids may be found where the two species grow together but are so far unconfirmed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vaginata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","68755543-7871-4dd5-8600-ad4c670e3552#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231861","distribution","<p>Carex vaginata is locally abundant in Highland Scotland but very local in the Southern Uplands (v.cc. 72, 78 and 79). In 2002 it was confirmed for Dufton Fell, v.c. 69 (Corner 2004), and further records between 2003 and 2005 extended the range to v.c. 70 and, most recently, to v.c. 65 (Corner et al. 2006).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vaginata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","68755543-7871-4dd5-8600-ad4c670e3552#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231861","distribution","<p>Japan: Hokkaido, Honshu and Kyushu (including Tsushima). Amr and Korea.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vaginata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","c676aa51-3281-4f65-b4b4-caccca1ea3d5#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231861","ecology","<p>An alpine plant usually occurring above 700 m, although recorded at 370 m on Creag an Eirionnaich, v.c. 88 (Foley & Porter 2002). On wet rocky sills on often vertical cliffs with Luzula sylvatica, Geum rivale, Angelica sylvestris and other tall herbs (U17) and on rock outcrops with Silene acaulis and dwarf shrubs such as Dryas octopetala and several rare Arctic-Alpine willows (CG14). A component of Carex saxatilis mires (M12) in the Breadalbane mountains and along streams in sedge-dominated mires and on small (well-drained?) ledges in the Grampians, where it is often abundant but usually shy-flowering and therefore liable to be overlooked. In the Pennines it grows in damp grassland below limestone escarpments. Recent findings of C. vaginata in flower in England, probably as a result of cessation of grazing after sheep-culling during the foot and mouth epidemic, suggest that intensive grazing on hill communities is an important factor (cf. Robinson 2003). Work using DNA fingerprinting (French et al. 2005) suggests these plants must have been present in these sites for a considerable period of time.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vaginata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","68755543-7871-4dd5-8600-ad4c670e3552#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:231861","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping; shoots tufted; roots brown; scales grey-brown, fibrous. <i>Stems </i> 15-40 cm, trigonous-subterete, striate. <i>Leaves </i> up to 60 cm × 3-6 mm, keeled, parallel-sided for much of their length and rather abruptly tapered to a flat point, yellow-to bronze-green, basal decumbent, those on the flowering stem subulate, at the very base only and 1-3 cm long; hypostomous; sheaths pale brown to dirty white, loose; ligule c. 2 mm, obtuse to subacute. <i>Inflorescence </i> 3/4 length of stem; lower bracts loosely sheathing (funnel-shaped) and shorter than spike. Male spike 1, 1-1.5 cm, ± clavate; male glumes more than 4.5 mm, orange-brown, with paler midrib. <i>Female spikes</i>  1-2(-3), 1-2 cm, ± distant, erect, few-and lax-flowered; female glumes 3 mm, broadly ovate, red-brown, with paler midrib; apex acute or mucronate. <i>Utricles</i>  3.8-5 mm, broadly obovoid, hardly inflated, ribbed; beak obliquely truncate, c. 1 mm; stigmas 3; nut ovoid-trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vaginata-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","68755543-7871-4dd5-8600-ad4c670e3552#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232043","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with long fine creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 10-25 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.  Leaves: 1-2 mm wide. Basal sheaths: light brown. Bracts: leaf-like, longer than inflorescence. Pistillate scales: pale green, apex shortly aristate. Spikes: 2-4, crowded at apex of culm; terminal spike staminate, small, linear, 3-5 mm long, pale green; lateral spikes pistillate, cylindrical, 3-6 mm long, sessile.       Perigynia: longer than pistillate scales, ovoid, 2 mm long, obscure veined, puberulent, shortly beaked, mouth notched.  Achenes: tightly enveloped by perigynium, obovoid, 1-1.2 mm long, style base minutely annulated. Stigmas: 3    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Takuji Hoshino <br /><br/>Additional authors: Tomomi Masaki <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: March, 2011.<br /><br/>Sources: Illustrated Sedges of Japan.","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-cyperaceae-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","101ec9fb-dccb-4d09-beee-aa515dbeb87c","","e21e50ee-18cc-4a73-aec9-05638603fca0#morphology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232045","general","<p>Var. bergrothii is a larger form within the variation of this subspecies. It is the tallest (typically 25-30 cm) of the segregates of subsp. viridula and may resemble an erect form of subsp. oedocarpa. It may be readily distinguished from the latter taxon by its upright and straight, not curved, culm, its narrower, erect leaves and, in particular, its ecological preferences. From the other segregate within subsp. viridula, var. bergrothii may be separated by its relatively large (3.2-4 mm long), conspicuously nerved, inflated, light green utricles that become yellow at maturity; these contrast strongly with the pale reddish-brown glumes with a distinct green midrib. The beak is relatively long (0.6-1.2 mm), straight to slightly deflexed, with a minutely scabrous margin. The 2 3(-4) female spikes are contiguous to often rather distant. It has been found in wet, base-rich fens and lake-shores, usually with a fluctuating water regime (e.g. in turloughs), so far only in W Ireland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-var-bergrothii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4fa019e8-d8b2-4421-8bbb-f1accff4de74#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232046","diagnostic","<p>The characters and ecology described may be taken as those of var. brachyrhyncha, but we recognise two further taxa at varietal rank. All these taxa grade into subsp. oedocarpa. Usually the ratio of leaf-length to stem-length is a good character to separate them. Additionally, the utricle in var. brachyrhyncha has a more gradual transition to a longer, deflexed beak, compared to the distinct shoulder on that of subsp. oedocarpa, where the beak is usually straight (but see var. jemtlandica).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-brachyrhyncha-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f58e60f4-8bf9-4f14-ac20-8cfca236f262#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232046","distribution","<p>The distribution of Carex viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha sensu lato follows that of base-rich strata, with sodium perhaps replacing calcium in coastal habitats. Var. jemtlandica has only been confirmed for Ireland, where it may be the more common variety on the turloughs of the west; fieldwork in W and N Scotland may reveal it there also. The upland var. scotica now needs to be recorded in detail.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-brachyrhyncha-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f58e60f4-8bf9-4f14-ac20-8cfca236f262#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232046","ecology","<p>Carex viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha probably has the most exacting ecological requirements of all the taxa in the C. flava group and is an indicator of good-quality base-rich habitats. It is a strong calcicole, as seedling growth is stunted by soluble aluminum ions released at low pH (Clymo 1960), and may be found occurring on base-rich fens and other wet areas that are regularly flushed with base-rich waters. C. viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha has been recorded from the following NVC communities: Carex rostrata-Sphagnum warnstorjii-Calliergonella cuspidata mires (M8, M9), Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris mire (M10), Saxifraga aizoides communities (M11, U15), Schoenus nigricans-Juncus subnodulosus mire (M13), Juncus subnodulosus-Cirsium palustre fen-meadow (M22) and springs dominated by Palustriella commutata (M37, M38); also in the Cicuta virosa sub-community of Phragmites-Peucedanum palustre tall-herb fen (S24e) and the Blysmus rufus saltmarsh community (SM19). See also Davies (1953b ).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-brachyrhyncha-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f58e60f4-8bf9-4f14-ac20-8cfca236f262#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232046","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots loosely tufted; roots pale buff-brown; scales grey-brown. <i>Stems </i> 20-80 cm, trigonous, solid, rough below spikes. <i>Leaves </i> 10-40 cm × 1.2-3.5(-5.4) mm, usually only 1/3-1/2 as long as stem, keeled, ± abruptly narrowed to a rough, blunt, trigonous point, mid-to yellow-green, becoming bleached straw colour, not overwintering; hypostomous; sheaths hyaline, ribbed, becoming pink-brown and fibrous; apex of inner face ± straight; ligule 1 mm, rounded, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> 1/10-1/4 length of stem; bracts leaf-like or the upper glumaceous, occasionally reflexed, exceeding inflorescence. Male spike 1, 10-20 mm, often on a conspicuous (up to 28 mm long) peduncle that is set at an angle to the flowering stem; male glumes 3-3.5 mm, lanceolate-elliptic, orange-or red-brown, with green midrib; apex subacute. <i>Female spikes</i>  1-3(-4), densely clustered to slightly distant, 8-15 mm, ovoid to cylindrical, sessile or lowermost with an ensheathed short peduncle; female glumes falling before the utricle, 2.5-4 mm, ovate-lanceolate, orange-or red-brown, with green midrib and often hyaline margin; apex acute. <i>Utricles</i>  3-5.5 mm, obovoid-trigonous, ribbed, yellow-green, patent, the lower deflexed; beak 1.5-2 mm, split, arcuate or deflexed in side view; stigmas 3; nut obovoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-brachyrhyncha-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f58e60f4-8bf9-4f14-ac20-8cfca236f262#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232049","general","<p>Culms 2–85 cm. Leaves of flowering stems much shorter than culms, to 19 cm × 1–5.4 mm; ligules of distal cauline leaves truncate or rounded. Inflorescences: peduncles of terminal staminate spikes to 25 mm; proximal pistillate spikes 1–4, 5.4–11 mm wide; terminal staminate spikes 5.1–25.3 × 1.3–3.6 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232050","diagnostic","<p>This variety is most readily distinguished by examination of the female spikes and utricles. The female spikes are generally contiguous to approximate and often clustered close to the sessile or shortly stalked male spike. The straight-beaked utricles are much more loosely packed, and this gives the female spikes a much more globose to ovate appearance. Unlike in var. brachyrhyncha, the lowermost female spikes of var. jemtlandica often have fewer utricles than the upper spikes, and this may also give the inflorescence an asymmetrical appearance. The part of the flowering stem just below the inflorescence of var. jemtlandica is smooth, as opposed to the rough flowering stem of the type variety.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-var-jemtlandica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","189306b7-4e08-4035-990a-7f2bce65330c#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232054","diagnostic","<p>Small stunted plants can be confused with subsp. viridula, but the straight stems, smaller utricles and clustered spikes distinguish that subspecies.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-oedocarpa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8ff79bac-3d8e-4f13-b039-5890feb2ad05#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232054","distribution","<p>Carex viridula subsp. oedocarpa is widespread in Britain, especially common in the N and W (at 0-930 m: Porter & Foley 2002) but less common in the chalk and limestone area of East Anglia, SE Midlands and S England. In Ireland it is common but scarcer in the central base-rich areas.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-oedocarpa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8ff79bac-3d8e-4f13-b039-5890feb2ad05#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232054","ecology","<p>A plant of similar mire habitats to C. viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha but usually found where the calcium concentration is less than 30 ppm. It can withstand a higher aluminium concentration than subsp. brachyrhyncha and is often found on inorganic soils, e.g. gravel of lake margins. It is a constant component of the following NVC communities: M11 C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa-Saxifraga aizoides mire, M12 Carex saxatilis mire, M34 C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa-Koenigia islandica flush and M38 Palustriella commutata-Carex nigra spring communities. Its ecological tolerance is shown by its occurrence in the following: M6, M8-10, M15, Ml7, M23, M29, M31, M32 and M37 mires, SD14 dune-slacks, MG8 mesotrophic grassland, CG10 and CG12 calcareous grasslands and U5, U15 and Ul7 montane communities.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-oedocarpa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8ff79bac-3d8e-4f13-b039-5890feb2ad05#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232054","general","<p>Rhizome short; shoots ± densely tufted; roots pale yellow-brown; scales grey-brown, soon fibrous and decaying completely. <i>Stems </i> 5-40 cm, often shorter than leaves, subterete, solid, often slightly curved. <i>Leaves </i> 5-35 cm × 1.5-5 mm, rigid, recurved, ± flat with keeled midrib, ± abruptly tapered at apex, dark yellow-green, dying to straw colour and often overwintering; hypostomous; sheaths hyaline or white with green veins, persistent, becoming grey-brown; apex of inner face ± straight; ligule c. 1 mm, rounded, notched. <i>Inflorescence </i> in upper half of stem but often with solitary distant spike at base; bracts leaf-like, often reflexed, ± flaccid and, except for the lowest, well exceeding inflorescence. Male spike 1, 15-20 mm; male glumes 3-4 mm, oblong-lanceolate, orange-brown to hyaline, with paler midrib; apex obtuse. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-4, ± contiguous but usually the lowest remote, 7- 13 mm, ovoid; peduncles short, the lower up to four times as long as the spike, half ensheathed; female glumes c. 3.5 mm, ovate, brown with green midrib; apex subacute. <i>Utricles</i>  3-4 mm, obovoid, abruptly narrowed into beak, patent, lower deflexed when ripe, yellow-green, faintly ribbed; beak c. 1 mm, occupying less than 1/3 of total length, bifid, not or rarely slightly deflexed (although drying may bring about an unequal collapse of the utricle apex, thus deflecting the beak); stigmas 3; nut obovoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-oedocarpa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","8ff79bac-3d8e-4f13-b039-5890feb2ad05#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232056","general","<p>Var. pulchella is an extreme, usually smaller, form within the range of variation seen in the subspecies; thus it is possible to find plants that are intermediate between this and var. viridula. This is typically a smaller plant, 2-15( 25) cm tall, and may be distinguished from var. viridula by its very small, 1.5 2.5 mm long, feebly ribbed grey-green utricles with a beak 0.2-0.6 mm and completely filled by the nut. Unlike in var. viridula, the tem1inal male spike may be shortly stalked (to 10 mm) and the 2 3(-5) female spikes are often distant. The female glumes are dark brown with a pale green midrib. The dark green leaves are 0.5-2 mm wide (narrower than in var. viridula) and shorter than the culm. Flowering typically occurs from May to July. Var. pulchella is usually found growing as small isolated tufts in area of sparse low-growing vegetation found on the upper reaches of saltmarshes, where typical associates include Eleocharis quinqueflora, Festuca rubra and Juncus gerardii (cf. SM19), and especially on the vertical edges of sandy channels formed by run-off water; also inland on sandy lake-shores.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-var-pulchella-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b5d62bcc-40d9-453a-bdd3-bdd8e11da74f#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232058","ecology","<p>Var. scotica can occur wherever there are suitable base-rich rocky ledges or flush-mire conditions in upland areas, possibly extending the altitudinal limit for the species to c. 1000 m. It is a characteristic component of the rich Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris mire (M10) and C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa-Saxifraga aizoides mire communities (M11) in the Highlands of Scotland and a few outlying areas such as Upper Teesdale. It is generally shorter and stockier in stature than the other two segregates of subsp. brachyrhyncha, being 10-20(-45) cm in height with very short (up to 10 cm), tough fibrous leaves (2.5-4 mm wide), and so is easily confused with subsp. oedocarpa. It should be separable from that taxon by the stout, straight, erect flowering stem and the larger utricles, which are (4-)4.25-4.5(-5) mm long. The female spikes are also characterised by the dark chestnut-brown, persistent glumes.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-var-scotica-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f8750528-2c8a-4213-be2f-c693e1550b0b#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232060","diagnostic","<p>This taxon may usually be separated from the other subspecies by the 1-8 female spikes clustered around a short, sessile to very shortly pedunculate male spike. For distinctions from subsp. oedocarpa see that taxon. Occasionally, especially in inland stations in southern England, the male spike is entirely absent and replaced by a terminal female spike (called C. oederi var. cyperoides Marsson in British literature but not accepted here).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-viridula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7f000761-54b3-42c9-b9c3-e7ba9eb70a6f#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232060","distribution","<p>C. viridula subsp. viridula var. viridula is scattered throughout the British Isles. Var. pulchella is more frequent along sea-loch margins in northern Scotland and the coasts of NW Britain and has been recorded along the whole length of our Atlantic seaboard (see Pcrring & Sell 1968); it is occasionally found inland. Var. bergrothii has so far been confirmed only from Counties Clare (H9), Galway (HI 5/ 16) and Leitrim (1129) but it could occur in Britain also.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-viridula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7f000761-54b3-42c9-b9c3-e7ba9eb70a6f#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232060","ecology","<p>A plant of sparsely vegetated base-rich to base-poor substrates, most commonly kept open by a fluctuating water regime, e.g. around stony lake shores in Carex rostrata-Calliergonella cuspidata/Calliergon giganteum mire (M9). In freshwater marshes, e.g. where Juncus acutiflorus is dominant. Most frequent in maritime situations where salt-laden winds provide calcium and magnesium: dune-slacks with Sagina nodosa-Bryum pseudotriquetrum (SD13), Salix repens communities with Campylium stellatum (SD14) and Holcus lanatus (SD16), Calluna vulgaris-Scilla verna heath (H7) and Festuca rubra-Plantago spp. maritime grassland (MC10). Also found in estuarine marshes and in sea-lochs, often around the high tide level.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-viridula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7f000761-54b3-42c9-b9c3-e7ba9eb70a6f#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232060","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots 4 to many, tufted; roots pale brown; scales pink-or grey-brown, becoming fibrous. <i>Stems </i> 5-40 cm, trigonous-terete, straight. <i>Leaves </i> 15-40 cm × 0.8-3.4 mm, rigid, spreading or erect, flat or ± channelled, with midrib rounded beneath, gradually narrowed to a trigonous blunt tip, yellow-to grey-green, becoming pale grey-brown and persistent on dying, sometimes overwintering; hypostomous; sheaths white or hyaline, becoming grey-brown, persistent; apex of inner face straight; ligule c. 1 mm, rounded, tubular. <i>Inflorescence </i> up to 3/4 length of stem; bracts leaf-like, stiff, spreading but rarely deflexed, much exceeding inflorescence. Male spike 1, 5-20 mm, often pushed over by developing female spike; male glumes c. 4 mm, oblong-lanceolate, orange-brown with pale or green midrib; apex acute. <i>Female spikes</i>  2-5, 5-10 mm, ovoid, upper contiguous and sessile, lower occasionally remote and pedunculate; female glumes 1.5-3 mm, ovate, pale yellow-brown, with green midrib and subacute apex. <i>Utricles</i>  2-3 mm, obovoid to ellipsoid, abruptly or gradually contracted into beak, faintly nerved, yellow-green, slightly inflated or not; beak 0.25-1 mm, straight or only slightly deflexed, split; stigmas 3; nut obovoid, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-viridula-subsp-viridula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7f000761-54b3-42c9-b9c3-e7ba9eb70a6f#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232133","conservation","<p>Carex vulpina is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Vulnerable (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7c4ee41f-ee06-4d74-b077-5868c9d13a4c#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232133","diagnostic","<p>Probably overlooked as a result of confusion with C. otrubae, from which it is distinguished by the very broad, overlapping, truncate ligule (in C. otrubae the ligule is ± acute and narrower than the width of the leaf), the acutely keeled leaf and the split beak to the papillose utricle. The strongly winged stem, the perforated glandular inner face of the leaf-sheaths, the dark auricles of the bracts and the dark young spikes are also diagnostic. Under the microscope C. vulpina has the epidermal cells of the utricle thick-walled and ± square, while those of C. otrubae are thin-walled and oblong (Samuelsson 1922).  <br />Hybrids with C. otrubae have been tentatively identified from W Kent and W Sussex (see p. 212). Hybrids with C. paniculata and C. remota are also recorded, but not in the British Isles.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7c4ee41f-ee06-4d74-b077-5868c9d13a4c#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232133","distribution","<p>Carex vulpina is now local in SE England, Oxon, Glos and SE and NE Yorks; in the last two it has been reintroduced. Formerly also in the Isle of Wight, Berks and Somerset.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7c4ee41f-ee06-4d74-b077-5868c9d13a4c#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232133","ecology","<p>In damp places, often standing in water in ditches and areas flooded in winter, usually on heavy clay soils and over chalk or limestone, enduring shade when encroached upon by shrubs and trees (W1, W2).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7c4ee41f-ee06-4d74-b077-5868c9d13a4c#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232133","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short; shoots stout, densely tufted; roots thick, grey-brown; scales dark brown, remaining only as black fibres. <i>Stems </i> 30-100 cm, smooth below, rough above, sharply trigonous, their faces ± concave and angles winged. <i>Leaves </i> up to 80 cm × 4-10 mm, ± erect, acutely keeled, ± abruptly tapering to a flat, sharp point, dark green even when dry, not auriculate at base; hypostomous; inner face of sheaths glandular, transversely wrinkled and perforated with a vertical line of small holes; apex markedly lingulate; ligule 2-6 mm, truncate, shorter than width of leaf, its free margin overlapping the edges of the leaf-blade. <i>Inflorescence </i> a stout, dense panicle; bracts short, setaceous, with ± prominent dark auricles. <i>Spikes </i> numerous, 8-14 mm, compound, all or most male above and female below. Male glumes 3.5-4 mm, oblanceolate-elliptic, dark or rusty brown with a green midrib. Female glumes 4-5 mm, ovate, acuminate, dark or rusty brown; midrib indistinct. <i>Utricles</i>  4-5 mm, ovoid-ellipsoid, minutely papillose, only faintly nerved, readily dropping at maturity; epidermal cells of adaxial face thick-walled, minutely papillous and ± isodiametric; beak 1-1.5 mm, split on back; stigmas 2; nut oblong-obovoid, biconvex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpina-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","7c4ee41f-ee06-4d74-b077-5868c9d13a4c#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232159","distribution","<p>Native of N. America; introduced in Turkey and in N.W. & C. Europe, where it is a rather frequent casual.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpinoidea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f3d6210c-31b9-4cd4-8c2e-58506a3d89da#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232159","general","<p>Similar to C. otrubae (Sect. Vulpinae) but densely caespitose; <i>Stems</i> erect, rather slender, leafy for c. 1/2 of their length, scabrid above; basal sheaths pale to dark brown; <i>Leaves</i> mid-green, flat, 2-4.5 mm broad, somewhat longer than <i>Stems</i> , mid-vein minutely papillose; ligule acute, twice as long as broad; <i>Inflorescence</i> branched in lower part, lowest cluster often slightly remote, upper overlapping, <i>Inflorescence</i> thus lobed, elongate, to 10 cm; spikes ovoid-oblong, 5-8 mm; bracts leaf-like or usually filiform, lowest longer than spike-clusters, usually several other bracts also visible; female glumes narrowly ovate, long scabrid-aristate, usually shorter than utricles, pale brown to greenish-brown; <i>Utricles </i> pale greenish-brown, ovate-orbicular, 2-2.6 mm, suberect, obscurely veined, dull, shortly stipitate; beak to 1 mm, scabrid-margined, ± curved.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-vulpinoidea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-l-1","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f3d6210c-31b9-4cd4-8c2e-58506a3d89da#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232275","distribution","<p>NW Yunnan (Lijiang).</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-yulungshanensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","558f0e45-01d7-4c8d-abec-5f6cf9db3b2d#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232275","general","<p>Plants perennial. Culms densely tufted, up to 50 cm, trigonous, tenuous, glabrous. Leaves shorter than culms, flat or margins involute, 1-2 mm wide, basal persistent leaf sheaths dark brown. Involucral bracts leafy, shorter than inflorescence, long sheathed. Spikes 5 or 6, bisexual, androgynous, single, distant, linear-cylindric, 30-40 × 3-4 mm, terminal one with 1(or 2) branches, male part much longer than female part, branched spikes arising from cladoprophylls with a developed female flower inside; male part of lateral spikes much shorter and with only few flowers, female part with dense numerous flowers; peduncles of spikes tenuous, lowest one up to 20 cm, upper ones shorter; male glumes purplish brown, oblong-lanceolate, 4-4.5 mm, membranous, apex acuminate; female glumes purplish brown laterally, green at middle, oblong, 3.5-4 mm, papery, 3-veined, scabrid on veins, margins narrowly hyaline, apex rounded, apiculate. Utricles yellowish green, obovate-lanceolate, compressed trigonous, 3.5-4 mm, papery, pubescent, with 2 raised lateral veins and no fine veins abaxially, base attenuate into a short stipe, apex contracted into a short excurved beak, orifice truncate. Nutlet obovate-oblong, 2.2-2.5 mm, sessile, apex not apiculate; style base slightly thickened; stigmas 3. Rachilla ca. 0.3 mm, flat.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-yulungshanensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","558f0e45-01d7-4c8d-abec-5f6cf9db3b2d#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232275","habitat","<p>Alpine meadows and scree; 3900-4300 m.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-yulungshanensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","558f0e45-01d7-4c8d-abec-5f6cf9db3b2d#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232288","distribution","<p>The species occurs in areas receiving rainfall in summer or in all seasons, from near the coast to montane areas, in Limpopo, Mpumalanga, Swaziland, KwaZulu-Natal and Eastern Cape. It is also recorded from East Africa, in Malawi and Zimbabwe, where it is fairly common in the Eastern Highlands.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-zuluensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","b96dfca8-4518-452b-a4f6-44405eb2e5f3#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232288","general","<p>Plants 1.0–1.2 m tall, caespitose. Rhizomes very short, 2.5–3.0(–5.0) mm in diameter. Shoot scales and basal leaves not developing extensive anthocyanin coloration (or sometimes small patches). Leaves yellow- or dark green, not glaucous, usually without conspicuous transverse venation. Basal leaf sheaths folded, old sheaths not becoming spongy; inner face simply splitting. Largest basal leaf blade 500–650 × 7–12 mm, flat in cross-section; adaxial surface scabrid; abaxial surface glabrous; margins proximally glabrous, distally minutely scabrid. Lowest culm leaf: sheath mouth concave, herbaceous; ligule 4 mm high, fuscous, membranous, apex acute or obtuse. Culms triangular in cross-section, 1.5–2.7 mm in diameter; internodes all of ± length, exposed; 2 or 3 nodes exposed. Inflorescence paniculate, 240–505 × 20–50 mm. Basal inflorescence bracts leaf-like; sheaths 20–60 mm long; blades 170–360 mm long. Primary inflorescence units 5–6; linear; all androgynous; usually 1, or sometimes 2 branches from basal nodes, erect, or suberect; the largest 50–95 × 8–20 mm. Longest peduncles exserted by 25–85 mm, hairy. Bracts subtending higher order branches with a long setaceous cusp; opposing bracteoles not inflated. Bracts of staminate spikelets not or only slightly dimorphic. Anthers 2.8–3.5 mm long. Bracts of pistillate spikelets ovate, 3.5–4.5 × 2 mm, shorter and narrower than perigynium, stramineous with light to heavy ferruginous striae and hyaline margins, glabrous, but ciliate distally on margin; carina narrow, single-nerved; apex obtuse, sometimes emarginate, shortly awned; awn (0–)1 mm long, margin scabrid. Mature perigynium suberect, not stipitate, with a conspicuous basal callus, rostrate, 4.5–6.0 × 1.5–2.0 mm, triangular with adaxial side winged in cross-section, slightly inflated, green, base without a layer of corky material, herbaceous, with 2 conspicuous curved submarginal nerves on abaxial surface, scabrid in distal half; rostrum tapered, 1.2–2.0 mm long, bent sharply upwards, margin not winged, scabrid; rostrum apex shallowly bidentate, apical teeth 0.4–0.7 mm long. Rachilla absent from perigynia. Style base straight; stigmas 3. Mature nutlet obovate, narrowly clawed, 2.5–3.5 × 1.2–1.8 mm, triangular in cross-section, fuscous with lighter angles, minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-zuluensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","b96dfca8-4518-452b-a4f6-44405eb2e5f3#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232288","habitat","<p>The plants grow in full sun, or light shade, on wet or moist forest margins, on clay or loam substrata.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-zuluensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-southern-african-species-carex-l-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","28dcda45-7e1d-46de-8e95-e17b548642cc","","b96dfca8-4518-452b-a4f6-44405eb2e5f3#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232327","general","<p>Tufted, mat-forming (rarely stoloniferous) perennials. Culms scapose or with a few nodes. Leaves eligulate. Inflorescence open to condensed paniculate with (sub)capitate partial inflorescences with few to many spikelets. Lower primary bracts ± leaflike, sheathing. Spikelets with 3-6 distichous, persistent glumes of increasing length, lower glumes empty, larger 1-2(-3) glume(s) each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Flowers bisexual, sometimes upper or lower flower functionally male. Bristles 6, ciliate to (partly) fimbriate or plumose, shorter than to much longer than the fruit, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 2-3, anthers conspicuously greenish yellow. Style 3-fid, base not distinct, (slightly) thickened, persistent. Achene narrowly (ob)ovate to oblong, trigonous, often with a long beak, surface smooth or finely reticulate.<br /><br/>About 15 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232532","general","<p>Perennials on a short-long creeping rhizome. Culms many-noded, often strongly sinuous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:232635","general","<p>Tufted or isolated caudex-forming dwarfshrubs, caudex covered by decaying leaf sheaths and adventitious roots. Culms lateral, scapose, compressed. Leaves crowded on top of the caudex, eligulate. Inflorescences contracted paniculate or capitate with few-several spikelets. Primary bracts small, sheathing, suberect. Inflorescences unisexual or bisexual, flowers often dioecious. Male spikelets with spiral, persistent glumes, lower and upper glumes smaller and empty, middle 5-9 largest each subtending a mostly 2-staminate flower. Female spikelet with few spiral, persistent glumes, penultimate glume subtending a flower (rarely a 2nd upper and nonfunctional flower present). Female flower with a pistil, surrounded at the base by 3 small, fimbriate scales. Style 3-fid, style base distinct, partly thickened and persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233188","general","<p>Creeping rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose, mostly septate. Leaves reduced to a very obliquemouthed sheath. Inflorescence pseudolateral, reduced to a single spikelet, ± partly sunken into the ± widened base of the single, erect, stemlike bract. Spikelet globose or ± compressed (from top to base!), with many spirally arranged deciduous glumes, each (except a few lower ones) subtending a flower. Rachilla extremely shortened, thick crescentiform. Flowers bisexual. Scales many, basal pair lateral, spathulate ± keeled, each with a single stamen, many middle scales smaller and narrower, each with a stamen, several upper empty. Style deeply 2-3-fid, style base not distinct, slightly thickened, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233284","general","<p>Tufted or creeping rhizomatous perennials with thick roots. Culms scapose, ancipitous to terete. Leaves distichous, eligulate, blade ancipitous or terete, or reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence pseudolateral, reduced to a single spikelet, partly hidden by the base of a ± culmlike bract. Spikelet with several spirally arranged empty, ± deciduous deciduous, dark glumes, seated on a broadly cylindrical rachilla, conically narrowed at the top, and there bearing a single bisexual flower with many spirally arranged lanceolate to linear scales, each with a single stamen, top with a central pistil, style deeply 4-6-fid, style base not distinct, not thickened, deciduous. Stamens with a short filament, a long linear anther, and a very elongated linear crest; rarely a second, lateral flower present in the axil of the first glume; sometimes the apex of the conical part of the rachilla divided into 3 smaller cones each bearing a number of scales and a stamen, plus a terminal pistil with a 2-fid style. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233322","general","<p>Rhizomatous and stoloniferous perennials. Culms few-noded. Leaves eligulate, blade flat or revolute. Inflorescence paniculate with numerous spikelets. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233412","distribution","<p>Cladium mariscus is scattered throughout Britain and is still locally common in East Anglia and on the western seaboard of Scotland, though there have been many losses elsewhere. In Ireland it is a frequent plant of mires in western and central areas but absent from much of the NE and SE.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cladium-mariscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","700c15d5-895f-40b9-b152-83abee75af19#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233412","ecology","<p>Cladium mariscus is found in base-rich to mesotrophic areas, where it can form beds consisting almost solely of Cladium (S2a) or with greater or lesser amounts of Phragmites (S2a, S4a), sometimes with Menyanthes trifoliata and Potentilla palustris (S2b); also associated with Carex elata (e.g. in S1). Also in mires, e.g. in the Schoenus nigricans-Juncus subnodulosus community (M13), where with Molinia caerulea and the moss Calliergonella cuspidata it can occasionally be dominant. Present, but less frequent, with Peucedanum palustre and other sedges in Juncus subnodulosus-Cirsium palustre fen-meadow (M22d) and in wetter situations, especially in Broadland, in tall-herb fens of Phragmites-Peucedanum (S24) and Phragmites-Eupatorium (S25), being co-dominant in sub-community S25c. See also the Biological Flora account (Conway 1942).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cladium-mariscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","700c15d5-895f-40b9-b152-83abee75af19#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233412","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> ± creeping, c. 8 mm in diameter, covered in purplish-brown scales. <i>Stems </i> up to 200 cm × 3-8 mm, solitary to loosely tufted, hollow, terete, finely ridged. <i>Leaves </i> mostly basal, 2-3 cauline, up to 200 cm × 5-20 mm, gradually narrowed, acute, flat, somewhat glaucous; margins and keel sharply serrate; sheath up to 20 cm long, reddish-brown, splitting early; ligule absent. <i>Inflorescence </i> paniculate, 30-70 × 5-12 cm; nodes up to 7, rather distant, each subtending a corymbose partial inflorescence, with dense to rather open branches; primary branches 1-2, 3.5-12 cm long; secondary branches up to 12, 0.5-7 cm long, subtending compact, ovoid to ± globose clusters of spikelets 4-10 × 10 cm; involucral bracts leaf-like, lowest up to 95 cm long. <i>Spikelets </i> up to 15 per cluster, 2-5 × 0.7-2 mm, ovoid, terete, 2-4-flowered. <i>Glumes </i> 2-4 × 1.5-3 mm, increasing in size towards spikelet apex, ovate, papery, nerveless except for indistinct midrib, mid brown; apex obtuse to acute. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0; stamens 2; anthers 2-3 mm long, with prominent, reddish, densely papillose connective tip; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1.5-3 (excluding style-base) × 1.5-1.7 mm, ellipsoid to ovoid, terete, shiny, smooth, with a small saucer-shaped disk at base and conical apex; style-base persistent, c. 0.5 mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cladium-mariscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","700c15d5-895f-40b9-b152-83abee75af19#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233412","use","<p>When dried, Cladium mariscus forms a strong thatch used for capping the ridges of cottages thatched with 'Norfolk reed' (Phragmites australis). It was formerly an important fuel, especially for bakers' ovens (Rowell 1986), and was also used as a source of cheap paper.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cladium-mariscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Use","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","700c15d5-895f-40b9-b152-83abee75af19#use"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233618","general","<p>Tufted or cushion-forming perennials with extensively branched rhizomes, sometimes forming a small caudex. Culms (sub)scapose, compressed. Leaves distichous, leaf sheath open, ligule fimbriate, blade flat or inrolled, deciduous. Inflorescence paniculate with few-many spikeletlike spikes. Primary bracts ± leaflike. Spikes.with numerous lateral spikelets subtended by spIrally arranged glumelike bracts. Spikes bisexual. Spikelets unisexual or bisexual, wIth few dIstlchous, persistent glumes, the larger 1-2 each s.ubtending a flower, lateral spikelets wIth an Irregularly shaped prophyll. Basal spikelets with 1-2 male flowers, apical spikelets mostly with 1 male and 1 female flower, more rarely completely female. Male flower with 2-3 stamens. Female flower with a pistil, surrounded at the base and opposite the sides by 3 small hypogynous sqles, deciduous with the fruit. Style 3-fid, style base not distnct, tapering, persistent. Achene fusiform, trigonous, long-beaked, surface smooth.<br /><br/>About seven spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233619","general","<p>(var. abyssinica) Stems 35-95 cm. tall. Peduncles very slender, erect, curved or flexuous. Spikes rather numerous or numerous in each fascicle, ellipsoid to obovoid, becoming obconic in fruit, 5-9 mm. long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:233628","general","<p>Perennial, up to 84 cm tall, sometimes the whole plant villous. Culms densely tufted, rounded to trigonous, 14-55 cm long, 0.4-1 mm wide, glabrous or sparsely to densely hairy. Leaves up to 60 cm long; sheath sometimes blackened basally, straw-yellow to brown, 1-7 cm long, ligulate; leaf blade narrowly linear, convolute-cylindrical, 21-58 cm long, 0.1-0.18 mm wide, upper surface sparsely to densely villous, lower surface ± glabrous, apex acuminate. Leaves subtending the primary branches; sheath 1-3.5 cm long, blade 3.5-18.5 cm long, surface and shape as in leaves. Inflorescence paniculate, lax and slender, erect or slightly curved, primary and secondary branches slender, erect or nearly erect. Spikes pedicellate, in fascicles of 1-3, ovate to obovate, 4-7 mm long, 2.5-5 mm wide. Spikelets numerous per spike, lanceolate, elliptic to oblong, 2-4 mm long, 0.5-1.1 mm wide, composed of 4-5 glumes, distichous, lower 2 empty and small, the upper ones flower bearing. Female flower; sac-like utricle lanceolate, overtopping the glumes, 2.3-4.2 mm long, 0.4-0.9 mm wide, the basal hairs % to nearly as long as the nutlet. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:234505","general","<p>Tufted or more rarely shortly rhizomatous perennials, sometimes sympodial caudex-forming dwarfshrubs. Culms scapose or few-noded. Leaves usually basally crowded or on top of the caudex, sometimes (spiro- )distichous, eligulate, blade sometime deciduous. Inflorescence paniculate with many-numerous spikelets. Primary bracts ± leaflike, sheathing. Spikelets with several distichous, deciduous glumes of increasing length, the larger (1-)2(-3) each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next flower. The lower flower (functionally) male or bisexual, the upper flower bisexual or functiona!ly female. Bristles 6, fimbriate to ciliate, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, style base often distinct (at anthesis), thickened, persistent. Achene ovate or oblong, rounded trigonous, often 3-ribbed, ± stipitate, beaked, smooth or rugulose.<br /><br/>About 20 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:234870","general","<p>Tufted annuals with a scent of curry. Culms scapose. Leaves eligulate. Inflorescence anthelate, with terminal clusters of many densely arranged spikelets, rarely completely contracted. Primary bracts leaflike, spreading. Spikelets with 2-several, distichous, persistent, winged glumes, usually each subtending a flower. Rachilla internodes elongated. Spikelets deciduous as a unit. Flowers bisexual. Bristles absent. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, style base not distinct, slightly thickened, persistent. Achene oblong, trigonous, beaked, finely puncticulate.<br /><br/>Two spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:234974","general","<p>Tufted annual (or short-lived perennial?). Culms scapose. Basal leaves with open sheath, eligulate, subtending the basal spikelets, subbasal leaves few, reduced to a mucronate sheath with a conspicuous scarious mouth. Basal spikelets abundant, with few-many (spiro)distichous ± leaflike glumes, flowers female, with elongated, 3-fid style. Inflorescence anthelate or capitate with fewnumerous spikelets. Primary bracts short, spreading, lowermost bract suberect. Spikelets with many densely (spiro)distichous, deciduous glumes, each subtending a flower. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235452","general","<p>Tufted perennials. Culms few-noded. Leaves sometimes spirodistichous, ligulate. Inflorescence paniculate with few-many spikelets. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235461","general","<p>Medium-sized tufted perennials. Culms scapose. Leaves eligulate. Inflorescence compacted paniculate with many spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike, sheathing, suberect. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235462","general","<p>Perennial, slenderly tufted. Rhizome hardly developed, connecting closely-placed shoots bearing adventitious roots intermingled with flattened, persistent, clearly veined, dull greyish-brown to slightly purplish, dead leaf bases spirally arranged, never becoming fibrous. Culms erect, 0.3-0.5 m high, up to 3 mm in diameter, slightly flattened, nodeless between basal leaves and inflorescence (Balkwill & Manning 423 NU, shows one culm node) hard, smooth. Leaves radical, fairly numerous, spiral, up to 3/4 culm length; sheaths poorly defined except by brown to purplish coloration, narrowing into inrolled blades up to 50 × 1-2 mm, margins finely scabrid, apices elongate, slender, almost pungent. Inflorescence a narrow, bracteated panicle of from 2-7 (occasionally more) branches from successive culm nodes, generally 1 branch per node, rebranching to carry narrow clusters of brown spikelets; bracts 1 per node, erect leaf-like, surpassing inflorescence length. Spikelets solitary, closely associated, 7 × 2 mm, oblong-elliptic in outline, flattened, brown. Glumes subdistichous, usually 5, proximal 2 sterile, awned, middle 2 fertile, aristate or mucronate, margins finely scabrid-ciliate, uppermost sterile, totally enclosed, membranous, prophyll-like with 2 ridges suggestive of veins. Florets 2 only, one functionally bisexual, one functionally male accompanied by rudimentary gynoecium, relative positions variable within spikelets of an inflorescence. Perianth 6 slender, bristle-shaped but soft, antrorsely scabrid outgrowths, usually not exceeding half length of mature-sized fruit plus style base, bases expanded, marginally fused to form a shallow cup enveloping fruit base, not 2-ranked. Stamens 6 arising within perianth. Style base 1/3 total fruit length excluding perianth base, persistent, triangular in outline, pubescent; style branches 3. Achene + style base lanceolate-elliptic in outline, faintly 3-ridged longitudinally, basal third gradually narrowing to form funnel-shaped portion containing embryo, 2.5-3.1 × 1.1-1.2 mm in total length and width including perigonial base, whitish to pale fawn, surface slightly transversely rugose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyathocoma-bachmannii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/studies-cyperaceae-southern-africa-31-third-species-cyathocoma-c-bachmannii","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1d0c02b1-c1e5-4c7f-b8b9-4a004dce45be#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235507","general","<p>Tufted perennial on an oblique rhizome. Culms lateral, (sub)scapose. Lower 4-5 leaves reduced to an open sheath with overlapping margins, eligulate, uppermost (?) leaf sheathless (?), eligulate, blade (or = expanded sheath?) large and wide, with undulate margins. Inflorescence a single spike with many spirally arranged small whitish bracts, lower bracts each subtending a female spikelet, upper bracts each subtending a 3-staminate male flower. Female spikelet with a rachilla, ca. half as long as the fruit, and a large, whitish, inflated utriculiform prophyll, subtending a female flower. Female flower with a 3-fid style, stigmatic branches conspicuously thickened-clavate, style base not distinct, not thickened, deciduous, ovary seated on a disk with 3 basal knobs, opposite the ribs. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235513","general","<p>Annuals, or tufted, rhizomatous, stoloniferous or bulbiferous perennials. Culms mostly scapose, triangular to subterete, rarely winged, compressed or septate. Leaves eligulate, sometimes reduced to a sheath, sheaths sometimes semisucculent. Inflorescence rarely pseudolateral, anthelate to capitate with few-numerous spikelets, rarely spicate or reduced to 1 single spikelet. Primary bracts often large and leaflike, lowermost bract rarely erect. Partial inflorescences spikelike with spicately or digitately arranged spikelets, or densely capitate. Spikelets with few-many distichous (very rarely spirally arranged) glumes, spikelet bract and prophyll ± glumelike, each glume subtending a flower, glumes deciduous or persistent. Rachilla internodes elongated. Spikelets sometimes deciduous as a unit, or breaking up into I-flowered units. Flowers bisexual, very rarely unisexual or even dioecious. Bristles absent. Stamens 1-3. Style (2-)3-fid, more rarely (sub)entire, style base mostly not distinct, not thickened, persistent or deciduous. Achene often obovate or elliptical, (sub)trigonous, rarely dorsiventrally compressed, rarely stipitate, beaked or not, smooth or variously ornamented, rarely corky thickened.<br /><br/>About 550 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235548","general","<p>Herbs, perennial, cespitose, rhizomatous. Culms trigonous, 20–100 cm × 0.8–2.5 mm, glabrous. Leaves 5–10, V-shaped to flanged V-shaped, 10–70(–90) cm × 2–7 mm, margins and midribs scabridulous or glabrous. Inflorescences: spikes 1(–6), densely cylindric, 6–30 × 5–11 mm; rays 3–12, 0.4–5(–7) cm; rays and rachis glabrous; usually only 1–2 spikes of inflorescence on elongate rays, other spikes sessile or nearly so; bracts 4–7, horizontal to slightly ascending, 1–16 cm × 0.5–4 mm; rachilla deciduous, wings persistent, 0.5 mm wide. Spikelets 20–80, ellipsoid, roughly quadrangular, 3–5 × 1–1.4 mm; floral scales 1–2(–4), appressed, stramineous to golden brown, often red-speckled, medially greenish, 9-ribbed, elliptic to ovate, 2.4–3.4 × 1.8–2.6 mm, apex obtuse. Flowers: anthers 0.4–0.6 mm; styles 0.7–1.1 mm; stigmas 1.4–2.1 mm. Achenes dark brown to reddish brown, sessile, broadly ellipsoid, 1.8–2.1 × 0.8–1 mm, apex apiculate, surfaces glabrous to finely puncticulate.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-aggregatus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-linnaeus-subg-cyperus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","1f4f1a17-c566-48b0-aad8-fe120e44b903#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:235818","general","<p>Herbácea, perenne, cespitosa. Tallos (3,6)4-7,5(13,4) cm, algo curvados, trígonos, rígidos, con la parte basal ligeramente engrosada, lo que le confiere una apariencia tuberosa. Hojas (5)6-10(11) × 0,1-0,4 cm, generalmente de menor longitud que el tallo, la mayoría basales, que dejan desnudo el tallo en su mitad superior, planas o a veces un poco aquilladas, antrorso-escábridas hacia el ápice en los márgenes y el nervio medio, eliguladas. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236414","general","<p>Perennial, 60-100 cm. Rhizome short, horizontal, covered by brown scales, with tillers. Stem 2-4 mm diam., trigonous, smooth. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236421","general","<p>Herbs, perennial, cespitose; rhizomes 0.5–2 cm, often absent. Culms trigonous, 35–170 cm × 2–4.7 mm, scabrid on angles. Leaves 4–12, with readily visible cross ribs especially on abaxial surface, flat to V-shaped, 25–100 cm × 2.4–11 mm. Inflorescences: heads digitate, globose, 1–1.7 cm diam.; rays 3–5, 1–7 cm; 2d order rays absent; bracts 3–5, horizontal to ascending at 30°, with prominent cross ribs, V-shaped, (4–)11–35(–48) cm × 1–6.7 mm (longest 1/2 as long as culm); 2d order bracts absent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236422","general","<p>Perennial with tufted culms up to 45 cm tall, with a bulbous culm-base; culms many, crowded, sometimes semi-succulent, 8–40 cm long, 0.5–2 mm wide, bluntly to sharply triangular, glabrous; roots fragrant (fide Hooper 928). Leaves many, up to 33 cm long, often recurved; leaf sheath pale brown, thin and membranous, the lower somewhat thicker, brown and occasionally splitting up into fibres, to 4 cm long; leaf blade bright green or glaucous in very dry situations, linear, flat or slightly v-shaped, 5–33 cm tall, 1–4(–5) mm wide, scabrid on at least margin and primary vein, apex attenuate. Involucral bracts leaf-like, erect to spreading, 3–6, lowermost 4–23 cm long, 0.5–3.5 mm wide. Inflorescence capitate, green or greenish white or white tinged green, hemispherical to ovoid, 5–15 mm in diameter, of 3–6 congested sessile spikes; spikelets narrowly ovoid, 2–6 mm long, 1–2 mm wide, 3–9(–18)-flowered but with only few maturing nutlets; glumes greenish with uncoloured margin, ovate, 2–3 mm long, keel narrow, with 5–8 slender veins on either side, apex concave. Stamens 2–3, with white filaments and yellow anthers; style white. Nutlet brown with dark brown angles, obovoid, trigonous, 1.2–1.4 mm long, (including 0.1–0.2 mm long apiculus), 0.8–0.9 mm wide, strongly papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-dubius-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-10","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","937e0eae-f39f-4178-a1f3-4b07b329110a#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236423","general","<p>Perennial with tufted culms up to 45 cm tall, with a bulbous culm-base; culms many, crowded, sometimes semi-succulent, 8–40 cm long, 0.5–2 mm wide, bluntly to sharply triangular, glabrous; roots fragrant (fide Hooper 928). Leaves many, up to 33 cm long, often recurved; leaf sheath pale brown, thin and membranous, the lower somewhat thicker, brown and occasionally splitting up into fibres, to 4 cm long; leaf blade bright green or glaucous in very dry situations, linear, flat or slightly v-shaped, 5–33 cm tall, 1–4(–5) mm wide, scabrid on at least margin and primary vein, apex attenuate. Involucral bracts leaf-like, erect to spreading, 3–6, lowermost 4–23 cm long, 0.5–3.5 mm wide. Inflorescence capitate, green or greenish white or white tinged green, hemispherical to ovoid, 5–15 mm in diameter, of 3–6 congested sessile spikes; spikelets narrowly ovoid, 2–6 mm long, 1–2 mm wide, 3–9(–18)-flowered but with only few maturing nutlets; glumes greenish with uncoloured margin, ovate, 2–3 mm long, keel narrow, with 5–8 slender veins on either side, apex concave. Stamens 2–3, with white filaments and yellow anthers; style white. Nutlet brown with dark brown angles, obovoid, trigonous, 1.2–1.4 mm long, (including 0.1–0.2 mm long apiculus), 0.8–0.9 mm wide, strongly papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-dubius-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-10","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","937e0eae-f39f-4178-a1f3-4b07b329110a#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236500","diagnostic","<p>Cyperus eragrostis is recognised by its dense clusters of pale yellowish-or greenish-brown spikelets.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-eragrostis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b3631b35-cbf5-4c2d-bd81-86bbe855271a#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236500","distribution","<p>Cyperus eragrostis is native to tropical America and was possibly introduced to cultivation in Britain in 1790. It is occasionally found in southern England, the Isle of Man, the extreme south of Ireland and the Channel Islands as a garden escape as well as a wool and grass-seed alien. It is naturalised in Guernsey, where it was first recorded in the wild in 1909.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-eragrostis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b3631b35-cbf5-4c2d-bd81-86bbe855271a#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236500","ecology","<p>The species is native to tropical America and naturalised in Britain and Ireland, where it is regarded as a stable or increasing neophyte (Porter & Foley 2002). It occurs on waste ground and roadsides, by ponds and other water-bodies and on ballast and rough ground where introduced with grass-seed or wool shoddy.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-eragrostis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b3631b35-cbf5-4c2d-bd81-86bbe855271a#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236500","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short, thick. <i>Stems </i> 20-60 cm × 1.2-2.5 mm, triquetrous, smooth. <i>Leaves </i> shorter than to exceeding inflorescence; blade linear, 10-45 cm × 5-10 mm, flattish, acuminate; sheath 2-15 cm long, pale brown to reddish; ligule absent Inflorescence 3-11 × 9-16 cm, compound and umbel-like; primary branches 8-11, 2-12 cm long; secondary branches 0-3, 0.5-1 cm long; branches terminated by dense clusters of few to numerous spikelets; involucral bracts 5-11, 13-47 cm long, leaf-like, all exceeding inflorescence. <i>Spikelets </i> 5-13 × 1-3 mm, narrowly lanceoloid, flattened; axis not winged. <i>Glumes </i> 2-3 × 1-1.5 mm, distichously arranged, 10-30 per spikelet, ovate-lanceolate to lanceolate, acute to subacuminate, indistinctly 1-3-nerved, pale yellowish-to greenish-brown with membranous sides and pale green keel. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0; stamen 1; anthers 1.2 mm long, with prominent connective; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1-1.5 × 0.5-0.6 mm, narrowly obovoid to obovoid, trigonous, minutely punctate, pale to dark greyish-brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-eragrostis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","b3631b35-cbf5-4c2d-bd81-86bbe855271a#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236532","general","<p>Annual or perennial; rhizomes long, slender, scaly, sometimes with tubers up to 15 mm; stems 5-60(-90) cm, solitary. Leaves 2-10 mm wide, shorter than to exceeding the stems. Bracts 2-9, usually several exceeding the inflorescence. Inflorescence a simple or compound umbel; rays 4-10, up to 10 cm. Spikelets 5-16 x 1-2.5 mm, linear to oblong, with 6-22 flowers, ascending to patent. Rhachilla broadly winged. Glumes 2-3 x c. 2 mm, lanceolate to ovate, obtuse, concave, pale yellow to yellowish-brown. Stamens 3. Nut 1/2 as long as the glumes, reddish or dark grey. Mediterranean region and S.W. Europe; cultivated here and locally in S.C. Europe for its edible tubers (tiger nuts).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-esculentus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","fe1a4457-e7cb-45c6-be6f-46805bd29fc7#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236743","conservation","<p>Cyperus fuscus is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Vulnerable (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).
