"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236743","diagnostic","<p>C. fuscus is easily distinguished from other species of Cyperus in being a rather small annual with dark purplish-brown spike lets.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-fuscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5933af8b-3d80-4e19-b481-a8fc854d4608#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236743","distribution","<p>Cyperus fuscus is entirely southern and local in distribution and used to occur from North Somerset eastwards to Middlesex and on Jersey. It is now very rare, occurring naturally only in Somerset, Hampshire, Surrey and Jersey, though it is occasionally grown as an ornamental.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-fuscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5933af8b-3d80-4e19-b481-a8fc854d4608#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236743","ecology","<p>A very rare annual of moist, open, muddy or stony ground with a humus-rich substrate around the margins of small ponds and ditches; associated with Agrostis stolonifera, Alopecurus geniculatus, Bidens tripartita, Ranunculus sceleratus and Rorippa palustris (OV28-31). Such areas are often subject to winter flooding but dry out in summer, when they need to be kept open by soil disturbance and grazing by animals. Since seed appears to be long-lived, populations may be revived with suitable conservation management (Foley & Porter 2002). Population sizes increase in hot summers. See Rich (1999).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-fuscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5933af8b-3d80-4e19-b481-a8fc854d4608#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236743","general","<p>Plant a tufted annual; roots fibrous. <i>Stems </i> 4-25(-46) cm × 1-3 mm, triquetrous, smooth, soft. <i>Leaves </i> shorter than inflorescence; blade linear, 2.5-17 cm × 1.5-4 mm, flat, acuminate; sheath 0.3-5 cm long, rather loose, pale to mid brown, often reddish-tinged; ligule c. 1 mm. <i>Inflorescence </i> 0.5-2 × 0.6-2.8 cm, simple, or compound with 2-4 primary branches, 1-15 mm long and bearing capitate to umbel-like clusters of spikes; involucral bracts 3, leaf-like, 1-11 cm long, the longest exceeding the inflorescence. <i>Spikes </i> 4-6 mm long, broadly ovoid; spikelets 2-5 × 1.5-2 mm, 2-10 per spike, in ± sessile clusters or with a peduncle 1 mm long, oblong to lanceoloid, ± flattened, suberect to spreading; axis not winged. <i>Glumes </i> 1-1.5 × 0.6-1 mm, distichously arranged, imbricate, 18 or more on the longest spikelets, ovate, obtuse with a minute excurrent mucro, nerveless, dark purplish-brown with membranous sides and greenish keel. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0; stamens 2; anthers 0.2-0.3 mm long, with minute connective; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  0.7-0.8 × 0.3-0.4 mm, narrowly obovoid, trigonous, minutely punctate, greenish-to golden-brown with paler ridges.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-fuscus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","5933af8b-3d80-4e19-b481-a8fc854d4608#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:236844","general","<p>Herbs, perennial, cespitose, rhizomatous. Culms basally cormlike, trigonous, 5–40 cm × 0.5–1.3 mm, glabrous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237182","general","<p>Perennial, often leafless; rhizomes slender, inconspicuous, usually long; stems 5-50 cm, caespitose or solitary, the sheaths sometimes with a lamina up to 10 cm x 2 mm. Nut 1/3-2/3 as long as the glumes, yellowish- or greyish-brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-laevigatus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","c65bdd51-2570-4381-955c-def2d6aab0ce#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237327","conservation","<p>Cyperus longus is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Near threatened (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-longus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a2ad5b85-b1c7-4caa-b803-c2048da41071#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237327","diagnostic","<p>This species is distinct in having a creeping rhizome and an umbel-like inflorescence with basal leaf-like bracts subtending a number of long inflorescence branches. It differs from C. fuscus in being a larger, perennial plant, usually with a compound inflorescence. Vegetatively it can be confused with Carex acutiformis and possibly C. acuta, but they have ligules, vegetative shoots without a pseudostem and a blue-green tinge to the leaves in contrast to the brighter green of C. longus.<br />C. longus seems rarely to set fruit in Britain. British material belongs to subsp. longus, although Collins et al. (J 988) noted that some specimens were visually intermediate with the southern European subsp. badius.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-longus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a2ad5b85-b1c7-4caa-b803-c2048da41071#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237327","distribution","<p>Cyperus longus, when naturally occurring, is predominantly southern in distribution, growing in the Channel Isles and in scattered localities from Cornwall eastwards to the Isle of Wight and through Wales as far north as the Conwy estuary. As an introduction it is frequent in central southern England and scattered north to outliers in Arran and Midlothian. Absent as a native from Ireland but introduced in Co. Waterford (v.c. H6).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-longus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a2ad5b85-b1c7-4caa-b803-c2048da41071#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237327","ecology","<p>C. longus is a lowland species of marshy pond margins, ditches and flushes, mainly in coastal areas, where it sometimes occurs in base-rich flushes on sea-cliffs. It is very local and has decreased in recent years through drainage of suitable habitats. It is also planted in many sites away from the coast. Once established, it can spread by vigorous rhizome growth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-longus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a2ad5b85-b1c7-4caa-b803-c2048da41071#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237327","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping. <i>Stems </i> 50-140 cm × 1-3.5 mm, not or slightly swollen at base, trigonous to subtriquetrous, smooth, often reddish below. <i>Leaves </i> shorter than or equalling inflorescence; blade linear, 35-85 cm × 3.5-7 mm, markedly W-shaped to flattish , acuminate; upper surface rough; sheath 18-45 cm long, pale to mid brown; vegetative shoots forming a pseudostem; ligule absent. <i>Inflorescence </i> 14-35 × 10-25 cm, compound; primary branches 5-12, 3-20 cm long, clustered and umbel-like, often branched; secondary branches 0-5, 0.5-7 cm long, arising from the upper section of the primary branches; branches terminated by a solitary spike; involucral bracts 3-5, 7-70 cm long, leaf-like, the longest usually exceeding the inflorescence. <i>Spikes </i> 1.5-5 cm long, obovoid; peduncles 0.1 -0.7 cm long; spikelets 7-20 × 1-1.7 mm, 2-15 per spike, narrowly oblong to linear-lanceoloid, flattened, suberect to patent; axis broadly winged. <i>Glumes </i> 2.7-3.5 × 1.7-1.8 mm, distichously arranged, 15 or more on the longest spikelets, ovate-lanceolate, obtuse, 1-3-nerved, reddish-brown with membranous sides and pale green keel. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0; stamens 3; anthers 1 mm long, with prominent connective; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  ± 1 mm long, narrowly obovoid-cylindric, trigonous, minutely punctate, brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-longus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a2ad5b85-b1c7-4caa-b803-c2048da41071#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237369","general","<p>Herbs, perennial, cespitose, bases cormose; rhizomes knotted, beaded. Culms trigonous, (3–)10–50 cm × 0.4–1.2 mm, glabrous. Leaves flat, 5–40 cm × 1–3.5 mm. Inflorescences: spikes rather densely ovoid to globose, 1.2–3.5 cm; rays 0 or 1–4, 1–6 cm; rachis 1–3.5 mm; bracts 2–4, horizontal to reflexed, flat, 6–25 cm; rachilla ± deciduous, wingless. Spikelets 15–60, compressed, oblong-lanceoloid, (3–)6–22 × 2.5–4 mm; floral scales deciduous, 5–22, off-white to light reddish brown, laterally 3–5-ribbed, ovate-elliptic, 2.5–4 × 2–2.6 mm, margins loosely spreading or clasping achene, apex entire to mucronate, mucro 0.05–0.2 mm. Flowers: anthers 0.3–0.6 mm; styles 1 mm; stigmas 1–1.5 mm. Achenes dark brown or black, sessile, oblong-ellipsoid to ellipsoid, 1.7–2.2 × 0.8–1.2 mm, apex obtuse, apiculate, surfaces puncticulate. 2n = 166.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-lupulinus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-linnaeus-subg-cyperus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","8e192ad5-a0e1-4d86-93d3-e7c9c72514e0#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237421","general","<p>Dwarf annual, delicate, up to 20 cm tall; culms tufted, crowded, 2.5–11(–20) cm long, 0.5–0.9 mm wide, trigonous, glabrous. Leaves up to 13 cm long; leaf sheath green to purple, 0.9–3.1 cm long; leaf blade linear, flat or inrolled, 1–10 cm long, 0.7–1.1 mm wide, scabrid on margin near apex, apex acuminate. Involucral bracts leaf-like, erect to spreading, 3–5, lowermost 3.5–14.5 cm long, 1.5–2.3 mm wide. Inflorescence a simple anthela, primary branches 1–4, 0.5–1.5 cm long; spikelets in digitate clusters, sessile and at the end of primary branches, 3–16 per cluster, linear-lanceolate, flattened, 7.2–9 mm long, 1–1.3 mm wide, rachis straight, 10–14-flowered; glumes green with red streaks, 2.2–2.8 mm long (including the 0.8–1.1 mm long recurved mucro), 0.4–0.5 mm wide, imbricate at flowering, later diverging and spreading, keel 3-veined, apex mucronate. Stamens 1–2; anthers ± 0.5 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237703","general","<p>Annuals. Roots many, slender, fibrous. Culms densely tufted, 5-20 cm tall, flaccid, compressed 3-angled, smooth, few leaved basally. Leaves usually shorter than to sometimes equaling culm; sheath reddish brown to purplish brown, submembranous; leaf blade 1.5-2 mm wide, flat or folded. Involucral bracts 3-5, leaflike, several times as long as inflorescence, basally slightly widened. Inflorescences usually capitate, globose, 1-2 cm in diam., sometimes with a 1-2 cm ray, with many densely arranged spikelets. Spikelets narrowly oblong-ovoid to ovoid-oblong, 3-8 × 1.5-2 mm, compressed, 8-30-flowered; rachilla wings white, hyaline. Glumes white on both surfaces but sometimes sparsely rusty brown shortly striate, slightly spreading, broadly ovate, ca. 2 mm, hyaline, several veined, midvein green, apex mucronate. Stamens 2; anthers linear-oblong. Style elongate; stigmas 2. Nutlet yellowish brown, oblong, ca. 1 mm, plano-convex, sometimes nearly concave-convex.</p>","<p>reprinted with permission from the Missouri Botanical Garden Press, St. Louis, and Science Press, Beijing.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-nipponicus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/33-carex-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1a357cf3-8192-4ba9-9333-a612b8bba2c7#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237787","general","<p>Herbácea, anual o perennizante, ± cespitosa. Tallos hasta de 80 cm, rectos, solitarios o fasciculados, trígonos; con frecuencia al lado de pies muy desarrollados crecen otros pequeños –de talla incluso menor de 5 cm–. Hojas hasta de 60 cm × (3)4,2-6(10)10 mm, generalmente de mayor longitud que el tallo, la mayoría basales que dejan una porción de tallo desnudo, planas, con los márgenes ligeramente antrorso-escábridos hacia el ápice. Inflorescencia terminal, en antela compuesta, con numerosos radios primarios hasta de 8 cm, muy desiguales, con los radios terminales rematados por una espiga laxa de numerosas espiguillas, entre las que se aprecia claramente el eje; brácteas 5-7, hasta de 40 cm × 7 mm, las inferiores de longitud mucho mayor que la de la inflorescencia, con los márgenes y el nervio medio antrorso-escábridos hacia el ápice; espiguillas 4,5-7,9 × 0,7-0,9 mm, erectas, o a veces patentes en la madurez, lineares, de sección subredondeada, hasta con 18 flores; raquidio recto, alado, articulado, que se descompone en la madurez junto con las glumas, que son persistentes. Glumas 1,6-2,6(5) × 0,5-0,8(1) mm, dísticas, lanceoladas u oblongo-lanceoladas, agudas, mucronadas, de color parduzco-rojizo, con una banda central verdosa y 2-6 nervios poco marcados; mucrón c. 0,1 mm, generalmente de color pardo amarillento. Estambres 2(3), exertos en la antesis. Estilo largo con 3 estigmas, exertos. Aquenios 1-1,5 × 0,4-0,6 mm, de menor longitud (1/2-2/3) que la gluma, linear-oblongos, trígonos, de color castaño claro.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-odoratus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperus-l-0","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","2757eb43-e1d4-40b5-bf64-237008ee6b81#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:237881","general","<p>Caespitose, usually leafless annual or perennial; rhizomes very short; stems 1- 40 cm; uppermost sheath sometimes with a lamina up to 5 cm x 1 mm. Bracts 2-3, conspicuously dilated at the base, the lower erect, forming an apparent prolongation of the stem, exceeding the inflorescence, the upper patent, shorter than to exceeding the inflorescence. Inflorescence a fascicle of 2-8 sessile spikelets. Spikelets 5-15 x 2-4 mm, broadly lanceolate or ovate, obtuse, with 10-40 flowers, ascending. Rhachilla not winged. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:238253","general","<p>Herbs, perennial, cespitose; rhizomes elongate, scaly, 2–3 mm wide. Culms roundly trigonous to terete, 30–80 cm × 1–1.6 mm, glabrous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:238921","general","<p>Perennial, fairly robust, up to 60 cm tall with a short creeping rhizome; culms rather crowded, 30–50 cm long, 1–2.1 mm wide, basal part bulbous, 6–8 mm in diameter, trigonous, glabrous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:239102","distribution","<p>The genus contains two specie endemic to Mexico.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cypringlea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cypringlea-new-genus-cyperaceae-mexico","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f5a3e489-15bd-4a60-8e20-c05d094cab5d#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:239102","general","<p>Rhizomatous perennial glabrous herbs: roots coarse, to 1 mm thick. Culms 30-70 cm tall, triquetrous or obtuosely trigonous in coss section. Leaves basal or several lower cauline; sheaths very short, herbaceous to thick herbaceous, auriculate at apex in one species. the inner band membranous with a truncate to deeply U- or V-shaped orifice; ligule a narrow band of thickened smooth or lacerate tissue at adaxial junction of sheath and blade; blades herbaceous, linear or linear-filiform, flattened to V-shaped or folded or wiry and triangular-channeled, the margins and abaxial midvein (when present) antrorsely scabrous. lnflorescence a compound umbel-like corymb or a single fascicle or cymose panicle of 2-3 subcontiguous fascicles of spikelets at the summit of the culm; involucral bracts 2-5, leaf-like or linear-setaceous, the lowermost 1-2 elongate and often exceeding the inflorescence; rays ascending or curving with age; spikelets ovoid-ellipsoid to ellipsoid or ellipsoid-obovoid when immature, 5-10 X 2-3 mm, each subtended by a 2-nerved prophyll at base, the scales often spreading with maturing achenes; scales ovate to widely ovate or ovate-elliptic to oblong-ovate, obtuse to rounded or broadly rounded in cross section, thinly herbaceous to submembranous, semi-glossy, midcosta distinct, mucronate at apex, lateral nerves indistinct; fertile scales 10-30 per spikelet; sterile scales 0-4 at base of spikelet. Flowers bisexual, loosely spirally arranged or sometimes irregularly distichous proximally; stamens 3, the anthers basifixed, thecae parallel, longitudinally dehiscent; style 3-branched. Achene obscurely trigonous to piano-convex, obovate to elliptic-obovate or broadly obovate, 1.5-2 x 0.8-1.5 mm, rounded to subrounded or obtuse at apex, cuneate at base, adaxial side often slightly concave, margins indistinctly costate or distinctly so proximally, pale brown, lighter than the sides, epidermis very finely cellular-reticulate when immature, papillose at maturity, stramineous to light brown when immature, dark brown at maturity, epidermal cells 6-sided, isodiametric, each with an apical nodule that is well-developed and buttressed at maturity, the walls essentially straight when immature, forming a wavy configuration at maturity; style base essentially absent, at most a depressed-pyramidal remnant of tissue or a low, 3-sided rim at achene apex, 0.1 mm long or less, 0.1-0.2 mm wide, brown; bristles 2-4, subulate, reddish, often represented only by short rudiments that rarely reach to middle of achene, the longer often with antrorse to divergent, blunt- or round-tipped barbs distally, these often reduced to small nubs proximally; embryo of the Carex-type.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cypringlea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cypringlea-new-genus-cyperaceae-mexico","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f5a3e489-15bd-4a60-8e20-c05d094cab5d#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:239658","general","<p>Tall rhizomatous perennial. Culms many-noded, woody. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242122","general","<p>Submerged stoloniferous perennial (?), with floating to partly emerged culms. Culms many-noded, with false whorls of tiny vegetative branchlets, at the base of a tubular leaf sheath (this ""culm"" probably representing a sympodial, elongated rhizome). Leaves a tiny, hyaline sheath, mouth often somewhat lobed. Inflorescence a single spikelet on a thick peduncle basally surrounded by a tubular leaf sheath. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242252","general","<p>Small to medium-sized tufted annuals or rhizomatous, stoloniferous, rarely bulbiferous perennials, rarely amphicarpous. Culms scapose, 3-4-angular, ridged or terete, rarely septate, ancipitous or bulbously thickened at the base. Leaves I-few per culm, eligulate, reduced to a ± hyaline sheath or blade present as a small mucro. Inflorescence a single spikelet. Spikelets with 2many spirally arranged, rarely (sub)distichous, deciduous glumes, each subtending a flower. Lowermost glume (""associated brad') often empty or with a vegetative bud (often developing into new shoots when submerged), rarely flower-bearing. Flowers bisexual. Bristles (0-)3-6(-10), shorter or longer than the fruit, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 1-3. Style 2-3-fid, style base mostly distinct, (sometimes only slightly) thickened, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242255","diagnostic","<p>This species is characterised by its narrow stems with spikelets that have the lowest glume up to half as long as the spikelet. It shows a wide range of variation, particularly in stem length. The description above applies to emergent fruiting plants only. Submerged plants remain vegetative, with long stems up to 50 cm long that may branch into numerous secondary stems at the apex. <br />Fruiting plants with long stems in deeper water have been called var. longicaulis H.C. Watson, but these are probably no more than phenotypic variants resulting from this habitat.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-acicularis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","61a7e7ca-2dd8-4e55-bc90-c02659cf0eb8#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242255","distribution","<p>Eleocharis acicularis is scattered through lowland Britain, N to the Grampian foothills, reaching 390 m in Drumore Loch, v.c. 89 (Porter & Foley 2002). There are old records in v.cc. 105 and 108 but an extant population in S Shetland (v.c. 112). Scattered in Ireland and absent from the south.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-acicularis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","61a7e7ca-2dd8-4e55-bc90-c02659cf0eb8#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242255","ecology","<p>Eleocharis acicularis is found in wet muddy and sandy places on the margins of still water with Callitriche stagnalis and Zannichellia palustris in the Nuphar lutea community (A8b) and in rich Potamogeton assemblages with Myriophyllum alterniflorum (A13). Less commonly it grows in bays in slow-flowing water, often forming a turf as a submerged aquatic, when it does not flower or fruit.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-acicularis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","61a7e7ca-2dd8-4e55-bc90-c02659cf0eb8#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242255","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> shortly creeping, brown. <i>Stems </i> 1-15 cm × 0.2-0.3 mm, tufted or sometimes solitary, 4-angled, smooth. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths up to 1 cm long, pale brown to reddish-brown; apex obliquely truncate. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid to narrowly cylindric spikelet, 2.2-7.5 × 0.6-1.8(-2.2) mm. <i>Glumes </i> 1.5-3 × 1 mm, up to 15 per spikelet, ovate-lanceolate, obtuse to acute, sometimes emarginate, with pale brown to reddish-brown sides, green midrib and scarious margins; the lowest glume usually empty and up to 1/2 as long as the spikelet, completely surrounding its base. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0-1(-4 ), up to 1/2 as long as nut; stamens 3, with anthers 0.9-1.2 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  0.7-1.05 × 0.5 mm, narrowly obovoid to obovoid-cylindric, obscurely trigonous, whitish or pale brown, finely trabeculate with longitudinal ridges and vertical lines of horizontally oblong epidermal cells; style-base small, conical, not confluent with nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-acicularis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","61a7e7ca-2dd8-4e55-bc90-c02659cf0eb8#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242319","general","<p>Like Eleocharis ovata but more delicate, with stems up to 10 cm and not more than 0.3 mm in diameter; spikelet 2-4 mm; nut c. 0.5 mm, shining, black; stylopodium minute, flattened and c. 1/4 as wide as nut; bristles never as long as fruit, often rudimentary or absent.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-atropurpurea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-br","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","37623e46-8e95-4a6e-a1d8-0df30feb7353#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242319","habitat","<p>Sandy ground, seasonally inundated.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-atropurpurea-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-br","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","37623e46-8e95-4a6e-a1d8-0df30feb7353#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242353","general","<p>Like Eleocharis acicularis but larger, with flowering stems up to 40 cm; uppermost sheath firm in texture, very obliquely truncate; spikelet 4-12 mm, pale brown, with 2 subequal empty glumes each half-encircling its base; bristles 3-4, about equalling nut, persistent.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-bonariensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-br","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","41f57b80-417b-4bb3-be5c-d254bc91a2c3#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242364","distribution","<p>East Tropical Africa from Ethiopia to Zimbabwe, extending to Madagascar, the Mascarene Islands, Socotra, and Yemen; scattered through the Sahara (Niger, Algeria, Libya, Chad, Egypt) except in the west; Mediterranean outposts on the Sinai Peninsula and in the Nile delta of Egypt, in W. Crete, and formerly S.W. Sardinia; doubtful and unconfirmed records from E. Liguria, S. Italy, and Syria.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-caduca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-caduca-cyperaceae-redeemed-species-tropical-african-origin-discovered-crete-greec","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ac5fe03b-7f88-404c-af58-951a30724eeb#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242364","general","<p>Plants normally perennial, first tufted, soon producing slender, fragile runners rooting and with single culms at the nodes, terminating in daughter rosettes. Culms 1.3-12 cm tall, 0.6-0.9 mm in diameter; uppermost leaf sheath reddish-brown below, strarnineous above, obliquely truncate. Spikes 2.3-5.5 mm long, with 3-13 fertile and 1-3 sterile flowers; lowermost glume 1.3-2 mm long, empty, with a green, 3-nerved keel and a reddish-brown membranous margin, ± encircling the spike's base; the second lowest glume usually fertile, rarely also empty. Fertile glumes 1.7-2.2 x 1.1-1.3 mm, with a green, 1-nerved keel reaching the tip and with reddish-brown membranous margins. Stamens 3, with filaments 0.8-2 mm long and anthers 0.6-0.9 mm long. Stigmas 2, 0.8-1 mm long, filiform. Nut (without the stylopodium) 0.8-1 x 0.7-0.8 mm, ± biconvex or planoconvex, smooth, shiny, purplish black, not narrowed into a neck; stylopodium 0.4 x 0.3-0.4 mm, conical, whitish, clearly demarcated from the nut. Bristles 7(-8), 0.9-1.6 mm long, retrorsely scabrous, somewhat unequal, the longer ones equalling or just exceeding the stylopodium. (In contrast to Eleocharis geniculata, in which populations lacking perigon setae are well known particularly in Africa, these bristles appear to be constantly present in E. caduca).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-caduca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-caduca-cyperaceae-redeemed-species-tropical-african-origin-discovered-crete-greec","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ac5fe03b-7f88-404c-af58-951a30724eeb#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242364","habitat","<p>Muddy, sandy or pebbly lake shores and other wet places. In Crete it appears to die back during the summer drought, sprouting again in autumn (perhaps mostly from germinating seed?) and setting fruit in autumn and winter (from late September). When moisture permits, it may strive the year round (the Sardinian specimens, with fruit, were collected in June). Its having passed unnoticed in Crete before 1985 might point to a recent introduction, but may equally well be due to its early die-back in spring when the collecting season begins. Long-range dispersal by waterfowl is the likely reason of its introduction, as the small diaspores may easily stick with mud to the feet or by their retrorsely scabrid barbs to the plumage.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-caduca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-caduca-cyperaceae-redeemed-species-tropical-african-origin-discovered-crete-greec","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ac5fe03b-7f88-404c-af58-951a30724eeb#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242386","general","<p>Caespitose perennial with almost capillary stems up to 30 cm and c. 0.5 mm in diameter. Leaf-sheaths pale brown; uppermost very obliquely truncate and acute. Spikelet 3-13 mm, many-flowered, pale brown, often proliferating vegetatively. Lowest glume empty, usually less than 1/4 as long as spikelet, encircling its base. Stamens 2(3); stigmas 2. Nut 1-1.5 mm, obovate, biconvex with acute margins, narrowed into a short neck, pale brown, shiny; stylopodium narrowly compressed-conical, acute, clearly demarcated from nut. Bristles 6 or 7, longer than nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-carniolica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-br","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","ea0c2cd0-8f56-4cc7-8984-3ada6c67d5de#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242466","general","<p>Culms 2–40 cm × 0.5–1.5(–2) mm. Leaves: apex of distal leaf sheath obtuse to acute, tooth to 0.3 mm. Spikelets lanceoloid to subcylindric or ovoid, 5–10(–20) × 2–3(–4) mm, apex acute (to rounded); proximal scale empty, encircling ca. 2/3 of culm; floral scales 25–100(–200), 8–12 per mm of rachilla, orange brown to stramineous, 2(–2.5) × 1–1.3 mm, midribs mostly keeled, ovate, apex narrowly rounded to subacute. Flowers: perianth bristles present or often absent, 5–8, brown, stout, rudimentary to slightly exceeding tubercle; stamens (2–)3; anthers brown to yellow, 0.3–0.7(–1) mm; styles 2–3-fid. Achenes 0.9–1.1(–1.5) × 0.7–1.1 mm. Tubercles depressed, subdeltoid, 0.1–0.3(–0.4) × 0.6–0.9(–1) mm, 1/10–2/5 as high as wide, 1/4 or less as high as achene, 9/10 as wide as achene, very rarely 2/5 as high as achene (in E. engelmannii var. robusta). 2n = 10.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-engelmannii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown-subg-eleocharis-sect-eleogenus-ser-ovatae-svenson","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","34b4510c-7745-4043-9cf5-31faed61430d#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242497","general","<p>Plants with creeping rhizomes 0.5–1 mm thick. Culms 3–42 cm × 0.3–0.6 mm. Leaves: distal leaf sheaths often disintegrating, thinly membranous-translucent, inflated distally, often wrinkled, apex blunt. Spikelets ellipsoid, 1.5–9 × 1–3.5 mm, apex acute to acuminate; proximal scale without flower, not amplexicaulous; floral scales to 65, 5–7 per mm of rachilla, loosely appressed to appressed, elliptic, 1–3 × 0.4–1.6 mm, membranous, apex acute. Flowers: perianth bristles (0–)5–8, typically 7, white to stramineous, spinules dense to few; styles 2-fid, rarely 3-fid. Achenes stramineous to green or dark brown, biconvex, rarely trigonous, obovoid to obpryiform, 0.4–1.1 × 0.3–0.8 mm, very finely reticulate at 40X. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242508","general","<p>Plants tufted, without creeping rhizomes. Culms to 45 cm × 0.2–1 mm. Leaves: distal leaf sheaths persistent, firm, distally tightly sheathing, apex acute. Spikelets orbicular to ovoid, 1–9 × 1–4 mm, apex rounded to acute; proximal scale without flower, not amplexicaulous; floral scales to 125, 11–14 per mm of rachilla, tightly appressed, dark red-brown to stramineous, ovate to elliptic, 0.8–3 × 0.6–2(–2.3) mm, membranous to cartilaginous, apex rounded to acute. Achenes brown ripening to black, biconvex, orbicular to obpyriform, 0.5–1.1 × 0.3–0.7 mm, apex rarely constricted proximal to tubercle, very finely reticulate at 40X. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242624","distribution","<p>Alta., B.C., N.W.T., Ont., Que., Sask., Yukon; Alaska, Minn., Wash., Wis.; Eurasia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown-subg-elecocharis-sect-eleocharis-ser-melanocarpae-svenson","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","9bfd0660-1c58-4ca5-a4e4-0d401416cbec#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242624","general","<p>Plants perennial, mat-forming; rhizomes evident, long, 0.7–1 mm thick, soft, cortex persistent, longer internodes 2–6 cm, scales often fugaceous, 5–9 mm, membranous, not fibrous. Culms terete, often with 8–14 blunt ridges when dry, 10–50 cm × 0.5–3 mm, very soft, internally spongy. Leaves: distal leaf sheaths persistent, often splitting abaxially, mostly reddish proximally, green to stramineous distally, not inflated, not callose, membranous, apex obtuse, tooth absent. Spikelets ovoid, 5–20 × 3–5 mm, acute; proximal scale clasping 2/3 of culm, entire; subproximal scale empty; floral scales often spreading in fruit, 15–80, 5 per mm of rachilla, medium brown, midrib regions stramineous or greenish, ovate, 2.5–4 × 1.5–2 mm, entire, apex acute to obtuse, sometimes carinate in distal part of spikelet. Flowers: perianth bristles (4–)5–6(–8), brown, slender to stout, mostly exceeding tubercle, to 2 times longer than achene; stamens 3; anthers stramineous, 0.9–1.5 mm; styles 2-fid. Achenes not persistent, yellow maturing to stramineous, biconvex, angles obscure, obovoid (to obpyriform), 1–1.4 × 0.9–1.3 mm, apex rounded, neck absent, smooth at 30X. Tubercles brown to partly whitish, pyramidal to mamillate, lower than to as high as wide, 0.2–0.6 × 0.4–0.6 mm. 2n = 16.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown-subg-elecocharis-sect-eleocharis-ser-melanocarpae-svenson","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","9bfd0660-1c58-4ca5-a4e4-0d401416cbec#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242624","habitat","<p>Fresh lakeshores, shallow ponds, streams, floating mats, bogs, fens, ditches; 20–800 m;</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown-subg-elecocharis-sect-eleocharis-ser-melanocarpae-svenson","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","9bfd0660-1c58-4ca5-a4e4-0d401416cbec#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242625","diagnostic","<p>It resembles E. palustris but is much rarer and is distinguished by its bright green stems, circular in cross-section and with longer stomata guard cells, its narrower glumes and usually 5 perianth bristles (compared with 0-4 in E. palustris). Detailed studies (Swan & Richards 2007) have shown most Northumbrian and Cumbrian specimens to be typical of subsp. austriaca. Similar plants also occur in NW Yorkshire and a distinctive and invariable morphology occurs there, showing signs of hybrid vigour, with untypically high density of fruits and number of vascular bundles. Some plants in Yorkshire and Selkirk could be referred to subsp. mamillata, having a short, broad style-base, but much variation in style-base shape occurs within the spikelet (fide F.J. Roberts pers. comm.). Further work on the group is needed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-subsp-austriaca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fa2ca138-d1d2-4029-9ca8-1e5dd7e203b7#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242625","distribution","<p>Eleocharis mamillata subsp. austriaca was first found in Wharfedale in 1947 (although not recognised until 1960: Waiters 1963) and has its main centre now in Ribblesdale (sites in v.cc. 59 and 64); also in several sites in the far north of England (v.cc. 67 and 70) and in southern Scotland by Tima Water and the River Ettrick (v.c. 79).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-subsp-austriaca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fa2ca138-d1d2-4029-9ca8-1e5dd7e203b7#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242625","ecology","<p>This plant grows along the margins of upland rivers, particularly on gravel with silt and where there is some protection from spates, e.g. in oxbow pools. Its rootstock is usually submerged. It moves into open habitats and has colonised old limestone quarries and a gravel-pit, but it rarely persists long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-subsp-austriaca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fa2ca138-d1d2-4029-9ca8-1e5dd7e203b7#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242625","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping, dark purplish. <i>Stems </i> up to 60 cm × 1.1-2.2 mm, tufted, ± terete, smooth, ± inflated, brittle, circular in cross-section, bright green, becoming ridged when dry; stomata guard cells longer than adjacent subsidiary cells. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths up to 9 cm long, brownish with reddish tinge, paler above; apex ± truncate. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid, lanceoloid-ovoid or often distinctly conical spikelet; spikelet, 5-20 × 3-8 mm. <i>Glumes </i> 2-3 × 1-1.5 mm, c. 40 but up to 107 per spikelet, ovate, obtuse, often caducous when in fruit, with sides dark reddish-brown, paler towards base; margins narrowly hyaline; midrib pale brown; the 2 lowest glumes empty, each surrounding ± half the base of the spikelet. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles (4-)5(-6), usually much longer than nut; stamens 3, with anthers 0.9-1.2 mm long; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  1-1.5 × 1.1-1.5 mm, obovate or elliptic-obovate, biconvex, yellowish to pale brown; style-base persistent, deltoid or more narrowly triangular in outline, flattened, with an acute apex, not confluent with nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-mamillata-subsp-austriaca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fa2ca138-d1d2-4029-9ca8-1e5dd7e203b7#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242680","diagnostic","<p>Dalby & Dalby (1989) suggest that the apex of the lower glume is usually bilobed whereas that of E. quinqueflora is not and this may be, in some areas, a useful character. The latter species has fewer (up to 7) glumes in the spikelet (whereas E. multicaulis may have 15 or more); also the lowest glume is more than half as long as the spikelet, which it completely surrounds at its base.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-multicaulis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a9ce8693-66ed-4a39-b166-0588dded45da#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242680","distribution","<p>Eleocharis multicaulis occurs throughout Britain and Ireland but is more frequent in the west, from sea level to 610 m on the Macgillycuddy's Reeks, v.c. Hl (Porter & Foley 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-multicaulis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a9ce8693-66ed-4a39-b166-0588dded45da#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242680","ecology","<p>Eleocharis multicaulis is usually found on more acidic soils than E. quinqueflora, e.g. around Sphagnum auriculatum pools (M1), in upland mires (M14 and M16) and occasionally in Narthecium-Sphagnum valley mires (M21). Mainly a plant of moderately enriched soligenous mires with Hypericum elodes-Potamogeton polygonifolius (M29) and of seasonally inundated habitats, e.g. in New Forest and Cornwall, with Baldellia (M30). It can also be found on wet sandy heaths and forming a sub-community with Schoenus nigricans, Erica tetralix, E. vagans and Molinia caerulea (H5).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-multicaulis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a9ce8693-66ed-4a39-b166-0588dded45da#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242680","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> stout, shortly creeping. <i>Stems </i> 15-40 cm × 1-1.5 mm, densely clustered, ± terete, smooth to minutely ridged when dry, minutely striate or dotted, often recurved. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths up to 9.5 cm long, pale yellowish or brownish to purplish; apex obliquely acute. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid, lanceoloid-ovoid or ellipsoid spikelet, 5-15 × 2-4 mm, often viviparous. <i>Glumes </i> 2.5-5(-7) × 1.2-1.8(-2.2) mm, c. 10-30 per spikelet, ovate-lanceolate, obtuse to acute, with dark reddish-brown sides, paler and often striate towards the base, with green or indistinct midrib; the lowest glume empty, c. 1/4 as long as the spikelet, not completely surrounding its base. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 4-6, longer than nut; stamens 3, with their anthers 1.9-2.3 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1.2-1.5 × 0.8-1 mm, narrowly obovoid, trigonous, yellowish-brown to olive-brown; style-base triangular, trigonous, acute, constricted at base, not confluent with nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-multicaulis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a9ce8693-66ed-4a39-b166-0588dded45da#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242709","general","<p>Like Eleocharis ovata but more robust, with stems up to 1.5 mm in diameter; stamens 3; stylopodium nearly as wide as nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-obtusa-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-br","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","9557bff2-1bb1-4988-97c8-edd5a6400e41#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242727","general","<p>Densely caespitose annual with stems up to 40 cm and c. 1 mm in diameter. Uppermost leaf- sheath greenish, very obliquely truncate and sometimes with a rudimentary lamina; other sheaths purplish. Spikelet 4-8 mm, ovoid to subconical, many-flowered, reddish-brown; glumes ovate-orbicular, the lowest 2 small, empty, subequal, each half-encircling base of spikelet. Stamens 2 or 3; stigmas 2. Nut c. 1 mm, biconvex, broadly obovate, smooth, brown; stylopodium mammiform, c. 2/3 as wide as nut, clearly constricted at junction with nut. Bristles 4-7, much longer than nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-ovata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-br","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","58dde99e-cf44-492e-a764-02f31082b921#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242738","diagnostic","<p>Eleocharis palustris is characterised by long-creeping rhizomes which lead to the formation of large clones, its relatively large spikes, the two sterile lower glumes which do not completely surround the base of the spikelet (as also in E. mamillata subsp. austriaca, which see for the differences) and the smaller number (0-4) of perianth bristles.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-palustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a6499966-e79e-4067-b105-ebf265b92cc7#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242738","distribution","<p>Eleocharis palustris sensu lato is widespread and common throughout most of the British Isles, but the distribution of the two subspecies still needs to be studied in detail.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-palustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a6499966-e79e-4067-b105-ebf265b92cc7#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242738","ecology","<p>This species is indifferent to soil types although more frequent in richer and slightly basic soils (Preston & Croft 1997). It is found, for example, by the side of or in water in ponds, ditches and river margins and in marshy edge communities with Schoenoplectus spp., Carex rostrata, Equisetum fluviatile, Glyceria spp., Menyanthes, Potentilla palustris etc. (S8, S9, S12, S14, S20 etc.), often forming large and dense populations in upland pools and lakes with Littorella, Lobelia dortmanna and Agrostis stolonifera (S19) where there is little competition, and in spring 'soaks' such as those with Potamogeton polygonifolius (M29). Not at all frequent round reservoirs and other water-bodies subject to fluctuation of water level (Grime et al. 1988). Recorded up to 550 m at Tyne Head, v.c. 70 (Porter & Foley 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-palustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a6499966-e79e-4067-b105-ebf265b92cc7#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242738","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> thick, long-creeping. <i>Stems </i> 8-95 cm × 0.6-4 mm, sparsely to densely tufted, terete, smooth to indistinctly longitudinally ridged; stomata guard cells shorter than adjacent subsidiary cells. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths at base of stem, up to 25 cm long, yellowish to dark reddish-brown; apex ± truncate. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid to lanceoloid-ovoid spikelet, 5-30 × 3-6 mm, usually with up to 70 flowers. <i>Glumes </i> 1.5-3.5 × 2-2.5 mm (from middle of spikelet), ovate, reddish-brown with pale brown midrib and narrow hyaline margins; apex obtuse to acute; the 2 lowest glumes empty, subequal, each surrounding not more than 2/3 of the base of the spikelet. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0-4, shorter to longer than nut; stamens 3, with anthers 1.6-2.5 mm; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  (1.2-) 1.5-2.0 × 1.3-1.5 mm (measurements of nut length do not include the length of the style-base), obovate, biconvex, yellowish to dark brown, finely punctate; style-base conical, not confluent with nut but strongly constricted beneath the cone base to form a rim.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-palustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a6499966-e79e-4067-b105-ebf265b92cc7#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242763","diagnostic","<p>This species is superficially similar to smaller plants of E. acicularis but is characterised by having stolons often terminating in a small tuber, slightly broader stems and inconspicuous leaf-sheaths.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-parvula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0b2ecff9-7ef4-4144-ad19-827946fdcb07#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242763","distribution","<p>Eleocharis parvula has two main centres of distribution -the south coast of England (v.cc. 3 and 13) and the north Cardigan Bay area in Wales (v.cc. 48 and 49). In Scotland, found only in E Ross (v.c. 106). In Ireland, recently found in two sites in Co. Londonderry (v.c. H40), but there are old records in N Kerry (v.c. H2) and Co. Wicklow (v.c. H20).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-parvula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0b2ecff9-7ef4-4144-ad19-827946fdcb07#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242763","ecology","<p>Eleocharis parvula is a plant of firm muddy places in the upper reaches of estuaries, avoiding strongly saline areas; it also occurs in tidal pans in brackish grazing-marshes. Its associates include Bolboschoenus maritimus, Juncus foliosus, Limosella australis, Ranunculus sceleratus and Veronica anagallis-aquatica. It often forms a close carpet in which other associates cannot easily establish themselves, a community briefly described by Rodwell (2000) as SM3. Grazing animals often poach areas, breaking the mat and thus spreading the population. Flowering and fruiting are apparently very poor in many areas: see A.J. Byfield in Wigginton (1999).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-parvula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0b2ecff9-7ef4-4144-ad19-827946fdcb07#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242763","general","<p>Plants connected by whitish capillary stolons creeping on the surface, often terminating in a small whitish tuber. <i>Stems </i> 2-8 cm × 0.3-0.5 mm, sparsely tufted, terete, often spongy, smooth to minutely septate-nodulose when dry, often flowerless and leaf-like. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths up to 1 cm long, translucent, indistinct. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid to ovoid-ellipsoid spikelet, 1.9-4 × 1-1.5 mm. <i>Glumes </i> 1.2-2.5 × 1-2 mm, up to 9 per spikelet, ovate, with an obtuse to acute apex and greenish to yellowish-brown striate margins and indistinct midrib, the lowest glume usually empty and half or more as long as the spikelet, completely surrounding its base. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles usually 3, equalling or longer than nut; stamens 3, with their anthers 1.0-1.2 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1.0-1.4 mm· long, obovoid, trigonous, pale yellowish, smooth to very minutely reticulate, shiny; style-base small, conical, confluent with nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-parvula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0b2ecff9-7ef4-4144-ad19-827946fdcb07#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242771","distribution","<p>Anhui, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Guizhou, Hainan, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Liaoning, Shaanxi, Shanxi, Sichuan, Yunnan, Zhejiang [India, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Russia (Far East), Sri Lanka, N Thailand].</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-pellucida-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","e3639799-3866-44fb-b761-f9d321694aa4#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242771","general","<p>Annual or short-lived perennials. Rhizomes absent. Culms tufted to densely tufted, 5-30 cm tall or more, 0.5-1 mm thick, soft, longitudinally sulcate. Leaf sheaths 2, basally ± purplish and apically green, tubular, 1.5-4 cm, mouth truncate, apex deltoid dentate. Spikelet narrowly ovoid, oblong-ovoid, cylindric, or rarely globose-ovoid, (3-)5-10 × 1.5-3 mm, several to many flowered. Basalmost glume empty, amplexicaul for whole spikelet base; fertile glumes pale rust-colored, ± laxly spirally imbricate, oblong to suboblong, ca. 2 × 1 mm, midvein greenish, margin hyaline, apex obtuse to rounded. Perianth bristles 6, rust-colored, ca. 1.5 × as long as nutlet or slightly shorter, densely or laxly retrorsely spinulose. Stigmas 3. Nutlet yellowish to olivaceous, obovoid, 0.8-1.2 × 0.5-0.7 mm, 3-sided, sides convex, narrowly costate on angles; persistent style base pyramidal to conic, 1/4-1/2 as long and ca. 1/2 as wide as nutlet, sometimes spongy-thickened, apex acuminate.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-pellucida-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","e3639799-3866-44fb-b761-f9d321694aa4#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242771","habitat","<p>Pond margins, shallow ponds, paddy fields, shallow water margins, lake banks; 200-1700 m.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-pellucida-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-r-brown","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","e3639799-3866-44fb-b761-f9d321694aa4#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242813","diagnostic","<p>This species has the largest and darkest glumes of the three Eleocharis species in which the lowest glume in the spikelet is half as long as the spikelet or more. From E. uniglumis it can be distinguished further by its three stigmas and/or trigonous nut, whereas E. multicaulis has the lowest glume usually less than half the length of the spikelet.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-quinqueflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f8d7ad47-40e6-4e1b-b5b9-2b880897716d#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242813","distribution","<p>Eleocharis quinqueflora is mainly an upland and northern plant in the British Isles, reaching 915 m in Atholl, v.c. 89 (Porter & Foley 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-quinqueflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f8d7ad47-40e6-4e1b-b5b9-2b880897716d#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242813","ecology","<p>Eleocharis quinqueflora is a plant of wet peaty mires, particularly in base-rich habitats such as spring-heads and calcareous flushes, giving its name to a distinct variant in the Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris mires (M10) and a sub-community with Palustriella commutata in mires characterised by Carex viridula subsp. oedocarpa and Saxifraga aizoides (M11b). Also in sedge communities of dune-slacks (SD14, SD16) and in seepage areas with Blysmus rufus and E. uniglumis (SM19, SM20) in the upper part of saltmarshes. It is a plant of open vegetation and is helped by grazing and minor disturbance. Scattered throughout the British Isles but commonest in the north and west.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-quinqueflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f8d7ad47-40e6-4e1b-b5b9-2b880897716d#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242813","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> stout, shortly creeping. <i>Stems </i> 3.5-40 cm × 0.4-1 mm, loosely to densely tufted, terete, smooth. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths up to 11 cm long, pale yellowish to brownish; apex obliquely obtuse to truncate. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid to ellipsoid spikelet, 4-10 × 3-5 mm. <i>Glumes </i> 2.5-7 × 1.2-2.2 mm, up to 7 per spikelet, lanceolate to oblong lanceolate, obtuse to acute, with mid to dark brown sides, green midrib and scarious margins, the lowest glume half or more as long as the spikelet and completely surrounding it at its base. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 4-6, shorter to longer than nut; stamens 3, with their anthers 1.8-2.1 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  2-3 × 1-1.2 mm, narrowly obovoid to obovoid, trigonous, blackish to grey, reticulate with rectangular epidermal cells; style-base narrowly triangular, confluent with nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-quinqueflora-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f8d7ad47-40e6-4e1b-b5b9-2b880897716d#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242956","diagnostic","<p>Eleocharis uniglumis resembles both E. palustris and E. mamillata subsp. austriaca but has only one sterile lower glume that more or less completely surrounds the base of the spikelet, which is frequently inserted obliquely.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-uniglumis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","6e519fd9-2088-49a7-8621-3e611511b2d8#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242956","distribution","<p>Eleocharis uniglumis is scattered throughout Britain but is being lost from many inland sites. In Ireland it is rarely recorded inland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-uniglumis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","6e519fd9-2088-49a7-8621-3e611511b2d8#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242956","ecology","<p>Eleocharis uniglumis is mostly a coastal species, occurring in depressions and pools on the upper parts of rocky coasts and tidal flats with Blysmus rufus, Triglochin maritimum, Agrostis stolonifera, Glaux maritima and Juncus gerardii (SM19) and dominant, with the last three species and Carex extensa, in SM20; also in brackish and surrounding marshes, often within the spray zone. It occasionally occurs inland in lowland Juncus subnodulosus fen-meadows with Carex elata (M22) and in upland calcareous marshes, especially associated with higher than normal sodium content of soils (Waiters 1943).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-uniglumis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","6e519fd9-2088-49a7-8621-3e611511b2d8#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:242956","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> creeping, dark purplish. <i>Stems </i> up to 60 cm × 0.8-1.5(-1.9) mm, tufted, ± terete, smooth to indistinctly ridged when dry. <i>Leaves </i> reduced to bladeless sheaths up to 9.5 cm long, dark reddish or purplish, paler above; apex ± truncate, often with a narrow purple ring. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, ovoid or lanceoloid-ovoid spikelet, 5-12 × 3-5 mm. <i>Glumes </i> 2.5-5 × 1.3-1.7 mm, c. 10-30 per spikelet, ovate to ovate-lanceolate, obtuse, with dark reddish-brown sides, paler towards the base, with paler brown or indistinct midrib and narrowly hyaline margins; only the lowest glume empty, more or less completely surrounding the base of the spikelet and with the inflorescence often tilted obliquely away from the point of insertion. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0-5, mostly shorter than nut, often poorly developed; stamens 3, with anthers 2.2-2.3 mm long; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  1.4-2.2* × 1.1-1.5 mm, narrowly obovate, biconvex, yellowish-brown to dark brown; style-base broadly triangular, flattened, acute to obtuse, constricted at base, not confluent with nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eleocharis-uniglumis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","6e519fd9-2088-49a7-8621-3e611511b2d8#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:243396","general","<p>Medium-sized tufted perennials. Culms (sub) scapose, terete to trigonous, rarely 4-angular or compressed. Leaves rarely distichous (?), eligulate, often reduced to a sheath, blade rarely ancipitous. Inflorescence (reduced) paniculate, with fewmany spikelets. Lower primary bracts mostly rather short and stiff. Spikelets with few-many distichous long persistent (finally deciduous ?) glumes of increasing length, upper 2-4 each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Rachilla internodes short, but last internode elongated, thickened, and curved. Lower 1-3 flowers functionally male, upper flower bisexual. Bristles absent (sometimes 3 poorly developed). Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, style base distinct or not, ± thickened, persistent. Achene ellipsoid to obovoid, often 3-ribbed, ± beaked, sometimes seated on a 3-lobed cuplike structure, surface smooth to tuberculate.<br /><br/>About eight spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244507","general","<p>Tufted perennials, sometimes rhizomatous, stoloniferous, or tussock-forming. Culms scapose or few-noded. Leaves ligulate, blade usually reduced in the cauline leaves. Inflorescence (compound-) anthelate or reduced to a single spikelet, fruiting spikelets sometimes drooping. Primary bracts mostly small, rarely leaflike. Spikelets with few to many spirally arranged deciduous glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. Bristles l0-many, extremely elongating after anthesis, silky, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 1-3. Style 3-fid, style base not distinct, not or slightly thickened, ± persistent. Achene obovate to oblong, trigonous, beak short to long, surface smooth.<br /><br/>About 20 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244512","diagnostic","<p>Eriophorum angustifolium is recognised by the stems that are ± terete to indistinctly trigonous, leaf-blades that are flat to V-shaped in cross-section, leaf-like inflorescence bracts, several ± nodding spikelets in fruit, smooth peduncles, and anthers 2.5-5 mm long. Vegetatively, the long (> 10 cm) trigonous tip to the leaf is unique and the leaf also ages characteristically, showing a wine-red band between the decaying tissue and the living leaf.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-angustifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","551fd008-08d5-40f0-99cd-2b1919966ca7#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244512","distribution","<p>Eriophorum angustifolium is common to locally abundant throughout N and W Britain, but is declining in the Midlands and SE owing to drainage, ground-water extraction and cessation of grazing (Porter & Foley 2002). In Ireland it is common throughout but will decline as peatlands are removed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-angustifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","551fd008-08d5-40f0-99cd-2b1919966ca7#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244512","ecology","<p>A ubiquitous species, found in most acid communities including shallow bog-pools with Sphagnum denticulatum, S. cuspidatum etc. (M1-3), in bogs typically with Carex canescens, C. nigra and C. rostrata (M5, M7, M9) and C. saxatilis (M12), and in various blanket mires (M17-21); also found in Trichophorum-Erica tetralix wet heath (M15) and the Eleocharis multicaulis sub-community of Erica vagans-Schoenus nigricans heath (H5). See also the Biological Flora account (Phillips 1954b) and other studies by Phillips (1953, 1954a).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-angustifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","551fd008-08d5-40f0-99cd-2b1919966ca7#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244512","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> extensive, long-creeping. <i>Stems </i> 15-75 cm × 1-2 mm, rather distant, erect, smooth, nodose, subterete to trigonous near apex. <i>Leaves </i> basal and cauline; blade 2-60 cm × 2-5(-7) mm, linear, channelled, gradually narrowed to a long triquetrous apex, otherwise flat to V -shaped in cross-section, yellowish-to bluish-green; sheaths up to 27 cm long (up to 8 cm on cauline leaves), ± inflated, pale to mid brown (greenish on some cauline leaves), the uppermost with a well developed blade usually at least 1.5 times as long as sheath; ligule very short, rounded. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal, comprising (1-)3-7 pedunculate spikelets, ± nodding in fruit; peduncles up to 8 cm long, slender, smooth; involucral bracts 1-2, leaf-like to glume-like, sheathing, the lowest ± equalling or exceeding the lowermost spikelet. <i>Spikelets </i> ovoid to ellipsoid when young, soon becoming obscured by the lengthening perianth bristles. <i>Glumes </i> 4-10 × 1.5-4 mm, spirally arranged, ovate to ovate-lanceolate or lanceolate, the upper narrower than the lower, ± obtuse, membranous, 1-nerved, reddish-to greyish-brown; margins hyaline. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual or male-sterile with abortive stamens; perianth bristles many, entire at the apex, elongating to 4-5 cm and forming a white cotton-like head; stamens 3; anthers 2.5-5 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1-3 × 0.7-1 mm, obovoid, trigonous, dull dark brown, ± smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-angustifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","551fd008-08d5-40f0-99cd-2b1919966ca7#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244534","general","<p>Plants colonial from long-creeping rhizomes. Culms solitary or few together, somewhat trigonous, (20–)30–70(–80) cm, stout, to 1.5(–4) mm diam. basally; basal sheaths persistent, brown to purplish brown, septate-nodulose. Leaves: blades filiform, trigonous-channeled, (2–)3–10 cm × 1–2 mm; distal 1–2 leaf sheaths bladeless, inflated. Inflorescences: involucral bracts absent. Spikelets solitary, erect, globose in fruit, 1.5–2(–4) cm; scales blackish to purplish brown; proximal empty scales not more than 7, obovate or trigonous-obovate, 4–20 mm, margins white or paler, as wide as dark portion, apex blunt; distal scales obovate to ovate-lanceolate, margins hyaline, 1 mm wide or wider. Flowers: perianth bristles 10 or more, red-brown to white, 20–40 mm, smooth; anthers (0.6–)1.5–3 mm. Achenes oblong-obovoid, 2–2.7 mm, as wide as long, apex apiculate (0.3–0.5 mm). 2n = 58.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-chamissonis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","d311382e-e0d4-4e74-9d38-194cbb1d3f9a#general"
