"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244552","conservation","<p>Eriophorum gracile is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Near threatened (Cheffings & Farrell 2005). It is also protected under the Flora (Protection) Order 1999 in the Republic of Ireland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-gracile-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","54d6457c-18e2-474c-8854-b614da9788a4#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244552","diagnostic","<p>E. gracile is recognised by the distant, solitary, triquetrous stems, leaf blades that are 0.5-2 mm wide, rough and minutely hairy peduncles, several somewhat nodding spikelets in fruit, several-nerved glumes and, when in flower, anthers 1.3-2 mm long; the apices of the perianth bristles are entire.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-gracile-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","54d6457c-18e2-474c-8854-b614da9788a4#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244552","distribution","<p>Eriophorum gracile still occurs very locally from Surrey to Caemarvonshire but has been lost from Somerset, Dorset and many sites in Hampshire. There are old records from Acle (v.c. 27), Easton Hornstocks (v.c. 32) and Crofton- Tees (v.c. 65). In Ireland it is scarce in the centre and local in the west.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-gracile-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","54d6457c-18e2-474c-8854-b614da9788a4#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244552","ecology","<p>Eriophorum gracile is found in wet neutral to slightly basic mires such as those included in the Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris community (M10), where it forms a variant with Molinia caerulea, especially where poached by grazing stock.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-gracile-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","54d6457c-18e2-474c-8854-b614da9788a4#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244552","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> extensive, long-creeping. <i>Stems </i> 20-60 cm × 0.4-0.8 mm, distant, solitary, erect, smooth, nodose in lower half only, triquetrous. <i>Leaves </i> basal and cauline; blade 2-40 cm × 0.5-2 mm, linear, 3-angled and slightly channelled, narrowed to an obtuse apex, yellowish-to bluish-green; sheaths up to 8 cm long (to 5 cm on cauline leaves), close-fitting, pale to mid brown (greenish on some cauline leaves), the uppermost with blade rarely more than 1/2 as long as the sheath; ligule short, rounded. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal, comprising 3-6 pedunculate spikelets, becoming ± pendulous in fruit; peduncles up to 3 cm long, slender, rough, densely but minutely hairy; involucral bracts 1-2, leaf-like to glume-like, sheathing, the lowermost ± equalling or shorter than the lowermost spikelet. <i>Spikelets </i> ovoid to ellipsoid when young, soon becoming obscured by lengthening perianth segments. <i>Glumes </i> 4-5 × 1.5-2.2 mm, spirally arranged, ovate to ovate-lanceolate, the upper slightly narrower than the lower, ± acute, membranous, several-nerved, yellowish-brown to greenish-brown; margins entire. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles many, entire at the apex, elongating to 1.5-2 cm and forming a white, cotton-like head; stamens 3; anthers 1.3-2 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  2.5-3 × 0.5-0.7 mm, ellipsoid-cylindric, trigonous, dull yellowish-brown, ± smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-gracile-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","54d6457c-18e2-474c-8854-b614da9788a4#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244565","diagnostic","<p>Eriophorum latifolium is recognised by the loosely tufted, triquetrous stems, leaf-blades that are 3-8 mm wide, rough, minutely hairy peduncles, several spikelets ± nodding in fruit and 1-nerved glumes. The perianth bristles are also minutely papillose at their apices (best seen under binocular microscope). The species is most easily observed in flower in early June, when the head is more compact and 'cleaner' than that of E. angustifolium, but it becomes inconspicuous when the seeds disperse from mid July onwards.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-latifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","03d8045c-bb14-4b52-8aa1-9874b0855cfa#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244565","distribution","<p>Eriophorum latifolium occurs in scattered localities throughout Britain where calcium or magnesium influences soil-water, especially on limestone in N England and mica schist areas in Scotland. Similarly distributed in Ireland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-latifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","03d8045c-bb14-4b52-8aa1-9874b0855cfa#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244565","ecology","<p>Found in calcareous, often open and stony, mires, e.g. M10a, in which small sedges such as C. viridula subspp. oedocarpa and brachyrhyncha and Schoenus ferrugineus form small hummocks and where Carex dioica, C. hostiana, Eleocharis quinqueflora and Schoenus nigricans can be plentiful; also in base-rich meadows of the Briza media-Primula farinosa sub-community (M10b), growing with Selaginella selaginoides, Kobresia simpliciuscula and the moss Ctenidium molluscum.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-latifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","03d8045c-bb14-4b52-8aa1-9874b0855cfa#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244565","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short. <i>Stems </i> 20-70 cm × 1-2 mm, loosely tufted, erect, smooth, nodose, triquetrous. <i>Leaves </i> basal and cauline; blade 2-60 cm × 3-8 mm, linear, narrowed to a triquetrous apex, otherwise flat, yellowish-to bluish-green; sheaths less than 12 cm long (to 5 cm on cauline leaves), close-fitting, pale to mid brown; lower leaves with a rounded ligule with free portion 0.5 mm; uppermost cauline leaf with a well developed blade about equalling sheath and no ligule. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal, comprising 2-12 pedunculate spikelets, ± nodding in fruit; peduncles up to 5 cm long, slender, rough with dense, minute, forward-pointing, stiff hairs (best detected when peduncle is drawn between the lips); involucral bracts 2-3, leaf-like to glume-like, sheathing, the lowest ± equalling or exceeding the lowermost spikelet. <i>Spikelets </i> ovoid to ellipsoid when young, soon becoming obscured by the lengthening perianth bristles. <i>Glumes </i> 5-6 × 1-2.1 mm, spirally arranged, ovate-lanceolate to lanceolate, the upper narrower than the lower, ± acute, membranous, 1-nerved, greyish-brown to blackish above, somewhat olivaceous below; margins narrowly hyaline. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles many, minutely papillose at the apex, elongating to 2-2.5 cm and forming a neat, almost 'brilliant' white, cotton-like head; stamens 3; anthers 1.3-2 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  3-3.5 × 1-1.4 mm, obovoid, trigonous, dull reddish-brown, ± smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-latifolium-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","03d8045c-bb14-4b52-8aa1-9874b0855cfa#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244598","general","<p>Plant rhizomatous; stems 8-40 cm, terete, leafy towards base. Leaves 1-2 mm wide, shorter than stems, linear and canaliculate at base, trigonous above; lower sheaths yellowish-brown; cauline leaves with inflated sheath, without or with a short lamina. Spikelet 1; bracts absent, or lowest glume bract-like, 3-veined. Glumes ovate- lanceolate, greyish-brown to blackish, with narrow hyaline margin, the lowest 2-6 empty. Bristles up to 30 mm, pure white, often patent or deflexed; anthers c. 1 mm, ovate. Nut c. 2 mm, oblong, subterete.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-scheuchzeri-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","de3ceef9-eb3b-4ad1-9446-6c0c042419f1#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244598","habitat","<p>Wet bogs and tundra and muddy or peaty lake-margins.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-scheuchzeri-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","de3ceef9-eb3b-4ad1-9446-6c0c042419f1#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244613","diagnostic","<p>E. vaginatum is easily recognisable, being the only species of Eriophorum in the British Isles with a single spikelet forming the inflorescence. In addition, there are no involucral bracts and the leaf-blade is ± triquetrous in cross-section and absent or reduced on the uppermost stem-sheath. See also 5 Trichophorum germanicum concerning vegetative characters.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-vaginatum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4f8bb1aa-3220-4607-a8ef-cc38e67dfaf6#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244613","distribution","<p>Eriophorum vaginatum is common in England north of the Mersey-Humber line and in Wales, but local south of SE Yorks/Cheshire, being lost from the valley bogs drained in lowland England. In Ireland, throughout the island but less common in the SE.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-vaginatum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4f8bb1aa-3220-4607-a8ef-cc38e67dfaf6#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244613","ecology","<p>Found in bogs, e.g. pool communities with Sphagnum cuspidatum/fallax, Calluna and Vaccinium oxycoccos (M2), frequent in deep waterlogged peat areas where E. vaginatum and Trichophorum germanicum can be codominant with E. angustifolium and Molinia as common species (M17); also in raised and blanket mires with Erica tetralix, Calluna, Sphagnum spp. (including S. papillosum, S. capillifolium and S. subnitens) and 'brown' mosses (M18, M19) and on degraded plateau peat and subsequent slumped peat in basins and on lower slopes (M20). It can also be found in high-level heath of Vaccinium myrtillus-Rubus chamaemorus, possibly as a relict. See also the Biological Flora account (Wein 1973).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-vaginatum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4f8bb1aa-3220-4607-a8ef-cc38e67dfaf6#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244613","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short, forming compact tussocks. <i>Stems </i> (15-)30-60(-80) cm × 0.8-1.5 mm, tufted, erect, smooth, nodose in lower half only, triquetrous above, terete below. <i>Leaves </i> basal and cauline; blade 3-50 cm × 0.4-0.8 mm, linear to ± setaceous, narrowed to an obtuse apex, ± triquetrous, yellowish-to bluish-green; sheaths up to 12 cm long (to 6 cm on cauline leaves), close-fitting, becoming fibrous on basal leaves, strongly inflated and pale to mid brown on cauline leaves, the uppermost sheath without a blade or with blade much reduced; ligule 0. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, terminal, erect spikelet; involucral bracts 0. Spikelet ovoid to ellipsoid when young, soon becoming obscured by the lengthening perianth bristles. <i>Glumes </i> spirally arranged, ovate-lanceolate, 6-7 × 1.5-2.2 mm, acuminate, membranous, 1-nerved, translucent mid to dark greyish, with margins hyaline, the lower 5-15 glumes sterile and often darker. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual or male-sterile with abortive stamens; perianth bristles many, entire at apex, elongating to 2-2.5 cm and forming a white, cotton-like head; stamens 3; anthers 1.5-2 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  2-3 × 1-1.5 mm, obovoid, trigonous, dull yellowish-brown to dark brown, ± smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/eriophorum-vaginatum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4f8bb1aa-3220-4607-a8ef-cc38e67dfaf6#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244944","general","<p>Rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose or fewnoded. Leaves eligulate (?). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244947","general","<p>Dwarf shrubs with woody caudex covered by fibrous leaf sheath remnants and adventitious roots. Culms lateral, scapose, compressed. Leaves crowded on top of the caudex, eligulate, contraligule ± triangular. Inflorescence paniculate with many-numerous spikelets. Primary bracts ± leaflike, sheathing. Lower branches (or lower partial inflorescences) usually with male spikelets, upper with female spikelets, rarely dioecious. Male spikelet with spiral, persistent glumes, lower empty, middle and upper each subtending a male flower with 2-9 stamens. Female spikelet with few spiral, persistent glumes, penultimate glume subtending a female flower with a pistil, surrounded at the base, opposite the sides, by 3 small ± triangular, long-fimbriate scales. Style 3-fid, base not distinct, not or slightly thickened, persistent. Achene oblong to obovate, rounded trigonous, 3-ribbed, often long-beaked, beak smooth or scabrid, surface smooth.<br /><br/>About 12 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244977","general","<p>Creeping rhizomatous perennial. Culms manynoded, slender. Leaves eligulate, lower leaves often reduced to a sheath. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:244984","general","<p>Perennial with short creeping rhizome. Culms scapose. Leaves eligulate, contraligule rounded triangular. Inflorescence paniculate with many spikelets, main axis conspicuously sinuous. Primarybracts boat-shaped, shortly sheathing, tightly clasping the partial inflorescences (only part of the spikelets visible). Lower (=long pedicelled) spikelets female, upper (=shortly pedicelled) spikelets male. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:245019","general","<p>Tufted perennials, frequently rhizomatous, stoloniferous, or decumbent. Culms scapose, more rarely few- to many-noded or branched. Leaves often (conspicuously) ligulate, blade sometimes with scarious margins, or leaf reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence rarely pseudolateral, mostly capitate, more rarely compacted paniculate, spicate, or spikelets scattered along a profusely branched stem, with 1-many spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike or short, lowermost bract sometimes erect. Spikelets with few to many spiral or distichous, usually long persistent glumes, each subtending a flower, or a few lower glumes empty. Flowers bisexual. Bristles absent. Stamens 3. Style deeply 3-fid (2-fid in F. lateralis Kunth), rarely almost undivided, style base not distinct, deciduous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:245205","general","<p>Annuals or tufted, more rarely creeping rhizomatous perennials. Culms (sub)scapose, terete to 3-4-5-angular or ancipitous. Leaves rarely (spiro)distichous or equitant, ligule absent or present as a membranous or hairy rim, blade sometimes ensiform or reduced to a sheath. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:245774","general","<p>Annuals or short-lived perennials. Rhizomes extremely short or absent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:245842","general","<p>Perennials. Rhizomes short, woody. Culms solitary, 5-16 cm tall, obtusely 3-angled to subterete, striate, basally leaved, base covered with blackish brown often fibrous old leaf sheaths. Leaves slightly shorter than to equaling culm; sheath adaxially membranous and brown, mouth obliquely split; ligule absent; leaf blade 1-2.5 mm wide, stiff, slightly scabrid, margin slightly involute, apex acute. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:246282","general","<p>Small to medium-sized annuals or rhizomatous perennials. Culms usually many-noded (scapose in F. enodis C.B. Clarke), 3-S-angular, occasionally thickened at the base. Leaves tri- or pentastichous, ligule tubular, membranous, blade often reduced in the lower leaves. Inflorescence paniculate to capitate with few to many spikelets, rarely pseudolateral. Primary bracts often leaflike, sheathing, lowermost bract sometimes erect. Spikelets with many spiral, rarely (spiro)pentastichous, deciduous glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. Bristles (0-1-)3, or 6, and then in 2 series, the rib-opposed bristlelike, the face-opposed often differentiated into variously shaped scales, rarely all bristles reduced or absent, or only 1 scale developed, as long as or shorter than the fruit, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 1-3. Style 3-fid, base not distinct, not or slightly thickened, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:246442","general","<p>Tufted or shortly rhizomatous perennials, sometimes with a long, erect, or ascending caudex. Culms scapose or few-noded. Leaves ligulate, blade flat or inrolled, often inverted (Wilson, Telopea 5: 601-602.1994). Inflorescence terminal, paniculate, partial inflorescences often ± condensed, with many-numerous spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike, sheathing. Spikelets mostly dark brown or black, with 5-8 spirally arranged, persistent glumes, 1-2 upper glume(s) each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Lower flower functionally male, upper bisexual. Bristles mostly absent. Stamens (2-)3-6, filaments persistent at the base of the fruit, with several glume-fixing mechanisms. Style 3(4)-fid, base rather distinct, slightly thickened, sometimes persistent. Achene ovate to elliptic, subterete to subtrigonous, sometimes beaked, often yellowish to reddish colored, with hard, thick fruitwall, endocarp sometimes with grooved inner side.<br /><br/>About 30 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:248691","general","<p>Medium-sized tufted perennial. Culms (sub)scapose. Leaves eligulate, lower leaves often reduced to a sheath. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:249605","general","<p>Perennials, often on a thick woody rhizome. Culms central or lateral (and then with a number of basal cataphylls), scapose or more rarely 1several noded. Leaves eligulate, sometimes pseudopetiolate, blade sometimes lanceolate or reduced (often in basal leaves). Inflorescence corymbose, paniculate or capitate, with numerous (-1) spikelets, often with 3(-more) collateral branches per bract. Primary bracts small, scalelike, or large and leaflike, patent to reflexed. Spikelets with many spirally arranged' persistent glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250129","general","<p>Annual or short lived-perennials; tufted or mat-forming. Roots minute, arising at culm base or at internodes; tubers usually absent. Rhizome ascending or horizontal, either below or above ground (runners). Culm 0.8 – 80 (200) cm tall, consisting of several internodes or reduced to peduncle only. Leaf comprising of a closed sheath and blade; blade a minute lobe or elongated to form a linear blade. Inflorescence comprising 1 – several spikelets, subtended by a single involucral bract. Bract shorter than spikelets resulting in a terminal inflorescence, or longer and continuing in direction of culm resulting in a pseudolateral inflorescence. Spikelets terete, with spirally arranged glumes, sometimes proliferating. Glumes ovate to obovate, green to reddish-brown, carinate, acute to obtuse, arranged on the rachilla with the space between successive glumes <0.1 mm. Flowers bisexual; perianth segments absent. Stamens 1 – 3; filament ribbon-like; anther 0.2 – 2.5 mm long, apex crested. Pistil with 2 – 3 stigma branches. Nutlets 2- or 3-sided, smooth, reticulate, papillose or striate; gynophore absent.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-cyperaceae-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","6694dd1c-cbd4-4ab5-a52e-fd18f8cac553#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250129","general","<p>Annuals or mat-forming perenni(ils, more rarely creeping rhizomatous or stoloniferous. Culms scapose or few- to many-noded. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250147","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis angelica closely resembles the three species from the East African mountains (I. keniaensis, I. kilimanjarica and I. ruwenzoriensis). Gordon-Gray (Cyperaceae of Natal) suggested that I. angelica is an interspecific hybrid between I. setacea and I. fluitans, following Haines & Lye's (1983) argument on the hybrid origin of I. kilimanjarica. On the basis of floral morphology, we treat I. angelica as more closely related to I. setacea than to I. fluitans.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-angelica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","457aae2d-9b8d-4adb-a101-2a10e391245b#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250171","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis beccarii has both bifid and trifid styles, an inflorescence bract topping the 1 -2 spikelets and a mat-forming habit. Kern (1974) comments on its distribution; it is found only in Sumatra where it seems to replace the widespread I. fluitans. We suspect that this species has evolved from I. fluitans, and has characters linking Eleogiton and Isolepis, thus removing the justification for recognising the former.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-beccarii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","5143eb47-01e9-4357-b866-872a50c36414#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250189","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis bulbifera has some characters in common with I. expallescens, particularly the trifid style and minutely reticulate nutlets. However, it has several distinguishing characters, including the tuberous culm base, a single terminal spikelet forming the inflorescence and glumes that increase in length from the base to the apex of the spikelets. Levyns (1944) described Scirpus delicatulus based on an immature specimen lacking nutlets whose type resembles Isolepis bulbifera in glume morphology and the presence of tuberous culm bases. We therefore include S. delicatulus in I. bulbifera.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-bulbifera-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","9b2f49d2-9a1f-4202-b5ae-5656a9a30351#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250189","distribution","<p>Suth Africa, endemic to the Cape Peninsula.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-bulbifera-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","9b2f49d2-9a1f-4202-b5ae-5656a9a30351#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250189","general","<p>Tufted annual. Roots minute; rhizome 2 – 41 × 0.2 – 0.4 mm, ascending, whitish. Culms 4 – 17 cm tall, 0.3 – 0.4 mm diam., without nodes, base enlarged to form a tuber. Leaves: sheath 10 – 34 × 0.4 – 0.6 mm, brown; blade 1 – 119 × 0.2 – 0.3 mm. Inflorescence terminal, not proliferating; bract 1 × 0.5 – 0.7 mm. Spikelet 1, 1.9 – 8.3 × 1.1 – 1.5 mm, with 6 – 22 glumes. Glumes 1.2 – 1.9 × 0.7 – 1 mm, obtuse, reddish-brown, midrib green with mucro <0.1 mm long; glume size increasing from spikelet base to apex. Style trifid. Stamens 3, anthers 0.7 – 1.1 mm long, crested. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250200","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis cernua is treated here in a broad sense and is diagnosed by the spherical spikelets, glumes with obtuse apex and the tuberculate or occasionally reticulate nutlet surface. Allied species in the Isolepis cernua complex are reduced to varieties as there are no discrete characters to separate them. In South Africa, three specimens from the Clanwilliam area (Gordon-Gray CP 209/59 (NU) and 215/59 (NU) differ from typical I. cernua in nutlet and glume morphology. We include these in I. cernua pending further studies to establish whether there is continuous variation in the morphological characters.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-cernua-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","367c99c5-3553-4014-b0de-6e27939eaa27#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250206","diagnostic","<p>We treat var. setiformis here to include I. setformis and I. verrucosula, diagnosed by the bifid style. Blake (1940) described this taxon as a new species (Scirpus setiformis) although he based it on the same type as Bentham's S. arenam'us var ? s~tiformis.We have no doubt they are the same plant; Blake should instead have treated S. setiformis as a new combination. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250248","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis diabolica is closely related to I. angelica. Typical I. diabolica is tufted with thin whitish rhizomes and grows in the lowlands in the Cape Peninsula whereas I. angelica has thicker yellowish rhizomes and grows in the alpine areas on the Drakensberg Mts. Some material of I. diabolica from the East Cape region combines characters of both species, thus obscuring the limits. However, as such plants appear exceptional, the two separate taxa are maintained.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-diabolica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","ecc16f69-82d2-47cb-9049-52553a5eb597#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250251","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis digitata is recognised by its semi-succulent culm bases, well developed leaf blades, digitate inflorescence and smooth nutlets. No type specimen is indicated by Schrader, and the first reference to any material is by Nees (1836) under Eleogiton digitatus. Two specimens are cited but neither have been located and may have been destroyed in Berlin. We did, however, locate an Ecklon & Zeyher specimen in SAM which was collected in a similar locality and at the same time of year as the material cited by Nees. Therefore we designate this specimen as a neotype.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-digitata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","19a93bd6-3658-451b-b7b9-9d639eba17f0#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250291","diagnostic","<p>There is wide morphological variation between populations of var. fluitans. However, much of this is phenotypic and often depends on whether plants are growing in aquatic or terrestrial habitats. A number of varieties previously recognised, e.g. var. major (eastern Africa) and varieties spadicea and fascicularis (India and Sri Lanka), are indistinguishable and are included here in var. fluitans. Variety nervosa is distinguished by the tufted habit and culms consisting of an elongated peduncle and restricted to Ethiopia. Variety lenticularis is distinguished by having bracts that are longer than the spikelets and occurs in Australia and New Zealand.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-fluitans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","41d81193-a230-4e65-93fc-3bd24c194d2d#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250319","diagnostic","<p>This species is distinguished from I. fluitans by the more erect habit and shortened peduncle. Haines & Lye (1983) suggested that I. grnmznoides is the most primitive member of Isolepzs and that I. fluitans had evolved from such a species by reduction of spikelet number and elongation of stem. Our study does not support the hypothesis that I. graminoidesis the most primitive member of Isolepis. We interpret the inflorescence in this species to consist of a single terminal spikelet but with the peduncles reduced, giving what appears to be a congested inflorescence comprising several spikelets.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-graminoides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","d687a97b-f6fd-4beb-8d00-f3735a6be3de#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250347","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis incomtula is diagnosed by its long-mucronate glumes, trifid style, anthers with a crested apex and minutely papillose nutlets. Nees (1836) described three species, I. incomtulus, I. exilis and I. echinidium. The two latter were placed into synonymy under Scirpus incomtulus by Boeckeler (1870), and this was also followed by Clarke (1894). Based on our understanding of the descriptions and observations of material, we choose incomtula as the accepted name under Isolepis.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-incomtula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","dbb9647b-509e-4453-9628-7a0c3f1019be#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250357","diagnostic","<p>The erect culm-like involucral bract makes the Isolepis keniaensis specimen superficially similar to the annual species of Schoenoplectus Palla. However, I. keniaensis has nutlets with longitudinal striations and no transverse ridges whereas the nutlets of Schoenoplectus species have no longitudinal striations but have transverse ridges. In addition, the annual Schoenoplectus species in Kenya have a basal nutlet (amphicarpy) and grow at lower altitudes (below 2000 m).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-keniaensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","d7597990-a564-4b1d-bd43-9e72b7a724ab#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250385","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis ludwigii is diagnosed by the congested peduncles (more than 10) at each node and the bifid styles. It mainly grows in seepages and the edges of ponds; rarely it is aquatic. Some aquatic material, with a slender habit and separated as Isolepis tenuior, is not distinguishable from typical I. ludwigii. However, Clarke (1897/98) noted that the variation in I. tenuior ends where I. fluitans starts. We consider I. tenuior to be an aquatic form of I. ludwigii, and the similarity to I. fluitans could be a habitat modification, i.e. developing slender leaves due to it being submerged.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-ludwigii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","2142a61c-ddb1-4482-b693-a660c5ea20b9#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250406","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis minuta is diagnosed by its dwarf stature, a recurved mucro at the glume apex and smooth nutlets with a longitudinally elongated surface cell outline. Archer (1998) transferred Cyperus leucoloma Nees to Isolepis, arguing that the 'glumes in the holotype appear subdistichous due to having been collected at a young stage and flattened by the collector'. We have examined three of the specimens she cited, two of which (Schlechter 16336 & Levyns 831) have distichous glumes whereas another (Barker 243) has spirally arranged glumes. [In our opinion, Barker 243 is Isolepis minuta and we interpret the distichous glumes in Schlechter 16336 & Levyns 831 to be typical of Cyperus. Based on the current acceptance of mostly spirally arranged glumes in Isolepis and mostly distichous glumes in Cyperus, we still recognise Cyperus leucoloma. Further studies of the annual species of Cyperus and Isolepis in the Cape area are needed to ascertain their generic placement and to evaluate whether distichous glumes is a character unique to Cyperus or could occur in other cyperoid genera.] DNA phylogenetic studies show I. leucoloma to be sister to I. minuta, and both taxa are part of Isolepis clade including I. marginata. Therefore presence of distichous glumes in I. leucoloma is homoplasy.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-minuta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","b338298c-a674-4f85-ba90-3ae63892c046#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250423","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis nigricans is diagnosed by the ascending rhizomes, well developed leaf blades, proliferating inflorescence, trifid styles, and smooth nutlets. It occurs in central and S America. In several herbaria (e.g., BM, K), material of this species has been determined as Isolepis inundata. The two species have a similar size and proliferating inflorescence but I. inundata has highly reduced leaf blades, reticulate nutlets and occurs in Australasia.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-nigricans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","7422ef33-5279-4a8d-b6be-e8b0eff0601b#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250509","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis reticularis is diagnosed by the slender culms, reduced leaf blades, proliferating inflorescence, mucronate glumes and minutely reticulate nutlets. We were unable to see the type material of L reticularis and S. inundatus var. gracillimus. According to Edgar (1970) there are are 10 Colenso specimens in WELT which represent syntypes of reticularis but no lectotype has been designated. As we have not seen all of these specimens we refrain from designating any as a lectotype. Cheeseman did not give any locality for S. inundatus var. gracillimus, although Moore & Edgar (1970) pointed out that several Colenso specimens in WELT have been annotated as this taxon, and may represent type material. Further work needs to be carried out on the typification of this species.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-reticularis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","23c0cfba-dc8d-4874-a4e4-f6d3bdb0b25a#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250537","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis setacea is one of the most widespread species in the genus. Lye & Haines (1977) described var. aberdarica based on material from Afroalpine moorland on the Aberdare Mts, differing from typical var. setacea in its branched rhizome, absence of leaves and highly reduced inflorescence bract. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250568","diagnostic","<p>Isolepis sulcata is recognised by the reduced leaf blades, proliferating inflorescence and minutely reticulate nutlets. It grows together with the closely related species, I. prolifera and can be separated by the rigid culms and leaf sheath colour. The rigid culms in I. sulcata are due to well developed sclerenchyma strands in the chlorenchyma.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-sulcata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","f9e30074-5d05-42a0-96c3-9193d3720ccc#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250613","general","<p>Tufted annual. Roots minute; rhizome 2 – 6 × 0.3 – 1.3 mm, ascending, whitish. Culms 6 – 39 cm tall, 0.5 – 1 mm diam., without nodes. Leaves: sheath 10 – 65 × 0.7 – 1.5 mm, brown; blade 1 – 47 × 0.1 – 0.9 mm. Inflorescence pseudolateral, proliferating; bract 4- 31 × 0.3 – 1 mm. Spikelet 2 – 13, 2.3 – 5.5 × 1.5 – 2.5 mm, with 9 – 27 glumes. Glumes 1.6 – 2.2 × 0.8 – 1 mm, obtuse, brown to dark brown, midrib green to partially brown with mucro <0.1 mm long. Style trifid. Stamens 1 – 3, anthers 0.5 – 0.7 mm long, crested. Nutlets 0.7 – 1 × 0.6 – 0.7 mm, straw-coloured to golden brown, surface with longitudinal ribs and densely set transverse bars connecting the ribs.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/isolepis-wakefieldiana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/monograph-genus-isolepis-r-br-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","92f153b1-89ec-4541-b80c-1a35205f0365","","12ef2220-1239-411e-b313-4b4c4c25e0a4#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:250913","general","<p>Herbae perennes; culmi 30-85 cm alti, cormis usque ad 7 vaginis coriaceis imbricatis brunneis instructis; folia 1-6, basalia; laminae usque ad 35 cm longae, 3 mm latae, vaginae 8-10 mm longae; inflorescentia capitata (1-) 1.5-2.2 cm lata e ca 4-10 spicis densis sessilibus (raro 1-3 spicis pedunculatis) constructa, bracteis foliaceis 10-15 cm longis; spiculae (4-) 10-15, ca 5 mm longae, ca 2.5 mm latae, 15-18-florae; squamae spirales, ovato-caudatae, (2.5-) 4-6 mm longae, 1.5-2 mm latae, marroninae, achenia amplectentes, basilari excepta fertiles, deciduae; flores bisexuales; antherae 2-3, 1-2.3 mm longae; styli 3; achenia trigona late elliptica, ca 1.2 mm longa, ca 0.7 mm lata. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251042","general","<p>Densely caespitose. Stems 5-30 cm, erect; basal sheaths leafless, brown, shining. Leaves equalling or longer than stems, 0.5-1.5(-2) mm wide, canaliculate. Spike solitary, 10-25(-30) x 2-3 mm, with 10-20 spikelets. Terminal spikelet of several male flowers; lateral each with 1 male flower above and 1 female flower below. Glumes brown, with scarious margin. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251090","diagnostic","<p>Kobresia is closely related to Carex, the former being distinguished by the fact that the utricle does not fully enclose the nut, being open at least at its apex and often down its side. In addition each spike has a male floret at the top and a female one below.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/kobresia-simpliciuscula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1dab535d-47e4-4b34-81f1-ec275bb73ed1#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251090","distribution","<p>Kobresia simpliciuscula is very locally distributed, being known only from Teesdale, Mid and East Perthshire (v.cc. 88 and 89) and Argyll (v.c. 98), but some populations contain tens of thousands of plants (Porter & Foley 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/kobresia-simpliciuscula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1dab535d-47e4-4b34-81f1-ec275bb73ed1#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251090","ecology","<p>Kobresia simpliciuscula is characteristic of highly calcareous, somewhat hummocky open flushes within the Briza media-Primula farinosa subcommunity of the Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris mire (M10b), and there distinguished as a variant, M10biii, best seen in Teesdale, in which Racomitrium lanuginosum and Carex capillaris are often prominent with the dominant Kobresia. In Scottish localities Carex dioica, C. hostiana, C. panicea, C. pulicaris and C. viridula subspp. brachyrhyncha and oedocarpa, Eleocharis quinqueflora, Juncus articulatus and the bryophytes Aneura pinguis, Ctenidium molluscum and Palustriella commutata amongst others, are common and Equisetum hyemale and Schoenus ferrugineus locally frequent.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/kobresia-simpliciuscula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1dab535d-47e4-4b34-81f1-ec275bb73ed1#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251090","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> very short, densely tufted. <i>Stems </i> 5-20 cm × 0.4-0.7 mm, trigonous, rough, stiff, greyish-green, leafy at base. <i>Leaves </i> mostly basal, narrowly linear, 3-12 cm × 0.5-1.5(-2) mm, shorter than stems, gradually narrowed to a shortly trigonous, ± obtuse apex, channelled, greyish-green, with margins scabrid near apex; sheaths 1-3 mm long, dull orange-brown to mid brown; ligule c. 0.4 mm long, truncate at apex. Lowest involucral bract comprising a sheath with a short (c. 3-5 mm) greenish to brown lamina. <i>Inflorescence </i> a cylindric to ovoid-cylindric, 1-2.5 mm long terminal cluster of 3-10 spikes. <i>Spikes </i> 0.4-0.8 mm long, usually crowded, rarely the lowest somewhat distant, mid brown to mid reddish-brown, with male florets above and female below in each spike. <i>Glumes </i> 4-5 × 1.3-1.6 mm, those of male and female florets similar, elliptic-ovate, with reddish-brown keel and greenish membranous sides with scarious margins; apex obtuse to acuminate-aristate. <i>Flowers </i> unisexual; perianth bristles 0; stamens 3; anthers c. 2 mm long; stigmas 3; prophyll (utricle) open at least towards the top, leaving nut exposed, frequently also open down the side, often more so as nut matures. <i>Nuts</i>  2-3 × c. 1.5 mm, oblong, trigonous, pale dull brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/kobresia-simpliciuscula-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1dab535d-47e4-4b34-81f1-ec275bb73ed1#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251139","general","<p>Loosely tufted to shortly rhizomatous perennial. Culm lateral, few-many-noded, velvety hairy. Leaves with a ciliate ligule, contraligule shortly triangular, hairy, lower leaves reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence capitate with few-several spikelets. Lower primary bracts leaflike, sheathing. Spikelets densely pilose, with many spirally arranged, persistent (?) glumes, several empty basal glumes, 1 female flower, many male flowers, and a few empty upper glumes, top cucullate. Male flower 3-staminate, some of the lower male flowers with 1-2 bristles. Female flower with 2-5 hypogynous bristles, shorter than the fruit, probably deciduous with the fruit. Style deeply 3-fid, style base not distinct, thickened, persistent. Achene elliptic, rounded triangular, 3-ribbed, beaked, smooth.<br /><br/>Only one sp., K. neblinensis W.W. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251185","general","<p>Annuals or tufted to creeping perennials. Culms scapose to few-noded, sometimes 6-angular or winged. Leaves eligulate, lowermost leaves often reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence rarely pseudolateral, ± capitate, with 1-many sessile, globose to cylindrical spikes. Primary bracts mostly leaflike. Spikes with few-many, densely (rarely loosely) spirally arranged glumelike bracts, each subtending a spikelet. Spikelets with 2-few distichous persistent glumes, 1-few subtending a flower. Rachilla internodes elongated. Spikelets deciduous as a unit. Flowers bisexual. Bristles absent. Stamens 1-3. Style 2-fid, style base not distinct, persistent. Achene often obovate, laterally lenticular, often minutely puncticulate.<br /><br/>About 60 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251469","general","<p>Perennial, medium-sized, up to 42 cm tall, with a thickish horizontal or curved rhizome; culms solitary or somewhat crowded, 15–40 cm long, 4–8 mm wide (?), trigonous, glabrous. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251536","general","<p>Rhizomatous or stoloniferous perennials. Culms scapose or several-many-noded. Leaves eligulate, contraligule ± triangular, lower leaves sometimes reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence paniculate with many-numerous spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike, sheathing. Partial inflorescences anthelate or ± contracted. Lower spikelets (or lower partial inflorescences) male, upper female, or flowers dioecious. Male spikelets with many densely spirally arranged, persistent glumes, middle and upper glumes subtending a male flower. Male flowers with 1-6 stamens. Female spikelets with few-several spirally arranged, persistent glumes, penultimate glume subtending a female flower. Female flower surrounded at the base, opposite the sides, by 3 small ciliate scales. Style 3-fid, style base distinct or not, thickened or not, mostly persistent. Achene ovate to obovate, rounded trigonous, often 3-ribbed, ± beaked, smooth or foveolate, rarely scabrid.<br /><br/>About 30 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251553","ecology","<p><br/>	 </p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/lagenocarpus-compactus-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","79ff70a1-1d1b-42c8-8775-8976d83b76c1#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251553","general","<p>A compact, rather robust, monoecious, tufted perennial sedge. Roots not seen. Base of plant 0.3-0.4 cm wide, slightly swollen by the somewhat fibrous, dark brown remains of leaf sheaths. Culms stiffly erect, 20-30 cm x 0.5-0.7 mm, rounded, smooth, green. Leaves basal; leaf-blade linear, stiffly erect, 11-17 cm x 0.5-0.7 mm, very gradually narrowed, acuminate, inrolled, greyish green; leaf sheaths open, margins partially inrolled, 3-5 cm x 1.2-2.5 mm, dark brown. Inflorescence paniculate, comprising 3-4 partial inflorescences, each subtended by a bract; bracts leaf-like, blade linear to setaceous 0.5-4 cm x 0.5-1 mm, green to dark brown, sheath tubular, 0.5-1 cm long, chocolate-brown, the bracts becoming progressively shorter towards apex of inflorescence; partial inflorescences comprising up to 6 peduncles; peduncles mostly erect, each supporting 1-6 sessile or shortly stalked spikes. Male spikes elliptic-cylindric, 5-6 x 1-1.5 mm, chocolate-brown, comprising 4-5 lower glumes and 4-5, reduced staminate partial inflorescences; lower glumes ovatelanceolate, 5.5-6 x 1 mm, aristate, coriaceous, chocolate-brown, the uppermost one subtending a single stamen; staminate partial inflorescences comprising 4-8 floral bracts; floral bracts lanceolate, 4.8-5.2 x 0.2-0.8 mm, acute, the lower ones keeled, membranous, mid-brown, 4-5 of the floral bracts each subtending a single stamen; anthers narrowly oblong, 1.8 mm long, yellowish, connective 0.2 mm long, reddish brown, fimbriate, filaments 5-6 mm long, dark reddish brown. Female spikes 6-8 x 1-2 mm, pale brown to chocolate-brown, cornprizing 2-3 glume-like bracts and a single reduced, pistillate partial inflorescence; glume-like bracts ovate-lanceolate, 5.5-8 x 1-1.7 mm, aristate, coriaceous, chocolate-brown; pistillate partial inflorescence comprising 5-6 floral bracts and a terminal gynoecium; floral bracts ovate-lanceolate, 3.8-6 x 1.3-1.5 mm, aristate, coriaceous, pale brown, the lower ones hardly distinct from the glumelike bracts; stigma branches and style not seen. Achene urn-shaped, 2-2.2 x 1 mm, apiculate; achene surface mid-brown, foveolate, 3-furrowed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/lagenocarpus-compactus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/new-species-and-new-combination-cyperaceae-brazil-notes-brazilian-cyperaceae-vi","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","79ff70a1-1d1b-42c8-8775-8976d83b76c1#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:251553","look_alikes","<p>Lagenocarpus compactus is characterized, as the name implies, by its compact habit, with short, crowded leaves and culms making it one of the smallest species in the genus. It is probably most closely related to L. rigidus. Both have a similar fruit structure, although L. rigidus is a much larger plant and otherwise distinct from L. compactus. Following the key given by Koyama & Maguire (1965), L. compactus should be placed in sect. Lagenocarpus.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/lagenocarpus-compactus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/new-species-and-new-combination-cyperaceae-brazil-notes-brazilian-cyperaceae-vi","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","79ff70a1-1d1b-42c8-8775-8976d83b76c1#look_alikes"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:252130","general","<p>Tufted, rhizomatous, or stoloniferous perennials. Culms scapose, rarely few-noded, terete, compressed 3-4-angular, or ancipitous. Leaves (spiro)distichous, ligulate, blade terete, often all reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence rarely ± pseudolateral, paniculate or spicately condensed with few-many spikelets. Primary bracts rather short, more rarely leaflike, lowermost bract often suberect. Spikelets with few-several spirally arranged, persistent glumes of increasing length, upper 1-2(-4) larger glumes each subtending a flower. Lower flowers, when present, functionally male, upper flower bisexual. Scales 6, thin and bristlelike at anthesis, afterwards basally spongy, thickening. Stamens 3. Style 3(4)-fid, style base distinct (at anthesis), thickened, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:252229","general","<p>Rhizomatous perennial with thick roots. Culms scapose, septate. Leaves reduced to a sheath, open in front, the margins overlapping. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:252550","general","<p>Annuals or tufted or rhizomatous, rarely stoloniferous perennials. Culms scapose. Leaves eligulate. Inflorescence sometimes pseudolateral, capitate with I-many spikeletlike spikes. Lower primary bracts mostly leaflike, lowermost bract sometimes larger and erect. Spikes extremely spikeletlike, composed of many glumelike bracts, spirally arranged along a thickened to shortly conical axis, each subtending a highly reduced spikelet. Spikelets either prophyllate and with 1 small ± hyaline glume, subtending a flower, or further reduced to the small ± hyaline prophyll, or even lacking this prophyll. Prophyll and glume, when present, often deciduous with the fruit. Flowers bisexual. Bristles absent. Stamens 1-3. Style deeply 2-3-fid, style base not distinct, thickened or not, deciduous or persistent. Achene ± obovoid to subcylindrical, often constricted at the base, sometimes beaked, surface finely puncticulate.<br /><br/>About 35 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:252578","general","<p>Culms 5–30 cm × 0.5–1.5 mm. Leaves 3–11 cm × 1–2 mm. Inflorescences: spikes (1–)2–5, ovoid-ellipsoid, 2.5–10(–12) × 2–4.5 mm; bracts 2–3, spreading to slightly reflexed, 4–12(–14) cm × 1–2.5 mm. Spikelets: floral scales 3; 1st scale yellowish brown to light reddish brown, midvein green, obtrullate, 1.5–2 × 0.3–0.5 mm, apex acuminate; 2d scale oblong, 1–1.6 × 0.2–0.4 mm; 3d scale oblong, 1–1.5 × 0.2–0.4 mm; stamens 1; anther 0.5 mm; stigmas 3. Achenes obovoid to narrowly ellipsoid, roundly trigonous, 0.7–1 × 0.2–0.3 mm.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/lipocarpha-maculata-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/lipocarpha-r-brown","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","552322b8-a07e-48fa-8bce-d69b521ea52e#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:252745","general","<p>Creeping rhizomatous or stoloniferous perennials. Culms scapose or few-noded, ancipitous, compressed or (sub)terete, sometimes septate. Leaves distichous, eligulate, blade ensiform to (sub-) terete, sometimes septate, rarely reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence sometimes ± pseudolateral, paniculate with many spikelets, main axis often sinuous, partial inflorescences sometimes capitately contracted. Primary bracts often leaflike, sheathing. Spikelets with 2-10 distichous, long persistent glumes of increasing length, with (1-) 2-4(5) flowers subtended by the larger glumes. Lower 1-2 flowers bisexual, upper flower(s) functionally male. Bristles absent, poorly developed, or up to 6, delicate, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, style base not distinct, thickened, persistent. Achene ovate to oblong, terete to triquetrous, ±3-ribbed to winged, stipitate or sessile, beaked, smooth to rugose.<br /><br/>About 50 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:253045","general","<p>Rhizomatous or stoloniferous perennials, roots thick, sometimes stiltlike on ascending rhizomes. Culms central or lateral, (sub)scapose. Lateral culms few to many, with several basal leaves reduced to a sheath. Leaves eligulate, sometimes pseudopetiolate, rarely all leaves reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence rarely pseudolateral, capitate, corymbiform, subanthelate or paniculate, when on lateral culms often reduced to I-few spikelets. Primary bracts small (on most lateral culms) or large and leaflike (on most central culms). Spikelets with few to numerous spirally arranged persistent glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. Scales 4-6, basal pair lateral, ± ciliate-keeled, each with a single stamen, of the remaining 2-4 scales 0-2 with a stamen, very rarely only 1 stamen per flower. Style 2-3-fid, base not distinct, not or slightly thickened, persistent or not. Achene thick lenticular or rounded trigonous, sometimes 3-ribbed, sometimes with a fleshy exocarp.<br /><br/>About 70 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. Inflorescences several per plant, sessile, composed of a single spike; spike lanceolate, 2–5.5 × 1 cm, usually hidden within leaf sheath, often distinctly 3–sided when young, pale green or brown, often with pinkish tinge; spicoid bracts ovate–lanceolate to lanceolate, 21–46 × 1.2–3.2 mm, acute, coriaceous, the lower ones somewhat keeled, sometimes hispid on keel, pale green or brown with pinkish tinge, somewhat translucent, nerves indistinct; floral bracts 6, free, lowest 2 bracts narowly lanceolate, 18–44 × 0.8–1.2 mm, acute, mid–brown, keel wingless to narrowly winged, sparsely denticulate–hispid, upper bracts linear to narrowly lanceolate, 18–44 × 0.3–1 mm, acute, glabrous, flat; staminate flowers 3 per spicoid, anthers linear, 3 mm long, whitish, filaments up to 22 mm long; stigma branches 3; style up to 22 mm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:254385","general","<p>Tufted perennials. Culms scapose or few-noded. Leaves ligulate, sometimes reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence often pseudolateral, capitate with (1-)few-many spikelets. Primary bracts rather short. Spikelets with several distichous, long persistent, awned glumes of increasing length, penultimate larger 2 glumes each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Lower flower functionally male, upper flower bisexual. Bristles 3, before anthesis slender, afterwards very much broadened at the base, top scabrid, abruptly acuminate, and twisted apically. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:255222","general","<p>Medium-sized to tall tufted perennial. Culms (sub)scapose or 1-noded. Basal leaves reduced to a sheath, uppermost leaf subbasal or cauline, ligulate, blade terete, stiff. Inflorescence ± pseudolateral, contracted paniculate, with many spikelets. Primary bracts rather short and stiff, erect, sheathing. Spikelets with several subdistichous, persistent glumes of increasing length, 2 middle glumes largest, each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:255263","general","<p>Annuals, or tufted to creeping rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose. Leaves often (spiro) distichous, ligulate (most perennials) or eligulate (all annuals), with a bundle of long pale hairs at both sides of the sheath mouth, blade rarely ensiform. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:256185","general","<p>Small, tufted to cushion-forming perennials. Culms few-many-noded, leafy. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:257439","general","<p>Rhizomatous perennials. Culms lateral, in the axil of the lower leaves, or below the leaves, with some basal bladeless sheaths, sometimes with 1-3 cauline sheaths also. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:259164","general","<p>Shortly rhizomatous perennials. Culms manynoded and leafy, rarely scapose, often thickened at the base. Leaves rarely all basal and then pseudopetiolate, lower leaves often reduced to a ± inflated sheath, upper leaves eligulate, blade often oblong. Inflorescence paniculate, with corymbose to anthelate or contracted partial inflorescences, with many-numerous spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike or more rarely short, sheathing. Spikelets small, with several to many spirally arranged or more rarely distichous, long persistent glumes of increasing length, lower glumes empty, middle (3-)5-7 glumes each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume, few upper glumes empty. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:260813","general","<p>Tufted perennial on woody rhizome. Culms scapose. Leaves eligulate (?), sheaths often ± inflated. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261474","general","<p>Perennial on a suberect rhizome. Culms 1-2noded. Leaves eligulate, blade flat or revolute. Inflorescence paniculate with many spikelets. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261491","general","<p>Tufted or creeping rhizomatous perennials, more rarely annuals, or stoloniferous to caudexforming perennials. Culms 1-many-noded. Leaves eligulate, Inflorescence rarely ± pseudolateral, paniculate, corymbose, anthelate, or capitate, with 1-numerous spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike or short, sometimes partly white (part of section Dichromena). Spikelets with few-several spirally arranged to more rarely distichous, often deciduous glumes of increasing length to subequal, larger (1-)2-few glumes each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Flowers all bisexual, or upper flowers functionally male. Bristles 0-6(-10?), deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 1-3(-6-12), sometimes partly adnate. Style deeply 2-fid or (nearly) undivided, style base mostly distinct, (much) thickened, persistent. Achene usually (ob)ovate and dorsiventrally (thick) lenticular, beaked, with various ornamentations, more rarely smooth.<br /><br/>About 250 spp.,</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261498","diagnostic","<p>R. alba is distinguished by having a short rhizome, spikelets in 1-4 heads with the bract subtending the lowermost head not exceeding the terminal head, whitish to pale brown glumes and 9-13 perianth bristles which are shorter than or equal to the nut and bear minute retrorse hairs. The arrangement of fertile and sterile glumes is characteristic of Rhynchospora.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-alba-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","d2ee0811-7c02-441b-8182-5e7b2ce296a4#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261498","distribution","<p>Rhynchospora alba has occurred through much of the British Isles in scattered localities, but it is absent or has disappeared from large parts of central and eastern England, eastern and southern Wales and eastern Scotland. In Ireland it is most common in the north and west.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-alba-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","d2ee0811-7c02-441b-8182-5e7b2ce296a4#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261498","ecology","<p>Rhynchospora alba is characteristic of the shallower parts of bog-pools dominated by Sphagnum auriculatum (Ml), found in the far W of Britain where the annual rainfall exceeds 1200 mm (Climatological Atlas 1952) and similarly in W Ireland (Horsfield et al. 1991), and of similar pools with S. cuspidatum (M2a). In Schoenus nigricans-Narthecium mire (M14), with Erica tetralix-Sphagnum compactum, forming, in wetter areas, a subcommunity with Drosera spp. (M16c), and, in wetter hollows of blanket mires (Ml7, M18), with Carex echinata, C. limosa and C. pauciflora. Also in New Forest valley mires dominated by Narthecium ossifragum and several Sphagnum species, especially S. auriculatum (M21a), and in Hypericum elodes-Potamogeton polygonifolius soakways (M29).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-alba-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","d2ee0811-7c02-441b-8182-5e7b2ce296a4#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261498","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short. <i>Stems </i> 10-60 cm × 0.3-0.5 mm, tufted, erect, terete to trigonous above. <i>Leaves </i> mostly cauline, reduced to bladeless sheaths near base; blade narrowly linear, up to 15 cm × 1-2 mm, channelled, gradually narrowing to an obtuse apex, grey to yellowish-green; sheath up to 3.5 cm long, greenish to pale brown; lower sheaths often subtending bulbil-like buds; ligule absent. <i>Inflorescence </i> comprising 1--4, distant, pedunculate, capitate heads of spikelets; involucral bracts leaf-like, that subtending the lowermost head not exceeding the terminal head. <i>Spikelets </i> 3.5-5 × 0.8-1.3 mm, fusiform to ellipsoid, acute, whitish to pale brown. <i>Glumes </i> 4-5, 2-5 × 0.7-1 mm, ovate-lanceolate, with an acute to aristate apex and membranous sides, whitish to pale brown, the lowest one or two sterile, the uppermost three fertile, sterile and fertile respectively. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 9-13, with minute retrorse hairs, shorter than or equalling the nut; stamens 2-3; anthers 0.8-1.2 mm long; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  1.5-2 (excluding style-base) × 0.9-1 mm, obovate, biconvex, smooth to minutely papillose, pale to mid brownish; style-base persistent, conical, quickly tapering to a 1 mm beak.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-alba-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","d2ee0811-7c02-441b-8182-5e7b2ce296a4#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261526","general","<p>Perennial, cespitose or with short rhizomes; culms 50-150 cm tall; leaves mostly basal or sub-basal, several cauline; largest blades 20-50 cm long, 3.5-8 (-9) mm wide; inflorescence a widely spaces series of open panicles; the terminal panicle usu. corymbose, its lowest primary branches usu. equalling or exceeding the main axis, ‘ ascending, 8-20 x 3-8 cm; lower panicles 2-4, from axes of cauline leaves, ‘ pyramidal, 2-4 cm long, the peduncles slender, lax; mature spikelets ovoid with attenuate tips, 6-11 mm long, castaneous to pale brown; hypogynous bristles usu 4-5, shroter than to barely exceeding achene body, antrorsely scabrous; achene lenticular, elliptic to widely so in outline, (1.5-) 1.8-2.5 x (1.3-) 1.7-2.3 mm, golden brown to castaneous or occasionally brownish-stramineous, smooth to lightly longitudinally pitted; style base narrowly triangular to triangular, (0.9-) 1.1-2.4 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-aristata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","58f552f7-9e35-4ca4-bff3-9f21f3bd015a","","e6808b3e-947e-422f-b0e4-0d1a3734d062#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261534","diagnostic","<p>The combination of a bilaterally flattened, narrow, oblong-obovate to oblanceolate achene; antrorse tubercles on the achene surface; and elongate bristles which are 2 to 4 times longer than the achene, separate this from other unicapitate Rhynchospora in the Guianas.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-armerioides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-distribution-rhynchospora-cyperaceae-guianas-south-america","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c7a4b5f5-2523-422b-83b2-15aa0973a899#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261534","distribution","<p>Central America (Costa Rica and Panama) and South America (Brazil, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname).</p><br/><p>Specimens examined: G UYANA : Sand Creek, Rupununi River, Sep 1948, Forestry Department British Guiana s.n. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261534","general","<p>Caespitose perennial, (5-) 6-45 (-55) cm tall; rhizomes short; roots medium to fine. Culm erect to ascending, 0.5-1.2 (-1.5) mm wide, obtusely trigonous to subterete, flexuous, finely ribbed and channeled, glabrous. Leaves numerous, ascending to reflexed, primarily basal, 1 or 2 short cauline ones often present below middle of culm, 5.5-16 cm long; sheaths eligulate, short, finely veined, glabrous, with a narrow, short, membranous inner band, the orifice concave; blades (0.6-) 1-3.5 (-5) mm wide, finely veined, glabrous, ciliate on margins and midvein beneath, green. Inflorescence a single hemispherical head of congested spikelets at the summit of the culm, 7-12 (-13) × (8-) 9-18 (-19) mm; involucral bracts numerous, spirally imbricated, 5-9.5 mm long (including awn), 2.3-5 mm wide, ovate to ovate-lanceolate, chartaceous, light brown, glabrous, ciliate on the margins, the apex acuminate, awn-tipped; spikelets numerous, linear-lanceolate, acuminate at apex, narrowly cuneate at base, 6-10 × 0.6-1(-1.4) mm, laterally compressed (at least when immature); scales 4-6 per spikelet, dorsally keeled, becoming acutely to subobtusely keeled with developing achenes, membranous, subtranslucent, uniformly light brown, glabrous; fertile scales 1 or 2, the proximal one subtending a bisexual flower, the terminal one sterile or sometimes bearing a staminate one, linear-lanceolate, (4.8-) 5-10 × 0.7-1.1(-1.3) mm; sterile scales 3 or 4, narrowly ovate to ovate- lanceolate, 1.3-6 × 0.4-0.8 mm. Stamens 3, the anthers linear, 1.4-2 mm long, with a triangular- subulate appendage at apex, the green body cuneate to a pale green or colorless, subulate, stipitate base above attachment to filament; style entire or shortly bi-lobed at tip, blackish. Achene bilaterally flattened, 2-2.3 × 0.6-0.9 mm, oblong-obovate to oblanceolate, dark brown, papillate to somewhat smooth except for antrorse tubercles distally on either side, the apex rounded; epidermal cells isodiametric, with conical central nodules; style base triangular to triangular-lanceolate, 0.8-1.1 mm long, 0.4-0.7 mm wide at base, about as wide as achene proximally, not constricted at base; light brown to stramineous, antrorsely scabrous on margins; bristles 6, 5-9 mm long, two to four times as long as achene body, minutely antrorsely barbed, inconspicuously plumose only at very base.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-armerioides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-distribution-rhynchospora-cyperaceae-guianas-south-america","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c7a4b5f5-2523-422b-83b2-15aa0973a899#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261534","habitat","<p>Habitat in the Guianas: Lowland savanna, 100-200 m.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-armerioides-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-distribution-rhynchospora-cyperaceae-guianas-south-america","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c7a4b5f5-2523-422b-83b2-15aa0973a899#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261548","diagnostic","<p>This is a species of Rhynchospora section Pseudoaureae C. B. Clarke. It is closely related to R. paraensis Schrad. ex Kunth but differs from that species in having glabrous culms and leaves, the blades only bluntly scabrous on margins; smaller achenes (1-1.3 × 0.9-1.1 mm); a flattened only slightly thickened style base with smooth margins; and longer perianth bristles that are from 1.5-2 times longer than those of R. paraensis . Rhynchospora paraensis differs in having finely pubescent culms and leaf sheaths, the orifice of the leaf sheath pilose; coarsely ciliate leaf blade margins; larger achenes (1.2-1.6 × 1- 1.3 mm); a swollen spongy-thickened style base that is antrorsely scabrous on margins at base; and shorter perianth bristles.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-bakhuisensis","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-distribution-rhynchospora-cyperaceae-guianas-south-america","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ac134dab-4edc-4205-94ca-b2067668f92a#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261548","distribution","<p>Endemic to Suriname</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-bakhuisensis","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-distribution-rhynchospora-cyperaceae-guianas-south-america","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ac134dab-4edc-4205-94ca-b2067668f92a#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261548","general","<p>Robust perennial, 1-1.5 m tall, with narrow, vertical, woody caudex bearing fibrous remnants of old leaf bases, the culms borne singly from the rhizome; roots coarse; sheathing base of culm 1- 1.5 cm wide. Culm ascending, 3-6 mm wide proximally, triquetrous, firm, finely ribbed and channeled, glabrous, dark green, shallowly canaliculate along one side distally. Leaves ascending, numerous, primarily basal, 2 or 3 cauline below the inflorescence, elongate, up to 1.5 m long; sheaths short, finely veined with cross partitions between veins, glabrous, brown, inner band firm, the orifice deeply U-shaped with a ciliate margin; ligule absent; blades of basal leaves narrowly linear, flattened to subfolded or V-shaped towards base, subplicate distally, 1.2-2.5 cm wide, finely veined with cross partitions between veins, glabrous, smooth, deep green, minutely punctate between veins abaxially, bluntly scabrous on margins and midvein abaxially, long-acuminate to apex; blades of cauline leaves like the basal ones but becoming increasingly shorter and narrower towards apex of culm. Inflorescence ca. 50 cm long, of 5 remote, partial panicles (including the terminal one) from the upper leaf-like bracts, the partial panicles somewhat open, globose to obtusely trigonous, 5-6 cm in diam, with 240-320 spikelets each; bracts gradually reduced distally; peduncles short, that of the lowest panicle to 5 cm × 1-1.2 mm, slender, flattened, finely ribbed, short pubescent; panicle branches trigonous to flattened- trigonous or plano-convex, pubescent, horizontally divergent to reflexed or only the uppermost ascending, each subtended by a tubular prophyll and linear bract at base, the bract ovate-lanceolate, long-awned, ciliate-scabrous on margins and nerves, the prophyll smaller, ovate, truncate at apex, unawned, pubescent; pedicels of spikelets, when present, short, flattened-trigonous to flattened, short-pubescent, the spikelets congested at tips of lateral branches, borne singly or more commonly sessile and in fascicles of 2 or 3 at branch tips; spikelets narrowly ovoid-ellipsoid to oblong-ovoid, 3.6-5 × 1-1.2 mm, the scales spreading at maturity, the spikelets then to 2 mm wide, greatly elongating when insect galls present; scales 11-13, thinly herbaceous, light brown to reddish brown, glabrous, with narrow scarious entire margins, the narrow pale green midvein prolonged at apex as a 0.3-0.5 mm antrorsely scabrous awn; upper fertile scales 3-5, all subtending bisexual flowers, oblong-ovate, 2.4-3 × 1-1.3 mm, lower sterile scales 7-10, ovate to oblong-ovate, decreasing in length to base, 2.3- 0.5 mm long. Stamens 3, the anthers linear, 1.5-2 mm long, apiculate at apex; style 2-branched, the branches minutely scaly. Achene biconvex, obovate, the broadly acute or subrounded apex with a pale, distinct rim extending downwards along angles, 1-1.3 mm long (excluding style base), 0.9- 1.1 mm wide, surface reticulated at early stages of maturity, at later stages of maturity shallowly reticulated to smooth, the lighter colored cell walls strikingly contrasting with the dark brown cell bodies, shiny, brown to reddish brown at maturity; epidermal cells isodiametric, no central nodules evident; style base triangular or triangular-sagittate, ca. 1 mm long, light brown, flattened, slightly thickened, smooth on margins; bristles 6, antrorsely barbed, exceeding achene and style base, frequently 1 or 2 rudimentary or shorter than achene body.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-bakhuisensis","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-distribution-rhynchospora-cyperaceae-guianas-south-america","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ac134dab-4edc-4205-94ca-b2067668f92a#general"
