"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261550","general","<p>Cespitose perennial, 14-60 cm tall; leaves basal, shorter than culm, glabrous adaxially, sparsely villous abaxially, longest blades 8-40 cm long, 0.9-2.4 mm wide; inflorescence a congested globose head of ca 30-100 spikelets subtended by 3-7 ciliate, green bracts; basal bract longest, 8-30 (-40) x 1-2 mm, ; mature spikelets ovoid to narrowly so, 4.1-4.7 x 1.2-1.5 mm, amber; hypogynous bristles 4, as long as to twice as long as achene and style base, antrorsely scabrous, plumose at very base; achene plano-convex to lenticular, ellipsoid, 1.3-1.5 x 0.4-0.8 mm, olive-brown to black, ñ smooth and shiny, margins with incurved, chartaceous wings; style base 0.5-1.1 mm high, chartaceous, confluent with wings of achene margin.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-barbata-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","58f552f7-9e35-4ca4-bff3-9f21f3bd015a","","be3dbfd0-d762-41c8-865d-d5e4d3ec3e90#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261553","general","<p>Stoloniferous perennial; stolons slender, to at least 8 cm long; culms slender, 0.6-13 cm tall, erect to arching; leaves basal or sub-basal, 3-8 per culm, 6-250 x 0.25-2.3 mm; inflorescence a crowded spike of 3-6 spikelets subtended by reduced filiform bracts, the longest of these 0.2-1.5 mm long; spikelets ovoid, 2.5-5 x 0.8-1.8 mm; hypogynous bristles absent; achene lenticular, very broadly obovate, 0.9-1 x 0.8-0.9 mm, transversely rugulose, stramineous to creamy white; style base very broadly triangular, 0.2-0.3 mm high, 0.5-0.7 mm wide at base.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-berteroi-spreng-c-b-clarke-0","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/systematics-rhynchospora-section-dichromena-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","58f552f7-9e35-4ca4-bff3-9f21f3bd015a","","6def39f6-16cc-4073-82f5-0d179b1dceea#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261808","diagnostic","<p>R. fusca is distinguished from R. alba by having distant stems on a long-creeping rhizome, dark reddish-brown spikelets, the bract subtending the lowermost head usually exceeding the terminal head and 5-6 perianth bristles which are much longer than the nut and bear minute antrorse hairs.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-fusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","39973e83-65c3-4bb4-a609-a39c9074ebdd#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261808","distribution","<p>Rhynchospora fusca is very local in Britain, occurring only in Wiltshire, Dorset, Hampshire, Surrey, Cardiganshire and Merioneth and in oceanic areas in NW Scotland, but some populations in Dorset and NW Scotland are very large. In Ireland there has been a widespread decline and it now occurs mainly in the SW, Wand centre.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-fusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","39973e83-65c3-4bb4-a609-a39c9074ebdd#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261808","ecology","<p>Rhynchospora fusca occurs on wet peaty soils with a pH between 3 and 5 (Averis et al. 2004) and especially in shallow pools and soakways in blanket mires with floating Sphagna (with S. auriculatum usually dominant), Eriophorum angustifolium and Menyanthes trifoliata (M1), preferring open areas where competition is minimal. Also, in southern England, in Erica tetralix-Sphagnum compactum mires in a sub-community with R. alba and Drosera spp. (M16c).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-fusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","39973e83-65c3-4bb4-a609-a39c9074ebdd#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:261808","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> long-creeping. <i>Stems </i> 10-40 cm × 0.4-0.7 mm, distant, erect, terete to trigonous. <i>Leaves </i> basal and cauline, up 15 cm × 0.8-1 mm; blade narrowly linear, channelled, gradually narrowing to an obtuse apex, pale greyish-green; sheath up to 4 cm long, greenish to pale brown; lower sheaths with short blade, without bulbil-like buds: ligule absent. <i>Inflorescence </i> comprising 1-2(-3), usually distant, pedunculate, capitate heads of spikelets; involucral bracts leaf-like, that subtending the lowermost head usually exceeding the terminal head. <i>Spikelets </i> 5-6 × 1-1.8 mm, oblong-ovoid, acute, dark reddish-brown. <i>Glumes </i> 4-5, 2-5 × 0.8-2.2 mm, lanceolate to ovate-lanceolate, acute, aristate, with membranous sides, dark reddish-brown, the lowest one or two sterile, the uppermost three fertile, sterile and fertile respectively. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 5-6, with minute antrorse hairs, twice as long as the nut or more; stamens 2-3; anthers 1.6-2.2 mm long; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  1.5-2 (excluding style-base) × 0.8-1 mm, obovate, biconvex, smooth, shiny, pale to mid brownish; style-base c. 0.5 mm long, conical, truncate at apex.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/rhynchospora-fusca-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","39973e83-65c3-4bb4-a609-a39c9074ebdd#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262031","general","<p>Hierba perenne, densamente cespitosa. Tallos (35)40-70(90) cm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262904","diagnostic","<p>The genus Schoenoplectiella differs from Schoenoplectus Palla in its smaller and annual habit and its basal solitary female flowers (Haines 1971; Raynal 1976; Browning 1991). However, a major reason for describing the genus is its rather remote relationship to the type-species of Schoenoplectus, viz. S. lacustris (L) Palla (see Palla 1889), as shown in recent DNA studies (Muasya et al. 1998).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectiella-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectiella-lye-gen-nov-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","632866d2-ca6f-4c87-b064-4acce6bc335f#diagnostic"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262908","general","<p>Anual, cespitosa. Tallos 6-35 cm × (0,4)0,6-1,1 mm, rectos o algo curvados, de sección circular, estriados cuando secos. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262931","general","<p>Annuals or perennials, tufted or creeping. Culms (sub)scapose, rarely septate. Leaves usually reduced to a sheath, more rarely developing a ligulate blade. Female basal flowers present in axil of 1 or more leaves in most species of sect. Supini [bisexual basal flowers only known from S. aberrans (Chermezon) Raynal]. Inflorescence pseudolateral, anthelate or more frequently capitate with (1-)few-many spikelets. Lowermost primary bract often large, erect, stemlike. Spikelets with many spiral, rarely pseudodistichous, deciduous, rarely persistent glumes, often each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual [partly male in S. perrieri (Chermezon) Raynal]. Bristles 0-6, shorter or longer than the fruit, smooth, scabrid or plumose, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 1-3. Style 2-3-fid, style base not distinct, not thickened, persistent. Achene obovate, ± trigonous or dorsiventrally lenticular, beaked or not, smooth to rugose.<br /><br/>About 50 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262959","general","<p>Perenne, que puede formar macollas ± conspicuas; rizoma de entrenudos ± largos, de c. 3 mm de diámetro. Tallos (38)62-150 cm × 1,6-10 mm, de sección circular, estriados cuando secos, verdes, que se curvan hacia el suelo tras la fructificación. Hojas reducidas a vainas, parduscas, las inferiores a veces teñidas de color púrpura obscuro. Inflorescencia en antela, generalmente simple, con 11-90 espiguillas, algunas sésiles –raramente todas– y el resto agrupadas en fascículos pedunculados de 2-10 espiguillas; ejes de la inflorescencia acanalados, lisos o con muy pocos dientes redondeados en los bordes; bráctea inferior (18)30-60(120) × 0,9-1,5 mm, erecta, cilíndrica en toda su longitud, igual o mayor que la inflorescencia; espiguillas 4-8 mm, de contorno ovado a ovado-lanceolado, con (3)12-20(30) flores, frecuentemente pseudovivíparas. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262997","diagnostic","<p>S. lacustris is distinguished from S. tabernaemontani in being usually larger, with deep green stems usually over 150 cm tall, and having glumes without papillae (or only a few on the midrib towards its apex) and 3 stigmas. <br />The species hybridises with S. triqueter (S. × carinatus (Sm.) Palla). Plants intermediate between spp. S. lacustris and S. tabernaemontani (treated by some, e.g. Sell & Murrell 1996, as two subspp.) have been described and drawn from Cambridgeshire (Easy 1990), but no proof of hybridisation has been given.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-lacustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4343e9a2-06a8-4744-9eab-daab6983678a#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262997","distribution","<p>Schoenoplectus lacustris is frequent in lowland Britain and was prolific in the Norfolk Broads in 1900, but decreased considerably during the twentieth century (George 1992); less common in the SW peninsula and parts of Wales and Scotland. In Ireland it is more common in the centre and west. It is sometimes planted.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-lacustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4343e9a2-06a8-4744-9eab-daab6983678a#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262997","ecology","<p>S. lacustris favours shallow lakes or slow-flowing rivers and canals as a single species community or codominant with Phragmites, Sparganium erectum and Equisetum fluviatile (S8 sub-communities); in the E Norfolk Broads often a primary coloniser of open water which remains in successive communities of the sere, e.g. tall-herb fen with Peucedanum palustre (S24). Also in less eutrophic waters with Potamogeton natans, Juncus bulbosus and Myriophyllum alterniflorum (A9c). When preserved in peat deposits, roots of S. lacustris may be distinguished by being a deep crimson.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-lacustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4343e9a2-06a8-4744-9eab-daab6983678a#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:262997","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> creeping, >10 mm thick. <i>Stems </i> up to 350 cm × 5-15 mm, terete, smooth, spongy, green to blue-green, with base thickened by leaf-sheaths. <i>Leaves </i> mostly reduced to bladeless sheaths; blade sometimes formed when plants submerged, 3-100 cm (or possibly more in deep, fast-flowing rivers, e.g. R. Teifi: A.O. Chater pers. comm.) × 1.8-2.5 mm, linear-subulate; sheath up to 40 cm long, purplish-brown to mid brown, membranous and splitting early; ligule present, membranous, brown. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal (often appearing to be lateral when young), compound, usually lax, with 3-10 flattened, scaberulous primary branches up to 10 cm long, sometimes with secondary branches up to 1.5 cm long; branches terminating in 1 to several spikelets; involucral bracts 2, subulate, with a membranous base, the lower up to 1 0 cm long, shorter to longer than inflorescence, erect and stem-like. <i>Spikelets </i> 6-15 × 3-5 mm, ovoid to ovoid-ellipsoid, acute to subacute, mid brown to dark reddish-brown. <i>Glumes </i> 2.5-4 × 1.5-3 mm, spirally arranged, broadly ovate, nerveless, mid brown to reddish-brown, with hyaline ciliate margins; surface with no or few papillae; apex emarginate with a substantial mucro; lateral lobes acutely pointed. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 4-6, ± equalling nut, retrorsely scabrid; stamens (2-)3, with anthers 2-2.5 mm; stigmas (2-)3. <i>Nuts</i>  2.5-3 × 1.8-2.5 mm, broadly obovoid, compressed-trigonous, grey-brown, shiny,± smooth to minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-lacustris-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4343e9a2-06a8-4744-9eab-daab6983678a#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263021","general","<p>Rhizomatous perennial. Stems 30-200 cm, solitary, trigonous, with leafless sheaths below, the upper sheath usually with a lamina. Lower bract equalling or exceeding the inflorescence. Spikelets 5-15 mm, ovoid to oblong mostly in fascicles in compound umbels with unequal rays. Glumes 3-4 mm, broadly obovate, emarginate, mucronate glabrous, brown, with scarious margin. Perianth-bristles 4-6, spathulate- dilated and hairy at apex, longer than nut. Stigmas 2(3). Nut 1-2(-3) mm, obovoid, plano- or biconvex (rarely trigonous), smooth, brown.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-litoralis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","4e371d6f-5b1c-4f8f-95da-3dc5e11d8ba6#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263021","habitat","<p>Damp places.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-litoralis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","4e371d6f-5b1c-4f8f-95da-3dc5e11d8ba6#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263065","diagnostic","<p>S. pungens is distinct in having a pseudolateral, capitate inflorescence with clusters of 1-6 sessile spikelets and glumes that are ± emarginate at the apex with acute lobes on either side of the mucro. In addition, the perianth bristles, when present, are less than half as long as the nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-pungens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fc8837b0-4f04-4e47-937d-dcc077e0a690#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263065","distribution","<p>Schoenoplectus pungens used to occur in Jersey, where it is assumed to have been native but has not been seen since the 1 970s. It was first collected at Ainsdale Sand Dunes (v.c. 59) in 1909 but remained unidentified until refound there in 1929, where it persisted until 1956. Thereafter it was introduced from original stock held in cultivation into local sand-dune slacks; is presently treated as an alien (see also P.H. Smith 2005)</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-pungens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fc8837b0-4f04-4e47-937d-dcc077e0a690#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263065","ecology","<p>Schoenoplectus pungens grows in wet sand-dune slacks and coastal lakes, but in North America it can grow inland and in freshwater mires (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2002).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-pungens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fc8837b0-4f04-4e47-937d-dcc077e0a690#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263065","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> creeping. <i>Stems </i> up to 60 cm × 2-5 mm, triquetrous, smooth, green, with base thickened by leaf-sheaths. <i>Leaves </i> mostly reduced to bladeless sheaths; blade 3-20 cm × 0.8-1.5 mm, sometimes present on upper 2-3 sheaths; ligule present, membranous, brown. <i>Inflorescence </i> pseudolateral, capitate, with 1-6, tightly clustered, sessile spikelets; involucral bracts 2, linear-subulate, the lower up to 13 cm long, much longer than inflorescence, erect. <i>Spikelets </i> 8-11 × 4-6 mm, ovoid, subacute, mid brown to dark reddish-brown. <i>Glumes </i> 3.5-4 × 2.5-3 mm, spirally arranged, broadly ovate, reddish-brown, ± emarginate, mucronate, with acute lobes on either side of mucro; sides membranous and margins hyaline, sometimes fringed. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 0-6, less than half as long as nut; stamens 2, with anthers 2.5-3 mm long; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  2-2.5 × 1-1.5 mm, obovoid, compressed, greyish-brown, shiny, smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-pungens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","fc8837b0-4f04-4e47-937d-dcc077e0a690#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263102","diagnostic","<p>S. tabernaemontani is closely related to S. lacustris and some authors (e.g. Sell & Murrell 1996) treat the two as conspecific, this plant being subsp. tabernaemontani (C.C. Gmel.) Á. & D. Löve of S. lacustris.  This taxon differs in having minute reddish papillae on the glumes, especially near the apex, and their lateral lobes obtusely rounded and less hyaline on the margins; in addition it usually has 2 stigmas and nuts that are 2-2.5 mm long. <br />A hybrid with S. triqueter (S. × kuekenthalianus (lunge) D.H. Kent) has been recorded in England but not yet in Ireland. See S. lacustris for a putative but unproven hybrid with that species.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-tabernaemontani-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a7631474-d77c-483f-aae2-5458bcdfaefe#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263102","distribution","<p>Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani is usually found near the coast in both Britain and Ireland but is infrequent in N Scotland. It also occurs inland, especially in C and S England, possibly in areas with a higher content of magnesium, potassium and sodium. It is sometimes planted.  @tab@</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-tabernaemontani-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a7631474-d77c-483f-aae2-5458bcdfaefe#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263102","ecology","<p>This plant is usually found near the coast in shallow brackish water and marshes with Agrostis stolonifera, Bolboschoenus maritimus, Juncus bufonius, Ranunculus sceleratus etc. (S20), but it is scarce in pure Bolboschoenus swamp (S21). It does occur inland, especially in C and S England, in eutrophic ponds (with Typha spp.: S12, S13), slow rivers, dykes, canals, marshes and flooded sand-and gravel-pits.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-tabernaemontani-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a7631474-d77c-483f-aae2-5458bcdfaefe#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263102","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> creeping, > 10 mm thick. <i>Stems </i> up to 150 cm × 3-9 mm, terete, smooth, spongy, glaucous, with base thickened by leaf-sheaths. <i>Leaves </i> mostly reduced to bladeless sheaths; blade not formed underwater (Preston & Croft 1997) but occasionally present when plant terrestrial, 3-20 cm × 0.8-1.5 mm, linear-subulate; sheath up to 18 cm long, purplish-brown to mid-brown, membranous and splitting early; ligule present, membranous, brown. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal (often appearing lateral when young), usually lax, with 3-10 flattened, scaberulous primary branches up to 5 cm long, sometimes with secondary branches up to 1.3 cm long; branches terminating in 1 to several spikelets; involucral bracts 2, subulate, with a membranous base, the lower < 6 cm long, shorter to longer than inflorescence, erect. <i>Spikelets </i> 5-12 × 2-4 mm, ovoid to ovoid-ellipsoid, acute to subacute, mid-brown to dark reddish-brown. <i>Glumes </i> 2.5-3.7 × 1.5-3 mm, spirally arranged, broadly ovate, mid brown to red-brown, with numerous minute red papillae especially towards apex; apex emarginate and shortly apiculate; lateral lobes ± rounded with membranous, ciliate-denticulate margins. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 4-5, ± equalling nut, retrorsely scabrid; stamens (2-)3, with anthers 2-2.5 mm long; stigmas 2(-3). <i>Nuts</i>  2-2.5 × 1.2- 1.7 mm, broadly obovoid, compressed, rarely compressed-trigonous, greyish-brown, somewhat shiny,± smooth to minutely papillose.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-tabernaemontani-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","a7631474-d77c-483f-aae2-5458bcdfaefe#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263109","conservation","<p>Schoenoplectus triqueter is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Critically Endangered (Cheffings & Farrell 2005). It is also protected under Schedule 8 of the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981. It is protected under the Flora (Protection) Order 1999 in the Republic of Ireland.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-triqueter-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","327e5272-9501-41e5-8d08-cc9bb47a5783#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263109","diagnostic","<p>S. triqueter is recognised by its triquetrous stem, the presence of a leaf-blade on the uppermost leaf-sheath only, glumes with an emarginate, mucronate apex with obtuse lobes on either side of the mucro, and six perianth bristles that are more than half as long as the nut. <br />The species hybridises with S. lacustris (S. × carinatus (Sm.) Palla) and S. tabernaemontani (S. × kuekenthalianus (Junge) D.H. Kent.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-triqueter-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","327e5272-9501-41e5-8d08-cc9bb47a5783#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263109","distribution","<p>Schoenoplectus triqueter has been recorded on the River Tamar (v.cc. 2 and 3) and from the Thames/Medway (v.cc. 16, 17 and 21), but mainly as a consequence of river engineering it is now extinct in the latter (Preston & Croft 1997; Rich & FitzGerald 2002). In Ireland it still occurs in Co. Limerick (v.c. H8).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-triqueter-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","327e5272-9501-41e5-8d08-cc9bb47a5783#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263109","ecology","<p>S. triqueter is a plant of brackish, nutrient-rich mud in estuaries and tidal rivers, often in places where it may become completely submerged owing to tides, although not by highly saline water (Rich & Fitzgerald 2002). Often associated with freshwater seepage lines (N.F. Stewart in Wigginton 1999) and can be found associated with Bolboschoenus maritimus, Phragmites australis, Schoenoplectus lacustris and S. tabernaemontani.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-triqueter-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","327e5272-9501-41e5-8d08-cc9bb47a5783#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263109","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> creeping. <i>Stems </i> up to 150 cm × 2-8 mm, triquetrous, smooth, solid, green or rarely glaucous, with base ± thickened by leaf-sheaths. <i>Leaves </i> mostly reduced to bladeless sheaths, with a blade present on uppermost sheath only, 1-20 cm × 2-8 mm, linear-subulate; sheath up to 18 cm long, pale to mid brown, membranous and splitting early; ligule present, membranous. <i>Inflorescence </i> with few to numerous spikelets, capitate or with 2-5 primary branches up to 2 cm long; secondary branches 0; involucral bracts 2, linear-subulate, the lower up to 11 cm long, always longer than inflorescence, erect. <i>Spikelets </i> 5-10 × 2-4 mm, ovoid, subacute, dark reddish-brown. <i>Glumes </i> 3.5-4 × 1.5-3 mm, spirally arranged, broadly obovate, membranous, reddish-brown, with narrow hyaline and ciliate margins; apex obtuse, mucronate with truncate or obtuse lobes on either side of mucro. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 6, ± equalling nut, retrorsely scabrid; stamens 3, with their anthers 1.4-1.5 mm long; stigmas 2. <i>Nuts</i>  2.5-3 × 1.5- 2.5 mm, ellipsoid to obovoid, compressed, reddish-brown, shiny, smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenoplectus-triqueter-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","327e5272-9501-41e5-8d08-cc9bb47a5783#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263125","general","<p>Tufted or (shortly) rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose. Leaves ligulate. Inflorescence open to condensed paniculate or spicate, with few-many spikelets, cladoprophylls sometimes ± utriculiform, swollen at the base, and subtending a female flower. Primary bracts leaflike or short, sheathing or not. Ultimate partial inflorescences spikelike, bisexual or unisexual, with few-many spirally arranged deciduous or persistent bracts (or glumes), either subtending (proximally) a bisexual spikelet or a female spikelet, or (distally) a male flower. Bisexual spikelet with a basal ± utriculiform prophyll, subtending a female flower, and a rachilla bearing at the top few-several glumes, each subtending a male flower. Female spikelet reduced to a ± open utriculiform flowerbearing prophyll, enclosing the well-developed, often laminar rachilla, ovary and style, only style branches and often the rachilla protruding. Male flower 3-staminate, without bristles. Female flower with a 3-fid style, style base not distinct, not or slightly thickened, persistent. Achene oblong or (ob)ovate, trigonous, often beaked, smooth.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. All rights reserved, whether whole or part of the material is concerned, specifically the rights of translation, reprinting, reuse of illustrations, broadcasting reproduction on microfilm or in any other way, and storage in data banks. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263164","distribution","<p>Concentrated in Australia and Malesia, S. nigricans L. subcosmopolitan.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263164","general","<p>Tufted or rhizomatous per-ennials, rarely annuals or short-living perennials. Culms mostly scapose, rarely 3-4-angular, sometimes bulbously thickened at the base, or creeping-decumbent and branched from the nodes (semiaquatic spp. of sect. Helothrix). Leaves ligulate, often reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence sometimes ± pseudolateral, paniculate to capitate, with 1-many spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike or short, sheathing or not, lowermost bract sometimes erect. Spikelets with few-many distichous, deciduous glumes of increasing length, but upper glumes smaller, the larger (1-)2-3(-9) glumes each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Rachilla internodes between and above the flowers often elongated and curved (short in, e.g., subgen. Pseudomesomelaena). Lower 1-2 flowers usually bisexual, upper 1-2 flowers (functionally) male (rarely inversed). Bristles 0-6, rarely laminar, shorter or longer than the fruit, usually deciduous with the fruit (persistent on the rachilla in sect. Helothrix). Stamens (1-)3-6. Style 3-fid [2-(3-) fid in S. tendo (Hook. f.) Hook. f.), style base not distinct, not or slightly thickened, deciduous, rarely persistent. Achene often obovate and rounded trigonous, rarely beaked, with various ornamentations.<br /><br/>About 100 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. All rights reserved, whether whole or part of the material is concerned, specifically the rights of translation, reprinting, reuse of illustrations, broadcasting reproduction on microfilm or in any other way, and storage in data banks. Duplication of this publication or parts thereof is permitted only under the provisions of the German Copyright Law of September 9, 1965, in its current version, and permission for use must always be obtained from Springer-Verlag. Violations are liable for prosecution under German Copyright Law.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","02faad25-4981-48e2-851a-f4aade95399a#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263309","diagnostic","<p>Schoenus ferrugineus often stands out with its densely packed stems and black heads. It differs from S. nigricans in having much shorter leaves, a lowermost involucral bract that is shorter than or equals the inflorescence and an inflorescence that comprises up to four spike1ets. Depauperate material of S. nigricans has a superficial resemblance to S. ferrugineus but always has longer leaves and a lowermost involucral bract exceeding the inflorescence. <br />Hybrids between the two species have been recorded in Europe (Stace 1975; Hedren 1997) but not so far in Britain.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-ferrugineus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1012f9ba-1678-4f80-898b-977fa99fbba5#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263309","distribution","<p>Schoenus ferrugineus was feared to have become extinct when in 1950 its original site on the edge of Loch Tummel (v.c. 88) was flooded; it was transplanted to nearby localities and still exists in one such site (Ben Vrackie). Since 1970, however, some 10 further sites on the Loch Tay limestones in Perthshire have been recorded.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-ferrugineus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1012f9ba-1678-4f80-898b-977fa99fbba5#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263309","ecology","<p>Schoenus ferrugineus occurs in base-rich flushes (small sedge mires), often forming large, dense tufts in semi-open, often stony areas with water running between them in a mosaic of Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris (M10) and Carex viridula subsp. oedocarpa-Saxifraga aizoides (M11) communities. Often on the edges of small hummocks with the above species and Carex panicea, C. pulicaris, C. viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha, Eleocharis quinqueflora, Festuca ovina, Juncus alpinoarticulatus, Kobresia simpliciuscula, Trichophorum cespitosum and calcicolous mosses, e.g. Ctenidium molluscum and Scorpidium spp. See also Wheeler et al. (1983).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-ferrugineus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1012f9ba-1678-4f80-898b-977fa99fbba5#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263309","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short, tufted; roots fleshy, dark brown. <i>Stems </i> 10-40 cm × 0.5-0.7 mm, erect, terete to somewhat flattened above. <i>Leaves </i> 1-8 cm × 0.5-0.7 mm, basal, up to 113 as long as stems; blade narrowly linear, wiry, obtuse to acute at apex, channelled, pale green; sheath up to 3 cm long, open, stiff, shiny dark reddish-brown to dark chocolate brown; ligule present, < 1 mm. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, dark brown to blackish, capitate head, comprising 1-4 spikelets; involucral bracts 1-2; lower bract always present, shorter than to equalling inflorescence, with an open, dark reddish-brown to chocolate brown sheathing base and short blade; upper bract glume-like. <i>Spikelets </i> 7-10 × 1.5-2.5 mm, flattened, lanceoloid, blackish or very dark brown; rachilla thick, zigzagged. <i>Glumes </i> 6-7, 5-7 × 1-2 mm, distichously arranged, the lowest two sterile, the remainder fertile, lanceolate, acute, with sides membranous, dark reddish-brown to dark chocolate brown, with a smooth keel. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles (3-)6, exceeding nut; stamens 3, anthers 2.5-3 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1 × 0.7 mm, ovoid, trigonous, smooth, shiny, whitish.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-ferrugineus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","1012f9ba-1678-4f80-898b-977fa99fbba5#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263443","diagnostic","<p>Schoenus nigricans is characterised as a densely tufted plant with stiff, erect (rarely recurved or prostrate) stems, stiff wiry leaves with shiny dark brown sheaths and a dark brown to blackish capitate inflorescence.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-nigricans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c0cfa9e7-16d4-44cb-8dbf-ebc61eefc815#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263443","distribution","<p>Schoenus nigricans is found mostly in western parts of the British Isles and on the deeper peat of East Anglia, the New Forest and the SW peninsula, where it can be locally frequent. Absent from large parts of England, Wales and eastern Scotland. In Ireland very common and often dominant in western and central bogs; absent in SE and rare in NE.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-nigricans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c0cfa9e7-16d4-44cb-8dbf-ebc61eefc815#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263443","ecology","<p>The plant occurs in damp or wet, peaty but base-rich areas, e.g. Carex dioica-Pinguicula vulgaris (M10), S. nigricans-Juncus subnodulosus (M13) and S. nigricans-Narthecium (M14) mires and less calcareous bogs and heaths in SW Britain, where it can be codominant with Erica vagans (H5) and occasional with that species and Molinia in H6d. Also on more acid heaths near the coast and affected by salt-laden winds, e.g. Trichophorum germanicum-Erica tetralix, Carex panicea sub-community (M15a). Found in coastal maritime grassland of Festuca rubra-Piantago spp. in a subcommunity (MC10c) with Carex panicea, C. viridula subsp. viridula and Molinia caerulea; also codominant with the last species on oceanic cliffs of western shores. See also the Biological Flora account (Sparling 1968).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-nigricans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c0cfa9e7-16d4-44cb-8dbf-ebc61eefc815#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263443","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short, densely tufted; roots fleshy, dark purplish, often growing between leaf-sheaths. <i>Stems </i> 15-80 cm × 0.9-1.4 mm, erect, rarely recurved or prostrate, terete to somewhat flattened above. <i>Leaves </i> up to 40 cm × 0.5-2 mm, basal, at least 1/2 as long as stems; blade narrowly linear, wiry, gradually tapering to an obtuse, trigonous apex, subterete to channelled, bright green to greyish-green; sheath up to 8 cm long, open, stiff, shiny dark reddish-brown to dark chocolate brown; ligule present, short, hard, often minutely ciliate. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single, dark brown to blackish, capitate head, comprising crowded fascicles each of up to 10 spikelets, each fascicle subtended by a glume-like bract; involucral bracts 2-3, leaf-like, with an open, dark brown to blackish sheathing base, the lowermost 2-5 times longer than inflorescence. <i>Spikelets </i> 10-12 × 2-4 mm, flattened, lanceoloid, acute, dark brown to blackish; rachilla thick, zigzagged, winged. <i>Glumes </i> 7-8, 5-7 × 2-2.5 mm, distichously arranged, the lowest two sterile, the remainder fertile, lanceolate, acute, shortly apiculate, strongly keeled, with sides membranous-leathery, dark reddish-brown to dark chocolate brown; keel minutely ciliate on upper glumes. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 3-4, much shorter than nut, often dropped as nut ripens; stamens 3; anthers 3.5-4 mm long, with connective tip 0.5-0.8 mm, yellow; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1-1.9 × 0.8-1.2 mm, ovoid to ovoid-ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous, smooth, shiny, creamy-white to grey.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/schoenus-nigricans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","c0cfa9e7-16d4-44cb-8dbf-ebc61eefc815#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263631","general","<p>Robust, tufted perennials. Culms (sub)scapose, rather short, hidden between the basal leaves. Leaves eligulate. Inflorescence densely paniculate with numerous spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike, not sheathing. Spikelets with several spirally arranged persistent glumes, each subtending a flower. Rachilla apparently terminated by a flower. Flowers bisexual. Terminal flower with a terminal pistil, surrounded by spirally arranged scales, often each with a single stamen. Lateral flowers dorsiventrally compressed, with a basal lateral pair of keeled and ± connate scales. Style 2-3-fid, style base not distinct, thickened, persistent. Fruit ovoid, with a large beak, ± drupaceous, ridged when dry.<br /><br/>Two spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263637","general","<p>Tufted or shortly rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose, thickened at the base. Leaves ligulate or not, often reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence pseudolateral, anthelate, or capitate, with manynumerous spikelets. Primary bracts culmlike, lowermost bract erect. Branches of partial inflorescences conspicuously crescentiform in crosssection. Spikelets with many spirally arranged, long persistent (finally deciduous ?) glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. Bristles absent. Stamens 2-3. Style deeply 3-fid, style base not distinct, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263641","conservation","<p>Scirpoides holoschoenus is a Red Data List species in Great Britain; Status: Endangered (Cheffings & Farrell 2005).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpoides-holoschoenus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f803d72c-0b5d-48fb-bdf6-f11960cc7cd1#conservation"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263641","diagnostic","<p>Scirpoides holoschoenus is distinct from all other British and Irish sedges in having an inflorescence of 2-8 branches terminating in densely globose spikes, each comprising numerous spikelets.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpoides-holoschoenus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f803d72c-0b5d-48fb-bdf6-f11960cc7cd1#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263641","distribution","<p>Scirpoides holoschoenus is considered to be native only at Braunton Burrows (v.c. 4), at Watchet (v.c 5) and at Berrow Dunes (v.c. 6). Other scattered populations in South Wales (mainly in dock areas), the Usk estuary, in Kent and at Poole Harbour, Dorset, are treated as introductions. The records for Northern Ireland (Preston et al. 2002) are erroneous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpoides-holoschoenus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f803d72c-0b5d-48fb-bdf6-f11960cc7cd1#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263641","ecology","<p>This plant occurs in damp, sandy areas by the sea. The only extant native populations occur in dune-slacks at Braunton Burrows (v.c. 4) with Salix repens, Agrostis stolonifera, Carex flacca, Juncus acutus, Mentha aquatica and Pulicaria dysenterica (SD14, SD15), where it is extensive but the community is under threat from scrub encroachment, and at Berrow Dunes (v.c. 6) on the edge of a golf course (J.H.S. Cox in Wigginton 1999). It is a common species of Mediterranean coasts, but its requirement for high summer temperatures for regeneration by seed (Willis 1985) may be restricting its spread in the British Isles.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpoides-holoschoenus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f803d72c-0b5d-48fb-bdf6-f11960cc7cd1#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263641","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> far-creeping, woody, with sand-binding roots. <i>Stems </i> 30-90 cm × 2-4 mm, densely clustered, erect, glaucous, terete, with two opposite longitudinal grooves. <i>Leaves </i> mostly basal, rarely one cauline, mostly reduced to sheaths; blade (when present) up to 20 cm × 1.5-2 mm, acuminate, hard, channelled, becoming flattened near apex, with margins scabrid; sheath up to 14 cm long, herbaceous to coriaceous, brown to reddish-brown, becoming fibrous at margins. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal but appearing lateral, compound with 2-8 primary branches, up to 8 cm long, flattened; secondary branches (when present) 1-2; branches terminated by 1(-3) spikes; involucral bracts 2, leaf-like, the longest one 10-40 cm long, erect and appearing ± continuous with stem. <i>Spikes </i> globose, 2-12 mm in diameter, composed of numerous densely packed spikelets; spikelets 2-3.5 × 1-2 mm, broadly ovoid and obtuse. <i>Glumes </i> 1.2-2 × 0.8-1.2 mm, obovate, brown to reddish-tinged, membranous towards margins; apex broadly obtuse, whitish, scabrid, shortly mucronate; midrib acutely keeled, greenish. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles absent; stamens 3; anthers 0.8-1.5 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1-1.75 × 0.5-0.75 mm, broadly ellipsoid, compressed-trigonous, minutely reticulate, greyish.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpoides-holoschoenus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","f803d72c-0b5d-48fb-bdf6-f11960cc7cd1#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263650","general","<p>Tufted or rhizomatous perennials. Culms fewmany- noded. Leaves ligulate. Inflorescence anthelate with many to numerous spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike, spreading. Partial inflorescences anthelate to capitate. Spikelets with many spirally arranged, deciduous glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. Bristles (0-)36, as long as to much longer than the fruit (and then often extremely contorted), ± scabrid, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 1-3. Style (2-) 3-fid, style base not distinct, not thickened, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:263762","general","<p>Plants cespitose; rhizomes short, tough, fibrous. Culms: fertile ones upright or nearly so; nodes without axillary bulblets. Leaves 6–11 per culm; sheaths of proximal leaves light brown; proximal sheaths and blades with septa many, ± conspicuous; blades 20–54 cm × 7–17 mm. Inflorescences terminal, rarely also with 1 lateral inflorescence from distal leaf axil; rays ascending or divergent (commonly both in the same inflorescence), proximal branches smooth, distal branches scabrellous to scabrous, rays often bearing axillary bulblets; bases of involucral bracts green, margins usually speckled with red-brown, rarely solid black, not glutinous. Spikelets in dense clusters of 4–110 (largest cluster with 17–25+), spikelets sessile, ovoid to narrowly ovoid, 2–5(–8) × 1–2.5 mm; scales dark brown with pale midribs, elliptic or broadly elliptic (rarely almost circular), 1.2–2.1 mm, apex mucronate, mucro 0.1–0.3(–0.4) mm. Flowers: perianth bristles persistent, (5–)6, rather stout to somewhat slender, straight or curved, shorter than to slightly exceeding achene, with retrorse, thin-walled, round-tipped barbs in distal 0.3–0.6, enclosed within scales; styles 3-fid. Achenes light brown, elliptic or obovate in outline, plumply trigonous or plano-convex, (0.8–)1–1.3 × 0.4–0.6 mm. 2n = 50–60.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-atrovirens-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","92228909-1b23-40c7-8842-23ff4b9e85d8#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264156","distribution","<p>Ont., P.E.I.; Ala., Ark., Conn., Ga., Ill., Ind., Iowa, Kans., Ky., La., Maine, Md., Mass., Minn., Miss., Mo., Nebr., N.H., N.J., N.Y., N.C., Ohio, Okla., Pa., S.C., Tenn., Tex., Vt., Va., W.Va., Wis.; introduced, New Zealand.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-georgianus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","b7806e31-5bc5-47f7-ae2a-8d4040902463#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264156","general","<p>Plants cespitose; rhizomes short, tough, fibrous. Culms: fertile ones upright or reclining; nodes without axillary bulblets. Leaves 6–12 per culm; sheaths of proximal leaves green or brownish; proximal sheaths and blades with septa few to many, usually not conspicuous; blades 19–50 cm × 6–13 mm. Inflorescences terminal; rays ascending or divaricate (often both in the same inflorescence), proximal branches smooth, distal branches scabrous or scabrellous, rays often bearing axillary bulblets; bases of involucral bracts green, margins brown or at least speckled with red-brown, not glutinous. Spikelets in clusters of 4–35 (largest cluster with 16 or more), spikelets sessile, ovoid, 2–4 × 1–2 mm; scales brown or blackish brown with pale midribs, elliptic, 1–1.8 mm, apex mucronate, mucro 0.1–0.3 mm. Flowers: perianth bristles persistent when present, 0–3, slender, straight or curved, much shorter than (rarely to 0.7 times as long as) achene, smooth or rarely with round-tipped, retrorse teeth near apex, enclosed within scales; styles 3-fid. Achenes pale brown to almost white, elliptic or obovate in outline, plumply trigonous or plano-convex, 0.6–1.2 × 0.4–0.5 mm. 2n = 50, 52, 54.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-georgianus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-linnaeus","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","b7806e31-5bc5-47f7-ae2a-8d4040902463#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264774","general","<p>Like Scirpus sylvaticus but stems caespitose; long, procumbent non-flowering shoots present which root and form new plants at their apices; spikelets 3-8 mm, lanceolate, ovoid-lanceolate or elliptical, acute, usually solitary at apices of ultimate rays; glumes not mucronulate; perianth-bristles 2-3 times as long as nut, smooth or with only a few retrorse hairs towards apex, flexuous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-radicans-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","acaed9e4-97bf-41c4-a254-b61a8d3d74cf#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264975","diagnostic","<p>Vegetatively, S. sylvaticus can be confused superficially with 55 Carex hirta, which is of a similar colour and can grow in similar riparian habitats. However, the latter has a ligule and hairs at least on the inner face of the sheath. When flowering stems are present S. sylvaticus is very distinctive.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-sylvaticus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0dfb06c7-56ff-48e8-a1f3-07bb5bb02f13#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264975","distribution","<p>Scirpus sylvaticus is widespread throughout England and Wales with a gap in East Anglia and the East Midlands; in Scotland it is rare N of the southern foothills of the Grampians and Loch Fyne in the west. In Ireland it is frequent in the north but absent in the peaty centre and rare in the southern counties.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-sylvaticus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0dfb06c7-56ff-48e8-a1f3-07bb5bb02f13#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264975","ecology","<p>S. sylvaticus can be found on wet silty soils in the Phragmites australis sub-community of valley alder woodland (W5a), where other trees include Fraxinus excelsior, Betula pubescens and Salix cinerea; the ground flora typically includes Carex paniculata and C. acutiformis, but S. sylvaticus may totally replace them with unusual abundance (Rodwell 1991a). Also often in more open areas, along stream and river margins and around lakes and pools which are periodically flooded. Often on gravel, sandy or clay substrates where there is an indication of free iron and high nitrogen, e.g. with Phalaris arundinacea in the Bidens tripartita-Persicaria amphibia community (OV30).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-sylvaticus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0dfb06c7-56ff-48e8-a1f3-07bb5bb02f13#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:264975","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> creeping. <i>Stems </i> 30-120 cm × 4-8 mm, erect, trigonous to triquetrous above, terete below. <i>Leaves </i> basal and up to 7 cauline, up to 40 cm × 5-20 mm, acuminate, ± flat; ligule absent; basal sheaths pale to chestnut brown; cauline sheaths greenish-brown; vegetative shoots forming a pseudostem. <i>Inflorescence </i> terminal, branched, somewhat umbel-like, 10-25 × 10-25 cm; primary branches 3 to 8, up to 10 cm long, unequal; secondary and tertiary branches up to 5 cm Long. <i>Spikelets </i> in finger-like to ± globose clusters of 3-10, 2.5-6 × 2-3 mm, ovoid to oblong-ovoid, obtuse, rarely subacute, dark brown; involucral bracts 2-4, up to 50 cm long. <i>Glumes </i> 1.2- 2.5 × 1-1.5 mm, ovate to ± orbicular, obtuse, ± mucronulate, membranous. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual; perianth bristles 6, shorter than glume, scaberulous above; stamens 2-3; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  0.7-1 4 × 0.5-0.8 mm, obovoid to subglobose, compressed-trigonous, pale brown, smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-sylvaticus-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","0dfb06c7-56ff-48e8-a1f3-07bb5bb02f13#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:265158","ecology","<p>Most spp. in seasonally to permanently damp to waterlogged places, often on sandy soils, many annuals on seasonally damp shallow soils overlying rocks, more rarely growing in open to dense woodland.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:265158","general","<p>Small annuals or medium-sized to tall tufted, rhizomatous, or even scrambling perennials. Culms mostly many-noded. Leaves sometimes pseudoverticillate, sheaths sometimes conspicuously winged, (hairy) ligule rarely present, contraligule often present, sometimes as a large outgrowth, blade rarely lanceolate or pseudopetiolate, sometimes pseudopremorse. Inflorescence polymorphic, basically paniculate, but often with contracted partial inflorescences. Spikelets with few-many distichous glumes, lower glumes empty, larger glume subtending a female flower, or a female (lower) and I-few upper glumes each a male flower, or male flowers only, glume length increasing towards the female flower. Male and female spikelets intermingled, or female spikelets only basal, rarely plants dioecious. Male flower with 3 stamens. Female flower with 3-fid style, style base mostly not distinct, thickened or not, persistent or deciduous, ovary surrounded at the base by a variously shaped (often 3-lobed, margin entire, ciliate or serrate) and sometimes reduced hypogynium, lobes - when present - opposite the ribs of the fruit, deciduous with the fruit. Achene globose to ovoid, rounded to trigonous, smooth or variously sculptured, glabrous or hairy, wall often bony hard, white or discolored, sometimes beaked.<br /><br/>About 250 spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. All rights reserved, whether whole or part of the material is concerned, specifically the rights of translation, reprinting, reuse of illustrations, broadcasting reproduction on microfilm or in any other way, and storage in data banks. Duplication of this publication or parts thereof is permitted only under the provisions of the German Copyright Law of September 9, 1965, in its current version, and permission for use must always be obtained from Springer-Verlag. Violations are liable for prosecution under German Copyright Law.</p>","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scleria-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","2b3bd6d5-b1c3-450c-a7ca-70f6b65f0efe#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:265173","general","<p>Perennial, probably dioecious, herb with thick, moniliform rhizome bearing conspicuously veined scales; roots coarse. Culm erect, trigonous, 30-120 cm long, 1.0-3.7 mm wide below inflorescence, 4.0-7.5 mm wide at widest point. Leaves many; blades green, (2-)13-42 cm long, (3-)5-12 mm wide, glabrous to slightly pubescent especially to- ward the apex or slightly pubescent along midrib adaxially, margins smooth to scabrous especially to- ward the apex, midrib smooth to slightly scabrous toward the apex, the apex abruptly narrowed to tip, probably cucullate (splitting in dried herbarium specimens), lowermost blades strongly reduced; sheaths not winged, glabrous to sparsely pubescent, the angles not scabrous; ligule conspicuously V-shaped, pointing upward, whitish to brownish, of mostly dense hairs, 0.7-1.5 mm long; contraligule triangular, unappendaged, 3.5-9.0 mm long, 3.5- 7.0 mm wide at base, margin sometimes pubescent. Inflorescence strictly unisexual, paniculate with rather dense partial inflorescences, brownish, 15- 46 cm long, 3-5 cm wide; primary bracts foliaceous, 1.4-25 cm long, 2-6 mm wide, glabrous to slightly pubescent on both sides, sometimes pubes- cent along midrib adaxially, margin and veins smooth to slightly scabrous especially toward the apex. Staminate spikelets 3.5-5.5 mm long; staminate scales with a yellowish brown to light brown midrib and brown to purple to blackish purple sides, glabrous to slightly pubescent, apex and apex margin sometimes prickly. Stamens 3, anthers ca. 1.5 mm long (excl. apical appendage), appendage 0.6-0.7 mm long, reddish to almost black, linear to narrowly triangular. Pistillate spikelets 5.0-7.1 mm long; pistillate scales with a tawny green to brown midrib and brown purplish sides, glabrous to pubescent especially toward the apex. Style 3-fid, brown, conspicuously papillose, the style base deciduous leaving a small residue. Achene stipitate, 3.1-3.6 mm long (incl. hypogynium), 2.5-3.3 mm wide, conspicuously coarsely reticulated with prickles on walls of reticulations, white to golden blond to brownish, ovoid to very broadly ovoid to broadly ellipsoid, obtusely trigonous to al- most rounded with convex sides. Hypogynium 0.6- 1.5 mm long, 2.0-2.3 mm wide, yellowish to chest- nut brown, surface smooth, margin glabrous, entire to inconspicuously 3-lobed, reflexed, undulate.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scleria-amazonica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scleria-amazonica-new-species-scleria-section-scleria-cyperaceae-venezuela","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","3b88235d-4226-4a06-840c-3ca4c87aa336#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:265215","general","<p>Annual. Culms loosely tufted, 25-60 cm by 1-2 mm, triquetrous, smooth. Leaves cauline; blade linear, 4-23 cm by 3-5( -8) mm, ± obtuse, flattish; sheath 3-5 cm long, narrowly winged; contraligule depressed-rounded, margin ciliolate. Lowest involucral bract leaf-like, up to 15 cm long. Inflorescence paniculate, up to 20 ctn long; nodes 2-4, distant, each subtending 1-2 partial inflorescences; partial inflorescences sessile to pedunculate,± simple, oblong-elliptic, 2-4 cm long; bracteoles setaceous, rather prominent. Spikelets unisexual, solitary or in pairs; female spikelets broadly obovoid, 4-4.5 mm long; male spikelets lanceolate, 2-4 mm long, peduncle 1-2 mm long. Glumes ovate, 3-4 mm long, acute, sides membranous, pale green to rusty brown, keel green. Stamens 2-3. Nutlets globose or somewhat depressed-globose, 1.8-2 by 1.8-2 mm, rounded to shortly beaked, white, finely trabeculate with regular longitudinal rows of square pits, pubescent on ridges between pit rows, beak dark brown or purplish brown; disk deeply 3-lobed; lobes ovate-lanceolate, ± as long as nutlet, with deep pit at sinus between lobes.<br /><br/>	Or Nutlets brown-tomentose at first, later ± glabrous, surface pitting less deep, often longer than broad, the walls between the pits broader; disk-lobes ca. 1/3 as long as the nutlet.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scleria-biflora","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-8","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d0d115b-7a23-48c6-a5d6-9541b2ef72e8#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:265425","general","<p>Robust perennial 0.6–2.1 m tall, the base swollen to 5–8 mm and forming an irregularly shaped knot or rarely stems in a straight line, 2–4 mm wide, ± glabrous below, hairy and usually with sharp scabrid angles. Leaves 30–60 cm long, 5–8 mm wide, scabrid on margins and ribs, sparsely to densely hairy beneath; sheaths hairy, scabrid on the angles, ligule with whitish or dark reddish brown dense hairs. Inflorescence of a terminal and 2–3 lateral panicles placed singly at the nodes, 3–7 cm long, 1.5–4 cm wide, on stiffly erect peduncles shortly exserted from the sheaths, up to 3 cm long; male spikelets 4–5 cm long, the glumes straw-coloured with dark reddish brown sides, hairy particularly on margin; female spikelets 5–7 mm long with glumes dark reddish brown with midrib and area near it straw-coloured or greenish, hairy on margin and midrib. Nutlets greyish white or whitish below, violet to blackish blue above or sometimes dark all over, broadly ovoid or ellipsoid, 3–4.2 mm long, 2.5–2.8 mm wide, smooth; hypogynium yellowish to reddish brown, with 3 distinct lobes with recurved margins.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scleria-iostephana-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/cyperaceae-10","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","e8d69520-7cbf-4663-a3bb-122e3d057b7f#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:265660","general","<p>Plants; roots purplish, fibrous; rhizomes short (in perennial forms). Culms solitary or in tufts, erect or spreading, slender, (6–)15–50 cm, glabrous or hairy. Leaves: sheaths often purple-tinged at base, sometimes somewhat winged, ribbed, glabrous or densely pubescent; contra-ligules rotund-obtuse, short; blades linear, flat, often ribbed, obtuse, shorter than or equaling culm, 1–3.5 mm wide, glabrous or occasionally margins and veins abaxially scabrous. Spikelets bisexual or unisexual; staminate spikelets 2–3 mm, pistillate spikelets 3–4(–5) mm; staminate scales lanceolate; pistillate scales ovate-lanceolate, apex acuminate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:268003","general","<p>Tufted perennials, or with a short woody seriate rhizome. Culms scapose or few-noded, terete to 3(-4)-angular. Leaves ligulate or not, sometimes reduced to a sheath. Inflorescence open or contracted paniculate. Primary bracts short or long and leaflike, sheathing or not. Spikelets with several to many distichous, long persistent (finally deciduous ?) glumes of increasing length, larger (1-)2-3(-4) glumes each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Lower 1-2(-3) flowers usually functionally male, upper 1-2 flowers bisexual (rarely male). Bristles 0-3-6 (or more), rather short, or absent. Stamens 3-6(-8). Style 3(-4-9)-fid, style base at first distinct, slightly to much thickened, persistent, rarely tuberculate. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270154","general","<p>Medium-sized tufted perennial. Culms (sub-) scapose. Leaves ligulate. Inflorescence anthelate with many spikelets. Primary bracts rather small. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270565","general","<p>Small, loosely tufted annuals, with frequent amphicarpy. Culms few-noded. Leaves eligulate. Basal leaves often reduced to a sheath, subtending a basal I-flowered female spikelet. Basal spikelet prophyllate, with a single utriculiform glume, tightly wrapped around the female flower, top conspicuously tubuliform, flower reduced to a 3carpellate pistil with an elongated style, achene larger and thicker than the aerial fruits, ± irregularly shaped. Inflorescence depauperate paniculate with I-few spikelets. Primary bracts leaflike, sheathing. Spikelets with 3-5 distichous, long persistent glumes, of increasing length, larger (1-)2 glume(s) each subtending a flower, enclosed by the wings of the next glume. Rachilla internodes short, but upper rachilla internode conspicuously elongated. Flowers bisexual. Scales 6, deciduous with the fruit, outer very short and thick, inner bristlelike. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, style base not distinct, thickened, persistent. Achene obovate, trigonous, 3-ribbed, beaked, surface finely reticulate.<br /><br/>Three spp.</p>","<p>With kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media: This work is subject to copyright. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270566","general","<p>glabrous; rhizomes 1/12– 1/2 in. long, slender, white, often terminating in a minute globose bulbil 1/10 in. in diam.; stems 2–6 in. long, with leaves or bracts throughout their length; leaves 2–4 by 1/10– 1/8 in.; panicle 2–3 1/2 in. long, linear, of 1–4 distant heads; bracts like the leaves, slightly overtopping the inflorescence; spikelets 3–8 in a head, loosely clustered, 1/5 in. long, elliptic, green-white; glumes usually 6 in the spikelet, lowest 3 empty, next bisexual producing a nut, upper male or sterile; flower-glume boat-shaped, elliptic, with many obscure nerves; hypogynous bristles 3 (petals, i.e. they are opposite the faces of the nut as the “petals” of Fuirena), much longer than the nut, feathered with cinnamon or pink hairs in the lower half, in the upper half yellowish rigid, ending in 3 points of which the middle is much the longest; nut obovoid, trigonous, yellow-brown, reticulated owing to the large subquadrate outermost cells; style linear, branches 3 linear; style-base small, conic, persistent (almost confluent with) the nut.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trianoptiles-capensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/order-cl-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","71c83157-d14b-4751-b266-8bfe785105d2#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270655","general","<p>Tufted or creeping rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose. Leaves ligulate, blade much reduced, rarely well developed, upwards subensiform or top conspicuously thickened. Inflorescence a single spikelet, rarely anthelate or capitate with few spikelets. Primary bracts small, lowermost bract suberect. Spikelets with several spirally arranged deciduous glumes, each subtending a flower. Flowers bisexual. Bristles 0-6, elongating after anthesis, silky or not, deciduous with the fruit. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, style base not distinct, slightly thickened, ± persistent.
