"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270661","diagnostic","<p>The general morphology of Trichophorum cespitosum is similar to that described for T. germanicum, with which it can grow. The micro-characters seen in stem section are the best way to confirm it. The species should be looked for in often open and stony, base-rich mires (as described above), which often show a mosaic with residual peat islands where T. germanicum will be more common; also in apparently base-poor communities, where it can be dominant (see Swan 1999). In the field it appears as a more slender-stemmed and more open tuft with a distinctive 'jizz'.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-cespitosum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d8d617e-5cf6-41ad-a9e7-1c36125e18f3#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270661","distribution","<p>Trichophorum cespitosum was first confirmed for Britain by G.A. Swan (1999) in Northumberland in 1988, growing often with T. germanicum and their hybrid. In later examination of herbarium material Swan has found specimens scattered in Britain from Sutherland to the North Welsh Borders and Somerset; more recently it has been found in Shetland. In Ireland there are recent records in Fermanagh and Co. Waterford.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-cespitosum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d8d617e-5cf6-41ad-a9e7-1c36125e18f3#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270661","ecology","<p>The ecology of Trichophorum cespitosum is difficult to define owing to the small number of populations found. In Northumberland it appears to be confined to the margins of raised or valley mires where there is some water movement and base enrichment, whilst 5 T. germanicum tolerates a wider range of habitats (see Swan 1999). In Perthshire (v.c. 88) it can be found on limestones in open, often stony, calcareous mires with Carex panicea, C. pulicaris, C. viridula subsp. oedocarpa and occasionally C. viridula subsp. brachyrhyncha with Schoenus ferrugineus and Saxifraga aizoides (M11).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-cespitosum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d8d617e-5cf6-41ad-a9e7-1c36125e18f3#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270661","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short, forming small  ± open tufts. <i>Stems </i> 5-25 cm × 0.5-0.8 mm, ± terete, smooth, but with distinct ridges; substomatal pits conspicuous in transverse section of stem, 20-26 μm deep; aerenchyma tissue between vascular bundles absent. <i>Leaves </i> as in T. germanicum, but upper leaf-sheath fitting tightly round stem, with a ± transverse and circular opening typically c. 1 mm in diameter. <i>Inflorescence </i> smaller and more compact than in T. germanicum, with fewer (3-5) flowers; sometimes up to 20% of the population proliferating (in Northumberland: see Swan 1999); involucral bracts 2, 4-5(-7) mm long, glume-like, brown to orange-brown, with midrib pale yellow-green with an obtuse, green apical projection. <i>Glumes </i> similar in size and texture to those of T. germanicum but sometimes paler brown with the central nerve dominant and the marginal ones indistinct; apex subobtuse, attenuated into a subulate tip. <i>Flowers </i> and nuts as in T. germanicum.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-cespitosum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d8d617e-5cf6-41ad-a9e7-1c36125e18f3#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270662","general","<p>Basal sheaths shining; uppermost sheath with suborbicular opening c. 1 mm and narrow scarious margin clasping the stem. Spikelets with 3-10 flowers. Perianth bristles usually smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-cespitosum-subsp-cespitosum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/scirpus-l","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","5c6c3be2-be3e-475c-935e-6b2e42322abd#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270672","diagnostic","<p>The simplest way to distinguish Trichophorum spp. from Eriophorum vaginatum and Eleocharis spp. vegetatively is by the small leaf-like appendage (a vestigial blade) on the upper, tubular sheaths. The sheaths of these other species lack this appendage and those of E. vaginatum are not tubular. If the leaf-blades have fallen off and the upper sheaths have split, further investigation is required: in Trichophorum the basal sheaths are pale brown, lanceolate to ovate-lanceolate, and thick and glossy, whereas in E. vaginatum they are pale reddish-brown, long and fibrous. <br />Trichophorum germanicum hybridises with T. cespitosum (T. × foersteri (G.A. Swan) D.A. Simpson.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-germanicum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","782e180d-2c42-495e-b175-79ec880fcd1d#diagnostic"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270672","distribution","<p>Trichophorum germanicum is common in all upland areas of Britain and in the southern lowland bogs but is mostly lost from the Midlands through drainage. In Ireland, more or less throughout but less common in the SE coastal areas.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-germanicum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","782e180d-2c42-495e-b175-79ec880fcd1d#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270672","ecology","<p>T. germanicum is a characteristic, common and often dominant species of some 20 acidic peat communities, in blanket and raised mires and wet heath communities from the lowlands to 1190 m above Caenlochan, v.c. 90 (Foley & Porter 2002). Codominant or abundant in Eriophorum vaginatum mires (M17-20) and common with Erica tetralix (M15-16, especially Ml6d); also on montane heaths (H10, H12-17, H20-22) with Calluna, Erica cinerea, Vaccinium myrtillus, Juniperus communis subsp. nana and Sphagnum spp.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-germanicum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","782e180d-2c42-495e-b175-79ec880fcd1d#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270672","general","<p><i>Rhizomes </i> short, forming substantial tufts or small tussocks. <i>Stems </i> 5-35(-60) cm × 1-1.6 mm, ± terete, smooth, but with indistinct ridges; substomatal pits very obscure, 6-7 μm deep; aerenchyma tissue between vascular bundles obvious in transverse section, showing tube-like spaces between cells. <i>Leaves </i> 5-18 cm long, mostly reduced to bladeless sheaths at base of stem; upper sheaths loose-fitting, with an oblique and oval opening 1.8-2.2(-3) × 1 mm and a short blade 5-10 mm long. <i>Inflorescence </i> a single terminal spikelet 3-8 × 1.5-3 mm, obovoid to cylindrical, pale brown to rusty brown, with 8-20 flowers; involucral bracts 2, 4-5(-7) mm long, glume-like, brown to orange-brown, with midrib pale yellow-green with an obtuse, green apical projection. <i>Glumes </i> 2.5-4 × 1.5-2 mm, linear-lanceolate, subobtuse, membranous, 3-nerved, pale brown to rusty-brown; apex subobtuse, attenuated into a subulate tip. <i>Flowers </i> bisexual, sometimes forming young plantlets within the spikelet; perianth bristles 5-6, shorter than glumes but c. 1.5 times as long as nut, pale to mid brownish, smooth to papillose; stamens 3; anthers 1.5-2 mm long; stigmas 3. <i>Nuts</i>  1.5-2 × 0.9-1 mm, ellipsoid to obovoid-trigonous, greyish-brown to yellowish-brown, minutely punctate.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/trichophorum-germanicum-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/sedges-british-isles","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","782e180d-2c42-495e-b175-79ec880fcd1d#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270682","general","<p>Densely caespitose, with long stolons. Stems 3-15 cm, terete, smooth. Leaf-lamina 0.5-1.5 cm. Spikelet 2-3 x 2 mm, ovoid, with 2-4 flowers. Glumes ovate, apiculate or subobtuse, reddish-brown, with paler or greenish midvein, the 2 lowest sometimes with obtuse apex about equalling the spikelet. Perianth-bristles 3 or absent, less than 1/2 as long as nut. Nut c. 1.5 mm, obovoid to ellipsoid, scarcely shiny, yellowish- to blackish-brown. Damp places; calcicole. Norway; Alps; W. Carpathians; C. & S. Ural; everywhere very local and rare. Cz Ga He It No Rs (E). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270767","general","<p>Tufted, rhizomatous perennials. Culms scapose or few-noded. Leaves eligulate, sometimes reduced to a sheath. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:270809","general","<p>Tufted perennials or dwarf shrubs with a (branched) caudex, covered by ± fibrous leaf sheath remnants and adventitious roots. Culms lateral, scapose, compressed. Leaves crowded on top of the caudex, eligulate, contraligula triangular. Inflorescence paniculate with few-many spikeletlike spikes. Primary bracts ± leaflike, sheathing. Spikes with numerous lateral spikelets, subtended by spirally arranged glumelike bracts. Basal spikes male, apical spikes female. Spikelets with few distichous, persistent glumes, 1-2 each subtending a flower, lateral spikelets with an irregularly shaped prophyll. Male flower with 3 stamens. Female flower with a pistil, surrounded at the base and opposite the sides by 3 small, long fimbriate hypogynous scales, deciduous with the fruit. Style 3-fid, style base not distinct, tapering, persistent. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:271105","general","<p>Tufted, rhizomatous, or rarely stoloniferous perennials. Culms scapose, rarely noded. Leaves ligulate. Inflorescence a bisexual spike with in the lower part female spikelets, and apically male flowers, forming a terminal male spikelet. Primary bracts mostly small and glumelike, or a few lower bracts ± leaflike, deciduous or persistent. Male spikelet with few-many densely spirally arranged glumes, each subtending a male flower with 2-3 stamens with broad or narrow filaments. Female spikelets 1-flowered, rachilla elongated, with a terminal recurved hook, formed by a thick, ± coriaceous glume, prophyll utriculiform, subtending the female flower. Female flower without bristles, with a 3-fid style, style base not distinct, often ± thickened and persistent, ovary seated on a small disk with 3 basal knobs, opposite the ribs. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:273166","ecology","<p><br/>	 </p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/zameioscirpus-atacamensis-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","105f604b-89fb-4291-818e-6bedc1640be5#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:273166","general","<p>Caespitose, perennial herbs, 3.2–11 cm tall. Culms 1.2–7.2 cm long, erect, terete, unbranched, 0.5–1.2 mm wide below the inflorescence, maximum width 0.7–1.9 mm, in cross section with a wavy outline. Leaves shorter than to as long as the culms, ligulate. Ligule membranous, sometimes weakly fringed. Leaf blades 0.8–2.5 cm × 0.5–1.85 mm. Leaf margins entirely smooth or weakly scabrous in the distal part of the leaf blade. Leaf tips mostly mucronulate. Old leaf sheaths brown, persistent at the base. Inflorescence a single terminal spikelet, 6–11 × 2.3–7.2 mm, yellow or brown or yellow variegated with orange. Spikelets with 6–18 glumes. All glumes fertile, including the lowermost one. Glumes 5.1–8.5 × 1.8–3.8 mm, ovate, acute, yellow or brown or yellow variegated with brown. Inferior glumes sometimes obtuse. Lowest rachilla internode sometimes elongated. Flowers bisexual. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, reddish. Fruit 1.5–2.4 × 1–1.5 mm wide, obovate to broadly obovate, olive green – brown, finely reticulate. Perianth segments not developed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/zameioscirpus-atacamensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/zameioscirpus-new-genus-cyperaceae-south-america-0","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","105f604b-89fb-4291-818e-6bedc1640be5#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:273167","general","<p>Small, perennial herbs, 3–7.5 cm tall. Culms 2.1–5 cm long, erect, terete, unbranched, 0.3– 0.6 mm wide below the inflorescence, maximum width 0.5–1.15 mm, inferior part sometimes inflated. Leaves shorter than to as long as the culms, ligulate. Ligule membranous, sometimes weakly fringed. Leaf blades 0.6– 2.5 cm × 0.4–1 mm. Leaf margins entirely smooth or weakly scabrous in the distal part of the leaf blade. Leaf tips muticous. Old leaf sheaths brown, persistent at the base. Inflorescence a single terminal spikelet, 5–8.5 × 2– 4.1 mm, yellow or brown. Spikelets with 6–10 glumes. All glumes fertile, including the lowermost one. Glumes 4–6 × 1.8–2.5 mm, ovate, acute to obtuse, yellow or brown. Inferior glume often inserted obliquely on the rachilla. Flowers bisexual. Stamens 3. Style 3-fid, reddish. Fruit 1.57–1.96 × 0.6–1.05 mm wide, narrowly obovate to obovate, brown, finely reticulate. Perianth segments not developed.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/zameioscirpus-gaimardioides","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/zameioscirpus-new-genus-cyperaceae-south-america-0","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4db5c1bf-6fbb-44eb-9d54-c127dab3396b#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:273168","general","<p>Small, perennial herbs, 1.5–5 cm tall. Culms 0.8–4 cm long, erect, terete, unbranched, 0.2–0.45 mm wide below the inflorescence, maximum width 0.6–1.15 mm, inferior part conspicuously inflated. Leaves shorter than to as long as the culms, ligulate. Ligule membranous, sometimes weakly fringed. Leaf blades 3.5–10.1 mm cm × 0.3– 0.7 mm. Leaf margins entirely smooth or weakly scabrous in the distal part of the leaf blade. Leaf tips muticous. Old leaf sheaths brown, persistent at the base. Inflorescence a single terminal spikelet, 3.5–6 × 1.2–3 mm, yellow or brown. Spikelets with 3–5 glumes. All glumes fertile, including the lowermost one. Glumes 2.8–5.5 × 0.75–1.8 mm, ovate, acute to obtuse, yellow or brown. Rachilla internodes conspicuously elongated between succeeding glumes, 0.6–1.1 mm. Flowers bisexual. Stamens 3. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:334784","general","<p>Robust, tussocky, rhizomatous, dioecious perennial, with fibrous remains of leaf sheaths at base of plant. CULMS up to 60 cm × 1.1–1.4 mm, twosided, erect to pendant, greenish-brown, margins scabrid. L EAVES many, crowded, pendant, basal, up to 60 cm long; blade narrowly linear, up to 51 cm × 2.5– 3 mm, apex very gradually narrowed, long-acuminate, v-shaped in cross-section, coriaceous, mid-green but drying in situ to pale brown towards apex, margins scabrid; sheath 8–9 cm long, open, ligulate; ligule membraneous, triangular, pale brown, the fibrous remains of the sheaths dark brown. INFLORESCENCE wholly male or female, narrowly paniculate, 3.5–7 × 1.9–4 cm, with 2–4 nodes, each node with a leaf-like inflorescence bract exceeding the inflorescence, up to 37 cm long, and subtending a 2– 7 cm long axis supporting 3–11 spikelets. SPIKELETS similar in male and female inflorescences, narrowly cylindric, 2.1–2.7 cm × 1.2–1.3 mm acute, pale brown maturing dark brown, the prophyll and lowest 7–9 glumes sterile, other glumes fertile; glumes ovate, 3.5–4 × 1.3–1.4 mm, obtuse, sides pale brown to dark rusty brown, nerves 0, margins pale, entire, membraneous; perianth bristles 7, unequal, shorter in the female flowers, antrorsely hairy; stamens 3, anthers 1.1 mm long, yellowish-white; stigmas 3, mid- to dark reddish-brown. NUTLETS immature, surface smooth.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/khaosokia","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/khaosokia-caricoides-new-genus-and-species-cyperaceae-thailand","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","647e1b02-0800-47a9-bd6a-10f6e05f7028#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:351095","general","<p>Culms: 20–87 cm × 1.0–1.5 mm at midheight. Leaves: ligule 1.25–2.5 mm, blades about 1⁄2 or 1/3 as long as culms, widest leaf blades 2.25–4 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:372376","general","<p>Caespitose perennial plant with or without short rhizomes. CULMS 30–80 cm × 0.8–1.5 mm at mid-height, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; sheaths light to dark brown. LIGULE 1–3 mm long, wider than long, subacute to rounded at apex. LEAVES green to dark green, about three-quarters as long as culms, widest leaf blades 2.0–3.0 mm, plicate to flat. INFLORESCENCE oblong, 35–55(70) × 7–10 mm, with six to nine globular spikes, sessile, single at nodes, first internode 13–30 mm long, the second one 7–14 mm, the remaining spikes contiguous. BRACTS glume-like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than the inflorescence, 10 mm long. FEMALE GLUME brown, with a midrib green to brown, with scarious margins, 2.75–3.75 × 1.5–2.25 mm, elliptic, apex acuminate 0.25–0.3 mm long. STAMINATE GLUME 2.75–3.5 × 1.5–2.0 mm, similar to the female. PERIGYNIUM patent to very patent, greenish to brown, body ovate to elliptic, nerveless or faintly veined, 4.0–4.75 × 1.75–2.5 mm, base rounded, gradually tapered into a beak. BEAK 0.75–1.35 mm long, brown distally, with serrulate winged margins reaching the body, the winged margins going to the middle or the full body, apex bifid, apical teeth 0.3–0.6 mm. ACHENE elliptic, shining, dark brown, 2.0–2.75 × 1.25–2.0 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:372379","general","<p>Caespitose perennial plant with short rhizomes c. 3–4 mm in diameter. CULMS 25–70 cm × 1.0–2 mm at mid-height, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; sheaths brown. LIGULE 1.0–3.0 mm long, subacute to acute at apex. LEAF blades grey green, about three-quarters as long as culms, widest leaf blades 3–4 mm, plicate to flat. INFLORESCENCE oblong, 40–90(145) × 10–12 mm, with 7–12 globular-elliptic spikes. Lowest spikes usually compound and shortly pedunculate, upper spikes single at nodes, sessile, and contiguous. The lowest internode 12–55 mm long, the second one 7–17 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:372379","habitat","<p>There is little information about the habitat of C. enokii. The plants inhabit waste lands and forest borders, such as savin woods. They also grow in shady and wet places by streams. The substrates mentioned for C. enokii include marl and volcanic rocks, and so it appears to need rich nutrient soils.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-enokii-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-carex-divulsa-aggregate-eurasia-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","959a1a3a-51a9-4d2e-ace4-e050615122d9#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:372380","general","<p>Caespitose perennial tufted plant with short rhizomes c. 4 mm in diameter. CULMS 28– 75 cm × 1.0–1.5 mm at mid-height, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above; sheaths pale to dark brown. LIGULE 0.5–1.25 mm long, wider than long, rounded at apex. LEAF blades pale green about three-quarters to as long as culms, widest leaf blades 3–3.5 mm, plicate to flat. INFLORESCENCE oblong, 40–75 × 8–9 mm, with 10–14 elliptic, sessile spikes, the first four branched. Lowest internode 6–12 mm long, the second one 6–8 mm, other spikes more crowded. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:372433","general","<p>Caespitose perennial plant with or without short rhizomes c. 5 mm in diameter. LEAF blades grey green, about three-quarters to longer than culms, widest leaf blades 2–3 mm, plicate to flat. INFLORESCENCE oblong, 30–50(68) × 9–13 mm, with 6–11 globular-elliptic, sessile spikes, the lowest spike sometimes branched, upper spikes single at nodes, first internode 6–13(20) mm long, the second one 3–9(13) mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:374579","general","<p>Culms 20–85 cm × 1.0–1.5 mm at midheight. Leaves: widest leaf blades 3–4 mm; ligule 1.0–3.5 mm, blades about 1/2 or 1/3 as long as culms. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:374579","habitat","<p>Habitat—Carex muricata subsp. cesanensis is adapted to mountains, between 850 and 1800 m. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:374580","distribution","<p>Endemic to the Sierra Nevada in the Southern Spain, and Atlas Range in the Moroccan Rif (Fig. 6).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-omeyica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-eurasian-carex-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","c2fddf95-6fd2-4810-8c7f-063153d91b25#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:374580","general","<p>Plants with short rhizomes. Culms: 30–70 cm × 0.8–1.25 mm at midheight, obtusely trigonous, slightly scabrid above, sheaths brown to dark brown. Leaves: blades about 1/2–1/3 as long as culms, widest leaf blades 2.5–3.0 mm, plicate to flat; ligule 1.0–3.0.mm, wider than long, round or subacute at apex. Inflorescences oblong, 25–34 mm × 8–11 mm, with 6–9 globular-elliptic spikes, one per node, sessile, spikes usually overlapping, the lowest spikes 4–9 mm distant; bracts glume like, the proximal setaceous, shorter than inflorescence, 5–12 mm long. Pistillate scales dark brown, with a narrow green to brown midrib and without scarious margins, 3.75–4.25 × 2.0–2.3 mm, oval, apex apiculate 0.1–0.2 mm. Staminate glume 4.0–4.5 × 1.75–2.0 mm, narrower than the female. Anthers 3, 1.75–3 mm long. Perigynium erect-spreading, pale greenish to brown, body oval, nerveless or whit faint veins in the body, 4.4–5.0 × 2.25–2.6 mm, base rounded not corky, apex more or less gradually tapered into a beak. Beak 0.75–1.0 mm long, green to brown distally, with serrulate margins reaching the summit, apex bidentate, apical teeth 0.25–0.6 mm. Achene ovate to oval, light brown 2.5–2.8 × 1.75–2.25 mm. Stigmas 2, 2.0–2.50 mm long.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-omeyica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-eurasian-carex-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","c2fddf95-6fd2-4810-8c7f-063153d91b25#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:374580","habitat","<p>Habitat—Carex omeyica occurs in forests of middle-high mountain, 1,500–1,700 m, in gullies on cedar or oak forests Querceto pyrenaicum, on acid soils.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-omeyica-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/taxonomy-and-new-taxa-eurasian-carex-section-phaestoglochin-cyperaceae","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","c2fddf95-6fd2-4810-8c7f-063153d91b25#habitat"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:374586","general","<p>Ligule 3.5–7.0 mm. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456808","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely tufted, with shortly creeping rhizomes.   Culms: 20-35 cm tall, upwardly scabrous.  Leaves: as long as or shorter than culms, 1.5-3 mm wide. Basal sheaths: yellow to yellowish brown. Bracts: 2.5-6 mm long, setaceous or leaf-like, with short sheaths. Spikes: terminal spike staminate, linear, 1.5-3.5 cm long, with short peduncles, 1-6 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, linear cylindrical, 1.5-3.5 cm long with short peduncles. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456810","distribution","<p>Carex derelicta is known only from the type locality at the Velká kotelná jáma glacial cirque, and is assumed to be endemic to the Krkonoše Mts (e.g., Havlíčková 1983, Holub 1999).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-new-species-krkonose-mountains-czech-republic","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d81c338-f329-4aab-ac2e-80b3dfbb15e9#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456810","ecology","<p><br/>	 </p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-cyperaceae","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d81c338-f329-4aab-ac2e-80b3dfbb15e9#ecology"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456810","general","<p>Cespitose in small clumps, perennial. Culms 10–25 cm tall, conspicuously exceeding the basal leaves, erect, obtusely triangular in cross section, smooth. Basal leaves 1.2–2.2 mm wide, canaliculate (in cross section), glabrous; basal sheaths glabrous, not reticulate-split, pale brown. Cauline leaves 2–3, 1.0–2.0 mm wide, canaliculate, with well developed sheaths; ligula very poorly defined; mouth of ventral face of leaf sheath concave or truncate, white or pale brown, hyaline. Staminate spike solitary, terminal, shortly pedunculate or sessile; staminate scales 2.8–3.5 mm long, ovate, subacute to acute, glabrous, brown with a stramineous or pale brown center and sometimes very narrow hyaline margins, 1 (–3)-veined. Pistillate spikes 2–3 (–5); upper ones crowded and the lower one remote or rarely all distant, globose to shortly cylindrical, 4–10 mm long, 3–6 mm wide at maturity; pistillate scales 1.5–2.5 mm long, equal or exceeding perigynia, ovate, acute to acuminate, sometimes with short awn, glabrous, brown with a stramineous or pale brown center and sometimes very narrow hyaline margins, 1–veined; lowermost bract leaf-like, conspicuously exceeding the inflorescence, the upper ones often setaceous, from shorter than to slightly exceeding the inflorescence. Perigynia straight, obliquely patent, 2.0–2.5 mm long, 1.3–2.0 mm wide at maturity, vivid green to yellowish brown, never grey green, glabrous; body of the perigynium ovoid, not inflated, abruptly contracted to the straight beak 0.4–0.7 mm long, clearly bifid, smooth at the margin. Achenes 0.9–1.3 mm long, 0.7–1.1 mm wide, closely included in the body of perigynium, ovoid, pale brown, short stipitate. Stigmas 2. Anthers 3</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-new-species-krkonose-mountains-czech-republic","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d81c338-f329-4aab-ac2e-80b3dfbb15e9#general"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456810","habitat","<p>A relatively rich population of these plants is restricted to the wet small valley situ - ated below the crest separating the Velká and Malá kotelná jáma glacial cirques, where there are moist flats consisting of muscovitic albitic mica-schist. As the locality lies under an outcrop of base-rich rocks of crystalline limestone and erlan, it is probable that leaching of Ca ++ ions influences the soil conditions in this stand. Carex derelicta occurs predominantly in open spring vegetation, regularly subjected to natural disturbance by water. The plant com- munities mainly associated with Carex derelicta is Swertio - Anisothecion squarrosi . Carex derelicta occasionally occurs in the community Saxifrago oppositifoliae - Festucetum versicoloris (alliance Agrostion alpinae ) – alpine basiphilous grassland occurring on the neighbouring rocky slopes. Rarely and ephemerally it is recorded in Sphagno com- pacti - Molinietum caeruleae (from the alliance Calamagrostion villosae ) subalpine grass- lands dominated by Molinia caerulea , which grow on adjacent sites.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-derelicta-new-species-krkonose-mountains-czech-republic","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","4d81c338-f329-4aab-ac2e-80b3dfbb15e9#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456812","distribution","<p>Its geographic range extends from extreme southeastern Ontario and northwestern Ohio westward to the southeast corner of Saskatchewan and the Red and Missouri River valleys. Several disjunct records of C. echinodes are known from the Black Hills of South Dakota</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-echinodes-fernald-rothrock-reznicek-hipp-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","3f418e08-345a-47b9-8bc9-5f4bd0f90dd4#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456812","habitat","<p>inhabits rich, moist bottomland and gallery forests, the edges of forested depressions, and occasionally wooded bluffs and ravines.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-echinodes-fernald-rothrock-reznicek-hipp-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","3f418e08-345a-47b9-8bc9-5f4bd0f90dd4#habitat"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456812","look_alikes","<p>C.normalis are very distinctive when compared to C. echinodes, which has narrow leaves and striking, elongate inflorescences. The broadest leaves per plant are usually 3.5 mm to as much as 6 mm wide in C. normalis and only 2–3 mm in C. echinodes. The length of the lowest internode is mostly less than 9 mm long in C. normalis, compared to (6–) 8–16 mm or more in C. echinodes. Narrow-leaved individuals of C. normalis, on the other hand, do occur, particularly in more shaded habits. Sometimes these may represent shade adapted genotypes as indicated by the persistence of narrow-leaf habit in the chromosome accession from Fountain County, Indiana (PER 4256), which remained so even after growing luxuriantly under greenhouse conditions. Regardless of whether narrow leaves are a product of genotype or environmental conditions, these forms blur the species delimitations. When seen in situ, C. echinodes can develop large clumps with 40 or more culms that tend to lodge with maturity. Clumps of C. normalis contain fewer, less densely arranged, and more erect culms. Carex normalis culms were mostly 0.55 mm or more in diameter and those of C. echinodes were mostly 0.5 mm or less. Since many narrow-leaved C. normalis individuals (width of ca. 3.5 mm or less) are associated with less favorable habitats, these plants would be expected to not only have more delicate culms but also shorter, less robust inflorescences. Generally differences in perigynia, such as body shape, coloration, and shape or length of the beak, are apparent between species of section Ovales. This was only subtly true for C. normalis and C. echinodes. The sharpest contrasts were provided by the shape of the perigynium base and the distance from achene summit to beak apex. The shape of the perigynium base is the ratio of the distance from perigynium base to achene summit divided by the width of the body. The perigynium base in C. echinodes is somewhat more elongate than that of C. normalis, often ranging from a value of 1.15 to 1.5, although the range extends to as low as 0.9. The similar measure in C. normalis seldom exceeds 1.2. The more familiar ratio, perigynium body L/W ratio, was also examined but showed much more overlap in variation between these 2 species. This added variation suggests that, in these species, the elongation of the area near the base of the beak may be more plastic in response to environmental fluctuations. There is broad overlap in the achene summit to beak apex distance for C. normalis and C. echinodes. However, this character in combination with the perigynium base L/W ratio has value in separating narrow-leaved C. normalis from C. echinodes. And it is these narrow-leaved specimens that fail to sort out cleanly from C. echinodes. Under the growth conditions experienced by most narrow-leaved C. normalis, the achene to beak summit distance shrinks compared to more vigorous individuals of C. normalis (mean = 1.64 ± 0.04 versus 1.92 ± 0.03). Thus, individuals of C. normalis with narrow leaves (less than 3.5 mm wide) also tend to have perigynia that combine a relatively broad base (a L/W ratio of less than 1.15) with a short achene to beak apex distance (less than 1.85 mm).</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-echinodes-fernald-rothrock-reznicek-hipp-0","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","3f418e08-345a-47b9-8bc9-5f4bd0f90dd4#look_alikes"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456812","morphology","Plant: Cespitose, often develops large clumps with 40 or more culms that tend to lodge with maturity.   Vegetative shoots: annual, ca. 20-40 cm tall during fruiting season, leaves 6 to 10, lower 2-4 evenly spaced along culm, the rest clustered apically Culms: 40-90 cm tall, erect, trigonous, smooth except for finely scabrous angles just below the inflorescence, 0.3-0.6 mm in diameter just below the inflorescence.  Inflorescence: 2.2-6.8 cm long, usually arched or nodding, the upper spikes overlapping, the lower 2 to 4 well separated, the lowest spikes (6-) 10-24 mm apart, the spikes single at nodes, sessile; lowermost bracts 3-18 mm long, the tip often an aristate bristle about as long as or exceeding the spike, sheathless, upper bracts much reduced.  Leaves: Bladeless basal sheaths pale to dark purple-brown, disintegrating into short brown fibers. Leaves 3-5, on the lower 1/4-2/5 of the culm; blades 2-34 cm long, 1.5-3 (-3.5) mm wide, flat to slightly plicate, glabrous or papillose adaxially, the margins and midrib smooth to antrorsely scabrous; leaf sheaths ca. 1.5-28 cm long, tightly enveloping the culms, smooth, the ribs greenish, the intervenal areas pale or white and with scattered green septae; ventral sheaths with a distinct Y-shaped hyaline area reaching 1-10 (-15) mm below the orifice, its apex concave or truncate, extending 0-0.5 mm above the base of the blade; ligules 1.2-3.5 mm long, rounded, the free portion entire or minutely erose and up to 0.6 mm long.  Pistillate scales: 2.3-3.1 × 0.95-1.35 mm, reaching from shoulder of perigynium to lower 2/5 of perigynium beak, (0.5-) 0.7-1.4 (-1.6) mm shorter than the perigynia, 1.9-3 times longer than wide, lanceolate to narrowly ovate, obtuse or acute, pale yellow to medium brown, with a narrow yellow-green center and hyaline margins, 1-nerved or faintly 3-nerved, the midnerve extending essentially to the tip. Spikes: 3-8 (-10), gynecandrous, 5.5-14 mm long, ovoid to globose, bases rounded, acute or attenuate, apices obtuse or rounded, pistillate portion 4.5-8.5 × 5.5-8.5 mm, ca. 15-30 flowered, staminate portion 1-6.5 × 1-2 mm, ca. 4-16 flowered . Staminate scales: 2.6-4 × 1-1.6 mm, ovate to elliptic, obtuse, pale yellow to medium brown, with narrow yellowish-green center and hyaline margins, 1 nerved or faintly 3-nerved.     Anthers: 1.3-1.8 mm long. Perigynia: (3.2-) 3.6-4.6 × 1.3-2.1 mm, (1.9-) 2.1-2.8 (-3.2) times as long as wide, glabrous, sessile, ascending to wide spreading or slightly recurved, concavo-convex, 0.4-0.5 mm thick, more or less thin and membranous; bodies elliptic to narrowly ovate, 1.9-2.9 mm long, (1.1-) 1.2-1.75 times as long as wide and 1.3-2 times as long as beak, widest 0.9-1.4 mm above the base, narrowly thin-winged, wings 0.3-0.45 mm wide, the margin finely serrulate to shoulder of body, entire below, contracted or gradually tapered into a beak, the wing margin greenish, greenish-yellow, to yellowish-brown tinged on shoulder and mostly yellowish-brown tinged below, faintly to distinctly 2 to 6-nerved adaxially over achene, faintly to distinctly 5 to 7-nerved abaxially over achene and 2-nerved in the winged margin; beaks 1.2-1.9 mm long, strongly flattened and serrulate-margined to apex, greenish, greenish-yellow or yellowish-brown tinged, the dorsal suture hyaline to yellowish-brown, the apex inconspicuously bidentate with teeth 0.1-0.6 mm long, distance from summit of achene to tip of beak 1.4-2.4 mm long.  Achenes: 1.4-1.7 × 0.8-1.15 mm, 1.4-1.8 times as long as wide, biconvex, elliptic, pale to dark brown, very short-stipitate at base, apiculum 0.1-0.3 mm long; style straight. Stigmas: 2.    Authorship and sources: Primary author(s): Paul E. Rothrock, Anton A. Reznicek, and Andrew L. Hipp.  <br /><br/>Additional authors: Additional editors on this taxon treatment have, unless otherwise indicated here, made primarily stylistic contributions or relatively minor contributions. <br /><br/>Authorship date and revision history: Authorship date is recorded in the ""Authored on"" field, which may not be visible depending on the platform you are using to view this treatment.<br /><br/>Sources: Sources used in writing this description are indicated in the bibliographic links to this taxon except as otherwise indicated here or in the description itself. <br /><br/> Rothrock et al. 2009.  Taxonomic study of the Carex tenera group (Cyperaceae). "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456820","morphology","Plant: perennial, loosely caespitose, with shortly ascending rhizomes.   Culms: 10-50 cm tall, scabrous.  Leaves: 2-3 mm wide, shorter than culms. Basal sheaths: dark reddish purple, fibrillose. Pistillate scales: dark reddish purple, acute. Spikes: upwardly crowded; terminal spike staminate, sessile, linear, 0.5-1 cm long; lateral spikes pistillate, sessile, ellipsoidal, 0.5-1 cm long. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:456825","morphology","Plant: perennial, caespitose.     Leaves: 2-4 mm wide, stiff, scabrous. Basal sheaths:<br /><br/>brownish, fibrillose. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:461716","general","<p>Perennial. Stems 40-100 cm, densely caespitose trigonous, with leafless sheaths. Lower bract exceeding the inflorescence. "urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:462327","distribution","<p>Cameroon.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/coleochloa-domensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/coleochloa-domensis-cyperaceae-new-epiphytic-species-cameroon","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ed0879f4-a4fe-4eab-ae93-15970a84f68e#distribution"
"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:462327","general","<p>A tufted perennial, lacking stolons or rhizomes. Culms 15 – 30 cm tall, thickness at base including leaf sheaths 3 – 5 mm. Leaves distichously arranged; sheaths open, margins overlapping, glabrous, 2 – 5 mm long; blades fl at, glabrous except upper surface of midrib which is densely hairy, 15.5 – 30.7 cm long and 2 – 4 mm wide, deciduous; ligule a dense band of white hairs, 1 – 1.5 mm long. In florescence a stiff panicle (not pendulous), spikes 2 – 4 per leaf axil, peduncles unequal in length and longest to 3 cm. Spikes comprising 6 – 10 spikelets; each spikelet bearing 4 – 6 florets; florets male or female. Spikelets to 3 mm long with protruding seeds excluded. Glumes distichously arranged, to 2.5 mm long, minutely papillose. Male flowers with 3 stamens, anthers to 1.2 mm long. Nutlet brownish, pilose, 5 – 5.5 mm long, including beak (to 3 mm excluding beak), linear to lanceolate, trigonous in transverse section; style persistent on mature nutlets, base with tuft of white hairs, to 2mm long; stigmas 3, with recurved tips.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/coleochloa-domensis-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/coleochloa-domensis-cyperaceae-new-epiphytic-species-cameroon","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","712f1396-bb33-4d9c-b373-b76828c89610","","ed0879f4-a4fe-4eab-ae93-15970a84f68e#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:462823","general","<p>Perennial, cespitose. Stems 7-40 cm length, trigonous, smooth, erect or slightly curved. Leaves 0.9-3 mm wide, usually shorter than stems, flat, light green; ligule short, slightly protruding beyond the sheath apex, truncate to rounded, scarious, absent from the cauline leaves; anteligule 1-2 mm, rounded; basal leaf sheaths unconspicuous, weak, light brown. Lowest bract 1-6 cm × 0.5-3 mm, as long as or a bit longer than inflorescence, shortly leaflike, sometimes bristle-like. Male spike 1, 7-20 × 3-3.5(4.2) mm, terminal, widely fusiform to elliptical, with a peduncle 1-15(20) mm; female spikes 1-3, the lowest one 7-10 mm long, generally clustered at stem apex, sessile or short-peduncled, erect, sometimes with a long-peduncled basilar spike, rarely some of them androgynous. Male glumes oval, subacute to obtuse, entirely brown, with a lighter middle nerve; female glumes oval, subacute to obtuse, brown, with a lighter middle nerve and sometimes an inconspicuous scarious margin. Stigmata 3. Utricles 3.2-4.5(4.8) × 0.9-1.5 mm, green to dark brown, those from the lower half of the spike strongly deflexed, those from the upper half deflexed to patent, the apical ones patent to erect-patent, elliptical, trigonous, plurinerved, gradually attenuated into a 1.2- 2.2(2.5) mm, deflexed (30-40º in reference to utricle body), bidentate or bifid, smooth beak. Achenes 1.5-1.8 × 1 mm, narrowly obovate, trigonous.</p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-castroviejoi-cyperaceae","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/content/carex-castroviejoi-luce%C3%B1o-jim%C3%A9nez-mej%C3%ADas-cyperaceae-new-species-north-greek-mountains","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","bf0edc3c-b3c3-43f0-b741-b0fb2bbdc746","","65c75a07-867c-4b07-8e2b-3c07789168bf#general"

"urn:kew.org:wcs:taxon:474797","distribution","<p>Washington & Hancock Counties in Maine, USA.  As a result of careful examination of specimens, especially in the light of the additional characters that separate these two taxa, it is now realized that Carex waponahkikensis is a globally restricted taxon that is found only in extreme eastern Maine along the coastal plain. </p>","","http://cyperaceae.e-monocot.org/node/13308","","eMonocot Cyperaceae","eng","http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution","text/html","http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/Text","0ae1b7fd-f01c-4fc1-9515-26ab69f11173","","9873cf2d-96bc-4e34-87e0-2d8ad7baddf4#distribution"
